{"othernum_articles": "319", "other": [{"archive_id": "8202225", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (01): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8202225", "date": "2020-07-22 21:23:15", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (ASSAM)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Jul 2020 21:59 IST\nSource: India TV [edited]\nhttps://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-assam-kills-48-japanese-encephalitis-636330\n\n\nAt least 48 persons have lost their lives in Japanese encephalitis (JE) and other such acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) out of 331 cases across Assam this year [2020], the National Health Mission (NHM) said on Wednesday [22 Jul 2020]. The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) held a video conference with all districts to review the status of AES and JE in Assam, a joint statement by the health department and the NHM's state unit said.\n\n\"The state currently has 331 AES cases and 48 deaths, which includes 148 non-JE cases, 24 non-JE deaths, and 183 JE cases, 24 JE deaths,\" it added.\n\nThe video conference was chaired by Health and Family Welfare Commissioner and Secretary Monalisa Goswami in the presence of NHM Mission Director Lakshmanan S and other officials.\n\nGoswami reviewed the status of the diseases in the state and instructed all concerned to ensure that the laboratories are functional and replace the Elisa Reader and Washer (equipment for testing), wherever needed.\n\nGoswami directed her department officials to closely monitor the activities and follow up on the treatment with the JE patients.\n\n\"The monitoring and supervision need to be strengthened, and IEC/awareness activities, too, should be rigorously done at all the districts; special focus should also be given at the tea garden areas in Assam,\" the statement said.\n\nGoswami further instructed all officials concerned to regularly conduct field visits to ensure that the District Task Force meetings are conducted in close coordination with various departments for a better management of AES and JE in the northeastern state.\n\n\"The VC concluded with the final remarks of the commissioner and secretary, instructing all concerned officials to work in cohesion with the different departments for better management of AES/JE in state,\" the statement said.\n\nShe also directed to ensure availability and earmarking of JE beds in all district hospitals and medical colleges to treat the patients of the mosquito-borne diseases, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) and acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases are increasing again this year (2020) in Assam state from 174 cases and 23 deaths reported on 9 Jul 2020 to 331 cases and 48 deaths as of 22 Jul 2020. Of these cases, 183 mentioned above are classified as JE, and 148 are AES cases.\n\nAs mentioned in previous ProMED-mail posts, the issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe report above does not indicate whether any of the AES etiologies above have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is well underway, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 3-4 months.\n\nAlthough mosquito control is not mentioned in the report above as a JE preventive measure, it is difficult to effectively accomplish in localities where the JE virus vectors, _Culex_ spp., are abundant and widespread. Because the _Culex_ vector mosquitoes also breed in rice paddies, which may be extensive, vector control over large areas is difficult. It is curious that no mention is made of vaccination campaigns in the affected areas. Vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent JE virus infection. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20190716.6570013\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS, BR) 20190710.6561773\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20190705.6552949\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\n.................................................ty/tw/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Goswami", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7942386", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7942386", "date": "2020-07-22 21:23:15", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (ASSAM)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Jul 2020 21:59 IST\nSource: India TV [edited]\nhttps://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-assam-kills-48-japanese-encephalitis-636330\n\n\nAt least 48 persons have lost their lives in Japanese encephalitis (JE) and other such acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) out of 331 cases across Assam this year [2020], the National Health Mission (NHM) said on Wednesday [22 Jul 2020]. The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) held a video conference with all districts to review the status of AES and JE in Assam, a joint statement by the health department and the NHM's state unit said.\n\n\"The state currently has 331 AES cases and 48 deaths, which includes 148 non-JE cases, 24 non-JE deaths, and 183 JE cases, 24 JE deaths,\" it added.\n\nThe video conference was chaired by Health and Family Welfare Commissioner and Secretary Monalisa Goswami in the presence of NHM Mission Director Lakshmanan S and other officials.\n\nGoswami reviewed the status of the diseases in the state and instructed all concerned to ensure that the laboratories are functional and replace the Elisa Reader and Washer (equipment for testing), wherever needed.\n\nGoswami directed her department officials to closely monitor the activities and follow up on the treatment with the JE patients.\n\n\"The monitoring and supervision need to be strengthened, and IEC/awareness activities, too, should be rigorously done at all the districts; special focus should also be given at the tea garden areas in Assam,\" the statement said.\n\nGoswami further instructed all officials concerned to regularly conduct field visits to ensure that the District Task Force meetings are conducted in close coordination with various departments for a better management of AES and JE in the northeastern state.\n\n\"The VC concluded with the final remarks of the commissioner and secretary, instructing all concerned officials to work in cohesion with the different departments for better management of AES/JE in state,\" the statement said.\n\nShe also directed to ensure availability and earmarking of JE beds in all district hospitals and medical colleges to treat the patients of the mosquito-borne diseases, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) and acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases are increasing again this year (2020) in Assam state from 174 cases and 23 deaths reported on 9 Jul 2020 to 331 cases and 48 deaths as of 22 Jul 2020. Of these cases, 183 mentioned above are classified as JE, and 148 are AES cases.\n\nAs mentioned in previous ProMED-mail posts, the issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe report above does not indicate whether any of the AES etiologies above have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is well underway, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 3-4 months.\n\nAlthough mosquito control is not mentioned in the report above as a JE preventive measure, it is difficult to effectively accomplish in localities where the JE virus vectors, _Culex_ spp., are abundant and widespread. Because the _Culex_ vector mosquitoes also breed in rice paddies, which may be extensive, vector control over large areas is difficult. It is curious that no mention is made of vaccination campaigns in the affected areas. Vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent JE virus infection. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\n.................................................ty/tw/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Goswami", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7811532", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7811532", "date": "2020-07-22 21:23:15", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (ASSAM)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Jul 2020 21:59 IST\nSource: India TV [edited]\nhttps://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-assam-kills-48-japanese-encephalitis-636330\n\n\nAt least 48 persons have lost their lives in Japanese encephalitis (JE) and other such acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) out of 331 cases across Assam this year [2020], the National Health Mission (NHM) said on Wednesday [22 Jul 2020]. The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) held a video conference with all districts to review the status of AES and JE in Assam, a joint statement by the health department and the NHM's state unit said.\n\n\"The state currently has 331 AES cases and 48 deaths, which includes 148 non-JE cases, 24 non-JE deaths, and 183 JE cases, 24 JE deaths,\" it added.\n\nThe video conference was chaired by Health and Family Welfare Commissioner and Secretary Monalisa Goswami in the presence of NHM Mission Director Lakshmanan S and other officials.\n\nGoswami reviewed the status of the diseases in the state and instructed all concerned to ensure that the laboratories are functional and replace the Elisa Reader and Washer (equipment for testing), wherever needed.\n\nGoswami directed her department officials to closely monitor the activities and follow up on the treatment with the JE patients.\n\n\"The monitoring and supervision need to be strengthened, and IEC/awareness activities, too, should be rigorously done at all the districts; special focus should also be given at the tea garden areas in Assam,\" the statement said.\n\nGoswami further instructed all officials concerned to regularly conduct field visits to ensure that the District Task Force meetings are conducted in close coordination with various departments for a better management of AES and JE in the northeastern state.\n\n\"The VC concluded with the final remarks of the commissioner and secretary, instructing all concerned officials to work in cohesion with the different departments for better management of AES/JE in state,\" the statement said.\n\nShe also directed to ensure availability and earmarking of JE beds in all district hospitals and medical colleges to treat the patients of the mosquito-borne diseases, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) and acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases are increasing again this year (2020) in Assam state from 174 cases and 23 deaths reported on 9 Jul 2020 to 331 cases and 48 deaths as of 22 Jul 2020. Of these cases, 183 mentioned above are classified as JE, and 148 are AES cases.\n\nAs mentioned in previous ProMED-mail posts, the issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe report above does not indicate whether any of the AES etiologies above have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is well underway, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 3-4 months.\n\nAlthough mosquito control is not mentioned in the report above as a JE preventive measure, it is difficult to effectively accomplish in localities where the JE virus vectors, _Culex_ spp., are abundant and widespread. Because the _Culex_ vector mosquitoes also breed in rice paddies, which may be extensive, vector control over large areas is difficult. It is curious that no mention is made of vaccination campaigns in the affected areas. Vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent JE virus infection. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (BR) corr, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7740196", "date": "2020-07-22 21:23:15", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (ASSAM)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Jul 2020 21:59 IST\nSource: India TV [edited]\nhttps://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-assam-kills-48-japanese-encephalitis-636330\n\n\nAt least 48 persons have lost their lives in Japanese encephalitis (JE) and other such acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) out of 331 cases across Assam this year [2020], the National Health Mission (NHM) said on Wednesday [22 Jul 2020]. The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) held a video conference with all districts to review the status of AES and JE in Assam, a joint statement by the health department and the NHM's state unit said.\n\n\"The state currently has 331 AES cases and 48 deaths, which includes 148 non-JE cases, 24 non-JE deaths, and 183 JE cases, 24 JE deaths,\" it added.\n\nThe video conference was chaired by Health and Family Welfare Commissioner and Secretary Monalisa Goswami in the presence of NHM Mission Director Lakshmanan S and other officials.\n\nGoswami reviewed the status of the diseases in the state and instructed all concerned to ensure that the laboratories are functional and replace the Elisa Reader and Washer (equipment for testing), wherever needed.\n\nGoswami directed her department officials to closely monitor the activities and follow up on the treatment with the JE patients.\n\n\"The monitoring and supervision need to be strengthened, and IEC/awareness activities, too, should be rigorously done at all the districts; special focus should also be given at the tea garden areas in Assam,\" the statement said.\n\nGoswami further instructed all officials concerned to regularly conduct field visits to ensure that the District Task Force meetings are conducted in close coordination with various departments for a better management of AES and JE in the northeastern state.\n\n\"The VC concluded with the final remarks of the commissioner and secretary, instructing all concerned officials to work in cohesion with the different departments for better management of AES/JE in state,\" the statement said.\n\nShe also directed to ensure availability and earmarking of JE beds in all district hospitals and medical colleges to treat the patients of the mosquito-borne diseases, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) and acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases are increasing again this year (2020) in Assam state from 174 cases and 23 deaths reported on 9 Jul 2020 to 331 cases and 48 deaths as of 22 Jul 2020. Of these cases, 183 mentioned above are classified as JE, and 148 are AES cases.\n\nAs mentioned in previous ProMED-mail posts, the issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe report above does not indicate whether any of the AES etiologies above have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is well underway, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 3-4 months.\n\nAlthough mosquito control is not mentioned in the report above as a JE preventive measure, it is difficult to effectively accomplish in localities where the JE virus vectors, _Culex_ spp., are abundant and widespread. Because the _Culex_ vector mosquitoes also breed in rice paddies, which may be extensive, vector control over large areas is difficult. It is curious that no mention is made of vaccination campaigns in the affected areas. Vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent JE virus infection. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\n.................................................ty/tw/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Goswami", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7730992", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7730992", "date": "2020-07-22 21:23:15", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (ASSAM)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Jul 2020 21:59 IST\nSource: India TV [edited]\nhttps://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-assam-kills-48-japanese-encephalitis-636330\n\n\nAt least 48 persons have lost their lives in Japanese encephalitis (JE) and other such acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) out of 331 cases across Assam this year [2020], the National Health Mission (NHM) said on Wednesday [22 Jul 2020]. The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) held a video conference with all districts to review the status of AES and JE in Assam, a joint statement by the health department and the NHM's state unit said.\n\n\"The state currently has 331 AES cases and 48 deaths, which includes 148 non-JE cases, 24 non-JE deaths, and 183 JE cases, 24 JE deaths,\" it added.\n\nThe video conference was chaired by Health and Family Welfare Commissioner and Secretary Monalisa Goswami in the presence of NHM Mission Director Lakshmanan S and other officials.\n\nGoswami reviewed the status of the diseases in the state and instructed all concerned to ensure that the laboratories are functional and replace the Elisa Reader and Washer (equipment for testing), wherever needed.\n\nGoswami directed her department officials to closely monitor the activities and follow up on the treatment with the JE patients.\n\n\"The monitoring and supervision need to be strengthened, and IEC/awareness activities, too, should be rigorously done at all the districts; special focus should also be given at the tea garden areas in Assam,\" the statement said.\n\nGoswami further instructed all officials concerned to regularly conduct field visits to ensure that the District Task Force meetings are conducted in close coordination with various departments for a better management of AES and JE in the northeastern state.\n\n\"The VC concluded with the final remarks of the commissioner and secretary, instructing all concerned officials to work in cohesion with the different departments for better management of AES/JE in state,\" the statement said.\n\nShe also directed to ensure availability and earmarking of JE beds in all district hospitals and medical colleges to treat the patients of the mosquito-borne diseases, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) and acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases are increasing again this year (2020) in Assam state from 174 cases and 23 deaths reported on 9 Jul 2020 to 331 cases and 48 deaths as of 22 Jul 2020. Of these cases, 183 mentioned above are classified as JE, and 148 are AES cases.\n\nAs mentioned in previous ProMED-mail posts, the issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe report above does not indicate whether any of the AES etiologies above have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is well underway, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 3-4 months.\n\nAlthough mosquito control is not mentioned in the report above as a JE preventive measure, it is difficult to effectively accomplish in localities where the JE virus vectors, _Culex_ spp., are abundant and widespread. Because the _Culex_ vector mosquitoes also breed in rice paddies, which may be extensive, vector control over large areas is difficult. It is curious that no mention is made of vaccination campaigns in the affected areas. Vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent JE virus infection. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (27): (AS) 20190914.6673745\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (AS) 20190728.6591689\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (AS) 20190720.6578446\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20190716.6570013\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS, BR) 20190710.6561773\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20190705.6552949\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\n.................................................ty/tw/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Goswami", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7676074", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7676074", "date": "2020-07-22 21:23:15", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (ASSAM)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Jul 2020 21:59 IST\nSource: India TV [edited]\nhttps://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-assam-kills-48-japanese-encephalitis-636330\n\n\nAt least 48 persons have lost their lives in Japanese encephalitis (JE) and other such acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) out of 331 cases across Assam this year [2020], the National Health Mission (NHM) said on Wednesday [22 Jul 2020]. The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) held a video conference with all districts to review the status of AES and JE in Assam, a joint statement by the health department and the NHM's state unit said.\n\n\"The state currently has 331 AES cases and 48 deaths, which includes 148 non-JE cases, 24 non-JE deaths, and 183 JE cases, 24 JE deaths,\" it added.\n\nThe video conference was chaired by Health and Family Welfare Commissioner and Secretary Monalisa Goswami in the presence of NHM Mission Director Lakshmanan S and other officials.\n\nGoswami reviewed the status of the diseases in the state and instructed all concerned to ensure that the laboratories are functional and replace the Elisa Reader and Washer (equipment for testing), wherever needed.\n\nGoswami directed her department officials to closely monitor the activities and follow up on the treatment with the JE patients.\n\n\"The monitoring and supervision need to be strengthened, and IEC/awareness activities, too, should be rigorously done at all the districts; special focus should also be given at the tea garden areas in Assam,\" the statement said.\n\nGoswami further instructed all officials concerned to regularly conduct field visits to ensure that the District Task Force meetings are conducted in close coordination with various departments for a better management of AES and JE in the northeastern state.\n\n\"The VC concluded with the final remarks of the commissioner and secretary, instructing all concerned officials to work in cohesion with the different departments for better management of AES/JE in state,\" the statement said.\n\nShe also directed to ensure availability and earmarking of JE beds in all district hospitals and medical colleges to treat the patients of the mosquito-borne diseases, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) and acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases are increasing again this year (2020) in Assam state from 174 cases and 23 deaths reported on 9 Jul 2020 to 331 cases and 48 deaths as of 22 Jul 2020. Of these cases, 183 mentioned above are classified as JE, and 148 are AES cases.\n\nAs mentioned in previous ProMED-mail posts, the issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe report above does not indicate whether any of the AES etiologies above have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is well underway, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 3-4 months.\n\nAlthough mosquito control is not mentioned in the report above as a JE preventive measure, it is difficult to effectively accomplish in localities where the JE virus vectors, _Culex_ spp., are abundant and widespread. Because the _Culex_ vector mosquitoes also breed in rice paddies, which may be extensive, vector control over large areas is difficult. It is curious that no mention is made of vaccination campaigns in the affected areas. Vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent JE virus infection. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20190716.6570013\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS, BR) 20190710.6561773\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20190705.6552949\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\n.................................................ty/tw/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Goswami", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7618995", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7618995", "date": "2020-07-22 21:23:15", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (ASSAM)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Jul 2020 21:59 IST\nSource: India TV [edited]\nhttps://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-assam-kills-48-japanese-encephalitis-636330\n\n\nAt least 48 persons have lost their lives in Japanese encephalitis (JE) and other such acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) out of 331 cases across Assam this year [2020], the National Health Mission (NHM) said on Wednesday [22 Jul 2020]. The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) held a video conference with all districts to review the status of AES and JE in Assam, a joint statement by the health department and the NHM's state unit said.\n\n\"The state currently has 331 AES cases and 48 deaths, which includes 148 non-JE cases, 24 non-JE deaths, and 183 JE cases, 24 JE deaths,\" it added.\n\nThe video conference was chaired by Health and Family Welfare Commissioner and Secretary Monalisa Goswami in the presence of NHM Mission Director Lakshmanan S and other officials.\n\nGoswami reviewed the status of the diseases in the state and instructed all concerned to ensure that the laboratories are functional and replace the Elisa Reader and Washer (equipment for testing), wherever needed.\n\nGoswami directed her department officials to closely monitor the activities and follow up on the treatment with the JE patients.\n\n\"The monitoring and supervision need to be strengthened, and IEC/awareness activities, too, should be rigorously done at all the districts; special focus should also be given at the tea garden areas in Assam,\" the statement said.\n\nGoswami further instructed all officials concerned to regularly conduct field visits to ensure that the District Task Force meetings are conducted in close coordination with various departments for a better management of AES and JE in the northeastern state.\n\n\"The VC concluded with the final remarks of the commissioner and secretary, instructing all concerned officials to work in cohesion with the different departments for better management of AES/JE in state,\" the statement said.\n\nShe also directed to ensure availability and earmarking of JE beds in all district hospitals and medical colleges to treat the patients of the mosquito-borne diseases, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) and acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases are increasing again this year (2020) in Assam state from 174 cases and 23 deaths reported on 9 Jul 2020 to 331 cases and 48 deaths as of 22 Jul 2020. Of these cases, 183 mentioned above are classified as JE, and 148 are AES cases.\n\nAs mentioned in previous ProMED-mail posts, the issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe report above does not indicate whether any of the AES etiologies above have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is well underway, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 3-4 months.\n\nAlthough mosquito control is not mentioned in the report above as a JE preventive measure, it is difficult to effectively accomplish in localities where the JE virus vectors, _Culex_ spp., are abundant and widespread. Because the _Culex_ vector mosquitoes also breed in rice paddies, which may be extensive, vector control over large areas is difficult. It is curious that no mention is made of vaccination campaigns in the affected areas. Vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent JE virus infection. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7602461", "date": "2020-07-22 21:23:15", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (ASSAM)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Jul 2020 21:59 IST\nSource: India TV [edited]\nhttps://www.indiatvnews.com/news/india/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-assam-kills-48-japanese-encephalitis-636330\n\n\nAt least 48 persons have lost their lives in Japanese encephalitis (JE) and other such acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) out of 331 cases across Assam this year [2020], the National Health Mission (NHM) said on Wednesday [22 Jul 2020]. The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) held a video conference with all districts to review the status of AES and JE in Assam, a joint statement by the health department and the NHM's state unit said.\n\n\"The state currently has 331 AES cases and 48 deaths, which includes 148 non-JE cases, 24 non-JE deaths, and 183 JE cases, 24 JE deaths,\" it added.\n\nThe video conference was chaired by Health and Family Welfare Commissioner and Secretary Monalisa Goswami in the presence of NHM Mission Director Lakshmanan S and other officials.\n\nGoswami reviewed the status of the diseases in the state and instructed all concerned to ensure that the laboratories are functional and replace the Elisa Reader and Washer (equipment for testing), wherever needed.\n\nGoswami directed her department officials to closely monitor the activities and follow up on the treatment with the JE patients.\n\n\"The monitoring and supervision need to be strengthened, and IEC/awareness activities, too, should be rigorously done at all the districts; special focus should also be given at the tea garden areas in Assam,\" the statement said.\n\nGoswami further instructed all officials concerned to regularly conduct field visits to ensure that the District Task Force meetings are conducted in close coordination with various departments for a better management of AES and JE in the northeastern state.\n\n\"The VC concluded with the final remarks of the commissioner and secretary, instructing all concerned officials to work in cohesion with the different departments for better management of AES/JE in state,\" the statement said.\n\nShe also directed to ensure availability and earmarking of JE beds in all district hospitals and medical colleges to treat the patients of the mosquito-borne diseases, the statement said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) and acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases are increasing again this year (2020) in Assam state from 174 cases and 23 deaths reported on 9 Jul 2020 to 331 cases and 48 deaths as of 22 Jul 2020. Of these cases, 183 mentioned above are classified as JE, and 148 are AES cases.\n\nAs mentioned in previous ProMED-mail posts, the issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe report above does not indicate whether any of the AES etiologies above have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is well underway, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 3-4 months.\n\nAlthough mosquito control is not mentioned in the report above as a JE preventive measure, it is difficult to effectively accomplish in localities where the JE virus vectors, _Culex_ spp., are abundant and widespread. Because the _Culex_ vector mosquitoes also breed in rice paddies, which may be extensive, vector control over large areas is difficult. It is curious that no mention is made of vaccination campaigns in the affected areas. Vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent JE virus infection. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7563226", "date": "2020-03-31 05:17:52", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA: (BIHAR)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Mar 2020\nSource: Zee News [edited]\nhttps://zeenews.india.com/india/child-dies-of-acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-bihar-2272616.html\n\n\nA child died due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) in Bihar on Sunday (29 Mar 2020). \"A child has lost his life due to acute encephalitis syndrome at Sri Krishna Medical College & Hospital (SKMCH) in Muzaffarpur,\" Dr SK Shahi, SKMCH superintendent said.\n\nThis is the 1st AES related death in the district this year [2020]. Last year [2019], over 140 children died due to AES in the district. As per official data, 121 deaths were reported at the government-run SKMCH, which handled the largest number of patients in the district, while 21 deaths were confirmed at the Kejriwal Hospital.\n\nAES is a viral disease that causes flu-like symptoms such as high fever, vomiting, and, in extreme cases, brain dysfunction, seizure, and inflammation of the heart and kidney.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[AES is a common ailment in children in northeastern India, especially in Bihar state.\n\nThe issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_).\n\nA recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 commonest agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe above report does not indicate whether any of the above etiologies have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is just beginning, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 6-7 months. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBihar State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/364]\nSee Also\n2019\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7373287", "date": "2020-03-31 05:17:52", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA: (BIHAR)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Mar 2020\nSource: Zee News [edited]\nhttps://zeenews.india.com/india/child-dies-of-acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-bihar-2272616.html\n\n\nA child died due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) in Bihar on Sunday (29 Mar 2020). \"A child has lost his life due to acute encephalitis syndrome at Sri Krishna Medical College & Hospital (SKMCH) in Muzaffarpur,\" Dr SK Shahi, SKMCH superintendent said.\n\nThis is the 1st AES related death in the district this year [2020]. Last year [2019], over 140 children died due to AES in the district. As per official data, 121 deaths were reported at the government-run SKMCH, which handled the largest number of patients in the district, while 21 deaths were confirmed at the Kejriwal Hospital.\n\nAES is a viral disease that causes flu-like symptoms such as high fever, vomiting, and, in extreme cases, brain dysfunction, seizure, and inflammation of the heart and kidney.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[AES is a common ailment in children in northeastern India, especially in Bihar state.\n\nThe issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_).\n\nA recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 commonest agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe above report does not indicate whether any of the above etiologies have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is just beginning, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 6-7 months. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBihar State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/364]\nSee Also\n2019\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7347800", "date": "2020-03-31 05:17:52", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA: (BIHAR)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Mar 2020\nSource: Zee News [edited]\nhttps://zeenews.india.com/india/child-dies-of-acute-encephalitis-syndrome-in-bihar-2272616.html\n\n\nA child died due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) in Bihar on Sunday (29 Mar 2020). \"A child has lost his life due to acute encephalitis syndrome at Sri Krishna Medical College & Hospital (SKMCH) in Muzaffarpur,\" Dr SK Shahi, SKMCH superintendent said.\n\nThis is the 1st AES related death in the district this year [2020]. Last year [2019], over 140 children died due to AES in the district. As per official data, 121 deaths were reported at the government-run SKMCH, which handled the largest number of patients in the district, while 21 deaths were confirmed at the Kejriwal Hospital.\n\nAES is a viral disease that causes flu-like symptoms such as high fever, vomiting, and, in extreme cases, brain dysfunction, seizure, and inflammation of the heart and kidney.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[AES is a common ailment in children in northeastern India, especially in Bihar state.\n\nThe issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. AES has continued to be attributed to various etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible Japanese encephalitis, enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, intoxication from lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_).\n\nA recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 commonest agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nThe above report does not indicate whether any of the above etiologies have been ruled out or confirmed. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The season in which AES cases occur is just beginning, and additional cases can be expected over the coming 6-7 months. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBihar State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/364]\nSee Also\n2019\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - Last year [2019], over 140 children died due to AES in the district. As per official data, 121 deaths were reported at the government-run SKMCH, which handled the largest number of patients in the district, while 21 deaths were confirmed at the Kejriwal Hospital.\n\nAES is a viral disease that causes flu-like symptoms such as high fever, vomiting, and, in extreme cases, brain dysfunction, seizure, and inflammation of the heart and kidney.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[AES is a common ailment in children in northeastern India, especially in Bihar state.\n\nThe issue of the etiology of AES has been under discussion for a long time. Until the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. USA: (ME) high prevalence in ticks, 2019, other tick-borne dz.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7086005", "date": "2019-09-14 14:09:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (27): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 12 Sep 2019\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttps://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/japanese-encephalitis-kills-154-in-assam-the-highest-since-2014/story-mwDReeGewst9m5WiV6ep3J.html\n\n\nJapanese encephalitis (JE) has killed 154 people in Assam in 2019, the highest in 5 years officials said even as they claimed that the outbreak, which peaked in July and August, was subsiding and only a few fresh cases were reported in September.\n\nA top state government official also said a state-wide adult vaccination campaign will begin in November [2019] covering all districts after the Centre agreed to provide around 57 lakh [5.7 million] vaccines.\n\n\"From [15 Nov 2019], we plan to start an intensive adult vaccination campaign covering the whole state. We plan to conclude it by [15 Mar 2020]. The Centre has agreed to provide around 57 lakh vaccines. We will procure the rest on our own if there is a shortfall,\" Samir Sinha, Principal Secretary, Health and Family Welfare Department said. The campaign is likely to be announced in a week.\n\nOn Thursday [12 Sep 2019], while no fresh JE cases were reported, one person from Kamrup (Rural) succumbed to the disease that is spread by _Culex_ mosquitoes, according to the daily bulletin from the office of JVN Subramanyam, Director, National Health Mission (NHM), Assam.\n\nThe state recorded 614 JE positive cases in 2015, 427 in 2016, 605 in 2017 and 509 in 2018. In 2015, the number of deaths due to JE stood at 135; in 2016 the number came down to 92 and further decreased to 87 in 2017. In 2018, the state saw 94 deaths due to the vector-borne disease. In 2014, the state recorded 165 deaths due to JE.\n\nThe bulletin from NHM said till 12 Sep [2019], the total number of persons who have been affected by JE stood at 630, out of which 154 people have died. While 13 persons who died belonged to Goalpara, 11 came from Kamrup (Rural), the 2 neighbouring districts in lower Assam where maximum fatalities have been recorded this year [2019]. Kokrajhar, in Bodo Territorial Administrative District, has not reported any JE positive case for the 1st time in the last 6 years, even as the rest of the state has been affected in [the] 2019 outbreak.\n\n\"Since the last 4, 5 years were relatively calm and quiet, this year [2019] the peripheral workers seemed to be reluctant to perform their field duties properly. During my visit to Goalpara, I found that peripheral workers did not attend to cases of fever initially,\" said CR Pathak, State Programme Officer of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, explaining how the lax attitude of the ground staff may have added to the late detection and higher fatalities.\n\nPathak pointed out another reason and explained how a lot of ground staff, the multipurpose workers were involved in National Register of Citizens (NRC) duty. \"I am sure the NRC authorities also did not know that the outbreak would be severe this year. We recalled the workers in July [2019],\" he said.\n\nHealth officials also introduced urgent measures like fogging, blood sample collection of all cases of fever and sending all suspected JE cases for proper tests, treatment at civil hospitals and medical colleges, among others.\n\n\"Post July [2019] the number of fresh cases have been on a decline,\" said Pathak.\n\nSinha said, \"The last 10 deaths are all old cases.\" In September [2019], only 4 fresh cases have been recorded in the state. Unlike previous years when the disease was mostly confined to Upper Assam and North Assam, the whole state was affected this time, he said.\n\nHe said analysis also showed that the adults constituted almost 80% of the casualties. \"The writing on the wall is clear. Vaccination of persons in the age group of 15-65 is the way forward to contain it,\" Sinha said.\n\nWhile the entire state has been covered under the JE vaccination campaign for children, 14 have been covered under the adult vaccination campaign in a phased manner. Officials point out the coverage [of the] latter has not been satisfactory for a multitude of reasons, including rumours about the effects of the vaccine.\n\nRecords show even vaccination is not a foolproof way to stop the outbreak. \"This year [2019], too, 15%-20% of the casualties would be from the section which had been given JE vaccination. We know that JE vaccine is effective in around 85% of the cases and depends on immunity of the persons among other factors,\" said Pathak.\n\n[Byline: Sadiq Naqvi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[All the above cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE), with no mention of non-JE acute encephalitis syndrome that was mentioned in the previous Assam report (see Japanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (AS) 20190728.6591689). It is not stated if the vaccine used is inactivated or a live modified one. The immunity of inactivated vaccine likely is of considerably shorter duration than a live vaccine would be. It is unfortunate to learn that the rumor that the vaccine is not safe reduces coverage of the population at risk of infection. The price paid for this rumor is a population of increased susceptibility with more cases and deaths. A public information campaign is necessary to counteract the rumors. - Mod.TY\n\nMap of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nIndia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142\nAssam State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (AS) 20190728.6591689\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (AS) 20190720.6578446\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20190716.6570013\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): (BR, AR) 20190714.6567249\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS, BR) 20190710.6561773\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20190705.6552949\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS) 20190630.6544796\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20180818.5974190\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.58623\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.581\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/rd/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2019-09-12 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "North Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.581\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/rd/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2019-09-12 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "North Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "non - JE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6785236", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Powassan virus encephalitis - USA (07): (NY) with 2 other pathogens", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6785236", "date": "2019-09-14 14:09:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (27): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 12 Sep 2019\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttps://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/japanese-encephalitis-kills-154-in-assam-the-highest-since-2014/story-mwDReeGewst9m5WiV6ep3J.html\n\n\nJapanese encephalitis (JE) has killed 154 people in Assam in 2019, the highest in 5 years officials said even as they claimed that the outbreak, which peaked in July and August, was subsiding and only a few fresh cases were reported in September.\n\nA top state government official also said a state-wide adult vaccination campaign will begin in November [2019] covering all districts after the Centre agreed to provide around 57 lakh [5.7 million] vaccines.\n\n\"From [15 Nov 2019], we plan to start an intensive adult vaccination campaign covering the whole state. We plan to conclude it by [15 Mar 2020]. The Centre has agreed to provide around 57 lakh vaccines. We will procure the rest on our own if there is a shortfall,\" Samir Sinha, Principal Secretary, Health and Family Welfare Department said. The campaign is likely to be announced in a week.\n\nOn Thursday [12 Sep 2019], while no fresh JE cases were reported, one person from Kamrup (Rural) succumbed to the disease that is spread by _Culex_ mosquitoes, according to the daily bulletin from the office of JVN Subramanyam, Director, National Health Mission (NHM), Assam.\n\nThe state recorded 614 JE positive cases in 2015, 427 in 2016, 605 in 2017 and 509 in 2018. In 2015, the number of deaths due to JE stood at 135; in 2016 the number came down to 92 and further decreased to 87 in 2017. In 2018, the state saw 94 deaths due to the vector-borne disease. In 2014, the state recorded 165 deaths due to JE.\n\nThe bulletin from NHM said till 12 Sep [2019], the total number of persons who have been affected by JE stood at 630, out of which 154 people have died. While 13 persons who died belonged to Goalpara, 11 came from Kamrup (Rural), the 2 neighbouring districts in lower Assam where maximum fatalities have been recorded this year [2019]. Kokrajhar, in Bodo Territorial Administrative District, has not reported any JE positive case for the 1st time in the last 6 years, even as the rest of the state has been affected in [the] 2019 outbreak.\n\n\"Since the last 4, 5 years were relatively calm and quiet, this year [2019] the peripheral workers seemed to be reluctant to perform their field duties properly. During my visit to Goalpara, I found that peripheral workers did not attend to cases of fever initially,\" said CR Pathak, State Programme Officer of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, explaining how the lax attitude of the ground staff may have added to the late detection and higher fatalities.\n\nPathak pointed out another reason and explained how a lot of ground staff, the multipurpose workers were involved in National Register of Citizens (NRC) duty. \"I am sure the NRC authorities also did not know that the outbreak would be severe this year. We recalled the workers in July [2019],\" he said.\n\nHealth officials also introduced urgent measures like fogging, blood sample collection of all cases of fever and sending all suspected JE cases for proper tests, treatment at civil hospitals and medical colleges, among others.\n\n\"Post July [2019] the number of fresh cases have been on a decline,\" said Pathak.\n\nSinha said, \"The last 10 deaths are all old cases.\" In September [2019], only 4 fresh cases have been recorded in the state. Unlike previous years when the disease was mostly confined to Upper Assam and North Assam, the whole state was affected this time, he said.\n\nHe said analysis also showed that the adults constituted almost 80% of the casualties. \"The writing on the wall is clear. Vaccination of persons in the age group of 15-65 is the way forward to contain it,\" Sinha said.\n\nWhile the entire state has been covered under the JE vaccination campaign for children, 14 have been covered under the adult vaccination campaign in a phased manner. Officials point out the coverage [of the] latter has not been satisfactory for a multitude of reasons, including rumours about the effects of the vaccine.\n\nRecords show even vaccination is not a foolproof way to stop the outbreak. \"This year [2019], too, 15%-20% of the casualties would be from the section which had been given JE vaccination. We know that JE vaccine is effective in around 85% of the cases and depends on immunity of the persons among other factors,\" said Pathak.\n\n[Byline: Sadiq Naqvi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[All the above cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE), with no mention of non-JE acute encephalitis syndrome that was mentioned in the previous Assam report (see Japanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (AS) 20190728.6591689). It is not stated if the vaccine used is inactivated or a live modified one. The immunity of inactivated vaccine likely is of considerably shorter duration than a live vaccine would be. It is unfortunate to learn that the rumor that the vaccine is not safe reduces coverage of the population at risk of infection. The price paid for this rumor is a population of increased susceptibility with more cases and deaths. A public information campaign is necessary to counteract the rumors. - Mod.TY\n\nMap of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nIndia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142\nAssam State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (AS) 20190728.6591689\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (AS) 20190720.6578446\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20190716.6570013\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): (BR, AR) 20190714.6567249\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS, BR) 20190710.6561773\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20190705.6552949\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS) 20190630.6544796\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20180818.5974190\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.58623\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.581\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/rd/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2019-09-12 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "North Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "other - India (29): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6687455", "date": "2019-09-14 14:09:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (27): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 12 Sep 2019\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttps://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/japanese-encephalitis-kills-154-in-assam-the-highest-since-2014/story-mwDReeGewst9m5WiV6ep3J.html\n\n\nJapanese encephalitis (JE) has killed 154 people in Assam in 2019, the highest in 5 years officials said even as they claimed that the outbreak, which peaked in July and August, was subsiding and only a few fresh cases were reported in September.\n\nA top state government official also said a state-wide adult vaccination campaign will begin in November [2019] covering all districts after the Centre agreed to provide around 57 lakh [5.7 million] vaccines.\n\n\"From [15 Nov 2019], we plan to start an intensive adult vaccination campaign covering the whole state. We plan to conclude it by [15 Mar 2020]. The Centre has agreed to provide around 57 lakh vaccines. We will procure the rest on our own if there is a shortfall,\" Samir Sinha, Principal Secretary, Health and Family Welfare Department said. The campaign is likely to be announced in a week.\n\nOn Thursday [12 Sep 2019], while no fresh JE cases were reported, one person from Kamrup (Rural) succumbed to the disease that is spread by _Culex_ mosquitoes, according to the daily bulletin from the office of JVN Subramanyam, Director, National Health Mission (NHM), Assam.\n\nThe state recorded 614 JE positive cases in 2015, 427 in 2016, 605 in 2017 and 509 in 2018. In 2015, the number of deaths due to JE stood at 135; in 2016 the number came down to 92 and further decreased to 87 in 2017. In 2018, the state saw 94 deaths due to the vector-borne disease. In 2014, the state recorded 165 deaths due to JE.\n\nThe bulletin from NHM said till 12 Sep [2019], the total number of persons who have been affected by JE stood at 630, out of which 154 people have died. While 13 persons who died belonged to Goalpara, 11 came from Kamrup (Rural), the 2 neighbouring districts in lower Assam where maximum fatalities have been recorded this year [2019]. Kokrajhar, in Bodo Territorial Administrative District, has not reported any JE positive case for the 1st time in the last 6 years, even as the rest of the state has been affected in [the] 2019 outbreak.\n\n\"Since the last 4, 5 years were relatively calm and quiet, this year [2019] the peripheral workers seemed to be reluctant to perform their field duties properly. During my visit to Goalpara, I found that peripheral workers did not attend to cases of fever initially,\" said CR Pathak, State Programme Officer of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, explaining how the lax attitude of the ground staff may have added to the late detection and higher fatalities.\n\nPathak pointed out another reason and explained how a lot of ground staff, the multipurpose workers were involved in National Register of Citizens (NRC) duty. \"I am sure the NRC authorities also did not know that the outbreak would be severe this year. We recalled the workers in July [2019],\" he said.\n\nHealth officials also introduced urgent measures like fogging, blood sample collection of all cases of fever and sending all suspected JE cases for proper tests, treatment at civil hospitals and medical colleges, among others.\n\n\"Post July [2019] the number of fresh cases have been on a decline,\" said Pathak.\n\nSinha said, \"The last 10 deaths are all old cases.\" In September [2019], only 4 fresh cases have been recorded in the state. Unlike previous years when the disease was mostly confined to Upper Assam and North Assam, the whole state was affected this time, he said.\n\nHe said analysis also showed that the adults constituted almost 80% of the casualties. \"The writing on the wall is clear. Vaccination of persons in the age group of 15-65 is the way forward to contain it,\" Sinha said.\n\nWhile the entire state has been covered under the JE vaccination campaign for children, 14 have been covered under the adult vaccination campaign in a phased manner. Officials point out the coverage [of the] latter has not been satisfactory for a multitude of reasons, including rumours about the effects of the vaccine.\n\nRecords show even vaccination is not a foolproof way to stop the outbreak. \"This year [2019], too, 15%-20% of the casualties would be from the section which had been given JE vaccination. We know that JE vaccine is effective in around 85% of the cases and depends on immunity of the persons among other factors,\" said Pathak.\n\n[Byline: Sadiq Naqvi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[All the above cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE), with no mention of non-JE acute encephalitis syndrome that was mentioned in the previous Assam report (see Japanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (AS) 20190728.6591689).
