India (03): (AS) 20180523.581\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/rd/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2019-09-12 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "North Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "non - JE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6684163", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (28): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6684163", "date": "2019-09-14 14:09:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (27): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 12 Sep 2019\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttps://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/japanese-encephalitis-kills-154-in-assam-the-highest-since-2014/story-mwDReeGewst9m5WiV6ep3J.html\n\n\nJapanese encephalitis (JE) has killed 154 people in Assam in 2019, the highest in 5 years officials said even as they claimed that the outbreak, which peaked in July and August, was subsiding and only a few fresh cases were reported in September.\n\nA top state government official also said a state-wide adult vaccination campaign will begin in November [2019] covering all districts after the Centre agreed to provide around 57 lakh [5.7 million] vaccines.\n\n\"From [15 Nov 2019], we plan to start an intensive adult vaccination campaign covering the whole state. We plan to conclude it by [15 Mar 2020]. The Centre has agreed to provide around 57 lakh vaccines. We will procure the rest on our own if there is a shortfall,\" Samir Sinha, Principal Secretary, Health and Family Welfare Department said. The campaign is likely to be announced in a week.\n\nOn Thursday [12 Sep 2019], while no fresh JE cases were reported, one person from Kamrup (Rural) succumbed to the disease that is spread by _Culex_ mosquitoes, according to the daily bulletin from the office of JVN Subramanyam, Director, National Health Mission (NHM), Assam.\n\nThe state recorded 614 JE positive cases in 2015, 427 in 2016, 605 in 2017 and 509 in 2018. In 2015, the number of deaths due to JE stood at 135; in 2016 the number came down to 92 and further decreased to 87 in 2017. In 2018, the state saw 94 deaths due to the vector-borne disease. In 2014, the state recorded 165 deaths due to JE.\n\nThe bulletin from NHM said till 12 Sep [2019], the total number of persons who have been affected by JE stood at 630, out of which 154 people have died. While 13 persons who died belonged to Goalpara, 11 came from Kamrup (Rural), the 2 neighbouring districts in lower Assam where maximum fatalities have been recorded this year [2019]. Kokrajhar, in Bodo Territorial Administrative District, has not reported any JE positive case for the 1st time in the last 6 years, even as the rest of the state has been affected in [the] 2019 outbreak.\n\n\"Since the last 4, 5 years were relatively calm and quiet, this year [2019] the peripheral workers seemed to be reluctant to perform their field duties properly. During my visit to Goalpara, I found that peripheral workers did not attend to cases of fever initially,\" said CR Pathak, State Programme Officer of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, explaining how the lax attitude of the ground staff may have added to the late detection and higher fatalities.\n\nPathak pointed out another reason and explained how a lot of ground staff, the multipurpose workers were involved in National Register of Citizens (NRC) duty. \"I am sure the NRC authorities also did not know that the outbreak would be severe this year. We recalled the workers in July [2019],\" he said.\n\nHealth officials also introduced urgent measures like fogging, blood sample collection of all cases of fever and sending all suspected JE cases for proper tests, treatment at civil hospitals and medical colleges, among others.\n\n\"Post July [2019] the number of fresh cases have been on a decline,\" said Pathak.\n\nSinha said, \"The last 10 deaths are all old cases.\" In September [2019], only 4 fresh cases have been recorded in the state. Unlike previous years when the disease was mostly confined to Upper Assam and North Assam, the whole state was affected this time, he said.\n\nHe said analysis also showed that the adults constituted almost 80% of the casualties. \"The writing on the wall is clear. Vaccination of persons in the age group of 15-65 is the way forward to contain it,\" Sinha said.\n\nWhile the entire state has been covered under the JE vaccination campaign for children, 14 have been covered under the adult vaccination campaign in a phased manner. Officials point out the coverage [of the] latter has not been satisfactory for a multitude of reasons, including rumours about the effects of the vaccine.\n\nRecords show even vaccination is not a foolproof way to stop the outbreak. \"This year [2019], too, 15%-20% of the casualties would be from the section which had been given JE vaccination. We know that JE vaccine is effective in around 85% of the cases and depends on immunity of the persons among other factors,\" said Pathak.\n\n[Byline: Sadiq Naqvi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[All the above cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE), with no mention of non-JE acute encephalitis syndrome that was mentioned in the previous Assam report (see Japanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (AS) 20190728.6591689). It is not stated if the vaccine used is inactivated or a live modified one. The immunity of inactivated vaccine likely is of considerably shorter duration than a live vaccine would be. It is unfortunate to learn that the rumor that the vaccine is not safe reduces coverage of the population at risk of infection. The price paid for this rumor is a population of increased susceptibility with more cases and deaths. A public information campaign is necessary to counteract the rumors. - Mod.TY\n\nMap of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nIndia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142\nAssam State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.581\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/rd/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2021-11-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2020-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2019-09-12 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "North Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "non - JE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6663432", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Salmonellosis, st I 4,[5],12:i:- - USA (04): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6663432", "date": "2019-08-01 17:10:32", "main_text": "SALMONELLOSIS, SEROTYPE I 4,[5],12:I:- - USA (03): PIG EAR DOG TREATS, OTHER SEROTYPES\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jul 2019\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CDC, salmonella homepage, [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/pet-treats-07-19/index.html\n\n\nOutbreak of multidrug-resistant Salmonella infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of multidrug-resistant _Salmonella_ serotypes I 4,[5],12:i:-, Infantis, Newport, and London infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats. As of [31 Jul 2019], a total of 127 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Salmonella_ have been reported from 33 states.\n\nState / Ill People\n----------------------\nAlabama / 1\nArizona / 1\nCalifornia / 1\nColorado / 3\nConnecticut / 1\nFlorida / 3\nGeorgia / 2\nHawaii / 1\nIllinois / 7\nIndiana / 5\nIowa / 23\nKansas / 3\nKentucky / 6\nLouisiana / 1\nMaine / 1\nMassachusetts / 4\nMichigan / 12\nMinnesota / 1\nMissouri / 6\nNew Hampshire / 1\nNew Jersey / 2\nNew Mexico / 1\nNew York / 15\nNorth Carolina / 2\nNorth Dakota / 1\nOhio / 5\nOregon / 2\nPennsylvania / 6\nSouth Carolina / 2\nTexas / 2\nUtah / 1\nWashington / 1\nWisconsin / 4\n-------------\nTotal / 127\n\nIllnesses started on dates ranging from [16 Jun 2015] to [6 Jul 2019]. Ill people range in age from less than 1 year to 90 years, with a median age of 40 years. A total of 55 (45%) ill people are female. Of 88 ill people with information available, 26 (30%) have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nIllnesses might not yet be reported due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nPredicted antimicrobial resistance based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) was determined for 71 isolates from ill people. There was no antimicrobial resistance predicted for one isolate; the remaining 70 isolates had predicted resistance or decreased susceptibility to one or more of the following antibacterials: amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, cefoxitin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, kanamycin, nalidixic acid, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, and tetracycline. Testing of one clinical isolate using standard susceptibility testing methods by CDC's National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) provided comparable results (kanamycin was not tested by this method). If antimicrobials are needed, infections related to this outbreak may be difficult to treat with some commonly recommended medications, and may require a different choice.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and traceback evidence indicates that contact with pig ear dog treats is the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about animal and pet food contact in the week before they became ill. A total of 76 (89%) of 85 ill people reported contact with a dog before getting sick. Of 62 people with available information, 45 (73%) reported contact with pig ear dog treats or with dogs who were fed pig ear dog treats. Both of these proportions are significantly higher than the results from a survey of healthy people who reported contact with dogs (61%) or handling dog treats (16%), such as pig ears, in the week before interview.\n\nDuring the investigation, health and regulatory officials from Kansas, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and FDA collected pig ears at retail locations where ill people reported buying the products or their suppliers and distributors. Testing identified many different strains of _Salmonella_. A search of the CDC PulseNet database found that people had been infected with some of these strains, including _S._ Infantis, _S._ London, and _S._ Newport. Some of these illnesses date back to 2015. These ill people were added to the outbreak investigation.\n\nAdditional _Salmonella_ strains were isolated from pig ears, and investigators are working to determine if any human illnesses are linked to those strains. Those strains include _S._ Panama, _S._ Brandenburg, _S._ Anatum, and _S._ Livingstone.\n\nSome of the tested pig ears were imported from Argentina, and Brazil. Some product labels indicated that the pig ears were irradiated; this process should kill _Salmonella_. _Salmonella_ identified in products labeled as irradiated indicate they may not have been irradiated or there was a another issue that led to _Salmonella_ contamination.\n\nOn [3 Jul 2019], Pet Supplies Plus recalled bulk pig ears stocked in open bins because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [26 Jul 2019], Lennox Intl Inc recalled pig ears because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [30 Jul 2019] Lennox Intl Inc expanded their recall. These recalls do not account for all of the illnesses in this outbreak.\n\nInformation collected to date about where ill people bought pig ears has not identified a single supplier, distributor, or common brand of pig ear treats. CDC and FDA recommend that people do not purchase or feed any pig ear pet treats to dogs because they could be contaminated with _Salmonella_ and could make people and dogs sick. CDC and FDA recommendations may change as more information becomes available.\n\nThis investigation is ongoing. CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A handful of the newly added cases seem to be from infections occurring between 2015-2017.\n\nAs a review, _Salmonella_ as a genus has 2 species, _enterica_ and _bongori_. _S. enterica_ is divided into 6 subspecies: _enterica_, _salamae_, _arizonae_, _diarizonae_, _houtenae_, and _indica_. _S. enterica_ subspecies _enterica_ (or subspecies I) strains are the ones usually isolated from humans or warm-blooded animals and represent a majority of the salmonellas that are clinically important.\n\nThe designation _Salmonella_ I 4,[5],12:i:- means:\n- the \"I\" reflects subspecies _enterica_;\n- the \"4, [5] 12\" are the O (or somatic) antigens associated with the organism. An O antigen underscored or placed in [ ] can refer to whether the antigen is related to phage conversion or not;\n- the nomenclature after the colon, in this case i:-, reflects the flagellar or H antigens.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nSalmonellosis - USA (03): live poultry, multiple serotypes, fatal 20190723.6581931\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA (02): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes 20190722.6581930\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA (02): Mexican papayas, alert 20190706.6554747\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA: pig ear dog treats 20190704.6551235\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA: Mexican papayas, alert 20190701.6545756\nSalmonellosis - USA (02): live poultry, multiple serotypes 20190615.6522442\nSalmonellosis, st Typhimurium - USA (03): pet hedgehog 20190602.6498690\nSalmonellosis, st Braenderup & Montevideo - USA: live poultry 20190518.6472999\nSalmonellosis, st Concord - USA: tahini, alert, recall request 20190517.6471874\nSalmonellosis, st Carrau - USA (02): precut melon, CDC 20190426.6442308\nSalmonellosis, st. Newport - USA: frozen raw tuna, alert, recall 20190416.6425979\nSalmonellosis, st. Carrau - USA: precut melon, CDC 20190415.6423047\nSalmonellosis, st. "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (26): (AR) pigs", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6624114", "date": "2019-08-01 17:10:32", "main_text": "SALMONELLOSIS, SEROTYPE I 4,[5],12:I:- - USA (03): PIG EAR DOG TREATS, OTHER SEROTYPES\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jul 2019\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CDC, salmonella homepage, [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/pet-treats-07-19/index.html\n\n\nOutbreak of multidrug-resistant Salmonella infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of multidrug-resistant _Salmonella_ serotypes I 4,[5],12:i:-, Infantis, Newport, and London infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats. As of [31 Jul 2019], a total of 127 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Salmonella_ have been reported from 33 states.\n\nState / Ill People\n----------------------\nAlabama / 1\nArizona / 1\nCalifornia / 1\nColorado / 3\nConnecticut / 1\nFlorida / 3\nGeorgia / 2\nHawaii / 1\nIllinois / 7\nIndiana / 5\nIowa / 23\nKansas / 3\nKentucky / 6\nLouisiana / 1\nMaine / 1\nMassachusetts / 4\nMichigan / 12\nMinnesota / 1\nMissouri / 6\nNew Hampshire / 1\nNew Jersey / 2\nNew Mexico / 1\nNew York / 15\nNorth Carolina / 2\nNorth Dakota / 1\nOhio / 5\nOregon / 2\nPennsylvania / 6\nSouth Carolina / 2\nTexas / 2\nUtah / 1\nWashington / 1\nWisconsin / 4\n-------------\nTotal / 127\n\nIllnesses started on dates ranging from [16 Jun 2015] to [6 Jul 2019]. Ill people range in age from less than 1 year to 90 years, with a median age of 40 years. A total of 55 (45%) ill people are female. Of 88 ill people with information available, 26 (30%) have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nIllnesses might not yet be reported due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nPredicted antimicrobial resistance based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) was determined for 71 isolates from ill people. There was no antimicrobial resistance predicted for one isolate; the remaining 70 isolates had predicted resistance or decreased susceptibility to one or more of the following antibacterials: amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, cefoxitin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, kanamycin, nalidixic acid, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, and tetracycline. Testing of one clinical isolate using standard susceptibility testing methods by CDC's National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) provided comparable results (kanamycin was not tested by this method). If antimicrobials are needed, infections related to this outbreak may be difficult to treat with some commonly recommended medications, and may require a different choice.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and traceback evidence indicates that contact with pig ear dog treats is the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about animal and pet food contact in the week before they became ill. A total of 76 (89%) of 85 ill people reported contact with a dog before getting sick. Of 62 people with available information, 45 (73%) reported contact with pig ear dog treats or with dogs who were fed pig ear dog treats. Both of these proportions are significantly higher than the results from a survey of healthy people who reported contact with dogs (61%) or handling dog treats (16%), such as pig ears, in the week before interview.\n\nDuring the investigation, health and regulatory officials from Kansas, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and FDA collected pig ears at retail locations where ill people reported buying the products or their suppliers and distributors. Testing identified many different strains of _Salmonella_. A search of the CDC PulseNet database found that people had been infected with some of these strains, including _S._ Infantis, _S._ London, and _S._ Newport. Some of these illnesses date back to 2015. These ill people were added to the outbreak investigation.\n\nAdditional _Salmonella_ strains were isolated from pig ears, and investigators are working to determine if any human illnesses are linked to those strains. Those strains include _S._ Panama, _S._ Brandenburg, _S._ Anatum, and _S._ Livingstone.\n\nSome of the tested pig ears were imported from Argentina, and Brazil. Some product labels indicated that the pig ears were irradiated; this process should kill _Salmonella_. _Salmonella_ identified in products labeled as irradiated indicate they may not have been irradiated or there was a another issue that led to _Salmonella_ contamination.\n\nOn [3 Jul 2019], Pet Supplies Plus recalled bulk pig ears stocked in open bins because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [26 Jul 2019], Lennox Intl Inc recalled pig ears because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [30 Jul 2019] Lennox Intl Inc expanded their recall. These recalls do not account for all of the illnesses in this outbreak.\n\nInformation collected to date about where ill people bought pig ears has not identified a single supplier, distributor, or common brand of pig ear treats. CDC and FDA recommend that people do not purchase or feed any pig ear pet treats to dogs because they could be contaminated with _Salmonella_ and could make people and dogs sick. CDC and FDA recommendations may change as more information becomes available.\n\nThis investigation is ongoing. CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A handful of the newly added cases seem to be from infections occurring between 2015-2017.\n\nAs a review, _Salmonella_ as a genus has 2 species, _enterica_ and _bongori_. _S. enterica_ is divided into 6 subspecies: _enterica_, _salamae_, _arizonae_, _diarizonae_, _houtenae_, and _indica_. _S. enterica_ subspecies _enterica_ (or subspecies I) strains are the ones usually isolated from humans or warm-blooded animals and represent a majority of the salmonellas that are clinically important.\n\nThe designation _Salmonella_ I 4,[5],12:i:- means:\n- the \"I\" reflects subspecies _enterica_;\n- the \"4, [5] 12\" are the O (or somatic) antigens associated with the organism. An O antigen underscored or placed in [ ] can refer to whether the antigen is related to phage conversion or not;\n- the nomenclature after the colon, in this case i:-, reflects the flagellar or H antigens.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nSalmonellosis - USA (03): live poultry, multiple serotypes, fatal 20190723.6581931\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA (02): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes 20190722.6581930\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA (02): Mexican papayas, alert 20190706.6554747\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA: pig ear dog treats 20190704.6551235\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA: Mexican papayas, alert 20190701.6545756\nSalmonellosis - USA (02): live poultry, multiple serotypes 20190615.6522442\nSalmonellosis, st Typhimurium - USA (03): pet hedgehog 20190602.6498690\nSalmonellosis, st Braenderup & Montevideo - USA: live poultry 20190518.6472999\nSalmonellosis, st Concord - USA: tahini, alert, recall request 20190517.6471874\nSalmonellosis, st Carrau - USA (02): precut melon, CDC 20190426.6442308\nSalmonellosis, st. "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (25): (NL,AS,BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6619171", "date": "2019-08-01 17:10:32", "main_text": "SALMONELLOSIS, SEROTYPE I 4,[5],12:I:- - USA (03): PIG EAR DOG TREATS, OTHER SEROTYPES\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jul 2019\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CDC, salmonella homepage, [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/pet-treats-07-19/index.html\n\n\nOutbreak of multidrug-resistant Salmonella infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of multidrug-resistant _Salmonella_ serotypes I 4,[5],12:i:-, Infantis, Newport, and London infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats. As of [31 Jul 2019], a total of 127 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Salmonella_ have been reported from 33 states.\n\nState / Ill People\n----------------------\nAlabama / 1\nArizona / 1\nCalifornia / 1\nColorado / 3\nConnecticut / 1\nFlorida / 3\nGeorgia / 2\nHawaii / 1\nIllinois / 7\nIndiana / 5\nIowa / 23\nKansas / 3\nKentucky / 6\nLouisiana / 1\nMaine / 1\nMassachusetts / 4\nMichigan / 12\nMinnesota / 1\nMissouri / 6\nNew Hampshire / 1\nNew Jersey / 2\nNew Mexico / 1\nNew York / 15\nNorth Carolina / 2\nNorth Dakota / 1\nOhio / 5\nOregon / 2\nPennsylvania / 6\nSouth Carolina / 2\nTexas / 2\nUtah / 1\nWashington / 1\nWisconsin / 4\n-------------\nTotal / 127\n\nIllnesses started on dates ranging from [16 Jun 2015] to [6 Jul 2019]. Ill people range in age from less than 1 year to 90 years, with a median age of 40 years. A total of 55 (45%) ill people are female. Of 88 ill people with information available, 26 (30%) have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nIllnesses might not yet be reported due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nPredicted antimicrobial resistance based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) was determined for 71 isolates from ill people. There was no antimicrobial resistance predicted for one isolate; the remaining 70 isolates had predicted resistance or decreased susceptibility to one or more of the following antibacterials: amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, cefoxitin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, kanamycin, nalidixic acid, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, and tetracycline. Testing of one clinical isolate using standard susceptibility testing methods by CDC's National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) provided comparable results (kanamycin was not tested by this method). If antimicrobials are needed, infections related to this outbreak may be difficult to treat with some commonly recommended medications, and may require a different choice.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and traceback evidence indicates that contact with pig ear dog treats is the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about animal and pet food contact in the week before they became ill. A total of 76 (89%) of 85 ill people reported contact with a dog before getting sick. Of 62 people with available information, 45 (73%) reported contact with pig ear dog treats or with dogs who were fed pig ear dog treats. Both of these proportions are significantly higher than the results from a survey of healthy people who reported contact with dogs (61%) or handling dog treats (16%), such as pig ears, in the week before interview.\n\nDuring the investigation, health and regulatory officials from Kansas, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and FDA collected pig ears at retail locations where ill people reported buying the products or their suppliers and distributors. Testing identified many different strains of _Salmonella_. A search of the CDC PulseNet database found that people had been infected with some of these strains, including _S._ Infantis, _S._ London, and _S._ Newport. Some of these illnesses date back to 2015. These ill people were added to the outbreak investigation.\n\nAdditional _Salmonella_ strains were isolated from pig ears, and investigators are working to determine if any human illnesses are linked to those strains. Those strains include _S._ Panama, _S._ Brandenburg, _S._ Anatum, and _S._ Livingstone.\n\nSome of the tested pig ears were imported from Argentina, and Brazil. Some product labels indicated that the pig ears were irradiated; this process should kill _Salmonella_. _Salmonella_ identified in products labeled as irradiated indicate they may not have been irradiated or there was a another issue that led to _Salmonella_ contamination.\n\nOn [3 Jul 2019], Pet Supplies Plus recalled bulk pig ears stocked in open bins because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [26 Jul 2019], Lennox Intl Inc recalled pig ears because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [30 Jul 2019] Lennox Intl Inc expanded their recall. These recalls do not account for all of the illnesses in this outbreak.\n\nInformation collected to date about where ill people bought pig ears has not identified a single supplier, distributor, or common brand of pig ear treats. CDC and FDA recommend that people do not purchase or feed any pig ear pet treats to dogs because they could be contaminated with _Salmonella_ and could make people and dogs sick. CDC and FDA recommendations may change as more information becomes available.\n\nThis investigation is ongoing. CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A handful of the newly added cases seem to be from infections occurring between 2015-2017.\n\nAs a review, _Salmonella_ as a genus has 2 species, _enterica_ and _bongori_. _S. enterica_ is divided into 6 subspecies: _enterica_, _salamae_, _arizonae_, _diarizonae_, _houtenae_, and _indica_. _S. enterica_ subspecies _enterica_ (or subspecies I) strains are the ones usually isolated from humans or warm-blooded animals and represent a majority of the salmonellas that are clinically important.\n\nThe designation _Salmonella_ I 4,[5],12:i:- means:\n- the \"I\" reflects subspecies _enterica_;\n- the \"4, [5] 12\" are the O (or somatic) antigens associated with the organism. An O antigen underscored or placed in [ ] can refer to whether the antigen is related to phage conversion or not;\n- the nomenclature after the colon, in this case i:-, reflects the flagellar or H antigens.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nSalmonellosis - USA (03): live poultry, multiple serotypes, fatal 20190723.6581931\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA (02): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes 20190722.6581930\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA (02): Mexican papayas, alert 20190706.6554747\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA: pig ear dog treats 20190704.6551235\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA: Mexican papayas, alert 20190701.6545756\nSalmonellosis - USA (02): live poultry, multiple serotypes 20190615.6522442\nSalmonellosis, st Typhimurium - USA (03): pet hedgehog 20190602.6498690\nSalmonellosis, st Braenderup & Montevideo - USA: live poultry 20190518.6472999\nSalmonellosis, st Concord - USA: tahini, alert, recall request 20190517.6471874\nSalmonellosis, st Carrau - USA (02): precut melon, CDC 20190426.6442308\nSalmonellosis, st. "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Salmonellosis, st I 4,[5],12:i:- - USA (03): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6600332", "date": "2019-08-01 17:10:32", "main_text": "SALMONELLOSIS, SEROTYPE I 4,[5],12:I:- - USA (03): PIG EAR DOG TREATS, OTHER SEROTYPES\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jul 2019\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CDC, salmonella homepage, [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/pet-treats-07-19/index.html\n\n\nOutbreak of multidrug-resistant Salmonella infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of multidrug-resistant _Salmonella_ serotypes I 4,[5],12:i:-, Infantis, Newport, and London infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats. As of [31 Jul 2019], a total of 127 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Salmonella_ have been reported from 33 states.\n\nState / Ill People\n----------------------\nAlabama / 1\nArizona / 1\nCalifornia / 1\nColorado / 3\nConnecticut / 1\nFlorida / 3\nGeorgia / 2\nHawaii / 1\nIllinois / 7\nIndiana / 5\nIowa / 23\nKansas / 3\nKentucky / 6\nLouisiana / 1\nMaine / 1\nMassachusetts / 4\nMichigan / 12\nMinnesota / 1\nMissouri / 6\nNew Hampshire / 1\nNew Jersey / 2\nNew Mexico / 1\nNew York / 15\nNorth Carolina / 2\nNorth Dakota / 1\nOhio / 5\nOregon / 2\nPennsylvania / 6\nSouth Carolina / 2\nTexas / 2\nUtah / 1\nWashington / 1\nWisconsin / 4\n-------------\nTotal / 127\n\nIllnesses started on dates ranging from [16 Jun 2015] to [6 Jul 2019]. Ill people range in age from less than 1 year to 90 years, with a median age of 40 years. A total of 55 (45%) ill people are female. Of 88 ill people with information available, 26 (30%) have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nIllnesses might not yet be reported due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nPredicted antimicrobial resistance based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) was determined for 71 isolates from ill people. There was no antimicrobial resistance predicted for one isolate; the remaining 70 isolates had predicted resistance or decreased susceptibility to one or more of the following antibacterials: amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, cefoxitin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, kanamycin, nalidixic acid, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, and tetracycline. Testing of one clinical isolate using standard susceptibility testing methods by CDC's National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) provided comparable results (kanamycin was not tested by this method). If antimicrobials are needed, infections related to this outbreak may be difficult to treat with some commonly recommended medications, and may require a different choice.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and traceback evidence indicates that contact with pig ear dog treats is the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about animal and pet food contact in the week before they became ill. A total of 76 (89%) of 85 ill people reported contact with a dog before getting sick. Of 62 people with available information, 45 (73%) reported contact with pig ear dog treats or with dogs who were fed pig ear dog treats. Both of these proportions are significantly higher than the results from a survey of healthy people who reported contact with dogs (61%) or handling dog treats (16%), such as pig ears, in the week before interview.\n\nDuring the investigation, health and regulatory officials from Kansas, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and FDA collected pig ears at retail locations where ill people reported buying the products or their suppliers and distributors. Testing identified many different strains of _Salmonella_. A search of the CDC PulseNet database found that people had been infected with some of these strains, including _S._ Infantis, _S._ London, and _S._ Newport. Some of these illnesses date back to 2015. These ill people were added to the outbreak investigation.\n\nAdditional _Salmonella_ strains were isolated from pig ears, and investigators are working to determine if any human illnesses are linked to those strains. Those strains include _S._ Panama, _S._ Brandenburg, _S._ Anatum, and _S._ Livingstone.\n\nSome of the tested pig ears were imported from Argentina, and Brazil. Some product labels indicated that the pig ears were irradiated; this process should kill _Salmonella_. _Salmonella_ identified in products labeled as irradiated indicate they may not have been irradiated or there was a another issue that led to _Salmonella_ contamination.\n\nOn [3 Jul 2019], Pet Supplies Plus recalled bulk pig ears stocked in open bins because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [26 Jul 2019], Lennox Intl Inc recalled pig ears because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [30 Jul 2019] Lennox Intl Inc expanded their recall. These recalls do not account for all of the illnesses in this outbreak.\n\nInformation collected to date about where ill people bought pig ears has not identified a single supplier, distributor, or common brand of pig ear treats. CDC and FDA recommend that people do not purchase or feed any pig ear pet treats to dogs because they could be contaminated with _Salmonella_ and could make people and dogs sick. CDC and FDA recommendations may change as more information becomes available.\n\nThis investigation is ongoing. CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A handful of the newly added cases seem to be from infections occurring between 2015-2017.\n\nAs a review, _Salmonella_ as a genus has 2 species, _enterica_ and _bongori_. _S. enterica_ is divided into 6 subspecies: _enterica_, _salamae_, _arizonae_, _diarizonae_, _houtenae_, and _indica_. _S. enterica_ subspecies _enterica_ (or subspecies I) strains are the ones usually isolated from humans or warm-blooded animals and represent a majority of the salmonellas that are clinically important.\n\nThe designation _Salmonella_ I 4,[5],12:i:- means:\n- the \"I\" reflects subspecies _enterica_;\n- the \"4, [5] 12\" are the O (or somatic) antigens associated with the organism. An O antigen underscored or placed in [ ] can refer to whether the antigen is related to phage conversion or not;\n- the nomenclature after the colon, in this case i:-, reflects the flagellar or H antigens.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nSalmonellosis - USA (03): live poultry, multiple serotypes, fatal 20190723.6581931\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA (02): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes 20190722.6581930\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA (02): Mexican papayas, alert 20190706.6554747\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA: pig ear dog treats 20190704.6551235\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA: Mexican papayas, alert 20190701.6545756\nSalmonellosis - USA (02): live poultry, multiple serotypes 20190615.6522442\nSalmonellosis, st Typhimurium - USA (03): pet hedgehog 20190602.6498690\nSalmonellosis, st Braenderup & Montevideo - USA: live poultry 20190518.6472999\nSalmonellosis, st Concord - USA: tahini, alert, recall request 20190517.6471874\nSalmonellosis, st Carrau - USA (02): precut melon, CDC 20190426.6442308\nSalmonellosis, st. Newport - USA: frozen raw tuna, alert, recall 20190416.6425979\nSalmonellosis, st. Carrau - USA: precut melon, CDC 20190415.6423047\nSalmonellosis, st. "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (ML)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6593137", "date": "2019-08-01 17:10:32", "main_text": "SALMONELLOSIS, SEROTYPE I 4,[5],12:I:- - USA (03): PIG EAR DOG TREATS, OTHER SEROTYPES\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jul 2019\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CDC, salmonella homepage, [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/pet-treats-07-19/index.html\n\n\nOutbreak of multidrug-resistant Salmonella infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of multidrug-resistant _Salmonella_ serotypes I 4,[5],12:i:-, Infantis, Newport, and London infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats. As of [31 Jul 2019], a total of 127 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Salmonella_ have been reported from 33 states.\n\nState / Ill People\n----------------------\nAlabama / 1\nArizona / 1\nCalifornia / 1\nColorado / 3\nConnecticut / 1\nFlorida / 3\nGeorgia / 2\nHawaii / 1\nIllinois / 7\nIndiana / 5\nIowa / 23\nKansas / 3\nKentucky / 6\nLouisiana / 1\nMaine / 1\nMassachusetts / 4\nMichigan / 12\nMinnesota / 1\nMissouri / 6\nNew Hampshire / 1\nNew Jersey / 2\nNew Mexico / 1\nNew York / 15\nNorth Carolina / 2\nNorth Dakota / 1\nOhio / 5\nOregon / 2\nPennsylvania / 6\nSouth Carolina / 2\nTexas / 2\nUtah / 1\nWashington / 1\nWisconsin / 4\n-------------\nTotal / 127\n\nIllnesses started on dates ranging from [16 Jun 2015] to [6 Jul 2019]. Ill people range in age from less than 1 year to 90 years, with a median age of 40 years. A total of 55 (45%) ill people are female. Of 88 ill people with information available, 26 (30%) have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nIllnesses might not yet be reported due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nPredicted antimicrobial resistance based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) was determined for 71 isolates from ill people. There was no antimicrobial resistance predicted for one isolate; the remaining 70 isolates had predicted resistance or decreased susceptibility to one or more of the following antibacterials: amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, cefoxitin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, kanamycin, nalidixic acid, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, and tetracycline. Testing of one clinical isolate using standard susceptibility testing methods by CDC's National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) provided comparable results (kanamycin was not tested by this method). If antimicrobials are needed, infections related to this outbreak may be difficult to treat with some commonly recommended medications, and may require a different choice.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and traceback evidence indicates that contact with pig ear dog treats is the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about animal and pet food contact in the week before they became ill. A total of 76 (89%) of 85 ill people reported contact with a dog before getting sick. Of 62 people with available information, 45 (73%) reported contact with pig ear dog treats or with dogs who were fed pig ear dog treats. Both of these proportions are significantly higher than the results from a survey of healthy people who reported contact with dogs (61%) or handling dog treats (16%), such as pig ears, in the week before interview.\n\nDuring the investigation, health and regulatory officials from Kansas, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and FDA collected pig ears at retail locations where ill people reported buying the products or their suppliers and distributors. Testing identified many different strains of _Salmonella_. A search of the CDC PulseNet database found that people had been infected with some of these strains, including _S._ Infantis, _S._ London, and _S._ Newport. Some of these illnesses date back to 2015. These ill people were added to the outbreak investigation.\n\nAdditional _Salmonella_ strains were isolated from pig ears, and investigators are working to determine if any human illnesses are linked to those strains. Those strains include _S._ Panama, _S._ Brandenburg, _S._ Anatum, and _S._ Livingstone.\n\nSome of the tested pig ears were imported from Argentina, and Brazil. Some product labels indicated that the pig ears were irradiated; this process should kill _Salmonella_. _Salmonella_ identified in products labeled as irradiated indicate they may not have been irradiated or there was a another issue that led to _Salmonella_ contamination.\n\nOn [3 Jul 2019], Pet Supplies Plus recalled bulk pig ears stocked in open bins because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [26 Jul 2019], Lennox Intl Inc recalled pig ears because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [30 Jul 2019] Lennox Intl Inc expanded their recall. These recalls do not account for all of the illnesses in this outbreak.\n\nInformation collected to date about where ill people bought pig ears has not identified a single supplier, distributor, or common brand of pig ear treats. CDC and FDA recommend that people do not purchase or feed any pig ear pet treats to dogs because they could be contaminated with _Salmonella_ and could make people and dogs sick. CDC and FDA recommendations may change as more information becomes available.\n\nThis investigation is ongoing. CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A handful of the newly added cases seem to be from infections occurring between 2015-2017.\n\nAs a review, _Salmonella_ as a genus has 2 species, _enterica_ and _bongori_. _S. enterica_ is divided into 6 subspecies: _enterica_, _salamae_, _arizonae_, _diarizonae_, _houtenae_, and _indica_. _S. enterica_ subspecies _enterica_ (or subspecies I) strains are the ones usually isolated from humans or warm-blooded animals and represent a majority of the salmonellas that are clinically important.\n\nThe designation _Salmonella_ I 4,[5],12:i:- means:\n- the \"I\" reflects subspecies _enterica_;\n- the \"4, [5] 12\" are the O (or somatic) antigens associated with the organism. An O antigen underscored or placed in [ ] can refer to whether the antigen is related to phage conversion or not;\n- the nomenclature after the colon, in this case i:-, reflects the flagellar or H antigens.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nSalmonellosis - USA (03): live poultry, multiple serotypes, fatal 20190723.6581931\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA (02): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes 20190722.6581930\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA (02): Mexican papayas, alert 20190706.6554747\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA: pig ear dog treats 20190704.6551235\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA: Mexican papayas, alert 20190701.6545756\nSalmonellosis - USA (02): live poultry, multiple serotypes 20190615.6522442\nSalmonellosis, st Typhimurium - USA (03): pet hedgehog 20190602.6498690\nSalmonellosis, st Braenderup & Montevideo - USA: live poultry 20190518.6472999\nSalmonellosis, st Concord - USA: tahini, alert, recall request 20190517.6471874\nSalmonellosis, st Carrau - USA (02): precut melon, CDC 20190426.6442308\nSalmonellosis, st. "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6591689", "date": "2019-08-01 17:10:32", "main_text": "SALMONELLOSIS, SEROTYPE I 4,[5],12:I:- - USA (03): PIG EAR DOG TREATS, OTHER SEROTYPES\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jul 2019\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CDC, salmonella homepage, [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/pet-treats-07-19/index.html\n\n\nOutbreak of multidrug-resistant Salmonella infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of multidrug-resistant _Salmonella_ serotypes I 4,[5],12:i:-, Infantis, Newport, and London infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats. As of [31 Jul 2019], a total of 127 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Salmonella_ have been reported from 33 states.\n\nState / Ill People\n----------------------\nAlabama / 1\nArizona / 1\nCalifornia / 1\nColorado / 3\nConnecticut / 1\nFlorida / 3\nGeorgia / 2\nHawaii / 1\nIllinois / 7\nIndiana / 5\nIowa / 23\nKansas / 3\nKentucky / 6\nLouisiana / 1\nMaine / 1\nMassachusetts / 4\nMichigan / 12\nMinnesota / 1\nMissouri / 6\nNew Hampshire / 1\nNew Jersey / 2\nNew Mexico / 1\nNew York / 15\nNorth Carolina / 2\nNorth Dakota / 1\nOhio / 5\nOregon / 2\nPennsylvania / 6\nSouth Carolina / 2\nTexas / 2\nUtah / 1\nWashington / 1\nWisconsin / 4\n-------------\nTotal / 127\n\nIllnesses started on dates ranging from [16 Jun 2015] to [6 Jul 2019]. Ill people range in age from less than 1 year to 90 years, with a median age of 40 years. A total of 55 (45%) ill people are female. Of 88 ill people with information available, 26 (30%) have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nIllnesses might not yet be reported due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nPredicted antimicrobial resistance based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) was determined for 71 isolates from ill people. There was no antimicrobial resistance predicted for one isolate; the remaining 70 isolates had predicted resistance or decreased susceptibility to one or more of the following antibacterials: amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, cefoxitin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, kanamycin, nalidixic acid, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, and tetracycline. Testing of one clinical isolate using standard susceptibility testing methods by CDC's National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) provided comparable results (kanamycin was not tested by this method). If antimicrobials are needed, infections related to this outbreak may be difficult to treat with some commonly recommended medications, and may require a different choice.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and traceback evidence indicates that contact with pig ear dog treats is the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about animal and pet food contact in the week before they became ill. A total of 76 (89%) of 85 ill people reported contact with a dog before getting sick. Of 62 people with available information, 45 (73%) reported contact with pig ear dog treats or with dogs who were fed pig ear dog treats. Both of these proportions are significantly higher than the results from a survey of healthy people who reported contact with dogs (61%) or handling dog treats (16%), such as pig ears, in the week before interview.\n\nDuring the investigation, health and regulatory officials from Kansas, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and FDA collected pig ears at retail locations where ill people reported buying the products or their suppliers and distributors. Testing identified many different strains of _Salmonella_. A search of the CDC PulseNet database found that people had been infected with some of these strains, including _S._ Infantis, _S._ London, and _S._ Newport. Some of these illnesses date back to 2015. These ill people were added to the outbreak investigation.\n\nAdditional _Salmonella_ strains were isolated from pig ears, and investigators are working to determine if any human illnesses are linked to those strains. Those strains include _S._ Panama, _S._ Brandenburg, _S._ Anatum, and _S._ Livingstone.\n\nSome of the tested pig ears were imported from Argentina, and Brazil. Some product labels indicated that the pig ears were irradiated; this process should kill _Salmonella_. _Salmonella_ identified in products labeled as irradiated indicate they may not have been irradiated or there was a another issue that led to _Salmonella_ contamination.\n\nOn [3 Jul 2019], Pet Supplies Plus recalled bulk pig ears stocked in open bins because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [26 Jul 2019], Lennox Intl Inc recalled pig ears because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [30 Jul 2019] Lennox Intl Inc expanded their recall. These recalls do not account for all of the illnesses in this outbreak.\n\nInformation collected to date about where ill people bought pig ears has not identified a single supplier, distributor, or common brand of pig ear treats. CDC and FDA recommend that people do not purchase or feed any pig ear pet treats to dogs because they could be contaminated with _Salmonella_ and could make people and dogs sick. CDC and FDA recommendations may change as more information becomes available.\n\nThis investigation is ongoing. CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A handful of the newly added cases seem to be from infections occurring between 2015-2017.\n\nAs a review, _Salmonella_ as a genus has 2 species, _enterica_ and _bongori_. _S. enterica_ is divided into 6 subspecies: _enterica_, _salamae_, _arizonae_, _diarizonae_, _houtenae_, and _indica_. _S. enterica_ subspecies _enterica_ (or subspecies I) strains are the ones usually isolated from humans or warm-blooded animals and represent a majority of the salmonellas that are clinically important.\n\nThe designation _Salmonella_ I 4,[5],12:i:- means:\n- the \"I\" reflects subspecies _enterica_;\n- the \"4, [5] 12\" are the O (or somatic) antigens associated with the organism. An O antigen underscored or placed in [ ] can refer to whether the antigen is related to phage conversion or not;\n- the nomenclature after the colon, in this case i:-, reflects the flagellar or H antigens.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nSalmonellosis - USA (03): live poultry, multiple serotypes, fatal 20190723.6581931\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA (02): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes 20190722.6581930\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA (02): Mexican papayas, alert 20190706.6554747\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA: pig ear dog treats 20190704.6551235\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA: Mexican papayas, alert 20190701.6545756\nSalmonellosis - USA (02): live poultry, multiple serotypes 20190615.6522442\nSalmonellosis, st Typhimurium - USA (03): pet hedgehog 20190602.6498690\nSalmonellosis, st Braenderup & Montevideo - USA: live poultry 20190518.6472999\nSalmonellosis, st Concord - USA: tahini, alert, recall request 20190517.6471874\nSalmonellosis, st Carrau - USA (02): precut melon, CDC 20190426.6442308\nSalmonellosis, st. "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (MH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6586440", "date": "2019-08-01 17:10:32", "main_text": "SALMONELLOSIS, SEROTYPE I 4,[5],12:I:- - USA (03): PIG EAR DOG TREATS, OTHER SEROTYPES\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jul 2019\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CDC, salmonella homepage, [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/pet-treats-07-19/index.html\n\n\nOutbreak of multidrug-resistant Salmonella infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of multidrug-resistant _Salmonella_ serotypes I 4,[5],12:i:-, Infantis, Newport, and London infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats. As of [31 Jul 2019], a total of 127 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Salmonella_ have been reported from 33 states.\n\nState / Ill People\n----------------------\nAlabama / 1\nArizona / 1\nCalifornia / 1\nColorado / 3\nConnecticut / 1\nFlorida / 3\nGeorgia / 2\nHawaii / 1\nIllinois / 7\nIndiana / 5\nIowa / 23\nKansas / 3\nKentucky / 6\nLouisiana / 1\nMaine / 1\nMassachusetts / 4\nMichigan / 12\nMinnesota / 1\nMissouri / 6\nNew Hampshire / 1\nNew Jersey / 2\nNew Mexico / 1\nNew York / 15\nNorth Carolina / 2\nNorth Dakota / 1\nOhio / 5\nOregon / 2\nPennsylvania / 6\nSouth Carolina / 2\nTexas / 2\nUtah / 1\nWashington / 1\nWisconsin / 4\n-------------\nTotal / 127\n\nIllnesses started on dates ranging from [16 Jun 2015] to [6 Jul 2019]. Ill people range in age from less than 1 year to 90 years, with a median age of 40 years. A total of 55 (45%) ill people are female. Of 88 ill people with information available, 26 (30%) have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nIllnesses might not yet be reported due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nPredicted antimicrobial resistance based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) was determined for 71 isolates from ill people. There was no antimicrobial resistance predicted for one isolate; the remaining 70 isolates had predicted resistance or decreased susceptibility to one or more of the following antibacterials: amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, cefoxitin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, kanamycin, nalidixic acid, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, and tetracycline. Testing of one clinical isolate using standard susceptibility testing methods by CDC's National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) provided comparable results (kanamycin was not tested by this method). If antimicrobials are needed, infections related to this outbreak may be difficult to treat with some commonly recommended medications, and may require a different choice.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and traceback evidence indicates that contact with pig ear dog treats is the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about animal and pet food contact in the week before they became ill. A total of 76 (89%) of 85 ill people reported contact with a dog before getting sick. Of 62 people with available information, 45 (73%) reported contact with pig ear dog treats or with dogs who were fed pig ear dog treats. Both of these proportions are significantly higher than the results from a survey of healthy people who reported contact with dogs (61%) or handling dog treats (16%), such as pig ears, in the week before interview.\n\nDuring the investigation, health and regulatory officials from Kansas, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and FDA collected pig ears at retail locations where ill people reported buying the products or their suppliers and distributors. Testing identified many different strains of _Salmonella_. A search of the CDC PulseNet database found that people had been infected with some of these strains, including _S._ Infantis, _S._ London, and _S._ Newport. Some of these illnesses date back to 2015. These ill people were added to the outbreak investigation.\n\nAdditional _Salmonella_ strains were isolated from pig ears, and investigators are working to determine if any human illnesses are linked to those strains. Those strains include _S._ Panama, _S._ Brandenburg, _S._ Anatum, and _S._ Livingstone.\n\nSome of the tested pig ears were imported from Argentina, and Brazil. Some product labels indicated that the pig ears were irradiated; this process should kill _Salmonella_. _Salmonella_ identified in products labeled as irradiated indicate they may not have been irradiated or there was a another issue that led to _Salmonella_ contamination.\n\nOn [3 Jul 2019], Pet Supplies Plus recalled bulk pig ears stocked in open bins because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [26 Jul 2019], Lennox Intl Inc recalled pig ears because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [30 Jul 2019] Lennox Intl Inc expanded their recall. These recalls do not account for all of the illnesses in this outbreak.\n\nInformation collected to date about where ill people bought pig ears has not identified a single supplier, distributor, or common brand of pig ear treats. CDC and FDA recommend that people do not purchase or feed any pig ear pet treats to dogs because they could be contaminated with _Salmonella_ and could make people and dogs sick. CDC and FDA recommendations may change as more information becomes available.\n\nThis investigation is ongoing. CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A handful of the newly added cases seem to be from infections occurring between 2015-2017.\n\nAs a review, _Salmonella_ as a genus has 2 species, _enterica_ and _bongori_. _S. enterica_ is divided into 6 subspecies: _enterica_, _salamae_, _arizonae_, _diarizonae_, _houtenae_, and _indica_. _S. enterica_ subspecies _enterica_ (or subspecies I) strains are the ones usually isolated from humans or warm-blooded animals and represent a majority of the salmonellas that are clinically important.\n\nThe designation _Salmonella_ I 4,[5],12:i:- means:\n- the \"I\" reflects subspecies _enterica_;\n- the \"4, [5] 12\" are the O (or somatic) antigens associated with the organism. An O antigen underscored or placed in [ ] can refer to whether the antigen is related to phage conversion or not;\n- the nomenclature after the colon, in this case i:-, reflects the flagellar or H antigens.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nSalmonellosis - USA (03): live poultry, multiple serotypes, fatal 20190723.6581931\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA (02): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes 20190722.6581930\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA (02): Mexican papayas, alert 20190706.6554747\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA: pig ear dog treats 20190704.6551235\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA: Mexican papayas, alert 20190701.6545756\nSalmonellosis - USA (02): live poultry, multiple serotypes 20190615.6522442\nSalmonellosis, st Typhimurium - USA (03): pet hedgehog 20190602.6498690\nSalmonellosis, st Braenderup & Montevideo - USA: live poultry 20190518.6472999\nSalmonellosis, st Concord - USA: tahini, alert, recall request 20190517.6471874\nSalmonellosis, st Carrau - USA (02): precut melon, CDC 20190426.6442308\nSalmonellosis, st. "headline": "PRO/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (MN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6582013", "date": "2019-08-01 17:10:32", "main_text": "SALMONELLOSIS, SEROTYPE I 4,[5],12:I:- - USA (03): PIG EAR DOG TREATS, OTHER SEROTYPES\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Jul 2019\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CDC, salmonella homepage, [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/pet-treats-07-19/index.html\n\n\nOutbreak of multidrug-resistant Salmonella infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nCDC, public health and regulatory officials in several states, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are investigating a multistate outbreak of multidrug-resistant _Salmonella_ serotypes I 4,[5],12:i:-, Infantis, Newport, and London infections linked to contact with pig ear dog treats. As of [31 Jul 2019], a total of 127 people infected with the outbreak strains of _Salmonella_ have been reported from 33 states.\n\nState / Ill People\n----------------------\nAlabama / 1\nArizona / 1\nCalifornia / 1\nColorado / 3\nConnecticut / 1\nFlorida / 3\nGeorgia / 2\nHawaii / 1\nIllinois / 7\nIndiana / 5\nIowa / 23\nKansas / 3\nKentucky / 6\nLouisiana / 1\nMaine / 1\nMassachusetts / 4\nMichigan / 12\nMinnesota / 1\nMissouri / 6\nNew Hampshire / 1\nNew Jersey / 2\nNew Mexico / 1\nNew York / 15\nNorth Carolina / 2\nNorth Dakota / 1\nOhio / 5\nOregon / 2\nPennsylvania / 6\nSouth Carolina / 2\nTexas / 2\nUtah / 1\nWashington / 1\nWisconsin / 4\n-------------\nTotal / 127\n\nIllnesses started on dates ranging from [16 Jun 2015] to [6 Jul 2019]. Ill people range in age from less than 1 year to 90 years, with a median age of 40 years. A total of 55 (45%) ill people are female. Of 88 ill people with information available, 26 (30%) have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported.\n\nIllnesses might not yet be reported due to the time it takes between when a person becomes ill and when the illness is reported. This takes an average of 2 to 4 weeks.\n\nPredicted antimicrobial resistance based on whole genome sequencing (WGS) was determined for 71 isolates from ill people. There was no antimicrobial resistance predicted for one isolate; the remaining 70 isolates had predicted resistance or decreased susceptibility to one or more of the following antibacterials: amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, ampicillin, cefoxitin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, kanamycin, nalidixic acid, streptomycin, sulfisoxazole, and tetracycline. Testing of one clinical isolate using standard susceptibility testing methods by CDC's National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) provided comparable results (kanamycin was not tested by this method). If antimicrobials are needed, infections related to this outbreak may be difficult to treat with some commonly recommended medications, and may require a different choice.\n\nInvestigation of the Outbreak\n-----------------------------\nEpidemiologic, laboratory, and traceback evidence indicates that contact with pig ear dog treats is the likely source of this outbreak.\n\nIn interviews, ill people answered questions about animal and pet food contact in the week before they became ill. A total of 76 (89%) of 85 ill people reported contact with a dog before getting sick. Of 62 people with available information, 45 (73%) reported contact with pig ear dog treats or with dogs who were fed pig ear dog treats. Both of these proportions are significantly higher than the results from a survey of healthy people who reported contact with dogs (61%) or handling dog treats (16%), such as pig ears, in the week before interview.\n\nDuring the investigation, health and regulatory officials from Kansas, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and FDA collected pig ears at retail locations where ill people reported buying the products or their suppliers and distributors. Testing identified many different strains of _Salmonella_. A search of the CDC PulseNet database found that people had been infected with some of these strains, including _S._ Infantis, _S._ London, and _S._ Newport. Some of these illnesses date back to 2015. These ill people were added to the outbreak investigation.\n\nAdditional _Salmonella_ strains were isolated from pig ears, and investigators are working to determine if any human illnesses are linked to those strains. Those strains include _S._ Panama, _S._ Brandenburg, _S._ Anatum, and _S._ Livingstone.\n\nSome of the tested pig ears were imported from Argentina, and Brazil. Some product labels indicated that the pig ears were irradiated; this process should kill _Salmonella_. _Salmonella_ identified in products labeled as irradiated indicate they may not have been irradiated or there was a another issue that led to _Salmonella_ contamination.\n\nOn [3 Jul 2019], Pet Supplies Plus recalled bulk pig ears stocked in open bins because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [26 Jul 2019], Lennox Intl Inc recalled pig ears because they might be contaminated with _Salmonella_. On [30 Jul 2019] Lennox Intl Inc expanded their recall. These recalls do not account for all of the illnesses in this outbreak.\n\nInformation collected to date about where ill people bought pig ears has not identified a single supplier, distributor, or common brand of pig ear treats. CDC and FDA recommend that people do not purchase or feed any pig ear pet treats to dogs because they could be contaminated with _Salmonella_ and could make people and dogs sick. CDC and FDA recommendations may change as more information becomes available.\n\nThis investigation is ongoing. CDC will provide updates when more information is available.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A handful of the newly added cases seem to be from infections occurring between 2015-2017.\n\nAs a review, _Salmonella_ as a genus has 2 species, _enterica_ and _bongori_. _S. enterica_ is divided into 6 subspecies: _enterica_, _salamae_, _arizonae_, _diarizonae_, _houtenae_, and _indica_. _S. enterica_ subspecies _enterica_ (or subspecies I) strains are the ones usually isolated from humans or warm-blooded animals and represent a majority of the salmonellas that are clinically important.\n\nThe designation _Salmonella_ I 4,[5],12:i:- means:\n- the \"I\" reflects subspecies _enterica_;\n- the \"4, [5] 12\" are the O (or somatic) antigens associated with the organism. An O antigen underscored or placed in [ ] can refer to whether the antigen is related to phage conversion or not;\n- the nomenclature after the colon, in this case i:-, reflects the flagellar or H antigens.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUnited States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nSalmonellosis - USA (03): live poultry, multiple serotypes, fatal 20190723.6581931\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA (02): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes 20190722.6581930\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA (02): Mexican papayas, alert 20190706.6554747\nSalmonellosis, st I 4,[5,12:i:- - USA: pig ear dog treats 20190704.6551235\nSalmonellosis, st Uganda - USA: Mexican papayas, alert 20190701.6545756\nSalmonellosis - USA (02): live poultry, multiple serotypes 20190615.6522442\nSalmonellosis, st Typhimurium - USA (03): pet hedgehog 20190602.6498690\nSalmonellosis, st Braenderup & Montevideo - USA: live poultry 20190518.6472999\nSalmonellosis, st Concord - USA: tahini, alert, recall request 20190517.6471874\nSalmonellosis, st Carrau - USA (02): precut melon, CDC 20190426.6442308\nSalmonellosis, st.
