"headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Salmonellosis, st I 4,[5],12:i:- - USA (02): pig ear dog treats, other serotypes", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6581930", "date": "2019-07-08 19:29:34", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (14): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Jul 2019\nSource: Business Standard [edited]\nhttps://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/assam-encephalitis-leaves-of-doctors-cancelled-119070800005_1.html\n\n\nThe Assam government has cancelled all leaves of doctors, para-medical staff, and surveillance workers in order to deal with an outbreak of encephalitis that has claimed 49 lives across the state since January [2019].\n\nIn an order issued by the Health and Family Welfare Department on Saturday [6 Jul 2019], all leaves of the government medical staff in the state were cancelled \"in order to effectively deal with the present situation of rising AES/JE cases.\"\n\nTo deal with the rising number of cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE), the government has decided to involve the private hospitals.\n\n\"Critical AES/JE patients, who are admitted in the ICUs of private hospitals/nursing homes ... will be extended a monetary support of up to Rs 1 lakh [USD 146],\" the order stated.\n\nAt least 49 deaths and 190 positive cases were reported due to Japanese encephalitis till 5 Jul [2019] from January this year [2019].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A 7 Jul 2019 report indicates that the death toll has just risen to 50 (https://nenow.in/health/assam-japanese-encephalitis-death-toll-rises-to-50.html).\n\nThe numbers of reported JE cases in Assam state continue to increase from 45 deaths to 49 and 190 cases positive for JE. This is the active JE virus transmission season there, so health officials are prudent to evaluate the situation and take measures to reduce incidence of the disease, because more cases can be expected. Interestingly, although AES is mentioned, all of the 190 positive cases are attributed to JE, and the number of AES cases, if any, is not mentioned, although the above report does indicate that the number of AES cases is rising.\n\nImmunization is the effective measure needed to avoid JE infections. Mosquito vector control is difficult. The previous report indicated that health officials had reviewed the immunization status but not stated of whom or what the findings were. It seems curious that no mention is made above of renewing vaccinations in the affected areas. Vaccination for JE was carried out in the affected areas last year (2018). It is not mentioned whether vaccination was carried out again this year (2019). The type of JE vaccine used previously is also not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine, the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20190705.6552949\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS) 20190630.6544796\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20180818.5974190\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.58623\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.5812921\n.................................................ty/msp/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6579447", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (NL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6579447", "date": "2019-07-08 19:29:34", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (14): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Jul 2019\nSource: Business Standard [edited]\nhttps://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/assam-encephalitis-leaves-of-doctors-cancelled-119070800005_1.html\n\n\nThe Assam government has cancelled all leaves of doctors, para-medical staff, and surveillance workers in order to deal with an outbreak of encephalitis that has claimed 49 lives across the state since January [2019].\n\nIn an order issued by the Health and Family Welfare Department on Saturday [6 Jul 2019], all leaves of the government medical staff in the state were cancelled \"in order to effectively deal with the present situation of rising AES/JE cases.\"\n\nTo deal with the rising number of cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE), the government has decided to involve the private hospitals.\n\n\"Critical AES/JE patients, who are admitted in the ICUs of private hospitals/nursing homes ... will be extended a monetary support of up to Rs 1 lakh [USD 146],\" the order stated.\n\nAt least 49 deaths and 190 positive cases were reported due to Japanese encephalitis till 5 Jul [2019] from January this year [2019].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A 7 Jul 2019 report indicates that the death toll has just risen to 50 (https://nenow.in/health/assam-japanese-encephalitis-death-toll-rises-to-50.html).\n\nThe numbers of reported JE cases in Assam state continue to increase from 45 deaths to 49 and 190 cases positive for JE. This is the active JE virus transmission season there, so health officials are prudent to evaluate the situation and take measures to reduce incidence of the disease, because more cases can be expected. Interestingly, although AES is mentioned, all of the 190 positive cases are attributed to JE, and the number of AES cases, if any, is not mentioned, although the above report does indicate that the number of AES cases is rising.\n\nImmunization is the effective measure needed to avoid JE infections. Mosquito vector control is difficult. The previous report indicated that health officials had reviewed the immunization status but not stated of whom or what the findings were. It seems curious that no mention is made above of renewing vaccinations in the affected areas. Vaccination for JE was carried out in the affected areas last year (2018). It is not mentioned whether vaccination was carried out again this year (2019). The type of JE vaccine used previously is also not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine, the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20190705.6552949\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS) 20190630.6544796\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20180818.5974190\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.58623\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.5812921\n.................................................ty/msp/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6578446", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6578446", "date": "2019-07-08 19:29:34", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (14): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Jul 2019\nSource: Business Standard [edited]\nhttps://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/assam-encephalitis-leaves-of-doctors-cancelled-119070800005_1.html\n\n\nThe Assam government has cancelled all leaves of doctors, para-medical staff, and surveillance workers in order to deal with an outbreak of encephalitis that has claimed 49 lives across the state since January [2019].\n\nIn an order issued by the Health and Family Welfare Department on Saturday [6 Jul 2019], all leaves of the government medical staff in the state were cancelled \"in order to effectively deal with the present situation of rising AES/JE cases.\"\n\nTo deal with the rising number of cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE), the government has decided to involve the private hospitals.\n\n\"Critical AES/JE patients, who are admitted in the ICUs of private hospitals/nursing homes ... will be extended a monetary support of up to Rs 1 lakh [USD 146],\" the order stated.\n\nAt least 49 deaths and 190 positive cases were reported due to Japanese encephalitis till 5 Jul [2019] from January this year [2019].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A 7 Jul 2019 report indicates that the death toll has just risen to 50 (https://nenow.in/health/assam-japanese-encephalitis-death-toll-rises-to-50.html).\n\nThe numbers of reported JE cases in Assam state continue to increase from 45 deaths to 49 and 190 cases positive for JE. This is the active JE virus transmission season there, so health officials are prudent to evaluate the situation and take measures to reduce incidence of the disease, because more cases can be expected. Interestingly, although AES is mentioned, all of the 190 positive cases are attributed to JE, and the number of AES cases, if any, is not mentioned, although the above report does indicate that the number of AES cases is rising.\n\nImmunization is the effective measure needed to avoid JE infections. Mosquito vector control is difficult. The previous report indicated that health officials had reviewed the immunization status but not stated of whom or what the findings were. It seems curious that no mention is made above of renewing vaccinations in the affected areas. Vaccination for JE was carried out in the affected areas last year (2018). It is not mentioned whether vaccination was carried out again this year (2019). The type of JE vaccine used previously is also not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine, the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA (14): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Jul 2019\nSource: Business Standard [edited]\nhttps://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/assam-encephalitis-leaves-of-doctors-cancelled-119070800005_1.html\n\n\nThe Assam government has cancelled all leaves of doctors, para-medical staff, and surveillance workers in order to deal with an outbreak of encephalitis that has claimed 49 lives across the state since January [2019].\n\nIn an order issued by the Health and Family Welfare Department on Saturday [6 Jul 2019], all leaves of the government medical staff in the state were cancelled \"in order to effectively deal with the present situation of rising AES/JE cases.\"\n\nTo deal with the rising number of cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE), the government has decided to involve the private hospitals.\n\n\"Critical AES/JE patients, who are admitted in the ICUs of private hospitals/nursing homes ... will be extended a monetary support of up to Rs 1 lakh [USD 146],\" the order stated.\n\nAt least 49 deaths and 190 positive cases were reported due to Japanese encephalitis till 5 Jul [2019] from January this year [2019].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A 7 Jul 2019 report indicates that the death toll has just risen to 50 (https://nenow.in/health/assam-japanese-encephalitis-death-toll-rises-to-50.html).\n\nThe numbers of reported JE cases in Assam state continue to increase from 45 deaths to 49 and 190 cases positive for JE. This is the active JE virus transmission season there, so health officials are prudent to evaluate the situation and take measures to reduce incidence of the disease, because more cases can be expected. Interestingly, although AES is mentioned, all of the 190 positive cases are attributed to JE, and the number of AES cases, if any, is not mentioned, although the above report does indicate that the number of AES cases is rising.\n\nImmunization is the effective measure needed to avoid JE infections. Mosquito vector control is difficult. The previous report indicated that health officials had reviewed the immunization status but not stated of whom or what the findings were. It seems curious that no mention is made above of renewing vaccinations in the affected areas. Vaccination for JE was carried out in the affected areas last year (2018). It is not mentioned whether vaccination was carried out again this year (2019). The type of JE vaccine used previously is also not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine, the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA (14): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Jul 2019\nSource: Business Standard [edited]\nhttps://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/assam-encephalitis-leaves-of-doctors-cancelled-119070800005_1.html\n\n\nThe Assam government has cancelled all leaves of doctors, para-medical staff, and surveillance workers in order to deal with an outbreak of encephalitis that has claimed 49 lives across the state since January [2019].\n\nIn an order issued by the Health and Family Welfare Department on Saturday [6 Jul 2019], all leaves of the government medical staff in the state were cancelled \"in order to effectively deal with the present situation of rising AES/JE cases.\"\n\nTo deal with the rising number of cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE), the government has decided to involve the private hospitals.\n\n\"Critical AES/JE patients, who are admitted in the ICUs of private hospitals/nursing homes ... will be extended a monetary support of up to Rs 1 lakh [USD 146],\" the order stated.\n\nAt least 49 deaths and 190 positive cases were reported due to Japanese encephalitis till 5 Jul [2019] from January this year [2019].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A 7 Jul 2019 report indicates that the death toll has just risen to 50 (https://nenow.in/health/assam-japanese-encephalitis-death-toll-rises-to-50.html).\n\nThe numbers of reported JE cases in Assam state continue to increase from 45 deaths to 49 and 190 cases positive for JE. This is the active JE virus transmission season there, so health officials are prudent to evaluate the situation and take measures to reduce incidence of the disease, because more cases can be expected. Interestingly, although AES is mentioned, all of the 190 positive cases are attributed to JE, and the number of AES cases, if any, is not mentioned, although the above report does indicate that the number of AES cases is rising.\n\nImmunization is the effective measure needed to avoid JE infections. Mosquito vector control is difficult. The previous report indicated that health officials had reviewed the immunization status but not stated of whom or what the findings were. It seems curious that no mention is made above of renewing vaccinations in the affected areas. Vaccination for JE was carried out in the affected areas last year (2018). It is not mentioned whether vaccination was carried out again this year (2019). The type of JE vaccine used previously is also not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine, the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20190705.6552949\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS) 20190630.6544796\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20180818.5974190\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.58623\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.5812921\n.................................................ty/msp/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6557798", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6557798", "date": "2019-07-08 19:29:34", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (14): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Jul 2019\nSource: Business Standard [edited]\nhttps://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/assam-encephalitis-leaves-of-doctors-cancelled-119070800005_1.html\n\n\nThe Assam government has cancelled all leaves of doctors, para-medical staff, and surveillance workers in order to deal with an outbreak of encephalitis that has claimed 49 lives across the state since January [2019].\n\nIn an order issued by the Health and Family Welfare Department on Saturday [6 Jul 2019], all leaves of the government medical staff in the state were cancelled \"in order to effectively deal with the present situation of rising AES/JE cases.\"\n\nTo deal with the rising number of cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE), the government has decided to involve the private hospitals.\n\n\"Critical AES/JE patients, who are admitted in the ICUs of private hospitals/nursing homes ... will be extended a monetary support of up to Rs 1 lakh [USD 146],\" the order stated.\n\nAt least 49 deaths and 190 positive cases were reported due to Japanese encephalitis till 5 Jul [2019] from January this year [2019].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A 7 Jul 2019 report indicates that the death toll has just risen to 50 (https://nenow.in/health/assam-japanese-encephalitis-death-toll-rises-to-50.html).\n\nThe numbers of reported JE cases in Assam state continue to increase from 45 deaths to 49 and 190 cases positive for JE. This is the active JE virus transmission season there, so health officials are prudent to evaluate the situation and take measures to reduce incidence of the disease, because more cases can be expected. Interestingly, although AES is mentioned, all of the 190 positive cases are attributed to JE, and the number of AES cases, if any, is not mentioned, although the above report does indicate that the number of AES cases is rising.\n\nImmunization is the effective measure needed to avoid JE infections. Mosquito vector control is difficult. The previous report indicated that health officials had reviewed the immunization status but not stated of whom or what the findings were. It seems curious that no mention is made above of renewing vaccinations in the affected areas. Vaccination for JE was carried out in the affected areas last year (2018). It is not mentioned whether vaccination was carried out again this year (2019). The type of JE vaccine used previously is also not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine, the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20190705.6552949\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20190703.6549201\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS) 20190630.6544796\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20180818.5974190\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.58623\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.5812921\n.................................................ty/msp/lxl", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6552949", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6552949", "date": "2019-06-20 21:21:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (06): (BIHAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Jun 2019\nSource: BBC [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-48610932\n\n\nMore than 100 children have now died in an outbreak of suspected encephalitis in India's Bihar state, officials say. At least 200 patients, many of whom are below the age of 10, are still being treated at 2 hospitals. State officials have said that many victims had died due to hypoglycaemia, or low blood sugar.\n\nThousands of children have died of encephalitis in Bihar and neighbouring Uttar Pradesh since the 1st case was detected in the late 1970s.\n\nThe state has announced that it will bear the cost of treatment for all those affected. The Indian government has said that it will \"extend all possible support\" to the state and affected families.\n\nThe outbreak since the beginning of June [2019] has seen the most deaths in the city of Muzaffarpur.\n\nThe disease usually occurs during the monsoon season, and children are the worst affected. Until 2005, doctors say that the majority of deaths were caused by Japanese encephalitis, a mosquito-borne virus. But in the past decade or so, children have been dying of other forms of viral encephalitis, the exact cause of which is unclear.\n\nThe disease causes headaches and vomiting and can lead to coma, brain dysfunction, seizure, and inflammation of the heart and kidney. Doctors say children between the age of 6 months and 15 years are the worst affected, and 1/5 of the children who survive have to live with neurological weaknesses.\n\n\"It is difficult to say with certainty if children are dying due to encephalitis, because there could be a number of reasons behind these deaths,\" Dr Mala Kaneria told BBC Hindi's Priyanka Dubey. \"It could also be due to malnutrition, insufficient levels of sugar and sodium, or electrolyte imbalances.\"\n\nDr Kaneria added that some of these deaths could also be caused by eating lychees on an empty stomach. Lychees contain toxins that inhibit the body's ability to produce glucose, which could affect young children whose blood sugar levels were already low because they were not eating dinner.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRaman Mahajan\nMedecins Sans Frontieres\n<msfe-delhi-epidem@barcelona.msf.org>\n\n[The number of cases of AES in the area continues to grow. A 19 Jun 2019 report indicates that the death toll has increased to 114 with more than 500 cases of AES registered since the outbreak began 1 Jun 2019, according to a government health bulletin released Wednesday [19 Jun 2019]. The outbreak has been exacerbated by a heatwave, with temperatures in Patna, Bihar's capital, reaching a high of 45.8 deg C / 114.5 deg F (https://federalnewsnetwork.com/health-news/2019/06/death-toll-rises-in-eastern-india-in-encephalitis-outbreak/). As noted in comments on early posts, although lychee fruit consumption by malnourished children is the main suspected etiology of AES in recent reports, apparently some scientists in India think that a virus, probably Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), is responsible for some of the cases. As noted previously, some cases of AES are frequently attributed to Japanese encephalitis, but many are of undefined etiology. The determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nIt has been proposed previously that consumption of lychees is responsible for some encephalitis cases. Encephalopathy and hypoglycemia have been associated with consumption of lychee fruit containing phytotoxins, specifically alpha-(methylenecyclopropyl)glycine (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20150201.3132842). However, Dr Jacob John has asserted that many of these are hypoglycemic Reye syndrome cases. He noted that in the pre-monsoon period, particularly in May and June, outbreaks of Reye-like acute hypoglycemic encephalopathy occur in the northwestern region of Bihar state, and that is also popularly, but unfortunately, called AES. Many doctors, the media, and the public consider these encephalopathy cases as encephalitis because of the term AES. This has been now clarified, and in June 2014, children were treated by 10% dextrose infusion and many lives were saved [dextrose administration is not mentioned in the above report]. Other etiologies have been proposed by clinicians. A published article in a pediatric journal proposed that some cases are due to heat stroke. A 16 Jun 2019 report stated that the Bihar state health department in a press release said maximum deaths have occurred this year due to hypoglycemia resulting from high heat, humidity, and no rain (http://en.rfi.fr/asia-pacific/20190616-heatwave-encephalitis-deaths-skyrocket-bihar-northern-india). In that press release, no mention is made of lychee consumption or virus infections.\n\nReference\n---------\nShrivastava A, Kumar A, Thomas JD, et al.; Association of acute toxic encephalopathy with litchi consumption in an outbreak in Muzaffarpur, India, 2014: a case-control study. Lancet Global Health. 2017; 5(4): e458-e466. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/S2214-109X(17)30035-9. https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(17)30035-9/fulltext\n\nUntil the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The presence of enterovirus had earlier been confirmed in the cerebrospinal fluid of one of the patients when it was tested at the virology lab attached to the Government Medical College, Alappuzha (https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/enterovirus-led-to-encephalitis-in-malappuram/article27957202.ece). Enterovirus infections have been attributed before as etiological agents of AES, but laboratory confirmations are scarce. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/364]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (BR) 20190609.6510811\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (01) 20190112.6255835\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (MH) 20181220.6216363\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (UP) 20180711.5900435\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.5862346\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (BR) 20180618.5860635\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MP) 20180614.5855342\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (HP) 20180607.5844658\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (KL) 20180605.5840545\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (KL) 20180530.5827153\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.5812921\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (UP), typhus 20180416.5749050\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.55507\n2015\n----\nEncephalopathy, hypoglycemia - India: (BR) litchi, methylenecyclopropylglycine 20150201.3132842\n.................................................jh/ty/tw/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-06-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2019-06-19 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2014-06-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Muzaffarpur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Patna", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6552595", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (KL) 20180605.5840545\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (KL) 20180530.5827153\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.5812921\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (UP), typhus 20180416.5749050\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.55507\n2015\n----\nEncephalopathy, hypoglycemia - India: (BR) litchi, methylenecyclopropylglycine 20150201.3132842\n.................................................jh/ty/tw/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-06-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2019-06-19 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2014-06-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Muzaffarpur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Patna", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6549201", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6549201", "date": "2019-06-20 21:21:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (06): (BIHAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Jun 2019\nSource: BBC [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-48610932\n\n\nMore than 100 children have now died in an outbreak of suspected encephalitis in India's Bihar state, officials say. At least 200 patients, many of whom are below the age of 10, are still being treated at 2 hospitals. State officials have said that many victims had died due to hypoglycaemia, or low blood sugar.\n\nThousands of children have died of encephalitis in Bihar and neighbouring Uttar Pradesh since the 1st case was detected in the late 1970s.\n\nThe state has announced that it will bear the cost of treatment for all those affected. The Indian government has said that it will \"extend all possible support\" to the state and affected families.\n\nThe outbreak since the beginning of June [2019] has seen the most deaths in the city of Muzaffarpur.\n\nThe disease usually occurs during the monsoon season, and children are the worst affected. Until 2005, doctors say that the majority of deaths were caused by Japanese encephalitis, a mosquito-borne virus. But in the past decade or so, children have been dying of other forms of viral encephalitis, the exact cause of which is unclear.\n\nThe disease causes headaches and vomiting and can lead to coma, brain dysfunction, seizure, and inflammation of the heart and kidney. Doctors say children between the age of 6 months and 15 years are the worst affected, and 1/5 of the children who survive have to live with neurological weaknesses.\n\n\"It is difficult to say with certainty if children are dying due to encephalitis, because there could be a number of reasons behind these deaths,\" Dr Mala Kaneria told BBC Hindi's Priyanka Dubey. \"It could also be due to malnutrition, insufficient levels of sugar and sodium, or electrolyte imbalances.\"\n\nDr Kaneria added that some of these deaths could also be caused by eating lychees on an empty stomach. Lychees contain toxins that inhibit the body's ability to produce glucose, which could affect young children whose blood sugar levels were already low because they were not eating dinner.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRaman Mahajan\nMedecins Sans Frontieres\n<msfe-delhi-epidem@barcelona.msf.org>\n\n[The number of cases of AES in the area continues to grow. A 19 Jun 2019 report indicates that the death toll has increased to 114 with more than 500 cases of AES registered since the outbreak began 1 Jun 2019, according to a government health bulletin released Wednesday [19 Jun 2019]. The outbreak has been exacerbated by a heatwave, with temperatures in Patna, Bihar's capital, reaching a high of 45.8 deg C / 114.5 deg F (https://federalnewsnetwork.com/health-news/2019/06/death-toll-rises-in-eastern-india-in-encephalitis-outbreak/). As noted in comments on early posts, although lychee fruit consumption by malnourished children is the main suspected etiology of AES in recent reports, apparently some scientists in India think that a virus, probably Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), is responsible for some of the cases. As noted previously, some cases of AES are frequently attributed to Japanese encephalitis, but many are of undefined etiology. The determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nIt has been proposed previously that consumption of lychees is responsible for some encephalitis cases. Encephalopathy and hypoglycemia have been associated with consumption of lychee fruit containing phytotoxins, specifically alpha-(methylenecyclopropyl)glycine (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20150201.3132842). However, Dr Jacob John has asserted that many of these are hypoglycemic Reye syndrome cases. He noted that in the pre-monsoon period, particularly in May and June, outbreaks of Reye-like acute hypoglycemic encephalopathy occur in the northwestern region of Bihar state, and that is also popularly, but unfortunately, called AES. Many doctors, the media, and the public consider these encephalopathy cases as encephalitis because of the term AES. This has been now clarified, and in June 2014, children were treated by 10% dextrose infusion and many lives were saved [dextrose administration is not mentioned in the above report]. Other etiologies have been proposed by clinicians. A published article in a pediatric journal proposed that some cases are due to heat stroke. A 16 Jun 2019 report stated that the Bihar state health department in a press release said maximum deaths have occurred this year due to hypoglycemia resulting from high heat, humidity, and no rain (http://en.rfi.fr/asia-pacific/20190616-heatwave-encephalitis-deaths-skyrocket-bihar-northern-india). In that press release, no mention is made of lychee consumption or virus infections.\n\nReference\n---------\nShrivastava A, Kumar A, Thomas JD, et al.; Association of acute toxic encephalopathy with litchi consumption in an outbreak in Muzaffarpur, India, 2014: a case-control study. Lancet Global Health. 2017; 5(4): e458-e466. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/S2214-109X(17)30035-9. https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(17)30035-9/fulltext\n\nUntil the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The presence of enterovirus had earlier been confirmed in the cerebrospinal fluid of one of the patients when it was tested at the virology lab attached to the Government Medical College, Alappuzha (https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/enterovirus-led-to-encephalitis-in-malappuram/article27957202.ece). Enterovirus infections have been attributed before as etiological agents of AES, but laboratory confirmations are scarce. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/364]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (BR) 20190619.6527331\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (BR) 20190614.6519707\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (BR) 20190612.6515634\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (BR) 20190609.6510811\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (01) 20190112.6255835\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (MH) 20181220.6216363\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (MP) 20181112.6141152\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (MP) 20180827.5991109\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (BR) 20180823.5981659\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20180818.5974190\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): (UP) 20180814.5964023\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (UP) 20180711.5900435\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.5862346\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (BR) 20180618.5860635\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MP) 20180614.5855342\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (HP) 20180607.5844658\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (KL) 20180605.5840545\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (KL) 20180530.5827153\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.5812921\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (UP), typhus 20180416.5749050\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.55507\n2015\n----\nEncephalopathy, hypoglycemia - India: (BR) litchi, methylenecyclopropylglycine 20150201.3132842\n.................................................jh/ty/tw/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-06-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2019-06-19 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2014-06-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Muzaffarpur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Patna", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6544796", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6536300", "date": "2019-06-20 21:21:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (06): (BIHAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Jun 2019\nSource: BBC [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-48610932\n\n\nMore than 100 children have now died in an outbreak of suspected encephalitis in India's Bihar state, officials say. At least 200 patients, many of whom are below the age of 10, are still being treated at 2 hospitals. State officials have said that many victims had died due to hypoglycaemia, or low blood sugar.\n\nThousands of children have died of encephalitis in Bihar and neighbouring Uttar Pradesh since the 1st case was detected in the late 1970s.\n\nThe state has announced that it will bear the cost of treatment for all those affected. The Indian government has said that it will \"extend all possible support\" to the state and affected families.\n\nThe outbreak since the beginning of June [2019] has seen the most deaths in the city of Muzaffarpur.\n\nThe disease usually occurs during the monsoon season, and children are the worst affected. Until 2005, doctors say that the majority of deaths were caused by Japanese encephalitis, a mosquito-borne virus. But in the past decade or so, children have been dying of other forms of viral encephalitis, the exact cause of which is unclear.\n\nThe disease causes headaches and vomiting and can lead to coma, brain dysfunction, seizure, and inflammation of the heart and kidney. Doctors say children between the age of 6 months and 15 years are the worst affected, and 1/5 of the children who survive have to live with neurological weaknesses.\n\n\"It is difficult to say with certainty if children are dying due to encephalitis, because there could be a number of reasons behind these deaths,\" Dr Mala Kaneria told BBC Hindi's Priyanka Dubey. \"It could also be due to malnutrition, insufficient levels of sugar and sodium, or electrolyte imbalances.\"\n\nDr Kaneria added that some of these deaths could also be caused by eating lychees on an empty stomach. Lychees contain toxins that inhibit the body's ability to produce glucose, which could affect young children whose blood sugar levels were already low because they were not eating dinner.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRaman Mahajan\nMedecins Sans Frontieres\n<msfe-delhi-epidem@barcelona.msf.org>\n\n[The number of cases of AES in the area continues to grow. A 19 Jun 2019 report indicates that the death toll has increased to 114 with more than 500 cases of AES registered since the outbreak began 1 Jun 2019, according to a government health bulletin released Wednesday [19 Jun 2019]. The outbreak has been exacerbated by a heatwave, with temperatures in Patna, Bihar's capital, reaching a high of 45.8 deg C / 114.5 deg F (https://federalnewsnetwork.com/health-news/2019/06/death-toll-rises-in-eastern-india-in-encephalitis-outbreak/). As noted in comments on early posts, although lychee fruit consumption by malnourished children is the main suspected etiology of AES in recent reports, apparently some scientists in India think that a virus, probably Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), is responsible for some of the cases. As noted previously, some cases of AES are frequently attributed to Japanese encephalitis, but many are of undefined etiology. The determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nIt has been proposed previously that consumption of lychees is responsible for some encephalitis cases. Many doctors, the media, and the public consider these encephalopathy cases as encephalitis because of the term AES. Other etiologies have been proposed by clinicians. A published article in a pediatric journal proposed that some cases are due to heat stroke. A 16 Jun 2019 report stated that the Bihar state health department in a press release said maximum deaths have occurred this year due to hypoglycemia resulting from high heat, humidity, and no rain (http://en.rfi.fr/asia-pacific/20190616-heatwave-encephalitis-deaths-skyrocket-bihar-northern-india). In that press release, no mention is made of lychee consumption or virus infections.\n\nReference\n---------\nShrivastava A, Kumar A, Thomas JD, et al.; Association of acute toxic encephalopathy with litchi consumption in an outbreak in Muzaffarpur, India, 2014: a case-control study. Lancet Global Health. 2017; 5(4): e458-e466. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/S2214-109X(17)30035-9. https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(17)30035-9/fulltext\n\nUntil the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The presence of enterovirus had earlier been confirmed in the cerebrospinal fluid of one of the patients when it was tested at the virology lab attached to the Government Medical College, Alappuzha (https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/enterovirus-led-to-encephalitis-in-malappuram/article27957202.ece). Enterovirus infections have been attributed before as etiological agents of AES, but laboratory confirmations are scarce. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/364]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (BR) 20190609.6510811\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (01) 20190112.6255835\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (MH) 20181220.6216363\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (UP) 20180711.5900435\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.5862346\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (BR) 20180618.5860635\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MP) 20180614.5855342\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (HP) 20180607.5844658\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (KL) 20180605.5840545\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (KL) 20180530.5827153\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.5812921\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (UP), typhus 20180416.5749050\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.55507\n2015\n----\nEncephalopathy, hypoglycemia - India: (BR) litchi, methylenecyclopropylglycine 20150201.3132842\n.................................................jh/ty/tw/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-06-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2019-06-19 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2014-06-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Muzaffarpur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Patna", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6534700", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6534700", "date": "2019-06-20 21:21:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (06): (BIHAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Jun 2019\nSource: BBC [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-48610932\n\n\nMore than 100 children have now died in an outbreak of suspected encephalitis in India's Bihar state, officials say. At least 200 patients, many of whom are below the age of 10, are still being treated at 2 hospitals. State officials have said that many victims had died due to hypoglycaemia, or low blood sugar.\n\nThousands of children have died of encephalitis in Bihar and neighbouring Uttar Pradesh since the 1st case was detected in the late 1970s.\n\nThe state has announced that it will bear the cost of treatment for all those affected. The Indian government has said that it will \"extend all possible support\" to the state and affected families.\n\nThe outbreak since the beginning of June [2019] has seen the most deaths in the city of Muzaffarpur.\n\nThe disease usually occurs during the monsoon season, and children are the worst affected. Until 2005, doctors say that the majority of deaths were caused by Japanese encephalitis, a mosquito-borne virus. But in the past decade or so, children have been dying of other forms of viral encephalitis, the exact cause of which is unclear.\n\nThe disease causes headaches and vomiting and can lead to coma, brain dysfunction, seizure, and inflammation of the heart and kidney. Doctors say children between the age of 6 months and 15 years are the worst affected, and 1/5 of the children who survive have to live with neurological weaknesses.\n\n\"It is difficult to say with certainty if children are dying due to encephalitis, because there could be a number of reasons behind these deaths,\" Dr Mala Kaneria told BBC Hindi's Priyanka Dubey. \"It could also be due to malnutrition, insufficient levels of sugar and sodium, or electrolyte imbalances.\"\n\nDr Kaneria added that some of these deaths could also be caused by eating lychees on an empty stomach. Lychees contain toxins that inhibit the body's ability to produce glucose, which could affect young children whose blood sugar levels were already low because they were not eating dinner.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRaman Mahajan\nMedecins Sans Frontieres\n<msfe-delhi-epidem@barcelona.msf.org>\n\n[The number of cases of AES in the area continues to grow. A 19 Jun 2019 report indicates that the death toll has increased to 114 with more than 500 cases of AES registered since the outbreak began 1 Jun 2019, according to a government health bulletin released Wednesday [19 Jun 2019]. The outbreak has been exacerbated by a heatwave, with temperatures in Patna, Bihar's capital, reaching a high of 45.8 deg C / 114.5 deg F (https://federalnewsnetwork.com/health-news/2019/06/death-toll-rises-in-eastern-india-in-encephalitis-outbreak/). As noted in comments on early posts, although lychee fruit consumption by malnourished children is the main suspected etiology of AES in recent reports, apparently some scientists in India think that a virus, probably Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), is responsible for some of the cases. As noted previously, some cases of AES are frequently attributed to Japanese encephalitis, but many are of undefined etiology. The determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nIt has been proposed previously that consumption of lychees is responsible for some encephalitis cases. Encephalopathy and hypoglycemia have been associated with consumption of lychee fruit containing phytotoxins, specifically alpha-(methylenecyclopropyl)glycine (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20150201.3132842). However, Dr Jacob John has asserted that many of these are hypoglycemic Reye syndrome cases. He noted that in the pre-monsoon period, particularly in May and June, outbreaks of Reye-like acute hypoglycemic encephalopathy occur in the northwestern region of Bihar state, and that is also popularly, but unfortunately, called AES. Many doctors, the media, and the public consider these encephalopathy cases as encephalitis because of the term AES. This has been now clarified, and in June 2014, children were treated by 10% dextrose infusion and many lives were saved [dextrose administration is not mentioned in the above report]. Other etiologies have been proposed by clinicians. A published article in a pediatric journal proposed that some cases are due to heat stroke. A 16 Jun 2019 report stated that the Bihar state health department in a press release said maximum deaths have occurred this year due to hypoglycemia resulting from high heat, humidity, and no rain (http://en.rfi.fr/asia-pacific/20190616-heatwave-encephalitis-deaths-skyrocket-bihar-northern-india). In that press release, no mention is made of lychee consumption or virus infections.\n\nReference\n---------\nShrivastava A, Kumar A, Thomas JD, et al.; Association of acute toxic encephalopathy with litchi consumption in an outbreak in Muzaffarpur, India, 2014: a case-control study. Lancet Global Health. 2017; 5(4): e458-e466. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/S2214-109X(17)30035-9. https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(17)30035-9/fulltext\n\nUntil the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The presence of enterovirus had earlier been confirmed in the cerebrospinal fluid of one of the patients when it was tested at the virology lab attached to the Government Medical College, Alappuzha (https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/enterovirus-led-to-encephalitis-in-malappuram/article27957202.ece). Enterovirus infections have been attributed before as etiological agents of AES, but laboratory confirmations are scarce. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/364]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (BR) 20190609.6510811\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (01) 20190112.6255835\n2018\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (MH) 20181220.6216363\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (UP), typhus 20180416.5749050\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.55507\n2015\n----\nEncephalopathy, hypoglycemia - India: (BR) litchi, methylenecyclopropylglycine 20150201.3132842\n.................................................jh/ty/tw/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-06-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2019-06-19 00:00:00", "2021-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-06-15 00:00:00", "2014-06-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Muzaffarpur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Patna", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6534477", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6530974", "date": "2019-06-20 21:21:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (06): (BIHAR)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Jun 2019\nSource: BBC [edited]\nhttps://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-48610932\n\n\nMore than 100 children have now died in an outbreak of suspected encephalitis in India's Bihar state, officials say. At least 200 patients, many of whom are below the age of 10, are still being treated at 2 hospitals. State officials have said that many victims had died due to hypoglycaemia, or low blood sugar.\n\nThousands of children have died of encephalitis in Bihar and neighbouring Uttar Pradesh since the 1st case was detected in the late 1970s.\n\nThe state has announced that it will bear the cost of treatment for all those affected. The Indian government has said that it will \"extend all possible support\" to the state and affected families.\n\nThe outbreak since the beginning of June [2019] has seen the most deaths in the city of Muzaffarpur.\n\nThe disease usually occurs during the monsoon season, and children are the worst affected. Until 2005, doctors say that the majority of deaths were caused by Japanese encephalitis, a mosquito-borne virus. But in the past decade or so, children have been dying of other forms of viral encephalitis, the exact cause of which is unclear.\n\nThe disease causes headaches and vomiting and can lead to coma, brain dysfunction, seizure, and inflammation of the heart and kidney. Doctors say children between the age of 6 months and 15 years are the worst affected, and 1/5 of the children who survive have to live with neurological weaknesses.\n\n\"It is difficult to say with certainty if children are dying due to encephalitis, because there could be a number of reasons behind these deaths,\" Dr Mala Kaneria told BBC Hindi's Priyanka Dubey. \"It could also be due to malnutrition, insufficient levels of sugar and sodium, or electrolyte imbalances.\"\n\nDr Kaneria added that some of these deaths could also be caused by eating lychees on an empty stomach. Lychees contain toxins that inhibit the body's ability to produce glucose, which could affect young children whose blood sugar levels were already low because they were not eating dinner.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRaman Mahajan\nMedecins Sans Frontieres\n<msfe-delhi-epidem@barcelona.msf.org>\n\n[The number of cases of AES in the area continues to grow. A 19 Jun 2019 report indicates that the death toll has increased to 114 with more than 500 cases of AES registered since the outbreak began 1 Jun 2019, according to a government health bulletin released Wednesday [19 Jun 2019]. The outbreak has been exacerbated by a heatwave, with temperatures in Patna, Bihar's capital, reaching a high of 45.8 deg C / 114.5 deg F (https://federalnewsnetwork.com/health-news/2019/06/death-toll-rises-in-eastern-india-in-encephalitis-outbreak/). As noted in comments on early posts, although lychee fruit consumption by malnourished children is the main suspected etiology of AES in recent reports, apparently some scientists in India think that a virus, probably Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), is responsible for some of the cases. As noted previously, some cases of AES are frequently attributed to Japanese encephalitis, but many are of undefined etiology. The determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heatstroke, lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). A recent publication states that dengue virus is one of the 3 most common agents identified in AES, but existing surveillance for AES does not include routine testing for dengue.\n\nIt has been proposed previously that consumption of lychees is responsible for some encephalitis cases. Encephalopathy and hypoglycemia have been associated with consumption of lychee fruit containing phytotoxins, specifically alpha-(methylenecyclopropyl)glycine (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20150201.3132842). However, Dr Jacob John has asserted that many of these are hypoglycemic Reye syndrome cases. He noted that in the pre-monsoon period, particularly in May and June, outbreaks of Reye-like acute hypoglycemic encephalopathy occur in the northwestern region of Bihar state, and that is also popularly, but unfortunately, called AES. Many doctors, the media, and the public consider these encephalopathy cases as encephalitis because of the term AES. This has been now clarified, and in June 2014, children were treated by 10% dextrose infusion and many lives were saved [dextrose administration is not mentioned in the above report]. Other etiologies have been proposed by clinicians. A published article in a pediatric journal proposed that some cases are due to heat stroke. A 16 Jun 2019 report stated that the Bihar state health department in a press release said maximum deaths have occurred this year due to hypoglycemia resulting from high heat, humidity, and no rain (http://en.rfi.fr/asia-pacific/20190616-heatwave-encephalitis-deaths-skyrocket-bihar-northern-india). In that press release, no mention is made of lychee consumption or virus infections.\n\nReference\n---------\nShrivastava A, Kumar A, Thomas JD, et al.; Association of acute toxic encephalopathy with litchi consumption in an outbreak in Muzaffarpur, India, 2014: a case-control study. Lancet Global Health. 2017; 5(4): e458-e466. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/S2214-109X(17)30035-9. https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(17)30035-9/fulltext\n\nUntil the etiology (or etiologies) of these AES cases is determined, effective and efficient prevention of these cases will not be possible. The presence of enterovirus had earlier been confirmed in the cerebrospinal fluid of one of the patients when it was tested at the virology lab attached to the Government Medical College, Alappuzha (https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/kerala/enterovirus-led-to-encephalitis-in-malappuram/article27957202.ece). Enterovirus infections have been attributed before as etiological agents of AES, but laboratory confirmations are scarce. - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/364]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6527331", "date": "2018-11-12 18:06:41", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (22): (MADHYA PRADESH)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 11 Nov 2018, 11:10 AM\nSource: The Hitavada [edited]\nhttp://thehitavada.com/Encyc/2018/11/11/8-Japanese-Encephalitis-patients-found-so-far.aspx\n\n\nGradually, hazardous diseases like Japanese encephalitis (JE) spreading its wings over the State [of Madhya Pradesh]. Currently, 8 patients of Japanese Encephalitis are found positive in Madhya Pradesh so far. Sources in the health department, on condition of anonymity, informed [us] that [there] are 8 JE patients and 3 of them are from Bhopal.\n\nA few days back a 3 year old child died of JE. Health officials have already started research about the virus around the localities of positive patients. Authorities concerned have confirmed the presence of JE virus in the areas.\n\nSources informed that [up to now] a total of 8 JE positive cases [have been] registered all across the state. The health department is taking all the necessary measures to get control over the hazardous JE virus disease.\n\nDr Himanshu Jaiswar, director [of the] State Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, talking to 'The Hitavada' said that in the wake of rising vectorborne diseases, the State Vector Borne Disease Control Department is conducting local entomological work, especially at the native lands of JE patients. He said that the vectorborne disease control department is trying to get control over JE. The department has already [commissioned] local entomological work and the health department is trying to overcome the disease as early as possible.\n\nDr Himanshu told [us what the] Vector Borne Disease Control Department is planning to do to stop JE virus. He said that the heath department is also planning to concern the Government of India to administer immunisation for the same as JE could be controlled with effective vaccination. Notably, Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infection of the brain caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV).\n\nSymptoms of JE may include headache, vomiting, fever, and confusion. This occurs about 5 to 15 days after infection. JEV is generally spread by mosquitoes, specifically culex mosquitoes, pigs and wild birds. It can be prevented by Japanese encephalitis vaccine, which is both safe and effective, and by avoiding mosquito bites.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the busy Japanese encephalitis virus transmission season in India. The report above uses the term \"Japanese encephalitis\" without mentioning \"acute encephalitis syndrome\" that has been used in previous reports from most localities in India. Where laboratory confirmation of exclusion is reported, usually these encephalitis cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE) as a minority of cases, with acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of unspecified etiology for the majority. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Fortunately, vaccination for JE is being carried out in the affected areas in the district, which will prevent cases of encephalitis due to infection with that virus. The type of vaccine used is not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (MP) 20180827.5991109\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6519707", "date": "2018-11-12 18:06:41", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (22): (MADHYA PRADESH)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 11 Nov 2018, 11:10 AM\nSource: The Hitavada [edited]\nhttp://thehitavada.com/Encyc/2018/11/11/8-Japanese-Encephalitis-patients-found-so-far.aspx\n\n\nGradually, hazardous diseases like Japanese encephalitis (JE) spreading its wings over the State [of Madhya Pradesh]. Currently, 8 patients of Japanese Encephalitis are found positive in Madhya Pradesh so far. Sources in the health department, on condition of anonymity, informed [us] that [there] are 8 JE patients and 3 of them are from Bhopal.\n\nA few days back a 3 year old child died of JE. Health officials have already started research about the virus around the localities of positive patients. Authorities concerned have confirmed the presence of JE virus in the areas.\n\nSources informed that [up to now] a total of 8 JE positive cases [have been] registered all across the state. The health department is taking all the necessary measures to get control over the hazardous JE virus disease.\n\nDr Himanshu Jaiswar, director [of the] State Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, talking to 'The Hitavada' said that in the wake of rising vectorborne diseases, the State Vector Borne Disease Control Department is conducting local entomological work, especially at the native lands of JE patients. He said that the vectorborne disease control department is trying to get control over JE. The department has already [commissioned] local entomological work and the health department is trying to overcome the disease as early as possible.\n\nDr Himanshu told [us what the] Vector Borne Disease Control Department is planning to do to stop JE virus. He said that the heath department is also planning to concern the Government of India to administer immunisation for the same as JE could be controlled with effective vaccination. Notably, Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infection of the brain caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV).\n\nSymptoms of JE may include headache, vomiting, fever, and confusion. This occurs about 5 to 15 days after infection. JEV is generally spread by mosquitoes, specifically culex mosquitoes, pigs and wild birds. It can be prevented by Japanese encephalitis vaccine, which is both safe and effective, and by avoiding mosquito bites.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the busy Japanese encephalitis virus transmission season in India. The report above uses the term \"Japanese encephalitis\" without mentioning \"acute encephalitis syndrome\" that has been used in previous reports from most localities in India. Where laboratory confirmation of exclusion is reported, usually these encephalitis cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE) as a minority of cases, with acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of unspecified etiology for the majority. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Fortunately, vaccination for JE is being carried out in the affected areas in the district, which will prevent cases of encephalitis due to infection with that virus. The type of vaccine used is not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (MP) 20180827.5991109\nJapanese encephalitis & other -
