India (03): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6515634", "date": "2018-11-12 18:06:41", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (22): (MADHYA PRADESH)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 11 Nov 2018, 11:10 AM\nSource: The Hitavada [edited]\nhttp://thehitavada.com/Encyc/2018/11/11/8-Japanese-Encephalitis-patients-found-so-far.aspx\n\n\nGradually, hazardous diseases like Japanese encephalitis (JE) spreading its wings over the State [of Madhya Pradesh]. Currently, 8 patients of Japanese Encephalitis are found positive in Madhya Pradesh so far. Sources in the health department, on condition of anonymity, informed [us] that [there] are 8 JE patients and 3 of them are from Bhopal.\n\nA few days back a 3 year old child died of JE. Health officials have already started research about the virus around the localities of positive patients. Authorities concerned have confirmed the presence of JE virus in the areas.\n\nSources informed that [up to now] a total of 8 JE positive cases [have been] registered all across the state. The health department is taking all the necessary measures to get control over the hazardous JE virus disease.\n\nDr Himanshu Jaiswar, director [of the] State Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, talking to 'The Hitavada' said that in the wake of rising vectorborne diseases, the State Vector Borne Disease Control Department is conducting local entomological work, especially at the native lands of JE patients. He said that the vectorborne disease control department is trying to get control over JE. The department has already [commissioned] local entomological work and the health department is trying to overcome the disease as early as possible.\n\nDr Himanshu told [us what the] Vector Borne Disease Control Department is planning to do to stop JE virus. He said that the heath department is also planning to concern the Government of India to administer immunisation for the same as JE could be controlled with effective vaccination. Notably, Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infection of the brain caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV).\n\nSymptoms of JE may include headache, vomiting, fever, and confusion. This occurs about 5 to 15 days after infection. JEV is generally spread by mosquitoes, specifically culex mosquitoes, pigs and wild birds. It can be prevented by Japanese encephalitis vaccine, which is both safe and effective, and by avoiding mosquito bites.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the busy Japanese encephalitis virus transmission season in India. The report above uses the term \"Japanese encephalitis\" without mentioning \"acute encephalitis syndrome\" that has been used in previous reports from most localities in India. Where laboratory confirmation of exclusion is reported, usually these encephalitis cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE) as a minority of cases, with acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of unspecified etiology for the majority. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Fortunately, vaccination for JE is being carried out in the affected areas in the district, which will prevent cases of encephalitis due to infection with that virus. The type of vaccine used is not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. India (02): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6510811", "date": "2018-11-12 18:06:41", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (22): (MADHYA PRADESH)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 11 Nov 2018, 11:10 AM\nSource: The Hitavada [edited]\nhttp://thehitavada.com/Encyc/2018/11/11/8-Japanese-Encephalitis-patients-found-so-far.aspx\n\n\nGradually, hazardous diseases like Japanese encephalitis (JE) spreading its wings over the State [of Madhya Pradesh]. Currently, 8 patients of Japanese Encephalitis are found positive in Madhya Pradesh so far. Sources in the health department, on condition of anonymity, informed [us] that [there] are 8 JE patients and 3 of them are from Bhopal.\n\nA few days back a 3 year old child died of JE. Health officials have already started research about the virus around the localities of positive patients. Authorities concerned have confirmed the presence of JE virus in the areas.\n\nSources informed that [up to now] a total of 8 JE positive cases [have been] registered all across the state. The health department is taking all the necessary measures to get control over the hazardous JE virus disease.\n\nDr Himanshu Jaiswar, director [of the] State Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, talking to 'The Hitavada' said that in the wake of rising vectorborne diseases, the State Vector Borne Disease Control Department is conducting local entomological work, especially at the native lands of JE patients. He said that the vectorborne disease control department is trying to get control over JE. The department has already [commissioned] local entomological work and the health department is trying to overcome the disease as early as possible.\n\nDr Himanshu told [us what the] Vector Borne Disease Control Department is planning to do to stop JE virus. He said that the heath department is also planning to concern the Government of India to administer immunisation for the same as JE could be controlled with effective vaccination. Notably, Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infection of the brain caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV).\n\nSymptoms of JE may include headache, vomiting, fever, and confusion. This occurs about 5 to 15 days after infection. JEV is generally spread by mosquitoes, specifically culex mosquitoes, pigs and wild birds. It can be prevented by Japanese encephalitis vaccine, which is both safe and effective, and by avoiding mosquito bites.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the busy Japanese encephalitis virus transmission season in India. The report above uses the term \"Japanese encephalitis\" without mentioning \"acute encephalitis syndrome\" that has been used in previous reports from most localities in India. Where laboratory confirmation of exclusion is reported, usually these encephalitis cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE) as a minority of cases, with acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of unspecified etiology for the majority. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Fortunately, vaccination for JE is being carried out in the affected areas in the district, which will prevent cases of encephalitis due to infection with that virus. The type of vaccine used is not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (MP) 20180827.5991109\nJapanese encephalitis & other - dogs and other animals: study", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6406476", "date": "2018-11-12 18:06:41", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (22): (MADHYA PRADESH)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 11 Nov 2018, 11:10 AM\nSource: The Hitavada [edited]\nhttp://thehitavada.com/Encyc/2018/11/11/8-Japanese-Encephalitis-patients-found-so-far.aspx\n\n\nGradually, hazardous diseases like Japanese encephalitis (JE) spreading its wings over the State [of Madhya Pradesh]. Currently, 8 patients of Japanese Encephalitis are found positive in Madhya Pradesh so far. Sources in the health department, on condition of anonymity, informed [us] that [there] are 8 JE patients and 3 of them are from Bhopal.\n\nA few days back a 3 year old child died of JE. Health officials have already started research about the virus around the localities of positive patients. Authorities concerned have confirmed the presence of JE virus in the areas.\n\nSources informed that [up to now] a total of 8 JE positive cases [have been] registered all across the state. The health department is taking all the necessary measures to get control over the hazardous JE virus disease.\n\nDr Himanshu Jaiswar, director [of the] State Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, talking to 'The Hitavada' said that in the wake of rising vectorborne diseases, the State Vector Borne Disease Control Department is conducting local entomological work, especially at the native lands of JE patients. He said that the vectorborne disease control department is trying to get control over JE. The department has already [commissioned] local entomological work and the health department is trying to overcome the disease as early as possible.\n\nDr Himanshu told [us what the] Vector Borne Disease Control Department is planning to do to stop JE virus. He said that the heath department is also planning to concern the Government of India to administer immunisation for the same as JE could be controlled with effective vaccination. Notably, Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infection of the brain caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV).\n\nSymptoms of JE may include headache, vomiting, fever, and confusion. This occurs about 5 to 15 days after infection. JEV is generally spread by mosquitoes, specifically culex mosquitoes, pigs and wild birds. It can be prevented by Japanese encephalitis vaccine, which is both safe and effective, and by avoiding mosquito bites.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the busy Japanese encephalitis virus transmission season in India. The report above uses the term \"Japanese encephalitis\" without mentioning \"acute encephalitis syndrome\" that has been used in previous reports from most localities in India. Where laboratory confirmation of exclusion is reported, usually these encephalitis cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE) as a minority of cases, with acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of unspecified etiology for the majority. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Fortunately, vaccination for JE is being carried out in the affected areas in the district, which will prevent cases of encephalitis due to infection with that virus. The type of vaccine used is not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (MP) 20180827.5991109\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (01)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6255835", "date": "2018-11-12 18:06:41", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (22): (MADHYA PRADESH)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 11 Nov 2018, 11:10 AM\nSource: The Hitavada [edited]\nhttp://thehitavada.com/Encyc/2018/11/11/8-Japanese-Encephalitis-patients-found-so-far.aspx\n\n\nGradually, hazardous diseases like Japanese encephalitis (JE) spreading its wings over the State [of Madhya Pradesh]. Currently, 8 patients of Japanese Encephalitis are found positive in Madhya Pradesh so far. Sources in the health department, on condition of anonymity, informed [us] that [there] are 8 JE patients and 3 of them are from Bhopal.\n\nA few days back a 3 year old child died of JE. Health officials have already started research about the virus around the localities of positive patients. Authorities concerned have confirmed the presence of JE virus in the areas.\n\nSources informed that [up to now] a total of 8 JE positive cases [have been] registered all across the state. The health department is taking all the necessary measures to get control over the hazardous JE virus disease.\n\nDr Himanshu Jaiswar, director [of the] State Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, talking to 'The Hitavada' said that in the wake of rising vectorborne diseases, the State Vector Borne Disease Control Department is conducting local entomological work, especially at the native lands of JE patients. He said that the vectorborne disease control department is trying to get control over JE. The department has already [commissioned] local entomological work and the health department is trying to overcome the disease as early as possible.\n\nDr Himanshu told [us what the] Vector Borne Disease Control Department is planning to do to stop JE virus. He said that the heath department is also planning to concern the Government of India to administer immunisation for the same as JE could be controlled with effective vaccination. Notably, Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infection of the brain caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV).\n\nSymptoms of JE may include headache, vomiting, fever, and confusion. This occurs about 5 to 15 days after infection. JEV is generally spread by mosquitoes, specifically culex mosquitoes, pigs and wild birds. It can be prevented by Japanese encephalitis vaccine, which is both safe and effective, and by avoiding mosquito bites.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the busy Japanese encephalitis virus transmission season in India. The report above uses the term \"Japanese encephalitis\" without mentioning \"acute encephalitis syndrome\" that has been used in previous reports from most localities in India. Where laboratory confirmation of exclusion is reported, usually these encephalitis cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE) as a minority of cases, with acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of unspecified etiology for the majority. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Fortunately, vaccination for JE is being carried out in the affected areas in the district, which will prevent cases of encephalitis due to infection with that virus. The type of vaccine used is not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. Attenuated live vaccine would provide longer immunity. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS) 20181108.6132872\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (MP) 20180827.5991109\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (MH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6216363", "date": "2018-11-12 18:06:41", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (22): (MADHYA PRADESH)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 11 Nov 2018, 11:10 AM\nSource: The Hitavada [edited]\nhttp://thehitavada.com/Encyc/2018/11/11/8-Japanese-Encephalitis-patients-found-so-far.aspx\n\n\nGradually, hazardous diseases like Japanese encephalitis (JE) spreading its wings over the State [of Madhya Pradesh]. Currently, 8 patients of Japanese Encephalitis are found positive in Madhya Pradesh so far. Sources in the health department, on condition of anonymity, informed [us] that [there] are 8 JE patients and 3 of them are from Bhopal.\n\nA few days back a 3 year old child died of JE. Health officials have already started research about the virus around the localities of positive patients. Authorities concerned have confirmed the presence of JE virus in the areas.\n\nSources informed that [up to now] a total of 8 JE positive cases [have been] registered all across the state. The health department is taking all the necessary measures to get control over the hazardous JE virus disease.\n\nDr Himanshu Jaiswar, director [of the] State Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, talking to 'The Hitavada' said that in the wake of rising vectorborne diseases, the State Vector Borne Disease Control Department is conducting local entomological work, especially at the native lands of JE patients. He said that the vectorborne disease control department is trying to get control over JE. The department has already [commissioned] local entomological work and the health department is trying to overcome the disease as early as possible.\n\nDr Himanshu told [us what the] Vector Borne Disease Control Department is planning to do to stop JE virus. He said that the heath department is also planning to concern the Government of India to administer immunisation for the same as JE could be controlled with effective vaccination. Notably, Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infection of the brain caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV).\n\nSymptoms of JE may include headache, vomiting, fever, and confusion. This occurs about 5 to 15 days after infection. JEV is generally spread by mosquitoes, specifically culex mosquitoes, pigs and wild birds. It can be prevented by Japanese encephalitis vaccine, which is both safe and effective, and by avoiding mosquito bites.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the busy Japanese encephalitis virus transmission season in India. The report above uses the term \"Japanese encephalitis\" without mentioning \"acute encephalitis syndrome\" that has been used in previous reports from most localities in India. Where laboratory confirmation of exclusion is reported, usually these encephalitis cases are attributed to Japanese encephalitis (JE) as a minority of cases, with acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of unspecified etiology for the majority. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Fortunately, vaccination for JE is being carried out in the affected areas in the district, which will prevent cases of encephalitis due to infection with that virus. The type of vaccine used is not mentioned. If it is an inactivated vaccine the duration of immunity may not be long-lasting. (KA, UP) 20180110.55507\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/ao/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6132872", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6132872", "date": "2018-09-05 21:21:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (20): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Aug 2018\nSource: The New Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/2018/aug/30/sharp-fall-in-encephalitis-cases-in-uttar-pradesh-this-year-1865068.html\n\n\nUttar Pradesh has seen a drastic fall in cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE) this year [2018], thanks to the concerted efforts of 6 state government departments, UP minister Sidharth Nath Singh said today [30 Aug 2018].\n\nThere has been a sharp decline in AES cases this year [2018] compared to the number of patients admitted to the BRD Medical College Hospital in Gorakhpur with the disease last year [2017], he said.\n\n\"A total of 1427 AES and JE cases were reported till 9 Aug 2018 in the state, which led to 111 deaths,\" the health minister said.\n\nSingh said over 5400 cases of acute encephalitis syndrome and Japanese encephalitis were reported in the state in 2017, leading to 748 deaths, compared to 4353 such cases and 715 deaths in 2016.\n\nAccording to the official figures, AES continued to be a bigger killer than JE in the northern state.\n\nThe minister said among the 111 deaths so far this year [2018], 108 were due to AES and 3 due to JE.\n\nNearly 90 per cent of encephalitis cases and deaths in 2016 and 2017 were also attributed to AES.\n\nSingh said the massive success in controlling the outbreak of the vector-borne disease was due to a planned strategy of the state government, which had started its work well in advance.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath had also launched the \"Dastak\" campaign against Japanese encephalitis and acute encephalitis syndrome in collaboration with the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF).\n\n\"Encephalitis affects children up to 15 years of age. This is our commitment to protect them from this deadly disease so that these children too can play an active role in nation building,\" he had noted.\n\nAs many as 38 districts of the northern state have been affected by the deadly disease.\n\nThe state health department was made the nodal agency to combat the disease, with other departments like Urban Development, Panchayati Raj, Women and Child Welfare, Rural Development, Medical Education, Animal Husbandry and basic education working under it.\n\nDetailing the various steps taken by the BJP-led state government to tackle the deadly disease, Singh said a detailed programme was prepared to combat encephalitis as part of which vaccination work was completed by March-April 2018.\n\nA sanitation drive was also launched. People were asked to keep their surroundings clean. Educational institutions as well as non-governmental organisations were also involved in this task, the health minister said.\n\nSingh said malnourishment, one of the causes of spread of encephalitis, was checked by ensuring that pregnant women, lactating mothers, and infants got nutritious food for which the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) department and Aanganwadi workers were involved.\n\nThe medical department has been directed to provide more ventilators and warmers to the BRD Medical College in Gorakhpur, he said, adding that paramedic staff were being trained to combat the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, including Uttar Pradesh state, and cases occur every year.\n\nThe reason for the reduction in JE and AES cases is not stated nor whether vaccination has reduced the number of JE cases. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Various etiological agents have been proposed in recent years as responsible for AES cases. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India:\nhttp://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/6506.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUttar Pradesh State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (MP) 20180827.5991109\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (BR) 20180823.5981659\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20180818.5974190\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): (UP) 20180814.5964023\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (UP) 20180711.5900435\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): 20180607.5844658\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (KL) 20180605.5840545\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (KL) 20180530.5827153\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Aug 2018\nSource: The New Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/2018/aug/30/sharp-fall-in-encephalitis-cases-in-uttar-pradesh-this-year-1865068.html\n\n\nUttar Pradesh has seen a drastic fall in cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE) this year [2018], thanks to the concerted efforts of 6 state government departments, UP minister Sidharth Nath Singh said today [30 Aug 2018].\n\nThere has been a sharp decline in AES cases this year [2018] compared to the number of patients admitted to the BRD Medical College Hospital in Gorakhpur with the disease last year [2017], he said.\n\n\"A total of 1427 AES and JE cases were reported till 9 Aug 2018 in the state, which led to 111 deaths,\" the health minister said.\n\nSingh said over 5400 cases of acute encephalitis syndrome and Japanese encephalitis were reported in the state in 2017, leading to 748 deaths, compared to 4353 such cases and 715 deaths in 2016.\n\nAccording to the official figures, AES continued to be a bigger killer than JE in the northern state.\n\nThe minister said among the 111 deaths so far this year [2018], 108 were due to AES and 3 due to JE.\n\nNearly 90 per cent of encephalitis cases and deaths in 2016 and 2017 were also attributed to AES.\n\nSingh said the massive success in controlling the outbreak of the vector-borne disease was due to a planned strategy of the state government, which had started its work well in advance.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath had also launched the \"Dastak\" campaign against Japanese encephalitis and acute encephalitis syndrome in collaboration with the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF).\n\n\"Encephalitis affects children up to 15 years of age. This is our commitment to protect them from this deadly disease so that these children too can play an active role in nation building,\" he had noted.\n\nAs many as 38 districts of the northern state have been affected by the deadly disease.\n\nThe state health department was made the nodal agency to combat the disease, with other departments like Urban Development, Panchayati Raj, Women and Child Welfare, Rural Development, Medical Education, Animal Husbandry and basic education working under it.\n\nDetailing the various steps taken by the BJP-led state government to tackle the deadly disease, Singh said a detailed programme was prepared to combat encephalitis as part of which vaccination work was completed by March-April 2018.\n\nA sanitation drive was also launched. People were asked to keep their surroundings clean. Educational institutions as well as non-governmental organisations were also involved in this task, the health minister said.\n\nSingh said malnourishment, one of the causes of spread of encephalitis, was checked by ensuring that pregnant women, lactating mothers, and infants got nutritious food for which the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) department and Aanganwadi workers were involved.\n\nThe medical department has been directed to provide more ventilators and warmers to the BRD Medical College in Gorakhpur, he said, adding that paramedic staff were being trained to combat the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, including Uttar Pradesh state, and cases occur every year.\n\nThe reason for the reduction in JE and AES cases is not stated nor whether vaccination has reduced the number of JE cases. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Various etiological agents have been proposed in recent years as responsible for AES cases. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, lychee fruit consumption, and 20180110.55507\n.................................................sb/mpp/ty/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "1427-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-08-09 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Gorakhpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Singh", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5974190", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5974190", "date": "2018-09-05 21:21:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (20): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Aug 2018\nSource: The New Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/2018/aug/30/sharp-fall-in-encephalitis-cases-in-uttar-pradesh-this-year-1865068.html\n\n\nUttar Pradesh has seen a drastic fall in cases of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and Japanese encephalitis (JE) this year [2018], thanks to the concerted efforts of 6 state government departments, UP minister Sidharth Nath Singh said today [30 Aug 2018].\n\nThere has been a sharp decline in AES cases this year [2018] compared to the number of patients admitted to the BRD Medical College Hospital in Gorakhpur with the disease last year [2017], he said.\n\n\"A total of 1427 AES and JE cases were reported till 9 Aug 2018 in the state, which led to 111 deaths,\" the health minister said.\n\nSingh said over 5400 cases of acute encephalitis syndrome and Japanese encephalitis were reported in the state in 2017, leading to 748 deaths, compared to 4353 such cases and 715 deaths in 2016.\n\nAccording to the official figures, AES continued to be a bigger killer than JE in the northern state.\n\nThe minister said among the 111 deaths so far this year [2018], 108 were due to AES and 3 due to JE.\n\nNearly 90 per cent of encephalitis cases and deaths in 2016 and 2017 were also attributed to AES.\n\nSingh said the massive success in controlling the outbreak of the vector-borne disease was due to a planned strategy of the state government, which had started its work well in advance.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath had also launched the \"Dastak\" campaign against Japanese encephalitis and acute encephalitis syndrome in collaboration with the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF).\n\n\"Encephalitis affects children up to 15 years of age. This is our commitment to protect them from this deadly disease so that these children too can play an active role in nation building,\" he had noted.\n\nAs many as 38 districts of the northern state have been affected by the deadly disease.\n\nThe state health department was made the nodal agency to combat the disease, with other departments like Urban Development, Panchayati Raj, Women and Child Welfare, Rural Development, Medical Education, Animal Husbandry and basic education working under it.\n\nDetailing the various steps taken by the BJP-led state government to tackle the deadly disease, Singh said a detailed programme was prepared to combat encephalitis as part of which vaccination work was completed by March-April 2018.\n\nA sanitation drive was also launched. People were asked to keep their surroundings clean. Educational institutions as well as non-governmental organisations were also involved in this task, the health minister said.\n\nSingh said malnourishment, one of the causes of spread of encephalitis, was checked by ensuring that pregnant women, lactating mothers, and infants got nutritious food for which the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) department and Aanganwadi workers were involved.\n\nThe medical department has been directed to provide more ventilators and warmers to the BRD Medical College in Gorakhpur, he said, adding that paramedic staff were being trained to combat the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, including Uttar Pradesh state, and cases occur every year.\n\nThe reason for the reduction in JE and AES cases is not stated nor whether vaccination has reduced the number of JE cases. This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Various etiological agents have been proposed in recent years as responsible for AES cases. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India:\nhttp://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/6506.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUttar Pradesh State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (MP) 20180827.5991109\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (BR) 20180823.5981659\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS) 20180818.5974190\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): (UP) 20180814.5964023\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (UP) 20180711.5900435\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (AS) 20180701.5883729\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20180628.5881510\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10) 20180620.5866496\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS) 20180618.5862346\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (BR) 20180618.5860635\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MP) 20180614.5855342\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (HP) 20180607.5844658\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (KL) 20180605.5840545\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (KL) 20180530.5827153\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) This is the season for JE virus, but AES also occurs at this time.\n\nAs noted in many earlier posts, the determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Various etiological agents have been proposed in recent years as responsible for AES cases. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, lychee fruit consumption, and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of India:\nhttp://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and\nhttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/6506.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nUttar Pradesh State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): (UP) 20180814.5964023\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS) 20180812.5961217\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (AS) 20180805.5948662\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (HP) 20180607.5844658\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (KL) 20180605.5840545\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (KL) 20180530.5827153\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20180523.5812921\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (UP), typhus 20180416.5749050\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.55507\n.................................................sb/mpp/ty/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "1427-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-08-09 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Gorakhpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Singh", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5900435", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5900435", "date": "2018-06-07 15:15:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (06): (HIMACHAL PRADESH)\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2018 12:40 AM\nSource: The Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.tribuneindia.com/news/himachal/je-virus-two-children-test-positive/600679.html\n\n\nThe Centre [source does not specify further. - Mod.SH] on [Tue 5 Jun 2018] confirmed the outbreak of Japanese encephalitis in Himachal, with 2 children from Solan district testing positive for the mosquitoborne viral infection of the brain.\n\nBoth children are currently in Indira Gandhi Medical Hospital, Shimla. One, a 3 year old boy from Dharampur is critical and on ventilator support. The other, a 6 year old boy from Dhalli is also under intensive care. Altogether, 7 Solan kids were referred to the IGMC, Shimla, with symptoms of viral infection, but 5 were discharged.\n\nHealth secretary Preeti Sudan told The Tribune that she had spoken to the state's principal health secretary, and directed teams from the National Centre for Disease Control and the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme to be sent to Himachal for detailed investigations into the cause of the infection.\n\nThe state surveillance officer under the Integrated Disease Control Programme had spotted symptoms of febrile illness in 7 children of Solan district and referred them to the IGMC, Shimla, suspecting Nipah virus. Their samples were sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, to rule out Nipah and 2 of these instead tested positive for JE. \"Blood samples of these 2 children have tested positive for JE. We have now sent their cerebrospinal fluid samples to the NIV, Pune, for further investigation,\" a Health Ministry official said.\n\nHimachal has never reported JE. This is the 1st time the state has seen cases of the virus which kills 220 children under 15 pan-India every year on an average. The highest mortality rate from JE is in Uttar Pradesh where children's deaths in Gorakhpur recently sent shock waves all over the country. These deaths were primarily attributed to JE aggravated by poor healthcare facilities.\n\nSince 2010, India has seen 10 893 JE cases and 1756 deaths, a mortality rate of 17 per cent.\n\nJE has no cure. There's a preventive vaccine the government now offers under routine immunisation plan. The management of JE-infected children to minimise chances of death is the main line of care.\n\nA central multi-sectoral team rushed to Himachal will now determine whether JE infection in the state is indigenous or imported. Domestic pigs and wild birds carry the JE virus mostly transmitted by mosquitoes found around paddy fields. Mosquitoes get the infection by feeding on diseased domestic pigs and wild birds. They then further transmit the JE virus to humans.\n\n\"Central experts will have to trace the virus host and its vector -- the mosquito -- in Solan for the infection to be notified as endemic. They will also interview the local population to rule out more cases. If the virus and vector are not traced, the virus could have been imported. That possibility will then have to be determined,\" a ministry official said.\n\nHimachal, the home state of health minister JP Nadda, is the 23rd state to be affected by the deadly JE virus now. Others are Andhra Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Delhi, Goa, Haryana, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashta, Manipur, Meghalaya, Nagaland, Odisha, Punjab, Tamil Nadu, Telangana, Tripura, Uttarakhand and Bengal.\n\n[byline: Aditi Tandon]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Himachal, in far and mountainous northern India, has not been a state that has reported JE virus infections previously. The JE virus transmission season has begun in India and most cases occur in north eastern India, mainly in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Assam states. Although a vaccine is available, there is no indication that the 2 patients had been vaccinated or whether a vaccination campaign is planned. Because vector control is difficult and expensive, vaccination is a more effective preventive measure.\n\nFrequently, in reports of JE cases in India, acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of undefined etiology is often mentioned with JE cases, a minority of those hospitalized. In the above 2 cases, AES is not mentioned but their JE virus etiology was laboratory confirmed.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299, and a Healthmap of Himachal Pradesh State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/304. - India (02): (UP), typhus 20180416.5749050\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.5550774\n2017\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (RJ) 20171113.5441846\nJapanese encephalitis & other - Although a vaccine is available, there is no indication that the 2 patients had been vaccinated or whether a vaccination campaign is planned. Mod.SH] on [Tue 5 Jun 2018] confirmed the outbreak of Japanese encephalitis in Himachal, with 2 children from Solan district testing positive for the mosquitoborne viral infection of the brain.\n\nBoth children are currently in Indira Gandhi Medical Hospital, Shimla. One, a 3 year old boy from Dharampur is critical and on ventilator support. The other, a 6 year old boy from Dhalli is also under intensive care. Altogether, 7 Solan kids were referred to the IGMC, Shimla, with symptoms of viral infection, but 5 were discharged.\n\nHealth secretary Preeti Sudan told The Tribune that she had spoken to the state's principal health secretary, and directed teams from the National Centre for Disease Control and the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme to be sent to Himachal for detailed investigations into the cause of the infection.\n\nThe state surveillance officer under the Integrated Disease Control Programme had spotted symptoms of febrile illness in 7 children of Solan district and referred them to the IGMC, Shimla, suspecting Nipah virus. Their samples were sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, to rule out Nipah and 2 of these instead tested positive for JE. \"Blood samples of these 2 children have tested positive for JE. We have now sent their cerebrospinal fluid samples to the NIV, Pune, for further investigation,\" a Health Ministry official said.\n\nHimachal has never reported JE. This is the 1st time the state has seen cases of the virus which kills 220 children under 15 pan-India every year on an average. The highest mortality rate from JE is in Uttar Pradesh where children's deaths in Gorakhpur recently sent shock waves all over the country. These deaths were primarily attributed to JE aggravated by poor healthcare facilities.\n\nSince 2010, India has seen 10 893 JE cases and 1756 deaths, a mortality rate of 17 per cent.\n\nJE has no cure. There's a preventive vaccine the government now offers under routine immunisation plan. The management of JE-infected children to minimise chances of death is the main line of care.\n\nA central multi-sectoral team rushed to Himachal will now determine whether JE infection in the state is indigenous or imported. Domestic pigs and wild birds carry the JE virus mostly transmitted by mosquitoes found around paddy fields. Mosquitoes get the infection by feeding on diseased domestic pigs and wild birds. They then further transmit the JE virus to humans.\n\n\"Central experts will have to trace the virus host and its vector -- the mosquito -- in Solan for the infection to be notified as endemic. They will also interview the local population to rule out more cases. If the virus and vector are not traced, the virus could have been imported. That possibility will then have to be determined,\" a ministry official said.\n\nHimachal, the home state of health minister JP Nadda, is the 23rd state to be affected by the deadly JE virus now. Others are Andhra Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Delhi, Goa, Haryana, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashta, Manipur, Meghalaya, Nagaland, Odisha, Punjab, Tamil Nadu, Telangana, Tripura, Uttarakhand and Bengal.\n\n[byline: Aditi Tandon]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Himachal, in far and mountainous northern India, has not been a state that has reported JE virus infections previously. The JE virus transmission season has begun in India and most cases occur in north eastern India, mainly in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Assam states. Although a vaccine is available, there is no indication that the 2 patients had been vaccinated or whether a vaccination campaign is planned. Because vector control is difficult and expensive, vaccination is a more effective preventive measure.\n\nFrequently, in reports of JE cases in India, acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of undefined etiology is often mentioned with JE cases, a minority of those hospitalized. In the above 2 cases, AES is not mentioned but their JE virus etiology was laboratory confirmed.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299, and a Healthmap of Himachal Pradesh State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/304. - India (02): (UP), typhus 20180416.5749050\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.5550774\n2017\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (RJ) 20171113.5441846\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (UP) 20170807.5234297\n.................................................sb/sh/ty/ao/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "nipah virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dharampur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tripura", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Haryana", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Goa", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Meghalaya", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Shimla", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kerala", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "IGMC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maharashta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jharkhand", "country": "India"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Telangana", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Karnataka", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nagaland", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5862346", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5862346", "date": "2018-06-07 15:15:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (06): (HIMACHAL PRADESH)\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2018 12:40 AM\nSource: The Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.tribuneindia.com/news/himachal/je-virus-two-children-test-positive/600679.html\n\n\nThe Centre [source does not specify further. - Mod.SH] on [Tue 5 Jun 2018] confirmed the outbreak of Japanese encephalitis in Himachal, with 2 children from Solan district testing positive for the mosquitoborne viral infection of the brain.\n\nBoth children are currently in Indira Gandhi Medical Hospital, Shimla. One, a 3 year old boy from Dharampur is critical and on ventilator support. The other, a 6 year old boy from Dhalli is also under intensive care. Altogether, 7 Solan kids were referred to the IGMC, Shimla, with symptoms of viral infection, but 5 were discharged.\n\nHealth secretary Preeti Sudan told The Tribune that she had spoken to the state's principal health secretary, and directed teams from the National Centre for Disease Control and the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme to be sent to Himachal for detailed investigations into the cause of the infection.\n\nThe state surveillance officer under the Integrated Disease Control Programme had spotted symptoms of febrile illness in 7 children of Solan district and referred them to the IGMC, Shimla, suspecting Nipah virus. Their samples were sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, to rule out Nipah and 2 of these instead tested positive for JE. \"Blood samples of these 2 children have tested positive for JE. We have now sent their cerebrospinal fluid samples to the NIV, Pune, for further investigation,\" a Health Ministry official said.\n\nHimachal has never reported JE. This is the 1st time the state has seen cases of the virus which kills 220 children under 15 pan-India every year on an average. The highest mortality rate from JE is in Uttar Pradesh where children's deaths in Gorakhpur recently sent shock waves all over the country. These deaths were primarily attributed to JE aggravated by poor healthcare facilities.\n\nSince 2010, India has seen 10 893 JE cases and 1756 deaths, a mortality rate of 17 per cent.\n\nJE has no cure. There's a preventive vaccine the government now offers under routine immunisation plan. The management of JE-infected children to minimise chances of death is the main line of care.\n\nA central multi-sectoral team rushed to Himachal will now determine whether JE infection in the state is indigenous or imported. Domestic pigs and wild birds carry the JE virus mostly transmitted by mosquitoes found around paddy fields. Mosquitoes get the infection by feeding on diseased domestic pigs and wild birds. They then further transmit the JE virus to humans.\n\n\"Central experts will have to trace the virus host and its vector -- the mosquito -- in Solan for the infection to be notified as endemic. They will also interview the local population to rule out more cases. If the virus and vector are not traced, the virus could have been imported. That possibility will then have to be determined,\" a ministry official said.\n\nHimachal, the home state of health minister JP Nadda, is the 23rd state to be affected by the deadly JE virus now. Others are Andhra Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Delhi, Goa, Haryana, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashta, Manipur, Meghalaya, Nagaland, Odisha, Punjab, Tamil Nadu, Telangana, Tripura, Uttarakhand and Bengal.\n\n[byline: Aditi Tandon]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Himachal, in far and mountainous northern India, has not been a state that has reported JE virus infections previously. The JE virus transmission season has begun in India and most cases occur in north eastern India, mainly in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Assam states. Although a vaccine is available, there is no indication that the 2 patients had been vaccinated or whether a vaccination campaign is planned. Because vector control is difficult and expensive, vaccination is a more effective preventive measure.\n\nFrequently, in reports of JE cases in India, acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of undefined etiology is often mentioned with JE cases, a minority of those hospitalized. In the above 2 cases, AES is not mentioned but their JE virus etiology was laboratory confirmed.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299, and a Healthmap of Himachal Pradesh State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/304. - One, a 3 year old boy from Dharampur is critical and on ventilator support. The other, a 6 year old boy from Dhalli is also under intensive care. There's a preventive vaccine the government now offers under routine immunisation plan. Domestic pigs and wild birds carry the JE virus mostly transmitted by mosquitoes found around paddy fields. Mosquitoes get the infection by feeding on diseased domestic pigs and wild birds. They then further transmit the JE virus to humans.\n\n\"Central experts will have to trace the virus host and its vector -- the mosquito -- in Solan for the infection to be notified as endemic. They will also interview the local population to rule out more cases. If the virus and vector are not traced, the virus could have been imported. That possibility will then have to be determined,\" a ministry official said.\n\nHimachal, the home state of health minister JP Nadda, is the 23rd state to be affected by the deadly JE virus now. Others are Andhra Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Delhi, Goa, Haryana, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashta, Manipur, Meghalaya, Nagaland, Odisha, Punjab, Tamil Nadu, Telangana, Tripura, Uttarakhand and Bengal.\n\n[byline: Aditi Tandon]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Himachal, in far and mountainous northern India, has not been a state that has reported JE virus infections previously. Although a vaccine is available, there is no indication that the 2 patients had been vaccinated or whether a vaccination campaign is planned. India (12): (UP) 20170807.5234297\n.................................................sb/sh/ty/ao/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "nipah virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dharampur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tripura", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Haryana", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - India (06): (HP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5844658", "date": "2018-06-07 15:15:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (06): (HIMACHAL PRADESH)\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Jun 2018 12:40 AM\nSource: The Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.tribuneindia.com/news/himachal/je-virus-two-children-test-positive/600679.html\n\n\nThe Centre [source does not specify further. - Mod.SH] on [Tue 5 Jun 2018] confirmed the outbreak of Japanese encephalitis in Himachal, with 2 children from Solan district testing positive for the mosquitoborne viral infection of the brain.\n\nBoth children are currently in Indira Gandhi Medical Hospital, Shimla. One, a 3 year old boy from Dharampur is critical and on ventilator support. The other, a 6 year old boy from Dhalli is also under intensive care. Altogether, 7 Solan kids were referred to the IGMC, Shimla, with symptoms of viral infection, but 5 were discharged.\n\nHealth secretary Preeti Sudan told The Tribune that she had spoken to the state's principal health secretary, and directed teams from the National Centre for Disease Control and the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme to be sent to Himachal for detailed investigations into the cause of the infection.\n\nThe state surveillance officer under the Integrated Disease Control Programme had spotted symptoms of febrile illness in 7 children of Solan district and referred them to the IGMC, Shimla, suspecting Nipah virus. Their samples were sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, to rule out Nipah and 2 of these instead tested positive for JE. \"Blood samples of these 2 children have tested positive for JE. We have now sent their cerebrospinal fluid samples to the NIV, Pune, for further investigation,\" a Health Ministry official said.\n\nHimachal has never reported JE. This is the 1st time the state has seen cases of the virus which kills 220 children under 15 pan-India every year on an average. The highest mortality rate from JE is in Uttar Pradesh where children's deaths in Gorakhpur recently sent shock waves all over the country. These deaths were primarily attributed to JE aggravated by poor healthcare facilities.\n\nSince 2010, India has seen 10 893 JE cases and 1756 deaths, a mortality rate of 17 per cent.\n\nJE has no cure. There's a preventive vaccine the government now offers under routine immunisation plan. The management of JE-infected children to minimise chances of death is the main line of care.\n\nA central multi-sectoral team rushed to Himachal will now determine whether JE infection in the state is indigenous or imported. Domestic pigs and wild birds carry the JE virus mostly transmitted by mosquitoes found around paddy fields. Mosquitoes get the infection by feeding on diseased domestic pigs and wild birds. They then further transmit the JE virus to humans.\n\n\"Central experts will have to trace the virus host and its vector -- the mosquito -- in Solan for the infection to be notified as endemic. They will also interview the local population to rule out more cases. If the virus and vector are not traced, the virus could have been imported. That possibility will then have to be determined,\" a ministry official said.\n\nHimachal, the home state of health minister JP Nadda, is the 23rd state to be affected by the deadly JE virus now. Others are Andhra Pradesh, Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Delhi, Goa, Haryana, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashta, Manipur, Meghalaya, Nagaland, Odisha, Punjab, Tamil Nadu, Telangana, Tripura, Uttarakhand and Bengal.\n\n[byline: Aditi Tandon]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Himachal, in far and mountainous northern India, has not been a state that has reported JE virus infections previously. The JE virus transmission season has begun in India and most cases occur in north eastern India, mainly in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Assam states. Although a vaccine is available, there is no indication that the 2 patients had been vaccinated or whether a vaccination campaign is planned. Because vector control is difficult and expensive, vaccination is a more effective preventive measure.\n\nFrequently, in reports of JE cases in India, acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) of undefined etiology is often mentioned with JE cases, a minority of those hospitalized. In the above 2 cases, AES is not mentioned but their JE virus etiology was laboratory confirmed.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299, and a Healthmap of Himachal Pradesh State, India: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/304. - India (12): (UP) 20170807.5234297\n.................................................sb/sh/ty/ao/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "nipah virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dharampur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tripura", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Haryana", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - India (05): (KL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5840545", "date": "2018-04-16 13:15:31", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (02): (UTTAR PRUDISH), TYPHUS\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 4 Apr 2018\nSource: Journal of Medical Entomology [edited]\nhttps://academic.oup.com/jme/advance-article/doi/10.1093/jme/tjy042/4955586\n\n\nManoj Murhekar, Jeromie Wesley, Vivian Thangaraj, Mahima Mittal, Nivedita Gupta. Acute Encephalitis Syndrome in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India: Changing Etiological Understanding.\n\nAbstract\nSeasonal outbreaks of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with high case fatality have been occurring in Gorakhpur division in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India, for more than 3 decades. Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) accounted for less than 10 percent of AES cases, while the etiology of the remaining cases remained largely unknown. Investigations conducted during the 2014 and 2015 outbreaks indicated _Orientia tsutsugamushi_ (Haruo Hayashi 1920) (Norio Ogata 1929) Tamura et al. 1995 (Rickettsiales: Rickettsiaceae) as the etiology in about 60 percent of AES cases. Hospital-based surveillance studies indicated that about 1/5th of the patients with acute febrile illness [AFI] were due to scrub typhus. Further studies are required to identify the etiology of about 1/3rd of AES cases that test negative for scrub typhus, JEV, or dengue.\n\nConclusions and way forward\nThe evidence available since 2014 indicates _O. tustsugamushi_ as the leading etiology of AES cases, accounting for over 60 percent of AES cases. In contrast, during this period, JEV accounted for only about 10 percent AES cases. The key strategies for AES control in the region needs to include 1) reducing incidence by maintaining high coverage of JEV vaccine as well as removing the misconception of vaccinators about simultaneous administration of vaccines, 2) administering doxycycline/Azithromycin to suspected scrub typhus patients attending peripheral health facilities, thereby preventing the progression of AFI to AES, and 3) reducing mortality by administering Azithromycin to all hospitalized AES patients. ICMR [Indian Council of Medical Research] has initiated several studies in the region to understand the epidemiology of scrub typhus. These include 1) entomological studies to characterize mite species present on rodents, 2) serological and molecular studies on rodent sera and mite pools for documenting _O. tsutsugamushi_ infection, 3) surveys to estimate the sero-prevalence of antibodies against _O. tsutsugamushi_ in human population, 4) studies to identify risk factors for acquiring scrub typhus, and 5) studies to identify factors associated with the progression of febrile illness to AES.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Occurrence of encephalitis cases in northeastern India, and especially in Uttar Pradesh state, has been a significant public health problem for many years. A report cited in an earlier ProMED-mail post (Japanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.5550774) stated that in 2017, there were 4759 acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases with 595 deaths. JE cases in 2017 were 677 with 81 deaths. This came after the health department claimed it had carried out a mass immunization campaign in 38 AES-JE endemic districts in May and June [2017], covering over 9.1 million children in the age group of 1-15 years.\n\nAlthough Japanese encephalitis virus is endemic in Uttar Pradesh state and other areas in eastern India, it is frequently shown to be responsible for a minor proportion of encephalitis cases in children, the majority being classified as AES of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Various etiological agents have been proposed in recent years as responsible for AES cases. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, lychee fruit consumption and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). Recently, scrub typhus has been implicated in many AES cases. The above retrospective study indicates that scrub typhus may be responsible for the majority of AES cases. The rationale for posting this published report of retrospective studies is that one hopes that these findings may stimulate prospective studies by ICMR and other scientists as the season for occurrence of encephalitis cases in children is now beginning in northeastern India and many cases of encephalitis in children are likely to occur again this year [2018].\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142 and Uttar Pradesh State, India at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322. - INDIA (02): (UTTAR PRUDISH), TYPHUS\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 4 Apr 2018\nSource: Journal of Medical Entomology [edited]\nhttps://academic.oup.com/jme/advance-article/doi/10.1093/jme/tjy042/4955586\n\n\nManoj Murhekar, Jeromie Wesley, Vivian Thangaraj, Mahima Mittal, Nivedita Gupta. Acute Encephalitis Syndrome in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India: Changing Etiological Understanding.\n\nAbstract\nSeasonal outbreaks of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with high case fatality have been occurring in Gorakhpur division in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India, for more than 3 decades. Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) accounted for less than 10 percent of AES cases, while the etiology of the remaining cases remained largely unknown. Investigations conducted during the 2014 and 2015 outbreaks indicated _Orientia tsutsugamushi_ (Haruo Hayashi 1920) (Norio Ogata 1929) Tamura et al. 1995 (Rickettsiales: Rickettsiaceae) as the etiology in about 60 percent of AES cases. Hospital-based surveillance studies indicated that about 1/5th of the patients with acute febrile illness [AFI] were due to scrub typhus. Further studies are required to identify the etiology of about 1/3rd of AES cases that test negative for scrub typhus, JEV, or dengue.\n\nConclusions and way forward\nThe evidence available since 2014 indicates _O. tustsugamushi_ as the leading etiology of AES cases, accounting for over 60 percent of AES cases. In contrast, during this period, JEV accounted for only about 10 percent AES cases. The key strategies for AES control in the region needs to include 1) reducing incidence by maintaining high coverage of JEV vaccine as well as removing the misconception of vaccinators about simultaneous administration of vaccines, 2) administering doxycycline/Azithromycin to suspected scrub typhus patients attending peripheral health facilities, thereby preventing the progression of AFI to AES, and 3) reducing mortality by administering Azithromycin to all hospitalized AES patients. ICMR [Indian Council of Medical Research] has initiated several studies in the region to understand the epidemiology of scrub typhus. These include 1) entomological studies to characterize mite species present on rodents, 2) serological and molecular studies on rodent sera and mite pools for documenting _O. tsutsugamushi_ infection, 3) surveys to estimate the sero-prevalence of antibodies against _O. tsutsugamushi_ in human population, 4) studies to identify risk factors for acquiring scrub typhus, and 5) studies to identify factors associated with the progression of febrile illness to AES.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Occurrence of encephalitis cases in northeastern India, and especially in Uttar Pradesh state, has been a significant public health problem for many years. A report cited in an earlier ProMED-mail post (Japanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.5550774) stated that in 2017, there were 4759 acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases with 595 deaths. JE cases in 2017 were 677 with 81 deaths. This came after the health department claimed it had carried out a mass immunization campaign in 38 AES-JE endemic districts in May and June [2017], covering over 9.1 million children in the age group of 1-15 years.\n\nAlthough Japanese encephalitis virus is endemic in Uttar Pradesh state and other areas in eastern India, it is frequently shown to be responsible for a minor proportion of encephalitis cases in children, the majority being classified as AES of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Various etiological agents have been proposed in recent years as responsible for AES cases. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, lychee fruit consumption and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). Recently, scrub typhus has been implicated in many AES cases. The above retrospective study indicates that scrub typhus may be responsible for the majority of AES cases. The rationale for posting this published report of retrospective studies is that one hopes that these findings may stimulate prospective studies by ICMR and other scientists as the season for occurrence of encephalitis cases in children is now beginning in northeastern India and many cases of encephalitis in children are likely to occur again this year [2018].\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142 and Uttar Pradesh State, India at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322. - INDIA (02): (UTTAR PRUDISH), TYPHUS\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 4 Apr 2018\nSource: Journal of Medical Entomology [edited]\nhttps://academic.oup.com/jme/advance-article/doi/10.1093/jme/tjy042/4955586\n\n\nManoj Murhekar, Jeromie Wesley, Vivian Thangaraj, Mahima Mittal, Nivedita Gupta. Acute Encephalitis Syndrome in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India: Changing Etiological Understanding.\n\nAbstract\nSeasonal outbreaks of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with high case fatality have been occurring in Gorakhpur division in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India, for more than 3 decades. Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) accounted for less than 10 percent of AES cases, while the etiology of the remaining cases remained largely unknown. Investigations conducted during the 2014 and 2015 outbreaks indicated _Orientia tsutsugamushi_ (Haruo Hayashi 1920) (Norio Ogata 1929) Tamura et al. 1995 (Rickettsiales: Rickettsiaceae) as the etiology in about 60 percent of AES cases. In contrast, during this period, JEV accounted for only about 10 percent AES cases. These include 1) entomological studies to characterize mite species present on rodents, 2) serological and molecular studies on rodent sera and mite pools for documenting _O. tsutsugamushi_ infection, 3) surveys to estimate the sero-prevalence of antibodies against _O. tsutsugamushi_ in human population, 4) studies to identify risk factors for acquiring scrub typhus, and 5) studies to identify factors associated with the progression of febrile illness to AES.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Occurrence of encephalitis cases in northeastern India, and especially in Uttar Pradesh state, has been a significant public health problem for many years. A report cited in an earlier ProMED-mail post (Japanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.5550774) stated that in 2017, there were 4759 acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases with 595 deaths. JE cases in 2017 were 677 with 81 deaths. This came after the health department claimed it had carried out a mass immunization campaign in 38 AES-JE endemic districts in May and June [2017], covering over 9.1 million children in the age group of 1-15 years.\n\nAlthough Japanese encephalitis virus is endemic in Uttar Pradesh state and other areas in eastern India, it is frequently shown to be responsible for a minor proportion of encephalitis cases in children, the majority being classified as AES of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Various etiological agents have been proposed in recent years as responsible for AES cases. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, lychee fruit consumption and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_).
