India (22): (UP) 20171010.5369812\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (UP), RFI 20170916.5320148\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (UP) 20170902.5290553\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): comment 20170830.5283261\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (UP) 20170825.5273513\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (UP) 20170825.5273513\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (UP) AES due to scrub typhus 20170817.5255252\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14) 20170816.5252801\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (UP) 20170807.5234297\n.................................................ty/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "4759-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "UP", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5749050", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (UP), typhus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5749050", "date": "2018-04-16 13:15:31", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (02): (UTTAR PRUDISH), TYPHUS\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 4 Apr 2018\nSource: Journal of Medical Entomology [edited]\nhttps://academic.oup.com/jme/advance-article/doi/10.1093/jme/tjy042/4955586\n\n\nManoj Murhekar, Jeromie Wesley, Vivian Thangaraj, Mahima Mittal, Nivedita Gupta. Acute Encephalitis Syndrome in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India: Changing Etiological Understanding.\n\nAbstract\nSeasonal outbreaks of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with high case fatality have been occurring in Gorakhpur division in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India, for more than 3 decades. Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) accounted for less than 10 percent of AES cases, while the etiology of the remaining cases remained largely unknown. Investigations conducted during the 2014 and 2015 outbreaks indicated _Orientia tsutsugamushi_ (Haruo Hayashi 1920) (Norio Ogata 1929) Tamura et al. 1995 (Rickettsiales: Rickettsiaceae) as the etiology in about 60 percent of AES cases. Hospital-based surveillance studies indicated that about 1/5th of the patients with acute febrile illness [AFI] were due to scrub typhus. Further studies are required to identify the etiology of about 1/3rd of AES cases that test negative for scrub typhus, JEV, or dengue.\n\nConclusions and way forward\nThe evidence available since 2014 indicates _O. tustsugamushi_ as the leading etiology of AES cases, accounting for over 60 percent of AES cases. In contrast, during this period, JEV accounted for only about 10 percent AES cases. The key strategies for AES control in the region needs to include 1) reducing incidence by maintaining high coverage of JEV vaccine as well as removing the misconception of vaccinators about simultaneous administration of vaccines, 2) administering doxycycline/Azithromycin to suspected scrub typhus patients attending peripheral health facilities, thereby preventing the progression of AFI to AES, and 3) reducing mortality by administering Azithromycin to all hospitalized AES patients. ICMR [Indian Council of Medical Research] has initiated several studies in the region to understand the epidemiology of scrub typhus. These include 1) entomological studies to characterize mite species present on rodents, 2) serological and molecular studies on rodent sera and mite pools for documenting _O. tsutsugamushi_ infection, 3) surveys to estimate the sero-prevalence of antibodies against _O. tsutsugamushi_ in human population, 4) studies to identify risk factors for acquiring scrub typhus, and 5) studies to identify factors associated with the progression of febrile illness to AES.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Occurrence of encephalitis cases in northeastern India, and especially in Uttar Pradesh state, has been a significant public health problem for many years. A report cited in an earlier ProMED-mail post (Japanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.5550774) stated that in 2017, there were 4759 acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases with 595 deaths. JE cases in 2017 were 677 with 81 deaths. This came after the health department claimed it had carried out a mass immunization campaign in 38 AES-JE endemic districts in May and June [2017], covering over 9.1 million children in the age group of 1-15 years.\n\nAlthough Japanese encephalitis virus is endemic in Uttar Pradesh state and other areas in eastern India, it is frequently shown to be responsible for a minor proportion of encephalitis cases in children, the majority being classified as AES of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Various etiological agents have been proposed in recent years as responsible for AES cases. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, lychee fruit consumption and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). Recently, scrub typhus has been implicated in many AES cases. The above retrospective study indicates that scrub typhus may be responsible for the majority of AES cases. The rationale for posting this published report of retrospective studies is that one hopes that these findings may stimulate prospective studies by ICMR and other scientists as the season for occurrence of encephalitis cases in children is now beginning in northeastern India and many cases of encephalitis in children are likely to occur again this year [2018].\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142 and Uttar Pradesh State, India at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5466854", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (26): (MH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5466854", "date": "2018-04-16 13:15:31", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (02): (UTTAR PRUDISH), TYPHUS\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 4 Apr 2018\nSource: Journal of Medical Entomology [edited]\nhttps://academic.oup.com/jme/advance-article/doi/10.1093/jme/tjy042/4955586\n\n\nManoj Murhekar, Jeromie Wesley, Vivian Thangaraj, Mahima Mittal, Nivedita Gupta. Acute Encephalitis Syndrome in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India: Changing Etiological Understanding.\n\nAbstract\nSeasonal outbreaks of acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with high case fatality have been occurring in Gorakhpur division in Eastern Uttar Pradesh, India, for more than 3 decades. Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) accounted for less than 10 percent of AES cases, while the etiology of the remaining cases remained largely unknown. Investigations conducted during the 2014 and 2015 outbreaks indicated _Orientia tsutsugamushi_ (Haruo Hayashi 1920) (Norio Ogata 1929) Tamura et al. 1995 (Rickettsiales: Rickettsiaceae) as the etiology in about 60 percent of AES cases. Hospital-based surveillance studies indicated that about 1/5th of the patients with acute febrile illness [AFI] were due to scrub typhus. Further studies are required to identify the etiology of about 1/3rd of AES cases that test negative for scrub typhus, JEV, or dengue.\n\nConclusions and way forward\nThe evidence available since 2014 indicates _O. tustsugamushi_ as the leading etiology of AES cases, accounting for over 60 percent of AES cases. In contrast, during this period, JEV accounted for only about 10 percent AES cases. The key strategies for AES control in the region needs to include 1) reducing incidence by maintaining high coverage of JEV vaccine as well as removing the misconception of vaccinators about simultaneous administration of vaccines, 2) administering doxycycline/Azithromycin to suspected scrub typhus patients attending peripheral health facilities, thereby preventing the progression of AFI to AES, and 3) reducing mortality by administering Azithromycin to all hospitalized AES patients. ICMR [Indian Council of Medical Research] has initiated several studies in the region to understand the epidemiology of scrub typhus. These include 1) entomological studies to characterize mite species present on rodents, 2) serological and molecular studies on rodent sera and mite pools for documenting _O. tsutsugamushi_ infection, 3) surveys to estimate the sero-prevalence of antibodies against _O. tsutsugamushi_ in human population, 4) studies to identify risk factors for acquiring scrub typhus, and 5) studies to identify factors associated with the progression of febrile illness to AES.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Occurrence of encephalitis cases in northeastern India, and especially in Uttar Pradesh state, has been a significant public health problem for many years. A report cited in an earlier ProMED-mail post (Japanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.5550774) stated that in 2017, there were 4759 acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases with 595 deaths. JE cases in 2017 were 677 with 81 deaths. This came after the health department claimed it had carried out a mass immunization campaign in 38 AES-JE endemic districts in May and June [2017], covering over 9.1 million children in the age group of 1-15 years.\n\nAlthough Japanese encephalitis virus is endemic in Uttar Pradesh state and other areas in eastern India, it is frequently shown to be responsible for a minor proportion of encephalitis cases in children, the majority being classified as AES of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe determination of the etiology or etiologies of AES has been confusing and elusive. Various etiological agents have been proposed in recent years as responsible for AES cases. AES has continued to be attributed to a variety of etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, lychee fruit consumption and scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_). Recently, scrub typhus has been implicated in many AES cases. The above retrospective study indicates that scrub typhus may be responsible for the majority of AES cases. The rationale for posting this published report of retrospective studies is that one hopes that these findings may stimulate prospective studies by ICMR and other scientists as the season for occurrence of encephalitis cases in children is now beginning in northeastern India and many cases of encephalitis in children are likely to occur again this year [2018].\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142 and Uttar Pradesh State, India at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (KA, UP) 20180110.5550774\n2017\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (RJ) 20171113.5441846\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (UP) 20171106.54263192011\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (UP) 20171010.5369812\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (UP), RFI 20170916.5320148\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (UP) 20170902.5290553\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): comment 20170830.5283261\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (UP) 20170825.5273513\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (UP) 20170825.5273513\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (UP) AES due to scrub typhus 20170817.5255252\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14) 20170816.5252801\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (UP) 20170807.5234297\n.................................................ty/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "4759-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "UP", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "KA", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5452732", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (25): (MP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5452732", "date": "2017-09-28 15:35:35", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (21): (MAHARASHTRA)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 27 Sep 2017, 11:57 PM IST\nSource: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/woman-with-je-citys-fourth-case-in-11-months/articleshow/60861880.cms\n\n\nAlready struggling to rein in the rising number of dengue and chikungunya cases, residents must now gear up to combat another mosquito-borne disease; Japanese encephalitis (JE). Though pigs and wild birds are the primary carriers of the JE virus, it is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected mosquito.\n\nRecently, the doctors at D Y Patil hospital in Pimpri had sent the blood sample of a 49-year-old woman to National Institute of Virology (NIV) for tests, and the sample tested positive for Japanese encephalitis. The patient is a resident of village Bhose (Khed taluka), in Pune district.\n\nThis is the 4th JE case recorded in Pune in the last 11 months. On [16 Jun 2017], a 10-month-old child from Kondhwa had tested positive for JE. Prior to that, 2 students in Pune had tested positive for JE in November and December last year [2016].\n\n\"The woman suffered from fever and convulsions. She was admitted to D Y Patil Medical College and hospital on [4 Sep 2017]. Her blood sample tested positive for JE antibodies (IgM) at NIV on [20 Sep 2017]. She is currently undergoing treatment at the hospital's intensive care unit (ICU),\" said district malaria officer Suresh Dhekle. The woman belongs to the family of ironsmiths. \"She has 3 children and a husband. All other family members are healthy. We have carried out fever surveillance in the village and have not found any other fever patient,\" Dhekle added.\n\nState surveillance officer Pradip Awate said, \"This is the 2nd case in Pune this year [2017] and 4th since November 2016. We have stepped up surveillance in and around the patient's home.\"\n\nExperts said the spread of the disease was a cause for concern as it indicates that the virus was circulating in a wider geographical area. In the past, JE cases were mainly reported from the state's eastern districts, including Chandrapur, Gondia, Bhandara, Nagpur and Gadchiroli.\n\n[Byline: Umesh Isalkar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE cases are relatively uncommon in this area. There were 2 JE cases confirmed in Pune in December 2016 (see Japanese encephalitis & other - India (39): (MA) 20161223.4720235). Avoidance of mosquito bites as is usually recommended is prudent, but vaccination is the best protective measure. The virus is endemic in north western India with birds as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifiers. The _Culex_ mosquito vectors can become very abundant seasonally, breeding in wetlands. Vector control is difficult.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gondia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Pune district", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5380964", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Monkeypox - Africa (09): Nigeria, hospital cases NOT, other states' cases susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5380964", "date": "2017-09-28 15:35:35", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (21): (MAHARASHTRA)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 27 Sep 2017, 11:57 PM IST\nSource: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/woman-with-je-citys-fourth-case-in-11-months/articleshow/60861880.cms\n\n\nAlready struggling to rein in the rising number of dengue and chikungunya cases, residents must now gear up to combat another mosquito-borne disease; Japanese encephalitis (JE). Though pigs and wild birds are the primary carriers of the JE virus, it is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected mosquito.\n\nRecently, the doctors at D Y Patil hospital in Pimpri had sent the blood sample of a 49-year-old woman to National Institute of Virology (NIV) for tests, and the sample tested positive for Japanese encephalitis. The patient is a resident of village Bhose (Khed taluka), in Pune district.\n\nThis is the 4th JE case recorded in Pune in the last 11 months. On [16 Jun 2017], a 10-month-old child from Kondhwa had tested positive for JE. Prior to that, 2 students in Pune had tested positive for JE in November and December last year [2016].\n\n\"The woman suffered from fever and convulsions. She was admitted to D Y Patil Medical College and hospital on [4 Sep 2017]. Her blood sample tested positive for JE antibodies (IgM) at NIV on [20 Sep 2017]. She is currently undergoing treatment at the hospital's intensive care unit (ICU),\" said district malaria officer Suresh Dhekle. The woman belongs to the family of ironsmiths. \"She has 3 children and a husband. All other family members are healthy. We have carried out fever surveillance in the village and have not found any other fever patient,\" Dhekle added.\n\nState surveillance officer Pradip Awate said, \"This is the 2nd case in Pune this year [2017] and 4th since November 2016. We have stepped up surveillance in and around the patient's home.\"\n\nExperts said the spread of the disease was a cause for concern as it indicates that the virus was circulating in a wider geographical area. In the past, JE cases were mainly reported from the state's eastern districts, including Chandrapur, Gondia, Bhandara, Nagpur and Gadchiroli.\n\n[Byline: Umesh Isalkar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE cases are relatively uncommon in this area. There were 2 JE cases confirmed in Pune in December 2016 (see Japanese encephalitis & other - India (39): (MA) 20161223.4720235). Avoidance of mosquito bites as is usually recommended is prudent, but vaccination is the best protective measure. The virus is endemic in north western India with birds as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifiers. The _Culex_ mosquito vectors can become very abundant seasonally, breeding in wetlands. Vector control is difficult.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gondia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Pune district", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5290553", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis and other - India (19): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5290553", "date": "2017-09-28 15:35:35", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (21): (MAHARASHTRA)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 27 Sep 2017, 11:57 PM IST\nSource: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/woman-with-je-citys-fourth-case-in-11-months/articleshow/60861880.cms\n\n\nAlready struggling to rein in the rising number of dengue and chikungunya cases, residents must now gear up to combat another mosquito-borne disease; Japanese encephalitis (JE). Though pigs and wild birds are the primary carriers of the JE virus, it is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected mosquito.\n\nRecently, the doctors at D Y Patil hospital in Pimpri had sent the blood sample of a 49-year-old woman to National Institute of Virology (NIV) for tests, and the sample tested positive for Japanese encephalitis. The patient is a resident of village Bhose (Khed taluka), in Pune district.\n\nThis is the 4th JE case recorded in Pune in the last 11 months. On [16 Jun 2017], a 10-month-old child from Kondhwa had tested positive for JE. Prior to that, 2 students in Pune had tested positive for JE in November and December last year [2016].\n\n\"The woman suffered from fever and convulsions. She was admitted to D Y Patil Medical College and hospital on [4 Sep 2017]. Her blood sample tested positive for JE antibodies (IgM) at NIV on [20 Sep 2017]. She is currently undergoing treatment at the hospital's intensive care unit (ICU),\" said district malaria officer Suresh Dhekle. The woman belongs to the family of ironsmiths. \"She has 3 children and a husband. All other family members are healthy. We have carried out fever surveillance in the village and have not found any other fever patient,\" Dhekle added.\n\nState surveillance officer Pradip Awate said, \"This is the 2nd case in Pune this year [2017] and 4th since November 2016. We have stepped up surveillance in and around the patient's home.\"\n\nExperts said the spread of the disease was a cause for concern as it indicates that the virus was circulating in a wider geographical area. In the past, JE cases were mainly reported from the state's eastern districts, including Chandrapur, Gondia, Bhandara, Nagpur and Gadchiroli.\n\n[Byline: Umesh Isalkar]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE cases are relatively uncommon in this area. There were 2 JE cases confirmed in Pune in December 2016 (see Japanese encephalitis & other - India (39): (MA) 20161223.4720235). Avoidance of mosquito bites as is usually recommended is prudent, but vaccination is the best protective measure. The virus is endemic in north western India with birds as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifiers. The _Culex_ mosquito vectors can become very abundant seasonally, breeding in wetlands. Vector control is difficult.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gondia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Pune district", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5283261", "headline": "PRO/AH> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (18): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5283261", "date": "2017-08-07 23:29:24", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (12): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 7 Aug 2017\nSource: Nyoooz [edited]\nhttps://www.nyoooz.com/news/lucknow/888765/hospitals-brace-for-encephalitis-season-in-cm-yogi-adityanaths-constituency-gorakhpur/\n\n\nCM Yogi Adityanath's Lok Sabha constituency of Gorakhpur has witnessed at least 114 deaths due to acute encephalitis syndrome [AES] this year [2017].\n\nAccording to the Newspaper, AES is an umbrella classification under which comes the diseases Japanese encephalitis (JE), water-borne encephalitis, and scrub typhus, among others.\n\nAs a Member of Parliament, Adityanath had actively raised the issue. In the last 2 days, 16 new cases of AES and 3 deaths were reported from Baba Raghav Das (BRD) Medical College, the largest in the district. However, the hospital and district health officials are claiming that the situation is much better than in the previous years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the Gorakhpur district, and eastern Uttar Pradesh state generally, have been localities of many cases of JE and AES in recent years, this is the 1st report from those locations this year (2017).\n\nAs with cases of encephalitis in Uttar Pradesh and other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus infections and are classified as AES with undetermined etiology. AES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined.\n\nThe above report does not indicate whether JE vaccination campaigns have been active there this year [2017]. Other etiologies for AES, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_), lychee fruit consumption, and agricultural-related toxicants have been proposed. The above report does not indicate what the etiologies of the AES cases might be. Getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of India can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306. AES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined.\n\nThe above report does not indicate whether JE vaccination campaigns have been active there this year [2017]. Other etiologies for AES, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_), lychee fruit consumption, and agricultural-related toxicants have been proposed. The above report does not indicate what the etiologies of the AES cases might be. INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5255252", "headline": "PRO/AH> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (UP) AES due to scrub typhus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5255252", "date": "2017-08-07 23:29:24", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (12): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 7 Aug 2017\nSource: Nyoooz [edited]\nhttps://www.nyoooz.com/news/lucknow/888765/hospitals-brace-for-encephalitis-season-in-cm-yogi-adityanaths-constituency-gorakhpur/\n\n\nCM Yogi Adityanath's Lok Sabha constituency of Gorakhpur has witnessed at least 114 deaths due to acute encephalitis syndrome [AES] this year [2017].\n\nAccording to the Newspaper, AES is an umbrella classification under which comes the diseases Japanese encephalitis (JE), water-borne encephalitis, and scrub typhus, among others.\n\nAs a Member of Parliament, Adityanath had actively raised the issue. In the last 2 days, 16 new cases of AES and 3 deaths were reported from Baba Raghav Das (BRD) Medical College, the largest in the district. However, the hospital and district health officials are claiming that the situation is much better than in the previous years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the Gorakhpur district, and eastern Uttar Pradesh state generally, have been localities of many cases of JE and AES in recent years, this is the 1st report from those locations this year (2017).\n\nAs with cases of encephalitis in Uttar Pradesh and other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus infections and are classified as AES with undetermined etiology. AES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined.\n\nThe above report does not indicate whether JE vaccination campaigns have been active there this year [2017]. Other etiologies for AES, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_), lychee fruit consumption, and agricultural-related toxicants have been proposed. The above report does not indicate what the etiologies of the AES cases might be. Getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of India can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306. INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5229244", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5229244", "date": "2017-06-20 21:58:45", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (05): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jun 2017\nSource: New India Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jun/19/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-scare-stalks-odisha-1618361.html\n\n\nAcute encephalitis syndrome (AES) has come back to haunt the state health administration. It has affected 313 persons, mostly children, and claimed 10 lives in Odisha till the end of May this year [2017].\n\nWhile 3 deaths have been reported from Khurda district and 2 from Balasore, one each has died in Kendrapara, Jajpur, Nayagarh, Puri and Sambalpur.\n\nAs per the statistics available from the directorate of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP), no deaths have been reported from Japanese encephalitis (JE); though 313 AES cases have been diagnosed so far, 2 have been found to be JE positive.\n\nOdisha is, in fact, the 4th state -- after Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Assam -- which has recorded the maximum number of deaths due to AES. Uttar Pradesh has registered the highest number, 56 deaths, followed by 49 in WB and 32 in Assam. Though Tamil Nadu has registered the highest at 401 cases, no deaths have been reported in the southern state this year [2017].\n\nJoint Director of Health Services (NVBDCP) Dr MM Pradhan said AES is a growing concern in the country, as it is a clinical neurologic manifestation caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins.\n\n\"Management of AES including JE is essentially symptomatic. It is important to identify early warning signs and refer patients to health facilities for treatment to reduce morbidity and mortality. Health workers have been educated for 1st line management of such cases at the grassroots level,\" he said.\n\nThere are many AES-causing viruses for which neither vaccines nor medicines are available. In many cases, people affected with AES suffer from brain aspiration [meaning unclear - Mod.JH] and edema, which develop as a result of an inflammatory reaction in brain. It is difficult to survive if such cases are not treated early.\n\nThe Health Department has alerted people to remain cautious, as early detection and treatment are 2 possible methods to put a check on AES. \"Since there is no particular medicine for the disease, we are adopting symptomatic treatment. Awareness activities have also been increased and health workers deployed at the periphery to spread awareness,\" Dr Pradhan said.\n\nAfter the spurt in AES and JE cases last year [2016], 10 sentinel laboratories were set up in the state for immediate diagnosis of blood samples. These laboratories have been provided with JE kits supplied by the Pune-based National Institute of Virology.\n\nThe Health authorities have also planned to train all treating paediatric specialists to deal with encephalitis cases. They will be imparted training at AIIMS next month [June 2017].\n\nLast year [2016], out of 1096 AES cases, 115 persons died of AES, and 42 children died of JE. Most of the cases were reported from Malkangiri district. Along with Malkangiri, mass vaccination was carried out in Mayurbhanj, Keonjhar and Jajpur districts in campaign mode. The state government has written to the Centre for Vaccination in the rest of the 13 districts that have reported AES cases in the past.\n\n[Byline: Hemant Kumar Rout]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The JE virus transmission season is beginning in northeastern India. Odisha state is endemic for Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, and cases occur there frequently. As with cases of encephalitis mentioned above and in other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus and are classified as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with undetermined etiology.\n\nAES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. As mentioned in many previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. Although JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus ( _O. tsutsugamushi_) and lychee fruit consumption, have been proposed. Getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and for Odisha state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/315. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (OR) 20170604.5082374\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (PB) 20170421.4984702\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (BR) 20170402.4942606\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR) 20160725.4368952\n.................................................ty/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2017-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00", "2037-03-15 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2034-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khurda", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Puri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "India"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kendrapara", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jajpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Keonjhar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mayurbhanj", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Nayagarh", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Malkangiri", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5216309", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - Asia: India (MN) Bangladesh (RP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5216309", "date": "2017-06-20 21:58:45", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (05): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jun 2017\nSource: New India Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jun/19/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-scare-stalks-odisha-1618361.html\n\n\nAcute encephalitis syndrome (AES) has come back to haunt the state health administration. It has affected 313 persons, mostly children, and claimed 10 lives in Odisha till the end of May this year [2017].\n\nWhile 3 deaths have been reported from Khurda district and 2 from Balasore, one each has died in Kendrapara, Jajpur, Nayagarh, Puri and Sambalpur.\n\nAs per the statistics available from the directorate of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP), no deaths have been reported from Japanese encephalitis (JE); though 313 AES cases have been diagnosed so far, 2 have been found to be JE positive.\n\nOdisha is, in fact, the 4th state -- after Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Assam -- which has recorded the maximum number of deaths due to AES. Uttar Pradesh has registered the highest number, 56 deaths, followed by 49 in WB and 32 in Assam. Though Tamil Nadu has registered the highest at 401 cases, no deaths have been reported in the southern state this year [2017].\n\nJoint Director of Health Services (NVBDCP) Dr MM Pradhan said AES is a growing concern in the country, as it is a clinical neurologic manifestation caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins.\n\n\"Management of AES including JE is essentially symptomatic. It is important to identify early warning signs and refer patients to health facilities for treatment to reduce morbidity and mortality. Health workers have been educated for 1st line management of such cases at the grassroots level,\" he said.\n\nThere are many AES-causing viruses for which neither vaccines nor medicines are available. In many cases, people affected with AES suffer from brain aspiration [meaning unclear - Mod.JH] and edema, which develop as a result of an inflammatory reaction in brain. It is difficult to survive if such cases are not treated early.\n\nThe Health Department has alerted people to remain cautious, as early detection and treatment are 2 possible methods to put a check on AES. \"Since there is no particular medicine for the disease, we are adopting symptomatic treatment. Awareness activities have also been increased and health workers deployed at the periphery to spread awareness,\" Dr Pradhan said.\n\nAfter the spurt in AES and JE cases last year [2016], 10 sentinel laboratories were set up in the state for immediate diagnosis of blood samples. These laboratories have been provided with JE kits supplied by the Pune-based National Institute of Virology.\n\nThe Health authorities have also planned to train all treating paediatric specialists to deal with encephalitis cases. They will be imparted training at AIIMS next month [June 2017].\n\nLast year [2016], out of 1096 AES cases, 115 persons died of AES, and 42 children died of JE. Most of the cases were reported from Malkangiri district. Along with Malkangiri, mass vaccination was carried out in Mayurbhanj, Keonjhar and Jajpur districts in campaign mode. The state government has written to the Centre for Vaccination in the rest of the 13 districts that have reported AES cases in the past.\n\n[Byline: Hemant Kumar Rout]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The JE virus transmission season is beginning in northeastern India. Odisha state is endemic for Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, and cases occur there frequently. As with cases of encephalitis mentioned above and in other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus and are classified as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with undetermined etiology.\n\nAES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. As mentioned in many previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. Although JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus ( _O. tsutsugamushi_) and lychee fruit consumption, have been proposed. Getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and for Odisha state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/315. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (OR) 20170604.5082374\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (PB) 20170421.4984702\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (BR) 20170402.4942606\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (30): (OR,TR) 20161107.4611260\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (29): (OR) 20161103.4603728\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (28): (OR), human, porcine 20161029.4594738\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (27): (OR) 20161026.4585027\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (26): (OR) RFI 20161024.4579882\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (25): (OR) 20161020.4572206\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (OR,UP) 20161014.4558708\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (OR) 20161007.4544425\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (OR) 20161006.4539552\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (OR) 20161005.4537043\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (OR) 20161003.4533613\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (OR) 20160929.4525723\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR) 20160725.4368952\n.................................................ty/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2017-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00", "2037-03-15 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2034-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khurda", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Puri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "India"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kendrapara", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jajpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Keonjhar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mayurbhanj", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - It has affected 313 persons, mostly children, and claimed 10 lives in Odisha till the end of May this year [2017].\n\nWhile 3 deaths have been reported from Khurda district and 2 from Balasore, one each has died in Kendrapara, Jajpur, Nayagarh, Puri and Sambalpur.\n\nAs per the statistics available from the directorate of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP), no deaths have been reported from Japanese encephalitis (JE); though 313 AES cases have been diagnosed so far, 2 have been found to be JE positive.\n\nOdisha is, in fact, the 4th state -- after Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Assam -- which has recorded the maximum number of deaths due to AES. Uttar Pradesh has registered the highest number, 56 deaths, followed by 49 in WB and 32 in Assam. Though Tamil Nadu has registered the highest at 401 cases, no deaths have been reported in the southern state this year [2017].\n\nJoint Director of Health Services (NVBDCP) Dr MM Pradhan said AES is a growing concern in the country, as it is a clinical neurologic manifestation caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins.\n\n\"Management of AES including JE is essentially symptomatic. It is important to identify early warning signs and refer patients to health facilities for treatment to reduce morbidity and mortality. Health workers have been educated for 1st line management of such cases at the grassroots level,\" he said.\n\nThere are many AES-causing viruses for which neither vaccines nor medicines are available. In many cases, people affected with AES suffer from brain aspiration [meaning unclear - Mod.JH] and edema, which develop as a result of an inflammatory reaction in brain. It is difficult to survive if such cases are not treated early.\n\nThe Health Department has alerted people to remain cautious, as early detection and treatment are 2 possible methods to put a check on AES. \"Since there is no particular medicine for the disease, we are adopting symptomatic treatment. Awareness activities have also been increased and health workers deployed at the periphery to spread awareness,\" Dr Pradhan said.\n\nAfter the spurt in AES and JE cases last year [2016], 10 sentinel laboratories were set up in the state for immediate diagnosis of blood samples. These laboratories have been provided with JE kits supplied by the Pune-based National Institute of Virology.\n\nThe Health authorities have also planned to train all treating paediatric specialists to deal with encephalitis cases. They will be imparted training at AIIMS next month [June 2017].\n\nLast year [2016], out of 1096 AES cases, 115 persons died of AES, and 42 children died of JE. Most of the cases were reported from Malkangiri district. Along with Malkangiri, mass vaccination was carried out in Mayurbhanj, Keonjhar and Jajpur districts in campaign mode. The state government has written to the Centre for Vaccination in the rest of the 13 districts that have reported AES cases in the past.\n\n[Byline: Hemant Kumar Rout]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The JE virus transmission season is beginning in northeastern India. Odisha state is endemic for Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, and cases occur there frequently. As with cases of encephalitis mentioned above and in other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus and are classified as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with undetermined etiology.\n\nAES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. As mentioned in many previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. Although JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus ( _O. tsutsugamushi_) and lychee fruit consumption, have been proposed. India (09): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5170870", "date": "2017-06-20 21:58:45", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (05): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jun 2017\nSource: New India Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jun/19/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-scare-stalks-odisha-1618361.html\n\n\nAcute encephalitis syndrome (AES) has come back to haunt the state health administration. It has affected 313 persons, mostly children, and claimed 10 lives in Odisha till the end of May this year [2017].\n\nWhile 3 deaths have been reported from Khurda district and 2 from Balasore, one each has died in Kendrapara, Jajpur, Nayagarh, Puri and Sambalpur.\n\nAs per the statistics available from the directorate of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP), no deaths have been reported from Japanese encephalitis (JE); though 313 AES cases have been diagnosed so far, 2 have been found to be JE positive.\n\nOdisha is, in fact, the 4th state -- after Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Assam -- which has recorded the maximum number of deaths due to AES. Uttar Pradesh has registered the highest number, 56 deaths, followed by 49 in WB and 32 in Assam. Though Tamil Nadu has registered the highest at 401 cases, no deaths have been reported in the southern state this year [2017].\n\nJoint Director of Health Services (NVBDCP) Dr MM Pradhan said AES is a growing concern in the country, as it is a clinical neurologic manifestation caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins.\n\n\"Management of AES including JE is essentially symptomatic. It is important to identify early warning signs and refer patients to health facilities for treatment to reduce morbidity and mortality. Health workers have been educated for 1st line management of such cases at the grassroots level,\" he said.\n\nThere are many AES-causing viruses for which neither vaccines nor medicines are available. In many cases, people affected with AES suffer from brain aspiration [meaning unclear - Mod.JH] and edema, which develop as a result of an inflammatory reaction in brain. It is difficult to survive if such cases are not treated early.\n\nThe Health Department has alerted people to remain cautious, as early detection and treatment are 2 possible methods to put a check on AES. \"Since there is no particular medicine for the disease, we are adopting symptomatic treatment. Awareness activities have also been increased and health workers deployed at the periphery to spread awareness,\" Dr Pradhan said.\n\nAfter the spurt in AES and JE cases last year [2016], 10 sentinel laboratories were set up in the state for immediate diagnosis of blood samples. These laboratories have been provided with JE kits supplied by the Pune-based National Institute of Virology.\n\nThe Health authorities have also planned to train all treating paediatric specialists to deal with encephalitis cases. They will be imparted training at AIIMS next month [June 2017].\n\nLast year [2016], out of 1096 AES cases, 115 persons died of AES, and 42 children died of JE. Most of the cases were reported from Malkangiri district. Along with Malkangiri, mass vaccination was carried out in Mayurbhanj, Keonjhar and Jajpur districts in campaign mode. The state government has written to the Centre for Vaccination in the rest of the 13 districts that have reported AES cases in the past.\n\n[Byline: Hemant Kumar Rout]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The JE virus transmission season is beginning in northeastern India. Odisha state is endemic for Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, and cases occur there frequently. As with cases of encephalitis mentioned above and in other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus and are classified as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with undetermined etiology.\n\nAES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. As mentioned in many previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. Although JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus ( _O. tsutsugamushi_) and lychee fruit consumption, have been proposed. Getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and for Odisha state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/315. - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR) 20160725.4368952\n.................................................ty/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2017-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00", "2037-03-15 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2034-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khurda", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Puri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "India"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kendrapara", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jajpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Keonjhar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mayurbhanj", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - India (08): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5162050", "date": "2017-06-20 21:58:45", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (05): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jun 2017\nSource: New India Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jun/19/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-scare-stalks-odisha-1618361.html\n\n\nAcute encephalitis syndrome (AES) has come back to haunt the state health administration. It has affected 313 persons, mostly children, and claimed 10 lives in Odisha till the end of May this year [2017].\n\nWhile 3 deaths have been reported from Khurda district and 2 from Balasore, one each has died in Kendrapara, Jajpur, Nayagarh, Puri and Sambalpur.\n\nAs per the statistics available from the directorate of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP), no deaths have been reported from Japanese encephalitis (JE); though 313 AES cases have been diagnosed so far, 2 have been found to be JE positive.\n\nOdisha is, in fact, the 4th state -- after Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Assam -- which has recorded the maximum number of deaths due to AES. Uttar Pradesh has registered the highest number, 56 deaths, followed by 49 in WB and 32 in Assam. Though Tamil Nadu has registered the highest at 401 cases, no deaths have been reported in the southern state this year [2017].\n\nJoint Director of Health Services (NVBDCP) Dr MM Pradhan said AES is a growing concern in the country, as it is a clinical neurologic manifestation caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins.\n\n\"Management of AES including JE is essentially symptomatic. It is important to identify early warning signs and refer patients to health facilities for treatment to reduce morbidity and mortality. Health workers have been educated for 1st line management of such cases at the grassroots level,\" he said.\n\nThere are many AES-causing viruses for which neither vaccines nor medicines are available. In many cases, people affected with AES suffer from brain aspiration [meaning unclear - Mod.JH] and edema, which develop as a result of an inflammatory reaction in brain. It is difficult to survive if such cases are not treated early.\n\nThe Health Department has alerted people to remain cautious, as early detection and treatment are 2 possible methods to put a check on AES. \"Since there is no particular medicine for the disease, we are adopting symptomatic treatment. Awareness activities have also been increased and health workers deployed at the periphery to spread awareness,\" Dr Pradhan said.\n\nAfter the spurt in AES and JE cases last year [2016], 10 sentinel laboratories were set up in the state for immediate diagnosis of blood samples. These laboratories have been provided with JE kits supplied by the Pune-based National Institute of Virology.\n\nThe Health authorities have also planned to train all treating paediatric specialists to deal with encephalitis cases. They will be imparted training at AIIMS next month [June 2017].\n\nLast year [2016], out of 1096 AES cases, 115 persons died of AES, and 42 children died of JE. Most of the cases were reported from Malkangiri district. Along with Malkangiri, mass vaccination was carried out in Mayurbhanj, Keonjhar and Jajpur districts in campaign mode. The state government has written to the Centre for Vaccination in the rest of the 13 districts that have reported AES cases in the past.\n\n[Byline: Hemant Kumar Rout]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The JE virus transmission season is beginning in northeastern India. Odisha state is endemic for Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, and cases occur there frequently. As with cases of encephalitis mentioned above and in other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus and are classified as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with undetermined etiology.\n\nAES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. As mentioned in many previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. Although JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus ( _O. tsutsugamushi_) and lychee fruit consumption, have been proposed. Getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and for Odisha state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/315. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (OR) 20170604.5082374\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (PB) 20170421.4984702\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (BR) 20170402.4942606\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (30): (OR,TR) 20161107.4611260\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (29): (OR) 20161103.4603728\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (28): (OR), human, porcine 20161029.4594738\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (27): (OR) 20161026.4585027\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (26): (OR) RFI 20161024.4579882\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (25): (OR) 20161020.4572206\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (OR,UP) 20161014.4558708\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (OR) 20161007.4544425\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (OR) 20161006.4539552\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (OR) 20161005.4537043\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (OR) 20161003.4533613\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (OR) 20160929.4525723\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR) 20160725.4368952\n.................................................ty/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2017-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00", "2037-03-15 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2034-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khurda", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Puri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "India"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kendrapara", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jajpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Keonjhar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mayurbhanj", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - Uttar Pradesh has registered the highest number, 56 deaths, followed by 49 in WB and 32 in Assam. Though Tamil Nadu has registered the highest at 401 cases, no deaths have been reported in the southern state this year [2017].\n\nJoint Director of Health Services (NVBDCP) Dr MM Pradhan said AES is a growing concern in the country, as it is a clinical neurologic manifestation caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins.\n\n\"Management of AES including JE is essentially symptomatic. It is important to identify early warning signs and refer patients to health facilities for treatment to reduce morbidity and mortality. Health workers have been educated for 1st line management of such cases at the grassroots level,\" he said.\n\nThere are many AES-causing viruses for which neither vaccines nor medicines are available. In many cases, people affected with AES suffer from brain aspiration [meaning unclear - Mod.JH] and edema, which develop as a result of an inflammatory reaction in brain. It is difficult to survive if such cases are not treated early.\n\nThe Health Department has alerted people to remain cautious, as early detection and treatment are 2 possible methods to put a check on AES. \"Since there is no particular medicine for the disease, we are adopting symptomatic treatment. Awareness activities have also been increased and health workers deployed at the periphery to spread awareness,\" Dr Pradhan said.\n\nAfter the spurt in AES and JE cases last year [2016], 10 sentinel laboratories were set up in the state for immediate diagnosis of blood samples. These laboratories have been provided with JE kits supplied by the Pune-based National Institute of Virology.\n\nThe Health authorities have also planned to train all treating paediatric specialists to deal with encephalitis cases. They will be imparted training at AIIMS next month [June 2017].\n\nLast year [2016], out of 1096 AES cases, 115 persons died of AES, and 42 children died of JE. Most of the cases were reported from Malkangiri district. Along with Malkangiri, mass vaccination was carried out in Mayurbhanj, Keonjhar and Jajpur districts in campaign mode. The state government has written to the Centre for Vaccination in the rest of the 13 districts that have reported AES cases in the past.\n\n[Byline: Hemant Kumar Rout]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The JE virus transmission season is beginning in northeastern India. As with cases of encephalitis mentioned above and in other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus and are classified as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with undetermined etiology.\n\nAES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. As mentioned in many previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. Although JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus ( _O. tsutsugamushi_) and lychee fruit consumption, have been proposed. India (06): (MH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5124128", "date": "2017-06-20 21:58:45", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (05): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jun 2017\nSource: New India Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jun/19/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-scare-stalks-odisha-1618361.html\n\n\nAcute encephalitis syndrome (AES) has come back to haunt the state health administration. It has affected 313 persons, mostly children, and claimed 10 lives in Odisha till the end of May this year [2017].\n\nWhile 3 deaths have been reported from Khurda district and 2 from Balasore, one each has died in Kendrapara, Jajpur, Nayagarh, Puri and Sambalpur.\n\nAs per the statistics available from the directorate of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP), no deaths have been reported from Japanese encephalitis (JE); though 313 AES cases have been diagnosed so far, 2 have been found to be JE positive.\n\nOdisha is, in fact, the 4th state -- after Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Assam -- which has recorded the maximum number of deaths due to AES. Uttar Pradesh has registered the highest number, 56 deaths, followed by 49 in WB and 32 in Assam. Though Tamil Nadu has registered the highest at 401 cases, no deaths have been reported in the southern state this year [2017].\n\nJoint Director of Health Services (NVBDCP) Dr MM Pradhan said AES is a growing concern in the country, as it is a clinical neurologic manifestation caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins.\n\n\"Management of AES including JE is essentially symptomatic. It is important to identify early warning signs and refer patients to health facilities for treatment to reduce morbidity and mortality. Health workers have been educated for 1st line management of such cases at the grassroots level,\" he said.\n\nThere are many AES-causing viruses for which neither vaccines nor medicines are available. In many cases, people affected with AES suffer from brain aspiration [meaning unclear - Mod.JH] and edema, which develop as a result of an inflammatory reaction in brain. It is difficult to survive if such cases are not treated early.\n\nThe Health Department has alerted people to remain cautious, as early detection and treatment are 2 possible methods to put a check on AES. \"Since there is no particular medicine for the disease, we are adopting symptomatic treatment. Awareness activities have also been increased and health workers deployed at the periphery to spread awareness,\" Dr Pradhan said.\n\nAfter the spurt in AES and JE cases last year [2016], 10 sentinel laboratories were set up in the state for immediate diagnosis of blood samples. These laboratories have been provided with JE kits supplied by the Pune-based National Institute of Virology.\n\nThe Health authorities have also planned to train all treating paediatric specialists to deal with encephalitis cases. They will be imparted training at AIIMS next month [June 2017].\n\nLast year [2016], out of 1096 AES cases, 115 persons died of AES, and 42 children died of JE. Most of the cases were reported from Malkangiri district. Along with Malkangiri, mass vaccination was carried out in Mayurbhanj, Keonjhar and Jajpur districts in campaign mode. The state government has written to the Centre for Vaccination in the rest of the 13 districts that have reported AES cases in the past.\n\n[Byline: Hemant Kumar Rout]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The JE virus transmission season is beginning in northeastern India. Odisha state is endemic for Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, and cases occur there frequently. As with cases of encephalitis mentioned above and in other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus and are classified as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with undetermined etiology.\n\nAES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. As mentioned in many previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. Although JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus ( _O. tsutsugamushi_) and lychee fruit consumption, have been proposed. Getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and for Odisha state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/315. - India (05): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5119632", "date": "2017-06-20 21:58:45", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (05): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jun 2017\nSource: New India Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jun/19/acute-encephalitis-syndrome-scare-stalks-odisha-1618361.html\n\n\nAcute encephalitis syndrome (AES) has come back to haunt the state health administration. It has affected 313 persons, mostly children, and claimed 10 lives in Odisha till the end of May this year [2017].\n\nWhile 3 deaths have been reported from Khurda district and 2 from Balasore, one each has died in Kendrapara, Jajpur, Nayagarh, Puri and Sambalpur.\n\nAs per the statistics available from the directorate of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP), no deaths have been reported from Japanese encephalitis (JE); though 313 AES cases have been diagnosed so far, 2 have been found to be JE positive.\n\nOdisha is, in fact, the 4th state -- after Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Assam -- which has recorded the maximum number of deaths due to AES. Uttar Pradesh has registered the highest number, 56 deaths, followed by 49 in WB and 32 in Assam. Though Tamil Nadu has registered the highest at 401 cases, no deaths have been reported in the southern state this year [2017].\n\nJoint Director of Health Services (NVBDCP) Dr MM Pradhan said AES is a growing concern in the country, as it is a clinical neurologic manifestation caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins.\n\n\"Management of AES including JE is essentially symptomatic. It is important to identify early warning signs and refer patients to health facilities for treatment to reduce morbidity and mortality. Health workers have been educated for 1st line management of such cases at the grassroots level,\" he said.\n\nThere are many AES-causing viruses for which neither vaccines nor medicines are available. In many cases, people affected with AES suffer from brain aspiration [meaning unclear - Mod.JH] and edema, which develop as a result of an inflammatory reaction in brain. It is difficult to survive if such cases are not treated early.\n\nThe Health Department has alerted people to remain cautious, as early detection and treatment are 2 possible methods to put a check on AES. \"Since there is no particular medicine for the disease, we are adopting symptomatic treatment. Awareness activities have also been increased and health workers deployed at the periphery to spread awareness,\" Dr Pradhan said.\n\nAfter the spurt in AES and JE cases last year [2016], 10 sentinel laboratories were set up in the state for immediate diagnosis of blood samples. These laboratories have been provided with JE kits supplied by the Pune-based National Institute of Virology.\n\nThe Health authorities have also planned to train all treating paediatric specialists to deal with encephalitis cases. They will be imparted training at AIIMS next month [June 2017].\n\nLast year [2016], out of 1096 AES cases, 115 persons died of AES, and 42 children died of JE. Most of the cases were reported from Malkangiri district. Along with Malkangiri, mass vaccination was carried out in Mayurbhanj, Keonjhar and Jajpur districts in campaign mode. The state government has written to the Centre for Vaccination in the rest of the 13 districts that have reported AES cases in the past.\n\n[Byline: Hemant Kumar Rout]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The JE virus transmission season is beginning in northeastern India. Odisha state is endemic for Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, and cases occur there frequently. As with cases of encephalitis mentioned above and in other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus and are classified as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with undetermined etiology.\n\nAES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. As mentioned in many previous comments, the encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. Although JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus ( _O. tsutsugamushi_) and lychee fruit consumption, have been proposed. Getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and for Odisha state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/315. - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR) 20160725.4368952\n.................................................ty/msp/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2017-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00", "2037-03-15 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2034-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khurda", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Puri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Pune", "country": "India"}, {"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Kendrapara", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jajpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Keonjhar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mayurbhanj", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other -
