India (04): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5082374", "date": "2016-12-11 11:08:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (37): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Dec 2016 00:00 IST\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\nhttp://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-otherstates/Threat-of-JE-diminishing-in-Malkangiri-district/article16782086.ece\n\n\nNo new patient with encephalitis syndrome has been admitted in Malkangiri district headquarter hospital in the last 4 days, hinting that the threat of Japanese encephalitis (JE) is diminishing in this remote tribal district of Odisha.\n\nAs per reports, during past 3 months around 120 children have died due to lethal viral disease JE or by consumption of beans of _Cassia occidentalis_ locally known as 'bada chakunda'. Anthraquinone, a toxin found in _Cassia occidentalis_ was also alleged to be cause of encephalopathy and deaths among children.\n\nTo prevent deaths of children, the administration had decided to transport any child suffering from encephalitis syndrome to the district hospital as early as possible. For the 1st time in the last 3 months, no new patient with such syndrome has been admitted in the district hospital. \"It is surely a spark of hope for all in the district including government officials, physicians, health workers, teachers, anganwadi [government sponsored child-care and mother-care centers] workers, ASHA [foundation] volunteers, panchayat bodies [system of local governance], social workers, and even security personnel, who have worked relentless since September [2016] to check encephalitis deaths of innocent children in the district,\" said Malkangiri collector K Sudarshan Chakravarthy.\n\nAs per the office of Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO), Malkangiri, the 15-day-long mass vaccination of children is continuing successfully in the district since [5 Dec 2016]. Initially, children of all major schools in the district are being vaccinated.\n\nIn the next phase, all other children would be vaccinated through grassroot level community approach. A total of 218 027 children are to be vaccinated against JE in the district.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An 8 Dec 2016 report stated that about 84 percent of children had already been vaccinated by [Wed 7 Dec 2016], with 175 vaccination centres currently functioning in the district. Until now, the total deaths due to JE, acute encephalitis syndrome, and encephalopathy reached 103, which is below that of the most afflicted states like Uttar Pradesh with the highest (538 cases), West Bengal (229), and Assam (183). Confirmed reports said that JE alone accounted for 37 deaths (http://pragativadi.com/je-outbreak-control-govt/).\n\nThe absence of new cases is good news indeed. It is also good to learn that the childhood JE vaccination program has begun and will continue. An earlier report also indicated that the local populace is being advised to avoid consumption of _Cassia occidentalis_ seeds by children, although some local health officials doubted that the seeds were responsible for the acute encephalitis syndrome (non-JE but without specific diagnosis). One hopes that this outbreak has ended.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (PB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4984702", "date": "2016-12-11 11:08:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (37): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Dec 2016 00:00 IST\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\nhttp://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-otherstates/Threat-of-JE-diminishing-in-Malkangiri-district/article16782086.ece\n\n\nNo new patient with encephalitis syndrome has been admitted in Malkangiri district headquarter hospital in the last 4 days, hinting that the threat of Japanese encephalitis (JE) is diminishing in this remote tribal district of Odisha.\n\nAs per reports, during past 3 months around 120 children have died due to lethal viral disease JE or by consumption of beans of _Cassia occidentalis_ locally known as 'bada chakunda'. Anthraquinone, a toxin found in _Cassia occidentalis_ was also alleged to be cause of encephalopathy and deaths among children.\n\nTo prevent deaths of children, the administration had decided to transport any child suffering from encephalitis syndrome to the district hospital as early as possible. For the 1st time in the last 3 months, no new patient with such syndrome has been admitted in the district hospital. \"It is surely a spark of hope for all in the district including government officials, physicians, health workers, teachers, anganwadi [government sponsored child-care and mother-care centers] workers, ASHA [foundation] volunteers, panchayat bodies [system of local governance], social workers, and even security personnel, who have worked relentless since September [2016] to check encephalitis deaths of innocent children in the district,\" said Malkangiri collector K Sudarshan Chakravarthy.\n\nAs per the office of Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO), Malkangiri, the 15-day-long mass vaccination of children is continuing successfully in the district since [5 Dec 2016]. Initially, children of all major schools in the district are being vaccinated.\n\nIn the next phase, all other children would be vaccinated through grassroot level community approach. A total of 218 027 children are to be vaccinated against JE in the district.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An 8 Dec 2016 report stated that about 84 percent of children had already been vaccinated by [Wed 7 Dec 2016], with 175 vaccination centres currently functioning in the district. Until now, the total deaths due to JE, acute encephalitis syndrome, and encephalopathy reached 103, which is below that of the most afflicted states like Uttar Pradesh with the highest (538 cases), West Bengal (229), and Assam (183). Confirmed reports said that JE alone accounted for 37 deaths (http://pragativadi.com/je-outbreak-control-govt/).\n\nThe absence of new cases is good news indeed. It is also good to learn that the childhood JE vaccination program has begun and will continue. An earlier report also indicated that the local populace is being advised to avoid consumption of _Cassia occidentalis_ seeds by children, although some local health officials doubted that the seeds were responsible for the acute encephalitis syndrome (non-JE but without specific diagnosis). One hopes that this outbreak has ended.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4942606", "date": "2016-12-11 11:08:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (37): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Dec 2016 00:00 IST\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\nhttp://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-otherstates/Threat-of-JE-diminishing-in-Malkangiri-district/article16782086.ece\n\n\nNo new patient with encephalitis syndrome has been admitted in Malkangiri district headquarter hospital in the last 4 days, hinting that the threat of Japanese encephalitis (JE) is diminishing in this remote tribal district of Odisha.\n\nAs per reports, during past 3 months around 120 children have died due to lethal viral disease JE or by consumption of beans of _Cassia occidentalis_ locally known as 'bada chakunda'. Anthraquinone, a toxin found in _Cassia occidentalis_ was also alleged to be cause of encephalopathy and deaths among children.\n\nTo prevent deaths of children, the administration had decided to transport any child suffering from encephalitis syndrome to the district hospital as early as possible. For the 1st time in the last 3 months, no new patient with such syndrome has been admitted in the district hospital. \"It is surely a spark of hope for all in the district including government officials, physicians, health workers, teachers, anganwadi [government sponsored child-care and mother-care centers] workers, ASHA [foundation] volunteers, panchayat bodies [system of local governance], social workers, and even security personnel, who have worked relentless since September [2016] to check encephalitis deaths of innocent children in the district,\" said Malkangiri collector K Sudarshan Chakravarthy.\n\nAs per the office of Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO), Malkangiri, the 15-day-long mass vaccination of children is continuing successfully in the district since [5 Dec 2016]. Initially, children of all major schools in the district are being vaccinated.\n\nIn the next phase, all other children would be vaccinated through grassroot level community approach. A total of 218 027 children are to be vaccinated against JE in the district.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An 8 Dec 2016 report stated that about 84 percent of children had already been vaccinated by [Wed 7 Dec 2016], with 175 vaccination centres currently functioning in the district. Until now, the total deaths due to JE, acute encephalitis syndrome, and encephalopathy reached 103, which is below that of the most afflicted states like Uttar Pradesh with the highest (538 cases), West Bengal (229), and Assam (183). Confirmed reports said that JE alone accounted for 37 deaths (http://pragativadi.com/je-outbreak-control-govt/).\n\nThe absence of new cases is good news indeed. It is also good to learn that the childhood JE vaccination program has begun and will continue. An earlier report also indicated that the local populace is being advised to avoid consumption of _Cassia occidentalis_ seeds by children, although some local health officials doubted that the seeds were responsible for the acute encephalitis syndrome (non-JE but without specific diagnosis). One hopes that this outbreak has ended.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR) 20160725.4368952\n.................................................sb/ml/ty/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2037-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2034-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Cassia", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Malkangiri", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4733821", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (01): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4733821", "date": "2016-12-11 11:08:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (37): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Dec 2016 00:00 IST\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\nhttp://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-otherstates/Threat-of-JE-diminishing-in-Malkangiri-district/article16782086.ece\n\n\nNo new patient with encephalitis syndrome has been admitted in Malkangiri district headquarter hospital in the last 4 days, hinting that the threat of Japanese encephalitis (JE) is diminishing in this remote tribal district of Odisha.\n\nAs per reports, during past 3 months around 120 children have died due to lethal viral disease JE or by consumption of beans of _Cassia occidentalis_ locally known as 'bada chakunda'. Anthraquinone, a toxin found in _Cassia occidentalis_ was also alleged to be cause of encephalopathy and deaths among children.\n\nTo prevent deaths of children, the administration had decided to transport any child suffering from encephalitis syndrome to the district hospital as early as possible. For the 1st time in the last 3 months, no new patient with such syndrome has been admitted in the district hospital. \"It is surely a spark of hope for all in the district including government officials, physicians, health workers, teachers, anganwadi [government sponsored child-care and mother-care centers] workers, ASHA [foundation] volunteers, panchayat bodies [system of local governance], social workers, and even security personnel, who have worked relentless since September [2016] to check encephalitis deaths of innocent children in the district,\" said Malkangiri collector K Sudarshan Chakravarthy.\n\nAs per the office of Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO), Malkangiri, the 15-day-long mass vaccination of children is continuing successfully in the district since [5 Dec 2016]. Initially, children of all major schools in the district are being vaccinated.\n\nIn the next phase, all other children would be vaccinated through grassroot level community approach. A total of 218 027 children are to be vaccinated against JE in the district.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An 8 Dec 2016 report stated that about 84 percent of children had already been vaccinated by [Wed 7 Dec 2016], with 175 vaccination centres currently functioning in the district. Until now, the total deaths due to JE, acute encephalitis syndrome, and encephalopathy reached 103, which is below that of the most afflicted states like Uttar Pradesh with the highest (538 cases), West Bengal (229), and Assam (183). Confirmed reports said that JE alone accounted for 37 deaths (http://pragativadi.com/je-outbreak-control-govt/).\n\nThe absence of new cases is good news indeed. It is also good to learn that the childhood JE vaccination program has begun and will continue. An earlier report also indicated that the local populace is being advised to avoid consumption of _Cassia occidentalis_ seeds by children, although some local health officials doubted that the seeds were responsible for the acute encephalitis syndrome (non-JE but without specific diagnosis). One hopes that this outbreak has ended.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - Anthraquinone, a toxin found in _Cassia occidentalis_ was also alleged to be cause of encephalopathy and deaths among children.\n\nTo prevent deaths of children, the administration had decided to transport any child suffering from encephalitis syndrome to the district hospital as early as possible. Initially, children of all major schools in the district are being vaccinated.\n\nIn the next phase, all other children would be vaccinated through grassroot level community approach. A total of 218 027 children are to be vaccinated against JE in the district.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An 8 Dec 2016 report stated that about 84 percent of children had already been vaccinated by [Wed 7 Dec 2016], with 175 vaccination centres currently functioning in the district. Confirmed reports said that JE alone accounted for 37 deaths (http://pragativadi.com/je-outbreak-control-govt/).\n\nThe absence of new cases is good news indeed. It is also good to learn that the childhood JE vaccination program has begun and will continue. Anthraquinone, a toxin found in _Cassia occidentalis_ was also alleged to be cause of encephalopathy and deaths among children.\n\nTo prevent deaths of children, the administration had decided to transport any child suffering from encephalitis syndrome to the district hospital as early as possible. For the 1st time in the last 3 months, no new patient with such syndrome has been admitted in the district hospital. \"It is surely a spark of hope for all in the district including government officials, physicians, health workers, teachers, anganwadi [government sponsored child-care and mother-care centers] workers, ASHA [foundation] volunteers, panchayat bodies [system of local governance], social workers, and even security personnel, who have worked relentless since September [2016] to check encephalitis deaths of innocent children in the district,\" said Malkangiri collector K Sudarshan Chakravarthy.\n\nAs per the office of Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO), Malkangiri, the 15-day-long mass vaccination of children is continuing successfully in the district since [5 Dec 2016]. Initially, children of all major schools in the district are being vaccinated.\n\nIn the next phase, all other children would be vaccinated through grassroot level community approach. A total of 218 027 children are to be vaccinated against JE in the district.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An 8 Dec 2016 report stated that about 84 percent of children had already been vaccinated by [Wed 7 Dec 2016], with 175 vaccination centres currently functioning in the district. Until now, the total deaths due to JE, acute encephalitis syndrome, and encephalopathy reached 103, which is below that of the most afflicted states like Uttar Pradesh with the highest (538 cases), West Bengal (229), and Assam (183). Confirmed reports said that JE alone accounted for 37 deaths (http://pragativadi.com/je-outbreak-control-govt/).\n\nThe absence of new cases is good news indeed. It is also good to learn that the childhood JE vaccination program has begun and will continue. An earlier report also indicated that the local populace is being advised to avoid consumption of _Cassia occidentalis_ seeds by children, although some local health officials doubted that the seeds were responsible for the acute encephalitis syndrome (non-JE but without specific diagnosis). One hopes that this outbreak has ended.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - A total of 218 027 children are to be vaccinated against JE in the district.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An 8 Dec 2016 report stated that about 84 percent of children had already been vaccinated by [Wed 7 Dec 2016], with 175 vaccination centres currently functioning in the district. India (37): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4690188", "date": "2016-12-11 11:08:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (37): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Dec 2016 00:00 IST\nSource: The Hindu [edited]\nhttp://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-otherstates/Threat-of-JE-diminishing-in-Malkangiri-district/article16782086.ece\n\n\nNo new patient with encephalitis syndrome has been admitted in Malkangiri district headquarter hospital in the last 4 days, hinting that the threat of Japanese encephalitis (JE) is diminishing in this remote tribal district of Odisha.\n\nAs per reports, during past 3 months around 120 children have died due to lethal viral disease JE or by consumption of beans of _Cassia occidentalis_ locally known as 'bada chakunda'. Anthraquinone, a toxin found in _Cassia occidentalis_ was also alleged to be cause of encephalopathy and deaths among children.\n\nTo prevent deaths of children, the administration had decided to transport any child suffering from encephalitis syndrome to the district hospital as early as possible. For the 1st time in the last 3 months, no new patient with such syndrome has been admitted in the district hospital. \"It is surely a spark of hope for all in the district including government officials, physicians, health workers, teachers, anganwadi [government sponsored child-care and mother-care centers] workers, ASHA [foundation] volunteers, panchayat bodies [system of local governance], social workers, and even security personnel, who have worked relentless since September [2016] to check encephalitis deaths of innocent children in the district,\" said Malkangiri collector K Sudarshan Chakravarthy.\n\nAs per the office of Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO), Malkangiri, the 15-day-long mass vaccination of children is continuing successfully in the district since [5 Dec 2016]. Initially, children of all major schools in the district are being vaccinated.\n\nIn the next phase, all other children would be vaccinated through grassroot level community approach. A total of 218 027 children are to be vaccinated against JE in the district.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[An 8 Dec 2016 report stated that about 84 percent of children had already been vaccinated by [Wed 7 Dec 2016], with 175 vaccination centres currently functioning in the district. Until now, the total deaths due to JE, acute encephalitis syndrome, and encephalopathy reached 103, which is below that of the most afflicted states like Uttar Pradesh with the highest (538 cases), West Bengal (229), and Assam (183). Confirmed reports said that JE alone accounted for 37 deaths (http://pragativadi.com/je-outbreak-control-govt/).\n\nThe absence of new cases is good news indeed. It is also good to learn that the childhood JE vaccination program has begun and will continue. An earlier report also indicated that the local populace is being advised to avoid consumption of _Cassia occidentalis_ seeds by children, although some local health officials doubted that the seeds were responsible for the acute encephalitis syndrome (non-JE but without specific diagnosis). One hopes that this outbreak has ended.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR) 20160725.4368952\n.................................................sb/ml/ty/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2037-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-09-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-12-15 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2034-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "West Bengal", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Cassia", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Malkangiri", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4681756", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (36): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4681756", "date": "2016-11-03 10:08:36", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (29): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New cases\n[2] Vaccination training\n\n******\n[1] New cases\nDate: Thu 3 Nov 2016 01:36 IST\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttp://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/encephalitis-kills-74-kids-in-odisha-s-worst-outbreak/story-Zbu8jZmcLocScBhs1Oho8N.html\n\n\nOdisha's worst-ever encephalitis outbreak has killed 74 children in the Maoist-hit Malkangiri district, home to nearly 6.2 lakh [620 000] people, mostly from the Scheduled Castes and tribes like Bondas, Koyas, Porajas, and Didayis.\n\n\"Till [Mon 31 Oct 2016], 74 children have died, all from the Koya community. 47 of the deaths have been due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and 27 from Japanese encephalitis (JE),\" Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan, joint director of the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme in Odisha, said. \"It's the biggest outbreak in the district. We are studying why it is happening.\"\n\n\"All children in the district will be vaccinated against JE on [1 Dec 2016],\" Odisha director of health services Dr Chittaranjan Nayak said. \"The process of procuring the vaccines from the Centre, training the staff and the logistical assessment has begun.\"\n\nA single shot protects children for up to a year against the JE [virus] strain prevalent in India.\n\nWhile JE is a viral infection spread by mosquitoes, AES can be caused by a range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, chemicals, and toxins. Encephalitis is marked by inflammation of the brain's membrane that causes rapidly rising fever, headache, stiffness of the neck, disorientation, coma, seizures, spastic paralysis, and even death.\n\nOdisha first reported encephalitis cases in 2015, when 660 AES cases and 33 JE cases were detected. There were 4 deaths, 2 from each.\n\n\"Children in Malkangiri have never been vaccinated against JE because there were no cases till now,\" says Dr Nayak. Till [2 Oct 2016], India reported 7443 AES cases and 840 deaths, while JE has infected another 974 people and killed 167. Of these, 456 AES and 16 JE cases were from Odisha.\n\n[Byline: Sanchita Sharma]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of encephalitis cases in the district continues to slowly increase. This is the 2nd time that acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases have been mentioned. Until now, almost all the encephalitis cases have been attributed to JE virus infections. AES cases go undiagnosed. When JE virus infection is ruled out, other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease and lychee consumption, have been proposed. Until definitive etiologies of AES are identified, appropriate treatment and control measures cannot be implemented. One hopes that the studies that Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan mentioned will determine the etiologies involved.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY\n\n******\n[2] Vaccination training\nDate: Tue 2 Nov 2016\nSource: Prameya News7 [edited]\nhttp://www.prameyanews7.com/en/nov2016/odisha/35541/Training-to-vaccinators-for-JE-immunisation-begins-JE-immunisationOdisha.htm\n\n\nThe National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) authorities on [Wed 26 Oct 2016] started imparting training to nodal officers of 4 [Odisha] districts, Malkangiri, Koraput, Keonjhar, and Jajpur to carry out immunization programme to tackle deadly Japanese encephalitis (JE).\n\nThe deadly disease so far claimed the lives of 82 children in Malkangiri district. [According to the report above, less than half of these cases are due to JE virus infection. - Mod.TY]\n\nThe exact date of vaccination is yet to be decided by the NVBDCP, but it is believed that vaccination drive against Japanese encephalitis (JE), a dreadful disease, would be organised either in the last week of November or 1st week of December [2016].\n\nAs part of vaccination drive, children in the age group of 1-15 [years] would be covered across the 4 districts. Action plan has drawn for effective implementation of JE vaccination programme in these districts.\n\nVaccine camps would be set up in Government schools besides Anganwadi centres [Anganwadi centers provide basic health care in Indian villages. - Mod.TY]. Children in the age group of 1-15 years are prone to Japanese encephalitis attack and there is no medicine to cure this viral disease. Sources said JE vaccination is free from all side effects.\n\nIt is advised vaccinators not to administer JE vaccine for those children who are suffering from fever and infectious diseases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear why the vaccination initiative has waited over 3 months to be organized, while the number of fatal cases has gradually increased. It is good to see that training has finally begun, but the vaccination effort itself is still 3-4 weeks off. JE vaccination will not prevent occurrence of AES cases, but the significant number of JE virus infections with fatalities still justifies the vaccination effort. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (35): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4672510", "date": "2016-11-03 10:08:36", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (29): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New cases\n[2] Vaccination training\n\n******\n[1] New cases\nDate: Thu 3 Nov 2016 01:36 IST\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttp://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/encephalitis-kills-74-kids-in-odisha-s-worst-outbreak/story-Zbu8jZmcLocScBhs1Oho8N.html\n\n\nOdisha's worst-ever encephalitis outbreak has killed 74 children in the Maoist-hit Malkangiri district, home to nearly 6.2 lakh [620 000] people, mostly from the Scheduled Castes and tribes like Bondas, Koyas, Porajas, and Didayis.\n\n\"Till [Mon 31 Oct 2016], 74 children have died, all from the Koya community. 47 of the deaths have been due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and 27 from Japanese encephalitis (JE),\" Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan, joint director of the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme in Odisha, said. \"It's the biggest outbreak in the district. We are studying why it is happening.\"\n\n\"All children in the district will be vaccinated against JE on [1 Dec 2016],\" Odisha director of health services Dr Chittaranjan Nayak said. \"The process of procuring the vaccines from the Centre, training the staff and the logistical assessment has begun.\"\n\nA single shot protects children for up to a year against the JE [virus] strain prevalent in India.\n\nWhile JE is a viral infection spread by mosquitoes, AES can be caused by a range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, chemicals, and toxins. Encephalitis is marked by inflammation of the brain's membrane that causes rapidly rising fever, headache, stiffness of the neck, disorientation, coma, seizures, spastic paralysis, and even death.\n\nOdisha first reported encephalitis cases in 2015, when 660 AES cases and 33 JE cases were detected. There were 4 deaths, 2 from each.\n\n\"Children in Malkangiri have never been vaccinated against JE because there were no cases till now,\" says Dr Nayak. Till [2 Oct 2016], India reported 7443 AES cases and 840 deaths, while JE has infected another 974 people and killed 167. Of these, 456 AES and 16 JE cases were from Odisha.\n\n[Byline: Sanchita Sharma]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of encephalitis cases in the district continues to slowly increase. This is the 2nd time that acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases have been mentioned. Until now, almost all the encephalitis cases have been attributed to JE virus infections. AES cases go undiagnosed. When JE virus infection is ruled out, other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease and lychee consumption, have been proposed. Until definitive etiologies of AES are identified, appropriate treatment and control measures cannot be implemented. One hopes that the studies that Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan mentioned will determine the etiologies involved.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY\n\n******\n[2] Vaccination training\nDate: Tue 2 Nov 2016\nSource: Prameya News7 [edited]\nhttp://www.prameyanews7.com/en/nov2016/odisha/35541/Training-to-vaccinators-for-JE-immunisation-begins-JE-immunisationOdisha.htm\n\n\nThe National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) authorities on [Wed 26 Oct 2016] started imparting training to nodal officers of 4 [Odisha] districts, Malkangiri, Koraput, Keonjhar, and Jajpur to carry out immunization programme to tackle deadly Japanese encephalitis (JE).\n\nThe deadly disease so far claimed the lives of 82 children in Malkangiri district. [According to the report above, less than half of these cases are due to JE virus infection. - Mod.TY]\n\nThe exact date of vaccination is yet to be decided by the NVBDCP, but it is believed that vaccination drive against Japanese encephalitis (JE), a dreadful disease, would be organised either in the last week of November or 1st week of December [2016].\n\nAs part of vaccination drive, children in the age group of 1-15 [years] would be covered across the 4 districts. Action plan has drawn for effective implementation of JE vaccination programme in these districts.\n\nVaccine camps would be set up in Government schools besides Anganwadi centres [Anganwadi centers provide basic health care in Indian villages. - Mod.TY]. Children in the age group of 1-15 years are prone to Japanese encephalitis attack and there is no medicine to cure this viral disease. Sources said JE vaccination is free from all side effects.\n\nIt is advised vaccinators not to administer JE vaccine for those children who are suffering from fever and infectious diseases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear why the vaccination initiative has waited over 3 months to be organized, while the number of fatal cases has gradually increased. It is good to see that training has finally begun, but the vaccination effort itself is still 3-4 weeks off. JE vaccination will not prevent occurrence of AES cases, but the significant number of JE virus infections with fatalities still justifies the vaccination effort. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (34): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4663950", "date": "2016-11-03 10:08:36", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (29): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New cases\n[2] Vaccination training\n\n******\n[1] New cases\nDate: Thu 3 Nov 2016 01:36 IST\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttp://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/encephalitis-kills-74-kids-in-odisha-s-worst-outbreak/story-Zbu8jZmcLocScBhs1Oho8N.html\n\n\nOdisha's worst-ever encephalitis outbreak has killed 74 children in the Maoist-hit Malkangiri district, home to nearly 6.2 lakh [620 000] people, mostly from the Scheduled Castes and tribes like Bondas, Koyas, Porajas, and Didayis.\n\n\"Till [Mon 31 Oct 2016], 74 children have died, all from the Koya community. 47 of the deaths have been due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and 27 from Japanese encephalitis (JE),\" Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan, joint director of the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme in Odisha, said. \"It's the biggest outbreak in the district. We are studying why it is happening.\"\n\n\"All children in the district will be vaccinated against JE on [1 Dec 2016],\" Odisha director of health services Dr Chittaranjan Nayak said. \"The process of procuring the vaccines from the Centre, training the staff and the logistical assessment has begun.\"\n\nA single shot protects children for up to a year against the JE [virus] strain prevalent in India.\n\nWhile JE is a viral infection spread by mosquitoes, AES can be caused by a range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, chemicals, and toxins. Encephalitis is marked by inflammation of the brain's membrane that causes rapidly rising fever, headache, stiffness of the neck, disorientation, coma, seizures, spastic paralysis, and even death.\n\nOdisha first reported encephalitis cases in 2015, when 660 AES cases and 33 JE cases were detected. There were 4 deaths, 2 from each.\n\n\"Children in Malkangiri have never been vaccinated against JE because there were no cases till now,\" says Dr Nayak. Till [2 Oct 2016], India reported 7443 AES cases and 840 deaths, while JE has infected another 974 people and killed 167. Of these, 456 AES and 16 JE cases were from Odisha.\n\n[Byline: Sanchita Sharma]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of encephalitis cases in the district continues to slowly increase. This is the 2nd time that acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases have been mentioned. Until now, almost all the encephalitis cases have been attributed to JE virus infections. AES cases go undiagnosed. When JE virus infection is ruled out, other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease and lychee consumption, have been proposed. Until definitive etiologies of AES are identified, appropriate treatment and control measures cannot be implemented. One hopes that the studies that Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan mentioned will determine the etiologies involved.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY\n\n******\n[2] Vaccination training\nDate: Tue 2 Nov 2016\nSource: Prameya News7 [edited]\nhttp://www.prameyanews7.com/en/nov2016/odisha/35541/Training-to-vaccinators-for-JE-immunisation-begins-JE-immunisationOdisha.htm\n\n\nThe National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) authorities on [Wed 26 Oct 2016] started imparting training to nodal officers of 4 [Odisha] districts, Malkangiri, Koraput, Keonjhar, and Jajpur to carry out immunization programme to tackle deadly Japanese encephalitis (JE).\n\nThe deadly disease so far claimed the lives of 82 children in Malkangiri district. [According to the report above, less than half of these cases are due to JE virus infection. - Mod.TY]\n\nThe exact date of vaccination is yet to be decided by the NVBDCP, but it is believed that vaccination drive against Japanese encephalitis (JE), a dreadful disease, would be organised either in the last week of November or 1st week of December [2016].\n\nAs part of vaccination drive, children in the age group of 1-15 [years] would be covered across the 4 districts. Action plan has drawn for effective implementation of JE vaccination programme in these districts.\n\nVaccine camps would be set up in Government schools besides Anganwadi centres [Anganwadi centers provide basic health care in Indian villages. - Mod.TY]. Children in the age group of 1-15 years are prone to Japanese encephalitis attack and there is no medicine to cure this viral disease. Sources said JE vaccination is free from all side effects.\n\nIt is advised vaccinators not to administer JE vaccine for those children who are suffering from fever and infectious diseases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear why the vaccination initiative has waited over 3 months to be organized, while the number of fatal cases has gradually increased. It is good to see that training has finally begun, but the vaccination effort itself is still 3-4 weeks off. JE vaccination will not prevent occurrence of AES cases, but the significant number of JE virus infections with fatalities still justifies the vaccination effort. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (28): (OR), human, porcine 20161029.4594738\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (27): (OR) 20161026.4585027\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (26): (OR) RFI 20161024.4579882\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (25): (OR) 20161020.4572206\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (OR,UP) 20161014.4558708\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (OR) 20161007.4544425\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (OR) 20161006.4539552\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (OR) 20161005.4537043\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (OR) 20161003.4533613\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (OR) 20160929.4525723\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR) 20160725.4368952\n.................................................ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "7443-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Koraput", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bondas", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Koyas", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Malkangiri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jajpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Keonjhar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "anganwadi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Anganwadi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Porajas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4641400", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (33): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4641400", "date": "2016-11-03 10:08:36", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (29): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New cases\n[2] Vaccination training\n\n******\n[1] New cases\nDate: Thu 3 Nov 2016 01:36 IST\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttp://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/encephalitis-kills-74-kids-in-odisha-s-worst-outbreak/story-Zbu8jZmcLocScBhs1Oho8N.html\n\n\nOdisha's worst-ever encephalitis outbreak has killed 74 children in the Maoist-hit Malkangiri district, home to nearly 6.2 lakh [620 000] people, mostly from the Scheduled Castes and tribes like Bondas, Koyas, Porajas, and Didayis.\n\n\"Till [Mon 31 Oct 2016], 74 children have died, all from the Koya community. 47 of the deaths have been due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and 27 from Japanese encephalitis (JE),\" Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan, joint director of the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme in Odisha, said. \"It's the biggest outbreak in the district. We are studying why it is happening.\"\n\n\"All children in the district will be vaccinated against JE on [1 Dec 2016],\" Odisha director of health services Dr Chittaranjan Nayak said. \"The process of procuring the vaccines from the Centre, training the staff and the logistical assessment has begun.\"\n\nA single shot protects children for up to a year against the JE [virus] strain prevalent in India.\n\nWhile JE is a viral infection spread by mosquitoes, AES can be caused by a range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, chemicals, and toxins. Encephalitis is marked by inflammation of the brain's membrane that causes rapidly rising fever, headache, stiffness of the neck, disorientation, coma, seizures, spastic paralysis, and even death.\n\nOdisha first reported encephalitis cases in 2015, when 660 AES cases and 33 JE cases were detected. There were 4 deaths, 2 from each.\n\n\"Children in Malkangiri have never been vaccinated against JE because there were no cases till now,\" says Dr Nayak. Till [2 Oct 2016], India reported 7443 AES cases and 840 deaths, while JE has infected another 974 people and killed 167. Of these, 456 AES and 16 JE cases were from Odisha.\n\n[Byline: Sanchita Sharma]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of encephalitis cases in the district continues to slowly increase. This is the 2nd time that acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases have been mentioned. Until now, almost all the encephalitis cases have been attributed to JE virus infections. AES cases go undiagnosed. When JE virus infection is ruled out, other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease and lychee consumption, have been proposed. Until definitive etiologies of AES are identified, appropriate treatment and control measures cannot be implemented. One hopes that the studies that Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan mentioned will determine the etiologies involved.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY\n\n******\n[2] Vaccination training\nDate: Tue 2 Nov 2016\nSource: Prameya News7 [edited]\nhttp://www.prameyanews7.com/en/nov2016/odisha/35541/Training-to-vaccinators-for-JE-immunisation-begins-JE-immunisationOdisha.htm\n\n\nThe National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) authorities on [Wed 26 Oct 2016] started imparting training to nodal officers of 4 [Odisha] districts, Malkangiri, Koraput, Keonjhar, and Jajpur to carry out immunization programme to tackle deadly Japanese encephalitis (JE).\n\nThe deadly disease so far claimed the lives of 82 children in Malkangiri district. [According to the report above, less than half of these cases are due to JE virus infection. - Mod.TY]\n\nThe exact date of vaccination is yet to be decided by the NVBDCP, but it is believed that vaccination drive against Japanese encephalitis (JE), a dreadful disease, would be organised either in the last week of November or 1st week of December [2016].\n\nAs part of vaccination drive, children in the age group of 1-15 [years] would be covered across the 4 districts. Action plan has drawn for effective implementation of JE vaccination programme in these districts.\n\nVaccine camps would be set up in Government schools besides Anganwadi centres [Anganwadi centers provide basic health care in Indian villages. - Mod.TY]. Children in the age group of 1-15 years are prone to Japanese encephalitis attack and there is no medicine to cure this viral disease. Sources said JE vaccination is free from all side effects.\n\nIt is advised vaccinators not to administer JE vaccine for those children who are suffering from fever and infectious diseases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear why the vaccination initiative has waited over 3 months to be organized, while the number of fatal cases has gradually increased. It is good to see that training has finally begun, but the vaccination effort itself is still 3-4 weeks off. JE vaccination will not prevent occurrence of AES cases, but the significant number of JE virus infections with fatalities still justifies the vaccination effort. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (32): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4623814", "date": "2016-11-03 10:08:36", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (29): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New cases\n[2] Vaccination training\n\n******\n[1] New cases\nDate: Thu 3 Nov 2016 01:36 IST\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttp://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/encephalitis-kills-74-kids-in-odisha-s-worst-outbreak/story-Zbu8jZmcLocScBhs1Oho8N.html\n\n\nOdisha's worst-ever encephalitis outbreak has killed 74 children in the Maoist-hit Malkangiri district, home to nearly 6.2 lakh [620 000] people, mostly from the Scheduled Castes and tribes like Bondas, Koyas, Porajas, and Didayis.\n\n\"Till [Mon 31 Oct 2016], 74 children have died, all from the Koya community. 47 of the deaths have been due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and 27 from Japanese encephalitis (JE),\" Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan, joint director of the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme in Odisha, said. \"It's the biggest outbreak in the district. We are studying why it is happening.\"\n\n\"All children in the district will be vaccinated against JE on [1 Dec 2016],\" Odisha director of health services Dr Chittaranjan Nayak said. \"The process of procuring the vaccines from the Centre, training the staff and the logistical assessment has begun.\"\n\nA single shot protects children for up to a year against the JE [virus] strain prevalent in India.\n\nWhile JE is a viral infection spread by mosquitoes, AES can be caused by a range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, chemicals, and toxins. Encephalitis is marked by inflammation of the brain's membrane that causes rapidly rising fever, headache, stiffness of the neck, disorientation, coma, seizures, spastic paralysis, and even death.\n\nOdisha first reported encephalitis cases in 2015, when 660 AES cases and 33 JE cases were detected. There were 4 deaths, 2 from each.\n\n\"Children in Malkangiri have never been vaccinated against JE because there were no cases till now,\" says Dr Nayak. Till [2 Oct 2016], India reported 7443 AES cases and 840 deaths, while JE has infected another 974 people and killed 167. Of these, 456 AES and 16 JE cases were from Odisha.\n\n[Byline: Sanchita Sharma]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of encephalitis cases in the district continues to slowly increase. This is the 2nd time that acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases have been mentioned. Until now, almost all the encephalitis cases have been attributed to JE virus infections. AES cases go undiagnosed. When JE virus infection is ruled out, other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease and lychee consumption, have been proposed. Until definitive etiologies of AES are identified, appropriate treatment and control measures cannot be implemented. One hopes that the studies that Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan mentioned will determine the etiologies involved.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY\n\n******\n[2] Vaccination training\nDate: Tue 2 Nov 2016\nSource: Prameya News7 [edited]\nhttp://www.prameyanews7.com/en/nov2016/odisha/35541/Training-to-vaccinators-for-JE-immunisation-begins-JE-immunisationOdisha.htm\n\n\nThe National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) authorities on [Wed 26 Oct 2016] started imparting training to nodal officers of 4 [Odisha] districts, Malkangiri, Koraput, Keonjhar, and Jajpur to carry out immunization programme to tackle deadly Japanese encephalitis (JE).\n\nThe deadly disease so far claimed the lives of 82 children in Malkangiri district. [According to the report above, less than half of these cases are due to JE virus infection. - Mod.TY]\n\nThe exact date of vaccination is yet to be decided by the NVBDCP, but it is believed that vaccination drive against Japanese encephalitis (JE), a dreadful disease, would be organised either in the last week of November or 1st week of December [2016].\n\nAs part of vaccination drive, children in the age group of 1-15 [years] would be covered across the 4 districts. Action plan has drawn for effective implementation of JE vaccination programme in these districts.\n\nVaccine camps would be set up in Government schools besides Anganwadi centres [Anganwadi centers provide basic health care in Indian villages. - Mod.TY]. Children in the age group of 1-15 years are prone to Japanese encephalitis attack and there is no medicine to cure this viral disease. Sources said JE vaccination is free from all side effects.\n\nIt is advised vaccinators not to administer JE vaccine for those children who are suffering from fever and infectious diseases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear why the vaccination initiative has waited over 3 months to be organized, while the number of fatal cases has gradually increased. It is good to see that training has finally begun, but the vaccination effort itself is still 3-4 weeks off. JE vaccination will not prevent occurrence of AES cases, but the significant number of JE virus infections with fatalities still justifies the vaccination effort. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odisha", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Anganwadi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Porajas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4611260", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (30): (OR,TR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4611260", "date": "2016-11-03 10:08:36", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (29): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New cases\n[2] Vaccination training\n\n******\n[1] New cases\nDate: Thu 3 Nov 2016 01:36 IST\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttp://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/encephalitis-kills-74-kids-in-odisha-s-worst-outbreak/story-Zbu8jZmcLocScBhs1Oho8N.html\n\n\nOdisha's worst-ever encephalitis outbreak has killed 74 children in the Maoist-hit Malkangiri district, home to nearly 6.2 lakh [620 000] people, mostly from the Scheduled Castes and tribes like Bondas, Koyas, Porajas, and Didayis.\n\n\"Till [Mon 31 Oct 2016], 74 children have died, all from the Koya community. 47 of the deaths have been due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and 27 from Japanese encephalitis (JE),\" Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan, joint director of the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme in Odisha, said. \"It's the biggest outbreak in the district. We are studying why it is happening.\"\n\n\"All children in the district will be vaccinated against JE on [1 Dec 2016],\" Odisha director of health services Dr Chittaranjan Nayak said. \"The process of procuring the vaccines from the Centre, training the staff and the logistical assessment has begun.\"\n\nA single shot protects children for up to a year against the JE [virus] strain prevalent in India.\n\nWhile JE is a viral infection spread by mosquitoes, AES can be caused by a range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, chemicals, and toxins. Encephalitis is marked by inflammation of the brain's membrane that causes rapidly rising fever, headache, stiffness of the neck, disorientation, coma, seizures, spastic paralysis, and even death.\n\nOdisha first reported encephalitis cases in 2015, when 660 AES cases and 33 JE cases were detected. There were 4 deaths, 2 from each.\n\n\"Children in Malkangiri have never been vaccinated against JE because there were no cases till now,\" says Dr Nayak. Till [2 Oct 2016], India reported 7443 AES cases and 840 deaths, while JE has infected another 974 people and killed 167. Of these, 456 AES and 16 JE cases were from Odisha.\n\n[Byline: Sanchita Sharma]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of encephalitis cases in the district continues to slowly increase. This is the 2nd time that acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases have been mentioned. Until now, almost all the encephalitis cases have been attributed to JE virus infections. AES cases go undiagnosed. When JE virus infection is ruled out, other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease and lychee consumption, have been proposed. Until definitive etiologies of AES are identified, appropriate treatment and control measures cannot be implemented. One hopes that the studies that Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan mentioned will determine the etiologies involved.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY\n\n******\n[2] Vaccination training\nDate: Tue 2 Nov 2016\nSource: Prameya News7 [edited]\nhttp://www.prameyanews7.com/en/nov2016/odisha/35541/Training-to-vaccinators-for-JE-immunisation-begins-JE-immunisationOdisha.htm\n\n\nThe National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) authorities on [Wed 26 Oct 2016] started imparting training to nodal officers of 4 [Odisha] districts, Malkangiri, Koraput, Keonjhar, and Jajpur to carry out immunization programme to tackle deadly Japanese encephalitis (JE).\n\nThe deadly disease so far claimed the lives of 82 children in Malkangiri district. [According to the report above, less than half of these cases are due to JE virus infection. - Mod.TY]\n\nThe exact date of vaccination is yet to be decided by the NVBDCP, but it is believed that vaccination drive against Japanese encephalitis (JE), a dreadful disease, would be organised either in the last week of November or 1st week of December [2016].\n\nAs part of vaccination drive, children in the age group of 1-15 [years] would be covered across the 4 districts. Action plan has drawn for effective implementation of JE vaccination programme in these districts.\n\nVaccine camps would be set up in Government schools besides Anganwadi centres [Anganwadi centers provide basic health care in Indian villages. - Mod.TY]. Children in the age group of 1-15 years are prone to Japanese encephalitis attack and there is no medicine to cure this viral disease. Sources said JE vaccination is free from all side effects.\n\nIt is advised vaccinators not to administer JE vaccine for those children who are suffering from fever and infectious diseases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear why the vaccination initiative has waited over 3 months to be organized, while the number of fatal cases has gradually increased. It is good to see that training has finally begun, but the vaccination effort itself is still 3-4 weeks off. JE vaccination will not prevent occurrence of AES cases, but the significant number of JE virus infections with fatalities still justifies the vaccination effort. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (29): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4603728", "date": "2016-11-03 10:08:36", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (29): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] New cases\n[2] Vaccination training\n\n******\n[1] New cases\nDate: Thu 3 Nov 2016 01:36 IST\nSource: Hindustan Times [edited]\nhttp://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/encephalitis-kills-74-kids-in-odisha-s-worst-outbreak/story-Zbu8jZmcLocScBhs1Oho8N.html\n\n\nOdisha's worst-ever encephalitis outbreak has killed 74 children in the Maoist-hit Malkangiri district, home to nearly 6.2 lakh [620 000] people, mostly from the Scheduled Castes and tribes like Bondas, Koyas, Porajas, and Didayis.\n\n\"Till [Mon 31 Oct 2016], 74 children have died, all from the Koya community. 47 of the deaths have been due to acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) and 27 from Japanese encephalitis (JE),\" Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan, joint director of the National Vector-Borne Disease Control Programme in Odisha, said. \"It's the biggest outbreak in the district. We are studying why it is happening.\"\n\n\"All children in the district will be vaccinated against JE on [1 Dec 2016],\" Odisha director of health services Dr Chittaranjan Nayak said. \"The process of procuring the vaccines from the Centre, training the staff and the logistical assessment has begun.\"\n\nA single shot protects children for up to a year against the JE [virus] strain prevalent in India.\n\nWhile JE is a viral infection spread by mosquitoes, AES can be caused by a range of viruses, bacteria, fungi, parasites, chemicals, and toxins. Encephalitis is marked by inflammation of the brain's membrane that causes rapidly rising fever, headache, stiffness of the neck, disorientation, coma, seizures, spastic paralysis, and even death.\n\nOdisha first reported encephalitis cases in 2015, when 660 AES cases and 33 JE cases were detected. There were 4 deaths, 2 from each.\n\n\"Children in Malkangiri have never been vaccinated against JE because there were no cases till now,\" says Dr Nayak. Till [2 Oct 2016], India reported 7443 AES cases and 840 deaths, while JE has infected another 974 people and killed 167. Of these, 456 AES and 16 JE cases were from Odisha.\n\n[Byline: Sanchita Sharma]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of encephalitis cases in the district continues to slowly increase. This is the 2nd time that acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases have been mentioned. Until now, almost all the encephalitis cases have been attributed to JE virus infections. AES cases go undiagnosed. When JE virus infection is ruled out, other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease and lychee consumption, have been proposed. Until definitive etiologies of AES are identified, appropriate treatment and control measures cannot be implemented. One hopes that the studies that Dr Madan Mohan Pradhan mentioned will determine the etiologies involved.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY\n\n******\n[2] Vaccination training\nDate: Tue 2 Nov 2016\nSource: Prameya News7 [edited]\nhttp://www.prameyanews7.com/en/nov2016/odisha/35541/Training-to-vaccinators-for-JE-immunisation-begins-JE-immunisationOdisha.htm\n\n\nThe National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) authorities on [Wed 26 Oct 2016] started imparting training to nodal officers of 4 [Odisha] districts, Malkangiri, Koraput, Keonjhar, and Jajpur to carry out immunization programme to tackle deadly Japanese encephalitis (JE).\n\nThe deadly disease so far claimed the lives of 82 children in Malkangiri district. [According to the report above, less than half of these cases are due to JE virus infection. - Mod.TY]\n\nThe exact date of vaccination is yet to be decided by the NVBDCP, but it is believed that vaccination drive against Japanese encephalitis (JE), a dreadful disease, would be organised either in the last week of November or 1st week of December [2016].\n\nAs part of vaccination drive, children in the age group of 1-15 [years] would be covered across the 4 districts. Action plan has drawn for effective implementation of JE vaccination programme in these districts.\n\nVaccine camps would be set up in Government schools besides Anganwadi centres [Anganwadi centers provide basic health care in Indian villages. - Mod.TY]. Children in the age group of 1-15 years are prone to Japanese encephalitis attack and there is no medicine to cure this viral disease. Sources said JE vaccination is free from all side effects.\n\nIt is advised vaccinators not to administer JE vaccine for those children who are suffering from fever and infectious diseases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear why the vaccination initiative has waited over 3 months to be organized, while the number of fatal cases has gradually increased. It is good to see that training has finally begun, but the vaccination effort itself is still 3-4 weeks off. JE vaccination will not prevent occurrence of AES cases, but the significant number of JE virus infections with fatalities still justifies the vaccination effort. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (OR) 20160929.4525723\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN, OR) 20160725.4368952\n.................................................ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "7443-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Koraput", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bondas", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Koyas", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Malkangiri", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Jajpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Keonjhar", "country": "India"}, {"location": "anganwadi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "other - India (28): (OR), human, porcine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4594738", "date": "2016-10-05 08:01:23", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (21): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Oct 2016 10:17 PM IST\nSource: The Indian Express, Press Trust of India (PTI) report [edited]\nhttp://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/odisha-encephalitis-toll-27-health-minister-visits-malkangiri-3063810/\n\n\nOdisha Health Minister Atanu Sabyasachi Nayak today [3 Oct 2016] visited the areas where Japanese encephalitis [JE] has claimed at least 27 lives so far and said preventive steps are being taken to contain the disease. The death toll due to Japanese encephalitis increased to 27 with 6 children falling prey to the disease since [Sun 2 Oct 2016], Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO) US Mishra said.\n\nThe outbreak of [encephalitis] in 21 villages under 6 blocks of [Malkangiri] district was reported last month [September 2016] and affected mostly children. While the deaths have taken place in about 25 days, around 5 patients are now undergoing treatment in a hospital, he said.\n\nNayak, who visited the district along with Secretary to Health Department, Arti Ahuja, and Secretary to Animal Resources Department, Bishnupad Sethi, said measures required to deal with the situation are being taken.\n\nSince mosquitoes are the vectors for the disease, which spreads from pigs to humans, mostly children, the immediate task is to isolate the animals and relocate the pig farms away from the villages. Necessary steps in this regard are being taken, he said.\n\nWhile a team of doctors and experts had been sent earlier to the affected areas to take stock of the situation, another expert team was sent there on [Sun 2 Oct 2016]. They would camp there and plan various measures required to deal with the situation, he added.\n\nA team of veterinary doctors are also being sent to the disease affected areas to identity the infected pigs.\n\nHealth assistance booths have been opened in the affected areas, while fogging work was intensified to control mosquitoes, official sources said.\n\nBlood samples of pigs are also being sent to laboratory for thorough examination, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of JE fatalities in this area has increased to 27. Health officials indicated that preventive steps are being taken. In this report, the steps appear to be moving pigs away from the village houses. A previous report indicated that vector mosquito control would also be implemented.\n\nCuriously, no mention is made of vaccination, which is the most effective way to prevent cases. Mosquito control, at least temporarily, may be possible (but difficult) but eradication is not possible with current technology. The virus is actively transmitted in this area. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts of JE virus, mosquitoes in the genus _Culex_ are vectors, and pigs are amplifying hosts.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (OR) 20161003.4533613\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (OR) 20160929.4525723\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (OR) 20160927.4517725\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (JH) confirmation 20160926.4516189\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16) 20160926.4514686\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (JH), RFI 20160921.4503861\nJapanese encephalitis (02): India, Nepal 20160905.4467223\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (TR) 20160903.4462527\nJapanese encephalitis and other - India (12): (BR,UP) 20160902.4459866\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (UP) 20160824.4438801\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (27): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4585027", "date": "2016-10-05 08:01:23", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (21): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Oct 2016 10:17 PM IST\nSource: The Indian Express, Press Trust of India (PTI) report [edited]\nhttp://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/odisha-encephalitis-toll-27-health-minister-visits-malkangiri-3063810/\n\n\nOdisha Health Minister Atanu Sabyasachi Nayak today [3 Oct 2016] visited the areas where Japanese encephalitis [JE] has claimed at least 27 lives so far and said preventive steps are being taken to contain the disease. The death toll due to Japanese encephalitis increased to 27 with 6 children falling prey to the disease since [Sun 2 Oct 2016], Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO) US Mishra said.\n\nThe outbreak of [encephalitis] in 21 villages under 6 blocks of [Malkangiri] district was reported last month [September 2016] and affected mostly children. While the deaths have taken place in about 25 days, around 5 patients are now undergoing treatment in a hospital, he said.\n\nNayak, who visited the district along with Secretary to Health Department, Arti Ahuja, and Secretary to Animal Resources Department, Bishnupad Sethi, said measures required to deal with the situation are being taken.\n\nSince mosquitoes are the vectors for the disease, which spreads from pigs to humans, mostly children, the immediate task is to isolate the animals and relocate the pig farms away from the villages. Necessary steps in this regard are being taken, he said.\n\nWhile a team of doctors and experts had been sent earlier to the affected areas to take stock of the situation, another expert team was sent there on [Sun 2 Oct 2016]. They would camp there and plan various measures required to deal with the situation, he added.\n\nA team of veterinary doctors are also being sent to the disease affected areas to identity the infected pigs.\n\nHealth assistance booths have been opened in the affected areas, while fogging work was intensified to control mosquitoes, official sources said.\n\nBlood samples of pigs are also being sent to laboratory for thorough examination, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of JE fatalities in this area has increased to 27. Health officials indicated that preventive steps are being taken. In this report, the steps appear to be moving pigs away from the village houses. A previous report indicated that vector mosquito control would also be implemented.\n\nCuriously, no mention is made of vaccination, which is the most effective way to prevent cases. Mosquito control, at least temporarily, may be possible (but difficult) but eradication is not possible with current technology. The virus is actively transmitted in this area. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts of JE virus, mosquitoes in the genus _Culex_ are vectors, and pigs are amplifying hosts.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - India (02): (AS) 20160613.4283791\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (UP) 20160103.3908735\n.................................................ty/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-09-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "CDMO", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4579882", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (26): (OR) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4579882", "date": "2016-10-05 08:01:23", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (21): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Oct 2016 10:17 PM IST\nSource: The Indian Express, Press Trust of India (PTI) report [edited]\nhttp://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/odisha-encephalitis-toll-27-health-minister-visits-malkangiri-3063810/\n\n\nOdisha Health Minister Atanu Sabyasachi Nayak today [3 Oct 2016] visited the areas where Japanese encephalitis [JE] has claimed at least 27 lives so far and said preventive steps are being taken to contain the disease. The death toll due to Japanese encephalitis increased to 27 with 6 children falling prey to the disease since [Sun 2 Oct 2016], Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO) US Mishra said.\n\nThe outbreak of [encephalitis] in 21 villages under 6 blocks of [Malkangiri] district was reported last month [September 2016] and affected mostly children. While the deaths have taken place in about 25 days, around 5 patients are now undergoing treatment in a hospital, he said.\n\nNayak, who visited the district along with Secretary to Health Department, Arti Ahuja, and Secretary to Animal Resources Department, Bishnupad Sethi, said measures required to deal with the situation are being taken.\n\nSince mosquitoes are the vectors for the disease, which spreads from pigs to humans, mostly children, the immediate task is to isolate the animals and relocate the pig farms away from the villages. Necessary steps in this regard are being taken, he said.\n\nWhile a team of doctors and experts had been sent earlier to the affected areas to take stock of the situation, another expert team was sent there on [Sun 2 Oct 2016]. They would camp there and plan various measures required to deal with the situation, he added.\n\nA team of veterinary doctors are also being sent to the disease affected areas to identity the infected pigs.\n\nHealth assistance booths have been opened in the affected areas, while fogging work was intensified to control mosquitoes, official sources said.\n\nBlood samples of pigs are also being sent to laboratory for thorough examination, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of JE fatalities in this area has increased to 27. Health officials indicated that preventive steps are being taken. In this report, the steps appear to be moving pigs away from the village houses. A previous report indicated that vector mosquito control would also be implemented.\n\nCuriously, no mention is made of vaccination, which is the most effective way to prevent cases. Mosquito control, at least temporarily, may be possible (but difficult) but eradication is not possible with current technology. The virus is actively transmitted in this area. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts of JE virus, mosquitoes in the genus _Culex_ are vectors, and pigs are amplifying hosts.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. -
