India (25): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4572206", "date": "2016-10-05 08:01:23", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (21): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Oct 2016 10:17 PM IST\nSource: The Indian Express, Press Trust of India (PTI) report [edited]\nhttp://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/odisha-encephalitis-toll-27-health-minister-visits-malkangiri-3063810/\n\n\nOdisha Health Minister Atanu Sabyasachi Nayak today [3 Oct 2016] visited the areas where Japanese encephalitis [JE] has claimed at least 27 lives so far and said preventive steps are being taken to contain the disease. The death toll due to Japanese encephalitis increased to 27 with 6 children falling prey to the disease since [Sun 2 Oct 2016], Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO) US Mishra said.\n\nThe outbreak of [encephalitis] in 21 villages under 6 blocks of [Malkangiri] district was reported last month [September 2016] and affected mostly children. While the deaths have taken place in about 25 days, around 5 patients are now undergoing treatment in a hospital, he said.\n\nNayak, who visited the district along with Secretary to Health Department, Arti Ahuja, and Secretary to Animal Resources Department, Bishnupad Sethi, said measures required to deal with the situation are being taken.\n\nSince mosquitoes are the vectors for the disease, which spreads from pigs to humans, mostly children, the immediate task is to isolate the animals and relocate the pig farms away from the villages. Necessary steps in this regard are being taken, he said.\n\nWhile a team of doctors and experts had been sent earlier to the affected areas to take stock of the situation, another expert team was sent there on [Sun 2 Oct 2016]. They would camp there and plan various measures required to deal with the situation, he added.\n\nA team of veterinary doctors are also being sent to the disease affected areas to identity the infected pigs.\n\nHealth assistance booths have been opened in the affected areas, while fogging work was intensified to control mosquitoes, official sources said.\n\nBlood samples of pigs are also being sent to laboratory for thorough examination, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of JE fatalities in this area has increased to 27. Health officials indicated that preventive steps are being taken. In this report, the steps appear to be moving pigs away from the village houses. A previous report indicated that vector mosquito control would also be implemented.\n\nCuriously, no mention is made of vaccination, which is the most effective way to prevent cases. Mosquito control, at least temporarily, may be possible (but difficult) but eradication is not possible with current technology. The virus is actively transmitted in this area. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts of JE virus, mosquitoes in the genus _Culex_ are vectors, and pigs are amplifying hosts.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - The death toll due to Japanese encephalitis increased to 27 with 6 children falling prey to the disease since [Sun 2 Oct 2016], Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO) US Mishra said.\n\nThe outbreak of [encephalitis] in 21 villages under 6 blocks of [Malkangiri] district was reported last month [September 2016] and affected mostly children. While the deaths have taken place in about 25 days, around 5 patients are now undergoing treatment in a hospital, he said.\n\nNayak, who visited the district along with Secretary to Health Department, Arti Ahuja, and Secretary to Animal Resources Department, Bishnupad Sethi, said measures required to deal with the situation are being taken.\n\nSince mosquitoes are the vectors for the disease, which spreads from pigs to humans, mostly children, the immediate task is to isolate the animals and relocate the pig farms away from the villages. Necessary steps in this regard are being taken, he said.\n\nWhile a team of doctors and experts had been sent earlier to the affected areas to take stock of the situation, another expert team was sent there on [Sun 2 Oct 2016]. They would camp there and plan various measures required to deal with the situation, he added.\n\nA team of veterinary doctors are also being sent to the disease affected areas to identity the infected pigs.\n\nHealth assistance booths have been opened in the affected areas, while fogging work was intensified to control mosquitoes, official sources said.\n\nBlood samples of pigs are also being sent to laboratory for thorough examination, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of JE fatalities in this area has increased to 27. Health officials indicated that preventive steps are being taken. In this report, the steps appear to be moving pigs away from the village houses. A previous report indicated that vector mosquito control would also be implemented.\n\nCuriously, no mention is made of vaccination, which is the most effective way to prevent cases. Mosquito control, at least temporarily, may be possible (but difficult) but eradication is not possible with current technology. The virus is actively transmitted in this area. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts of JE virus, mosquitoes in the genus _Culex_ are vectors, and pigs are amplifying hosts.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - The death toll due to Japanese encephalitis increased to 27 with 6 children falling prey to the disease since [Sun 2 Oct 2016], Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO) US Mishra said.\n\nThe outbreak of [encephalitis] in 21 villages under 6 blocks of [Malkangiri] district was reported last month [September 2016] and affected mostly children. While the deaths have taken place in about 25 days, around 5 patients are now undergoing treatment in a hospital, he said.\n\nNayak, who visited the district along with Secretary to Health Department, Arti Ahuja, and Secretary to Animal Resources Department, Bishnupad Sethi, said measures required to deal with the situation are being taken.\n\nSince mosquitoes are the vectors for the disease, which spreads from pigs to humans, mostly children, the immediate task is to isolate the animals and relocate the pig farms away from the villages. Necessary steps in this regard are being taken, he said.\n\nWhile a team of doctors and experts had been sent earlier to the affected areas to take stock of the situation, another expert team was sent there on [Sun 2 Oct 2016]. They would camp there and plan various measures required to deal with the situation, he added.\n\nA team of veterinary doctors are also being sent to the disease affected areas to identity the infected pigs.\n\nHealth assistance booths have been opened in the affected areas, while fogging work was intensified to control mosquitoes, official sources said.\n\nBlood samples of pigs are also being sent to laboratory for thorough examination, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of JE fatalities in this area has increased to 27. A previous report indicated that vector mosquito control would also be implemented.\n\nCuriously, no mention is made of vaccination, which is the most effective way to prevent cases. Mosquito control, at least temporarily, may be possible (but difficult) but eradication is not possible with current technology. The virus is actively transmitted in this area. India (22): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4539552", "date": "2016-10-05 08:01:23", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (21): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Oct 2016 10:17 PM IST\nSource: The Indian Express, Press Trust of India (PTI) report [edited]\nhttp://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/odisha-encephalitis-toll-27-health-minister-visits-malkangiri-3063810/\n\n\nOdisha Health Minister Atanu Sabyasachi Nayak today [3 Oct 2016] visited the areas where Japanese encephalitis [JE] has claimed at least 27 lives so far and said preventive steps are being taken to contain the disease. The death toll due to Japanese encephalitis increased to 27 with 6 children falling prey to the disease since [Sun 2 Oct 2016], Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO) US Mishra said.\n\nThe outbreak of [encephalitis] in 21 villages under 6 blocks of [Malkangiri] district was reported last month [September 2016] and affected mostly children. While the deaths have taken place in about 25 days, around 5 patients are now undergoing treatment in a hospital, he said.\n\nNayak, who visited the district along with Secretary to Health Department, Arti Ahuja, and Secretary to Animal Resources Department, Bishnupad Sethi, said measures required to deal with the situation are being taken.\n\nSince mosquitoes are the vectors for the disease, which spreads from pigs to humans, mostly children, the immediate task is to isolate the animals and relocate the pig farms away from the villages. Necessary steps in this regard are being taken, he said.\n\nWhile a team of doctors and experts had been sent earlier to the affected areas to take stock of the situation, another expert team was sent there on [Sun 2 Oct 2016]. They would camp there and plan various measures required to deal with the situation, he added.\n\nA team of veterinary doctors are also being sent to the disease affected areas to identity the infected pigs.\n\nHealth assistance booths have been opened in the affected areas, while fogging work was intensified to control mosquitoes, official sources said.\n\nBlood samples of pigs are also being sent to laboratory for thorough examination, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of JE fatalities in this area has increased to 27. Health officials indicated that preventive steps are being taken. In this report, the steps appear to be moving pigs away from the village houses. A previous report indicated that vector mosquito control would also be implemented.\n\nCuriously, no mention is made of vaccination, which is the most effective way to prevent cases. Mosquito control, at least temporarily, may be possible (but difficult) but eradication is not possible with current technology. The virus is actively transmitted in this area. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts of JE virus, mosquitoes in the genus _Culex_ are vectors, and pigs are amplifying hosts.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "CDMO", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4537043", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4537043", "date": "2016-10-05 08:01:23", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (21): (ODISHA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Oct 2016 10:17 PM IST\nSource: The Indian Express, Press Trust of India (PTI) report [edited]\nhttp://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/odisha-encephalitis-toll-27-health-minister-visits-malkangiri-3063810/\n\n\nOdisha Health Minister Atanu Sabyasachi Nayak today [3 Oct 2016] visited the areas where Japanese encephalitis [JE] has claimed at least 27 lives so far and said preventive steps are being taken to contain the disease. The death toll due to Japanese encephalitis increased to 27 with 6 children falling prey to the disease since [Sun 2 Oct 2016], Chief District Medical Officer (CDMO) US Mishra said.\n\nThe outbreak of [encephalitis] in 21 villages under 6 blocks of [Malkangiri] district was reported last month [September 2016] and affected mostly children. While the deaths have taken place in about 25 days, around 5 patients are now undergoing treatment in a hospital, he said.\n\nNayak, who visited the district along with Secretary to Health Department, Arti Ahuja, and Secretary to Animal Resources Department, Bishnupad Sethi, said measures required to deal with the situation are being taken.\n\nSince mosquitoes are the vectors for the disease, which spreads from pigs to humans, mostly children, the immediate task is to isolate the animals and relocate the pig farms away from the villages. Necessary steps in this regard are being taken, he said.\n\nWhile a team of doctors and experts had been sent earlier to the affected areas to take stock of the situation, another expert team was sent there on [Sun 2 Oct 2016]. They would camp there and plan various measures required to deal with the situation, he added.\n\nA team of veterinary doctors are also being sent to the disease affected areas to identity the infected pigs.\n\nHealth assistance booths have been opened in the affected areas, while fogging work was intensified to control mosquitoes, official sources said.\n\nBlood samples of pigs are also being sent to laboratory for thorough examination, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of JE fatalities in this area has increased to 27. Health officials indicated that preventive steps are being taken. In this report, the steps appear to be moving pigs away from the village houses. A previous report indicated that vector mosquito control would also be implemented.\n\nCuriously, no mention is made of vaccination, which is the most effective way to prevent cases. Mosquito control, at least temporarily, may be possible (but difficult) but eradication is not possible with current technology. The virus is actively transmitted in this area. Ardeid birds (heron family) are reservoir hosts of JE virus, mosquitoes in the genus _Culex_ are vectors, and pigs are amplifying hosts.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18170. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "CDMO", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4533613", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4533613", "date": "2016-09-03 12:25:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (13): (TRIPURA)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 2 Sep 2016\nSource: The Northeast Today [edited]\nhttp://thenortheasttoday.com/tripura-43-japanese-encephalitis-cases-recorded-in-four-months/\n\n\nAt least 43 cases of Japanese encephalitis were recorded across Tripura in the last 4 months as per a report. Of the total, 19 were women. The record stated that these cases were reported from May till 26 Aug [2016]. However, no death occurred due to the Japanese encephalitis.\n\nOfficial sources said that 10 cases were reported from West District, 4 cases in Sepahijala District, 6 cases each in Khowai District, Gomati District and Dhalai District, 3 cases each in South District and Unakoti District and 5 cases in North Tripura.\n\nThe Health Department has taken certain preventive measures to tackle the situation.\n\nLast year [2015], 3 children died soon after being administered anti-Japanese encephalitis [what was given?]. Later, the Tripura government urged Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to send a team to investigate the cause of the 3 deaths. During that time, a total of 207 986 children between the age group of 1-15 years old were vaccinated in 3 districts -- West Tripura, Sepahijala and Khowai -- as part of national level immunization programme.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is endemic in north eastern India and cases occur there yearly during the transmission season. This report indicates that all the reported cases are JE only and does not attribute any cases to the non-specific acute encephalitis syndrome that has been reported in many previous reports from north eastern India. Although vaccination in the areas was mentioned, there is no indication if the JE cases reported above had been vaccinated, or if a vaccination campaign in the state is planned.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/320. - India (19): (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4525723", "date": "2016-09-03 12:25:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (13): (TRIPURA)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 2 Sep 2016\nSource: The Northeast Today [edited]\nhttp://thenortheasttoday.com/tripura-43-japanese-encephalitis-cases-recorded-in-four-months/\n\n\nAt least 43 cases of Japanese encephalitis were recorded across Tripura in the last 4 months as per a report. Of the total, 19 were women. The record stated that these cases were reported from May till 26 Aug [2016]. However, no death occurred due to the Japanese encephalitis.\n\nOfficial sources said that 10 cases were reported from West District, 4 cases in Sepahijala District, 6 cases each in Khowai District, Gomati District and Dhalai District, 3 cases each in South District and Unakoti District and 5 cases in North Tripura.\n\nThe Health Department has taken certain preventive measures to tackle the situation.\n\nLast year [2015], 3 children died soon after being administered anti-Japanese encephalitis [what was given?]. Later, the Tripura government urged Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to send a team to investigate the cause of the 3 deaths. During that time, a total of 207 986 children between the age group of 1-15 years old were vaccinated in 3 districts -- West Tripura, Sepahijala and Khowai -- as part of national level immunization programme.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is endemic in north eastern India and cases occur there yearly during the transmission season. This report indicates that all the reported cases are JE only and does not attribute any cases to the non-specific acute encephalitis syndrome that has been reported in many previous reports from north eastern India. Although vaccination in the areas was mentioned, there is no indication if the JE cases reported above had been vaccinated, or if a vaccination campaign in the state is planned.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/320. - Of the total, 19 were women. The record stated that these cases were reported from May till 26 Aug [2016]. However, no death occurred due to the Japanese encephalitis.\n\nOfficial sources said that 10 cases were reported from West District, 4 cases in Sepahijala District, 6 cases each in Khowai District, Gomati District and Dhalai District, 3 cases each in South District and Unakoti District and 5 cases in North Tripura.\n\nThe Health Department has taken certain preventive measures to tackle the situation.\n\nLast year [2015], 3 children died soon after being administered anti-Japanese encephalitis [what was given?]. India (17): (JH) confirmation", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4516189", "date": "2016-09-03 12:25:44", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (13): (TRIPURA)\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 2 Sep 2016\nSource: The Northeast Today [edited]\nhttp://thenortheasttoday.com/tripura-43-japanese-encephalitis-cases-recorded-in-four-months/\n\n\nAt least 43 cases of Japanese encephalitis were recorded across Tripura in the last 4 months as per a report. Of the total, 19 were women. The record stated that these cases were reported from May till 26 Aug [2016]. However, no death occurred due to the Japanese encephalitis.\n\nOfficial sources said that 10 cases were reported from West District, 4 cases in Sepahijala District, 6 cases each in Khowai District, Gomati District and Dhalai District, 3 cases each in South District and Unakoti District and 5 cases in North Tripura.\n\nThe Health Department has taken certain preventive measures to tackle the situation.\n\nLast year [2015], 3 children died soon after being administered anti-Japanese encephalitis [what was given?]. Later, the Tripura government urged Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to send a team to investigate the cause of the 3 deaths. During that time, a total of 207 986 children between the age group of 1-15 years old were vaccinated in 3 districts -- West Tripura, Sepahijala and Khowai -- as part of national level immunization programme.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is endemic in north eastern India and cases occur there yearly during the transmission season. This report indicates that all the reported cases are JE only and does not attribute any cases to the non-specific acute encephalitis syndrome that has been reported in many previous reports from north eastern India. Although vaccination in the areas was mentioned, there is no indication if the JE cases reported above had been vaccinated, or if a vaccination campaign in the state is planned.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/320. - India (12): (BR,UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4459866", "date": "2016-07-21 19:56:38", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (06): (JHARKHAND) SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Jul 2016\nSource: The Telegraph [edited]\nhttp://www.telegraphindia.com/1160720/jsp/jharkhand/story_97616.jsp\n\n\nThe monsoon nightmare is back to haunt Jamshedpur [Jharkhand state] and its neighbours.\n\nThe East Singhbhum civil surgeon's office on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016] issued a double alert for dengue and Japanese encephalitis in the steel city after 18 suspected cases of the vector-borne diseases were reported from Tata Main Hospital (TMH) on Monday [18 Jul 2016].\n\n\"A general alert has been sounded to all hospitals, nursing homes and health centres in and around Jamshedpur. We have to maintain strict vigil,\" said civil surgeon Dr S.K. Jha.\n\nSahir Pall, district officer for the Centre's Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), said the private hospital had reported 4 Japanese encephalitis [JE] suspects. \"Blood serum samples have been sent to the microbiology department of MGM Medical College in Dimna for confirmation. Reports are expected in another 48 hours,\" Pall added.\n\nSources at TMH said all the 4 encephalitis suspects were children -- 3 boys and a girl aged between 4-12 years.\n\n\"The patients have come from various parts of Jamshedpur like Birsanagar, Sakchi, Sonari, Kadma, Mango and Bagbera as well as Adityapur in adjoining Seraikela-Kharsawan district.\n\nJapanese encephalitis [virus] is transmitted to humans through infected _Culex_ mosquitoes, particularly _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_.\n\nOf the 200-plus samples tested for Japanese encephalitis in 2015, 40 had confirmed presence of the virus. No cases were reported in 2014.\n\nThe civil surgeon's office, once again on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016], prodded Jamshedpur Notified Area Committee, Mango Notified Area Committee, Jugsalai Municipality and Jusco to increase frequency of fogging, sprinkling of bleaching powder, spraying of larvicides and other disinfectants in areas under their command. It also issued a notice to all government and private hospitals/nursing homes, asking them to report suspected cases within 24 hours.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, where the JE virus transmission season is beginning. Fogging is not an effective long-term approach to JE prevention -- vaccination is. This report does not indicate if there is widespread vaccination against JE in the affected area, which is the most effective preventive measure. Vector control may provide short-term mosquito population reduction, but is not a long-term preventive measure. Extensive rice fields offer ample breeding sites.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306, and a map showing the location of Jamshedpur in Jharkhand state at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamshedpur. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis: Philippines (DR), Viet Nam, India (KL,BR) 20160716.4350209\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (BR) fatal 20160627.4312442\nJapanese encephalitis and other - India (04): (AS) 20160618.4295497\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20160614.4287590\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (AS) 20160613.4283791\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (UP) 20160103.3908735\n.................................................ty/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2040-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bagbera", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Sonari", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Jharkhand", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4438801", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4438801", "date": "2016-07-21 19:56:38", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (06): (JHARKHAND) SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Jul 2016\nSource: The Telegraph [edited]\nhttp://www.telegraphindia.com/1160720/jsp/jharkhand/story_97616.jsp\n\n\nThe monsoon nightmare is back to haunt Jamshedpur [Jharkhand state] and its neighbours.\n\nThe East Singhbhum civil surgeon's office on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016] issued a double alert for dengue and Japanese encephalitis in the steel city after 18 suspected cases of the vector-borne diseases were reported from Tata Main Hospital (TMH) on Monday [18 Jul 2016].\n\n\"A general alert has been sounded to all hospitals, nursing homes and health centres in and around Jamshedpur. We have to maintain strict vigil,\" said civil surgeon Dr S.K. Jha.\n\nSahir Pall, district officer for the Centre's Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), said the private hospital had reported 4 Japanese encephalitis [JE] suspects. \"Blood serum samples have been sent to the microbiology department of MGM Medical College in Dimna for confirmation. Reports are expected in another 48 hours,\" Pall added.\n\nSources at TMH said all the 4 encephalitis suspects were children -- 3 boys and a girl aged between 4-12 years.\n\n\"The patients have come from various parts of Jamshedpur like Birsanagar, Sakchi, Sonari, Kadma, Mango and Bagbera as well as Adityapur in adjoining Seraikela-Kharsawan district.\n\nJapanese encephalitis [virus] is transmitted to humans through infected _Culex_ mosquitoes, particularly _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_.\n\nOf the 200-plus samples tested for Japanese encephalitis in 2015, 40 had confirmed presence of the virus. No cases were reported in 2014.\n\nThe civil surgeon's office, once again on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016], prodded Jamshedpur Notified Area Committee, Mango Notified Area Committee, Jugsalai Municipality and Jusco to increase frequency of fogging, sprinkling of bleaching powder, spraying of larvicides and other disinfectants in areas under their command. It also issued a notice to all government and private hospitals/nursing homes, asking them to report suspected cases within 24 hours.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, where the JE virus transmission season is beginning. Fogging is not an effective long-term approach to JE prevention -- vaccination is. This report does not indicate if there is widespread vaccination against JE in the affected area, which is the most effective preventive measure. Vector control may provide short-term mosquito population reduction, but is not a long-term preventive measure. Extensive rice fields offer ample breeding sites.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306, and a map showing the location of Jamshedpur in Jharkhand state at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamshedpur. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis: Philippines (DR), Viet Nam, India (KL,BR) 20160716.4350209\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (BR) fatal 20160627.4312442\nJapanese encephalitis and other - India (04): (AS) 20160618.4295497\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20160614.4287590\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (AS) 20160613.4283791\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bagbera", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Sonari", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Jharkhand", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4430470", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4430470", "date": "2016-07-21 19:56:38", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (06): (JHARKHAND) SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Jul 2016\nSource: The Telegraph [edited]\nhttp://www.telegraphindia.com/1160720/jsp/jharkhand/story_97616.jsp\n\n\nThe monsoon nightmare is back to haunt Jamshedpur [Jharkhand state] and its neighbours.\n\nThe East Singhbhum civil surgeon's office on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016] issued a double alert for dengue and Japanese encephalitis in the steel city after 18 suspected cases of the vector-borne diseases were reported from Tata Main Hospital (TMH) on Monday [18 Jul 2016].\n\n\"A general alert has been sounded to all hospitals, nursing homes and health centres in and around Jamshedpur. We have to maintain strict vigil,\" said civil surgeon Dr S.K. Jha.\n\nSahir Pall, district officer for the Centre's Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), said the private hospital had reported 4 Japanese encephalitis [JE] suspects. \"Blood serum samples have been sent to the microbiology department of MGM Medical College in Dimna for confirmation. Reports are expected in another 48 hours,\" Pall added.\n\nSources at TMH said all the 4 encephalitis suspects were children -- 3 boys and a girl aged between 4-12 years.\n\n\"The patients have come from various parts of Jamshedpur like Birsanagar, Sakchi, Sonari, Kadma, Mango and Bagbera as well as Adityapur in adjoining Seraikela-Kharsawan district.\n\nJapanese encephalitis [virus] is transmitted to humans through infected _Culex_ mosquitoes, particularly _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_.\n\nOf the 200-plus samples tested for Japanese encephalitis in 2015, 40 had confirmed presence of the virus. No cases were reported in 2014.\n\nThe civil surgeon's office, once again on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016], prodded Jamshedpur Notified Area Committee, Mango Notified Area Committee, Jugsalai Municipality and Jusco to increase frequency of fogging, sprinkling of bleaching powder, spraying of larvicides and other disinfectants in areas under their command. It also issued a notice to all government and private hospitals/nursing homes, asking them to report suspected cases within 24 hours.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, where the JE virus transmission season is beginning. Fogging is not an effective long-term approach to JE prevention -- vaccination is. This report does not indicate if there is widespread vaccination against JE in the affected area, which is the most effective preventive measure. Vector control may provide short-term mosquito population reduction, but is not a long-term preventive measure. Extensive rice fields offer ample breeding sites.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306, and a map showing the location of Jamshedpur in Jharkhand state at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamshedpur. - India (09): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4390885", "date": "2016-07-21 19:56:38", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (06): (JHARKHAND) SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Jul 2016\nSource: The Telegraph [edited]\nhttp://www.telegraphindia.com/1160720/jsp/jharkhand/story_97616.jsp\n\n\nThe monsoon nightmare is back to haunt Jamshedpur [Jharkhand state] and its neighbours.\n\nThe East Singhbhum civil surgeon's office on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016] issued a double alert for dengue and Japanese encephalitis in the steel city after 18 suspected cases of the vector-borne diseases were reported from Tata Main Hospital (TMH) on Monday [18 Jul 2016].\n\n\"A general alert has been sounded to all hospitals, nursing homes and health centres in and around Jamshedpur. We have to maintain strict vigil,\" said civil surgeon Dr S.K. Jha.\n\nSahir Pall, district officer for the Centre's Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), said the private hospital had reported 4 Japanese encephalitis [JE] suspects. \"Blood serum samples have been sent to the microbiology department of MGM Medical College in Dimna for confirmation. Reports are expected in another 48 hours,\" Pall added.\n\nSources at TMH said all the 4 encephalitis suspects were children -- 3 boys and a girl aged between 4-12 years.\n\n\"The patients have come from various parts of Jamshedpur like Birsanagar, Sakchi, Sonari, Kadma, Mango and Bagbera as well as Adityapur in adjoining Seraikela-Kharsawan district.\n\nJapanese encephalitis [virus] is transmitted to humans through infected _Culex_ mosquitoes, particularly _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_.\n\nOf the 200-plus samples tested for Japanese encephalitis in 2015, 40 had confirmed presence of the virus. No cases were reported in 2014.\n\nThe civil surgeon's office, once again on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016], prodded Jamshedpur Notified Area Committee, Mango Notified Area Committee, Jugsalai Municipality and Jusco to increase frequency of fogging, sprinkling of bleaching powder, spraying of larvicides and other disinfectants in areas under their command. It also issued a notice to all government and private hospitals/nursing homes, asking them to report suspected cases within 24 hours.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, where the JE virus transmission season is beginning. Fogging is not an effective long-term approach to JE prevention -- vaccination is. This report does not indicate if there is widespread vaccination against JE in the affected area, which is the most effective preventive measure. Vector control may provide short-term mosquito population reduction, but is not a long-term preventive measure. Extensive rice fields offer ample breeding sites.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306, and a map showing the location of Jamshedpur in Jharkhand state at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamshedpur. - It also issued a notice to all government and private hospitals/nursing homes, asking them to report suspected cases within 24 hours.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, where the JE virus transmission season is beginning. Fogging is not an effective long-term approach to JE prevention -- vaccination is. This report does not indicate if there is widespread vaccination against JE in the affected area, which is the most effective preventive measure. Vector control may provide short-term mosquito population reduction, but is not a long-term preventive measure. This report does not indicate if there is widespread vaccination against JE in the affected area, which is the most effective preventive measure. Vector control may provide short-term mosquito population reduction, but is not a long-term preventive measure. We have to maintain strict vigil,\" said civil surgeon Dr S.K. Jha.\n\nSahir Pall, district officer for the Centre's Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), said the private hospital had reported 4 Japanese encephalitis [JE] suspects. \"Blood serum samples have been sent to the microbiology department of MGM Medical College in Dimna for confirmation. It also issued a notice to all government and private hospitals/nursing homes, asking them to report suspected cases within 24 hours.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, where the JE virus transmission season is beginning. Fogging is not an effective long-term approach to JE prevention -- vaccination is. This report does not indicate if there is widespread vaccination against JE in the affected area, which is the most effective preventive measure. Vector control may provide short-term mosquito population reduction, but is not a long-term preventive measure. Extensive rice fields offer ample breeding sites.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306, and a map showing the location of Jamshedpur in Jharkhand state at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamshedpur. - India: (UP) 20160103.3908735\n.................................................ty/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2040-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bagbera", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Sonari", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Jharkhand", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4312442", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (BR) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4312442", "date": "2016-07-21 19:56:38", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (06): (JHARKHAND) SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Jul 2016\nSource: The Telegraph [edited]\nhttp://www.telegraphindia.com/1160720/jsp/jharkhand/story_97616.jsp\n\n\nThe monsoon nightmare is back to haunt Jamshedpur [Jharkhand state] and its neighbours.\n\nThe East Singhbhum civil surgeon's office on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016] issued a double alert for dengue and Japanese encephalitis in the steel city after 18 suspected cases of the vector-borne diseases were reported from Tata Main Hospital (TMH) on Monday [18 Jul 2016].\n\n\"A general alert has been sounded to all hospitals, nursing homes and health centres in and around Jamshedpur. We have to maintain strict vigil,\" said civil surgeon Dr S.K. Jha.\n\nSahir Pall, district officer for the Centre's Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), said the private hospital had reported 4 Japanese encephalitis [JE] suspects. \"Blood serum samples have been sent to the microbiology department of MGM Medical College in Dimna for confirmation. Reports are expected in another 48 hours,\" Pall added.\n\nSources at TMH said all the 4 encephalitis suspects were children -- 3 boys and a girl aged between 4-12 years.\n\n\"The patients have come from various parts of Jamshedpur like Birsanagar, Sakchi, Sonari, Kadma, Mango and Bagbera as well as Adityapur in adjoining Seraikela-Kharsawan district.\n\nJapanese encephalitis [virus] is transmitted to humans through infected _Culex_ mosquitoes, particularly _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_.\n\nOf the 200-plus samples tested for Japanese encephalitis in 2015, 40 had confirmed presence of the virus. No cases were reported in 2014.\n\nThe civil surgeon's office, once again on Tuesday [19 Jul 2016], prodded Jamshedpur Notified Area Committee, Mango Notified Area Committee, Jugsalai Municipality and Jusco to increase frequency of fogging, sprinkling of bleaching powder, spraying of larvicides and other disinfectants in areas under their command. It also issued a notice to all government and private hospitals/nursing homes, asking them to report suspected cases within 24 hours.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[JE virus is endemic in northeastern India, where the JE virus transmission season is beginning. Fogging is not an effective long-term approach to JE prevention -- vaccination is. This report does not indicate if there is widespread vaccination against JE in the affected area, which is the most effective preventive measure. Vector control may provide short-term mosquito population reduction, but is not a long-term preventive measure. Extensive rice fields offer ample breeding sites.\n\nMaps of India can be accessed at http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306, and a map showing the location of Jamshedpur in Jharkhand state at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamshedpur. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis: Philippines (DR), Viet Nam, India (KL,BR) 20160716.4350209\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (BR) fatal 20160627.4312442\nJapanese encephalitis and other - India (04): (AS) 20160618.4295497\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (AS) 20160614.4287590\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (AS) 20160613.4283791\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (UP) 20160103.3908735\n.................................................ty/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2040-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Centre", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bagbera", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Sonari", "country": "Bangladesh"}, {"location": "Jharkhand", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4295497", "headline": "PRO/AH> Japanese encephalitis and other - India (04): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4295497", "date": "2015-11-16 00:22:46", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (16): (BIHAR)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 15 Nov 2015\nSource: The Times of India [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/Encephalitis-toll-goes-up-to-24-in-Gaya/articleshow/49790043.cms\n\n\nWith 1 more death reported from Anugrah Narain Magadh Medical College Hospital, the number of encephalitis deaths has gone up to 24. Altogether, 123 AES [acute encephalitis syndrome] patients were admitted to the children's ward of the ANMMCH with AES symptoms. Of these, 35 of the patients were found suffering from Japanese encephalitis, the more deadly form of the disease.\n\nConfirming 24 deaths due to AES this season, ANMMCH superintendent Dr SK Sinha said that 35 of the 123 AES patients admitted to the hospital this season tested JE positive. Giving a further breakdown, the superintendent said that of the 23 deaths reported this season, 8 suffered from Japanese encephalitis while the other 15 died due to AES.\n\nNow that the temperature has come down and winter is beginning to set in, there was little likelihood of the disease spreading any further. Altogether 96 encephalitis patients have been discharged while another 4 were undergoing treatment in the children's ward of the hospital; 2 of the patients were discharged on Friday [13 Nov 2015] after satisfactory recovery.\n\nThe encephalitis survivors have suffered mild to severe mental retardation and physical infirmities, particularly weakening of the upper and lower limbs. Facilities for the rehabilitation of the AES survivors are not available in the hospital and as such the discharged patients have to fend for themselves. According to activist Brajnandan Pathak, the affected patients -- being very poor (almost all of them belong to the Mahadalit social group) -- cannot afford rehabilitation at centres outside the district.\n\nAs per available statistics, the maximum number of AES deaths were reported in 2011 when no fewer than 70 children died of encephalitis in ANMMCH alone. In 2009 too, 46 AES deaths took place. The numbers of affected children in 2011 and 2009 were 321 and 151 respectively.\n\nHealth officials claim to have undertaken a massive immunisation drive in the district to prevent [spread of] the deadly disease. But the claims have fallen flat after the outbreak of the disease which took almost epidemic form.\n\n[Byline: Abdul Qadir]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report gives definite numbers of cases due to Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus infections. However, the etiology of the AES cases remains undetermined. A 22 Sep 2015 report indicated that there were 10 834 AES cases in 2014. That report describes AES as \"a group of clinical neurologic manifestations caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungus, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins\" (http://zeenews.india.com/news/health/health-news/india-had-over-10000-acute-encephalitis-syndrome-cases-in-2014_1800724.html).\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts have implicated Reye syndrome, consumption of lychees, and heat stroke, as well as JE virus infections, as responsible for AES. The above report indicates that a massive immunization drive has been taken in the district, but the type of immunization is not specified. Presumably, it is JE virus vaccine, since the etiology of the AES cases is not identified. Prevention and control of AES will be difficult until there is a clear indication of the etiologies involved in these cases. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46246.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - Altogether, 123 AES [acute encephalitis syndrome] patients were admitted to the children's ward of the ANMMCH with AES symptoms. Of these, 35 of the patients were found suffering from Japanese encephalitis, the more deadly form of the disease.\n\nConfirming 24 deaths due to AES this season, ANMMCH superintendent Dr SK Sinha said that 35 of the 123 AES patients admitted to the hospital this season tested JE positive. Giving a further breakdown, the superintendent said that of the 23 deaths reported this season, 8 suffered from Japanese encephalitis while the other 15 died due to AES.\n\nNow that the temperature has come down and winter is beginning to set in, there was little likelihood of the disease spreading any further. Altogether 96 encephalitis patients have been discharged while another 4 were undergoing treatment in the children's ward of the hospital; 2 of the patients were discharged on Friday [13 Nov 2015] after satisfactory recovery.\n\nThe encephalitis survivors have suffered mild to severe mental retardation and physical infirmities, particularly weakening of the upper and lower limbs. Facilities for the rehabilitation of the AES survivors are not available in the hospital and as such the discharged patients have to fend for themselves. In 2009 too, 46 AES deaths took place. The numbers of affected children in 2011 and 2009 were 321 and 151 respectively.\n\nHealth officials claim to have undertaken a massive immunisation drive in the district to prevent [spread of] the deadly disease. But the claims have fallen flat after the outbreak of the disease which took almost epidemic form.\n\n[Byline: Abdul Qadir]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report gives definite numbers of cases due to Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus infections. That report describes AES as \"a group of clinical neurologic manifestations caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungus, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins\" (http://zeenews.india.com/news/health/health-news/india-had-over-10000-acute-encephalitis-syndrome-cases-in-2014_1800724.html).\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts have implicated Reye syndrome, consumption of lychees, and heat stroke, as well as JE virus infections, as responsible for AES. The above report indicates that a massive immunization drive has been taken in the district, but the type of immunization is not specified. Presumably, it is JE virus vaccine, since the etiology of the AES cases is not identified. INDIA (16): (BIHAR)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 15 Nov 2015\nSource: The Times of India [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/Encephalitis-toll-goes-up-to-24-in-Gaya/articleshow/49790043.cms\n\n\nWith 1 more death reported from Anugrah Narain Magadh Medical College Hospital, the number of encephalitis deaths has gone up to 24. Altogether, 123 AES [acute encephalitis syndrome] patients were admitted to the children's ward of the ANMMCH with AES symptoms. Of these, 35 of the patients were found suffering from Japanese encephalitis, the more deadly form of the disease.\n\nConfirming 24 deaths due to AES this season, ANMMCH superintendent Dr SK Sinha said that 35 of the 123 AES patients admitted to the hospital this season tested JE positive. Giving a further breakdown, the superintendent said that of the 23 deaths reported this season, 8 suffered from Japanese encephalitis while the other 15 died due to AES.\n\nNow that the temperature has come down and winter is beginning to set in, there was little likelihood of the disease spreading any further. Altogether 96 encephalitis patients have been discharged while another 4 were undergoing treatment in the children's ward of the hospital; 2 of the patients were discharged on Friday [13 Nov 2015] after satisfactory recovery.\n\nThe encephalitis survivors have suffered mild to severe mental retardation and physical infirmities, particularly weakening of the upper and lower limbs. Facilities for the rehabilitation of the AES survivors are not available in the hospital and as such the discharged patients have to fend for themselves. According to activist Brajnandan Pathak, the affected patients -- being very poor (almost all of them belong to the Mahadalit social group) -- cannot afford rehabilitation at centres outside the district.\n\nAs per available statistics, the maximum number of AES deaths were reported in 2011 when no fewer than 70 children died of encephalitis in ANMMCH alone. In 2009 too, 46 AES deaths took place. The numbers of affected children in 2011 and 2009 were 321 and 151 respectively.\n\nHealth officials claim to have undertaken a massive immunisation drive in the district to prevent [spread of] the deadly disease. But the claims have fallen flat after the outbreak of the disease which took almost epidemic form.\n\n[Byline: Abdul Qadir]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report gives definite numbers of cases due to Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus infections. However, the etiology of the AES cases remains undetermined. A 22 Sep 2015 report indicated that there were 10 834 AES cases in 2014. That report describes AES as \"a group of clinical neurologic manifestations caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungus, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins\" (http://zeenews.india.com/news/health/health-news/india-had-over-10000-acute-encephalitis-syndrome-cases-in-2014_1800724.html).\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts have implicated Reye syndrome, consumption of lychees, and heat stroke, as well as JE virus infections, as responsible for AES. The above report indicates that a massive immunization drive has been taken in the district, but the type of immunization is not specified. Presumably, it is JE virus vaccine, since the etiology of the AES cases is not identified. Prevention and control of AES will be difficult until there is a clear indication of the etiologies involved in these cases. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46246.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA (16): (BIHAR)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 15 Nov 2015\nSource: The Times of India [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/Encephalitis-toll-goes-up-to-24-in-Gaya/articleshow/49790043.cms\n\n\nWith 1 more death reported from Anugrah Narain Magadh Medical College Hospital, the number of encephalitis deaths has gone up to 24. Altogether, 123 AES [acute encephalitis syndrome] patients were admitted to the children's ward of the ANMMCH with AES symptoms. Of these, 35 of the patients were found suffering from Japanese encephalitis, the more deadly form of the disease.\n\nConfirming 24 deaths due to AES this season, ANMMCH superintendent Dr SK Sinha said that 35 of the 123 AES patients admitted to the hospital this season tested JE positive. Giving a further breakdown, the superintendent said that of the 23 deaths reported this season, 8 suffered from Japanese encephalitis while the other 15 died due to AES.\n\nNow that the temperature has come down and winter is beginning to set in, there was little likelihood of the disease spreading any further. Altogether 96 encephalitis patients have been discharged while another 4 were undergoing treatment in the children's ward of the hospital; 2 of the patients were discharged on Friday [13 Nov 2015] after satisfactory recovery.\n\nThe encephalitis survivors have suffered mild to severe mental retardation and physical infirmities, particularly weakening of the upper and lower limbs. Facilities for the rehabilitation of the AES survivors are not available in the hospital and as such the discharged patients have to fend for themselves. According to activist Brajnandan Pathak, the affected patients -- being very poor (almost all of them belong to the Mahadalit social group) -- cannot afford rehabilitation at centres outside the district.\n\nAs per available statistics, the maximum number of AES deaths were reported in 2011 when no fewer than 70 children died of encephalitis in ANMMCH alone. In 2009 too, 46 AES deaths took place. The numbers of affected children in 2011 and 2009 were 321 and 151 respectively.\n\nHealth officials claim to have undertaken a massive immunisation drive in the district to prevent [spread of] the deadly disease. But the claims have fallen flat after the outbreak of the disease which took almost epidemic form.\n\n[Byline: Abdul Qadir]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report gives definite numbers of cases due to Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus infections. However, the etiology of the AES cases remains undetermined. A 22 Sep 2015 report indicated that there were 10 834 AES cases in 2014. That report describes AES as \"a group of clinical neurologic manifestations caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungus, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins\" (http://zeenews.india.com/news/health/health-news/india-had-over-10000-acute-encephalitis-syndrome-cases-in-2014_1800724.html).\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts have implicated Reye syndrome, consumption of lychees, and heat stroke, as well as JE virus infections, as responsible for AES. The above report indicates that a massive immunization drive has been taken in the district, but the type of immunization is not specified. Presumably, it is JE virus vaccine, since the etiology of the AES cases is not identified. Prevention and control of AES will be difficult until there is a clear indication of the etiologies involved in these cases. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46246.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (BR) litchi, methylenecyclopropylglycine 20150201.3132842\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (01): (AS) 20150128.3126931\n.................................................ty/pg/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-09-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3830275", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (WB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3830275", "date": "2015-11-16 00:22:46", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (16): (BIHAR)\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 15 Nov 2015\nSource: The Times of India [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/Encephalitis-toll-goes-up-to-24-in-Gaya/articleshow/49790043.cms\n\n\nWith 1 more death reported from Anugrah Narain Magadh Medical College Hospital, the number of encephalitis deaths has gone up to 24. Altogether, 123 AES [acute encephalitis syndrome] patients were admitted to the children's ward of the ANMMCH with AES symptoms. Of these, 35 of the patients were found suffering from Japanese encephalitis, the more deadly form of the disease.\n\nConfirming 24 deaths due to AES this season, ANMMCH superintendent Dr SK Sinha said that 35 of the 123 AES patients admitted to the hospital this season tested JE positive. Giving a further breakdown, the superintendent said that of the 23 deaths reported this season, 8 suffered from Japanese encephalitis while the other 15 died due to AES.\n\nNow that the temperature has come down and winter is beginning to set in, there was little likelihood of the disease spreading any further. Altogether 96 encephalitis patients have been discharged while another 4 were undergoing treatment in the children's ward of the hospital; 2 of the patients were discharged on Friday [13 Nov 2015] after satisfactory recovery.\n\nThe encephalitis survivors have suffered mild to severe mental retardation and physical infirmities, particularly weakening of the upper and lower limbs. Facilities for the rehabilitation of the AES survivors are not available in the hospital and as such the discharged patients have to fend for themselves. According to activist Brajnandan Pathak, the affected patients -- being very poor (almost all of them belong to the Mahadalit social group) -- cannot afford rehabilitation at centres outside the district.\n\nAs per available statistics, the maximum number of AES deaths were reported in 2011 when no fewer than 70 children died of encephalitis in ANMMCH alone. In 2009 too, 46 AES deaths took place. The numbers of affected children in 2011 and 2009 were 321 and 151 respectively.\n\nHealth officials claim to have undertaken a massive immunisation drive in the district to prevent [spread of] the deadly disease. But the claims have fallen flat after the outbreak of the disease which took almost epidemic form.\n\n[Byline: Abdul Qadir]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report gives definite numbers of cases due to Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus infections. However, the etiology of the AES cases remains undetermined. A 22 Sep 2015 report indicated that there were 10 834 AES cases in 2014. That report describes AES as \"a group of clinical neurologic manifestations caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, fungus, parasites, spirochetes, chemicals and toxins\" (http://zeenews.india.com/news/health/health-news/india-had-over-10000-acute-encephalitis-syndrome-cases-in-2014_1800724.html).\n\nPrevious ProMED-mail posts have implicated Reye syndrome, consumption of lychees, and heat stroke, as well as JE virus infections, as responsible for AES. The above report indicates that a massive immunization drive has been taken in the district, but the type of immunization is not specified. Presumably, it is JE virus vaccine, since the etiology of the AES cases is not identified. Prevention and control of AES will be difficult until there is a clear indication of the etiologies involved in these cases. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46246.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - Of these, 35 of the patients were found suffering from Japanese encephalitis, the more deadly form of the disease.\n\nConfirming 24 deaths due to AES this season, ANMMCH superintendent Dr SK Sinha said that 35 of the 123 AES patients admitted to the hospital this season tested JE positive. Giving a further breakdown, the superintendent said that of the 23 deaths reported this season, 8 suffered from Japanese encephalitis while the other 15 died due to AES.\n\nNow that the temperature has come down and winter is beginning to set in, there was little likelihood of the disease spreading any further. The numbers of affected children in 2011 and 2009 were 321 and 151 respectively.\n\nHealth officials claim to have undertaken a massive immunisation drive in the district to prevent [spread of] the deadly disease. India: (BR) litchi, methylenecyclopropylglycine 20150201.3132842\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (01): (AS) 20150128.3126931\n.................................................ty/pg/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-09-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3681239", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (15)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3681239", "date": "2015-08-08 21:34:40", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (TAMIL NADU)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 8 Aug 2015\nSource: The New Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Four-year-old-Dies-of-Japanese-Encephalitis/2015/08/08/article2963400.ece\n\n\nIn a rare case of Japanese encephalitis (JE), a mosquito-borne disease, a 4-year-old boy from Keezhlsathamangalur near Ariyur here died at the Institute of Child Health in Chennai on 1 Aug [2015].\n\nInitially, the boy was administered rabies vaccine at Indira Gandhi Government General Hospital and Post Graduate Institute (IGMCRI) after being bitten by a stray dog, but subsequently the family took him to the JIPMER [Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education & Research].\n\nWhen the boy developed fever and complications, suspecting it to be a case of rabies encephalopathy, JIPMER referred the boy to Rajiv Gandhi Women and Children Hospital on 27 Jul 2015. The parents instead took the child to IGMCRI, which in turn referred the boy to Chennai.\n\nThis is a rare (JE) case reported in Puducherry, though in some parts of neighbouring Villupuram district it is endemic, Director of Health and Family Welfare Dr K V Raman told Express. The departments of Revenue, Local Administration and Vector Control Research centre (VCRC) were alerted. The entire region was surveyed for fever cases. Blood test was done for more than 90 residents. Fogging was done to destroy all mosquitoes. Ducks and cranes were removed and tested. Stagnant water in the fields was drained out by the Agriculture Department.\n\nMeanwhile, the Sentinel Surveillance unit for JE is being set up after getting approval from National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), said Dr Raman. Diagnostic kits are being procured from National institute of Virology, Pune. Till the testing facilities are established, samples will be sent to District Hospitals in Villupuram and Cuddalore, he added.\n\n[Byline: Debjani Dutta]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is no mention of laboratory confirmation of JE virus infection in this report. If this is a confirmed case, this is the 1st report of JE virus infection in Tamil Nadu state that ProMED-mail has posted, although the Director of Health and Family Welfare is quoted as saying that the virus is known to be endemic in a neighboring district. Both districts are located in the northern part of Tamil Nadu state. There are numerous JE cases in northeastern India again in 2015, along with some cases of encephalopathy and hypoglycemia associated with consumption of lychee fruit containing phytotoxins, specifically \u03b1-(methylenecyclopropyl)glycine. However, Tamil Nadu is far from the lychee producing areas in northern India http://www.mapsofindia.com/indiaagriculture/fruits-map/litchi-producing-states.html.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/images2/india-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306,\nWest Bengal state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/323, and Assam state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/319.]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (AS) 20150729.3545979\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS, WB) Viet Nam 20140807.2669178\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): comment, Reye-like encephalopathy 20140804.2656983\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS,WB) 20140801.2652476\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "District Hospitals", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Cuddalore", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Chennai", "country": "India"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/319", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Villupuram", "country": "India"}, {"location": "west bengal", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3633134", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3633134", "date": "2015-08-08 21:34:40", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS & OTHER - INDIA (09): (TAMIL NADU)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 8 Aug 2015\nSource: The New Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/Four-year-old-Dies-of-Japanese-Encephalitis/2015/08/08/article2963400.ece\n\n\nIn a rare case of Japanese encephalitis (JE), a mosquito-borne disease, a 4-year-old boy from Keezhlsathamangalur near Ariyur here died at the Institute of Child Health in Chennai on 1 Aug [2015].\n\nInitially, the boy was administered rabies vaccine at Indira Gandhi Government General Hospital and Post Graduate Institute (IGMCRI) after being bitten by a stray dog, but subsequently the family took him to the JIPMER [Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education & Research].\n\nWhen the boy developed fever and complications, suspecting it to be a case of rabies encephalopathy, JIPMER referred the boy to Rajiv Gandhi Women and Children Hospital on 27 Jul 2015. The parents instead took the child to IGMCRI, which in turn referred the boy to Chennai.\n\nThis is a rare (JE) case reported in Puducherry, though in some parts of neighbouring Villupuram district it is endemic, Director of Health and Family Welfare Dr K V Raman told Express. The departments of Revenue, Local Administration and Vector Control Research centre (VCRC) were alerted. The entire region was surveyed for fever cases. Blood test was done for more than 90 residents. Fogging was done to destroy all mosquitoes. Ducks and cranes were removed and tested. Stagnant water in the fields was drained out by the Agriculture Department.\n\nMeanwhile, the Sentinel Surveillance unit for JE is being set up after getting approval from National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), said Dr Raman. Diagnostic kits are being procured from National institute of Virology, Pune. Till the testing facilities are established, samples will be sent to District Hospitals in Villupuram and Cuddalore, he added.\n\n[Byline: Debjani Dutta]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is no mention of laboratory confirmation of JE virus infection in this report. If this is a confirmed case, this is the 1st report of JE virus infection in Tamil Nadu state that ProMED-mail has posted, although the Director of Health and Family Welfare is quoted as saying that the virus is known to be endemic in a neighboring district. Both districts are located in the northern part of Tamil Nadu state. There are numerous JE cases in northeastern India again in 2015, along with some cases of encephalopathy and hypoglycemia associated with consumption of lychee fruit containing phytotoxins, specifically \u03b1-(methylenecyclopropyl)glycine. However, Tamil Nadu is far from the lychee producing areas in northern India http://www.mapsofindia.com/indiaagriculture/fruits-map/litchi-producing-states.html.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/images2/india-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/306,\nWest Bengal state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/323, and Assam state at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/299. -
