India (17): (AS, WB) Viet Nam 20140807.2669178\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): comment, Reye-like encephalopathy 20140804.2656983\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS,WB) 20140801.2652476\n.................................................sb/dk/ty/pg/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "District Hospitals", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Cuddalore", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Chennai", "country": "India"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/319", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Villupuram", "country": "India"}, {"location": "west bengal", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3545979", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3545979", "date": "2015-01-28 20:10:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (01): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/26/us-india-encephalitis-idUSKBN0KZ10L20150126\n\n\nCases of deadly mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis [JE] have risen nearly 5-fold in 5 years in India's northeast Assam state as a result of warming weather and changing rainfall, health experts say.\n\nBetween 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. The disease, which in 2009 was recorded in only half of the state's districts, now is seen in all of them.\n\nDoctors say climate change has played a major role in the spread of the disease, which once appeared largely from May to July but now is seen as late in the year as November, as mosquitoes survive longer in warmer conditions.\n\nJapanese encephalitis is characterized by inflammation of the brain and high fever.\n\n\"Now, the temperature ... which is ideal for breeding of the _Culex_ mosquito, is present almost until October or so, and as a result of this, the cases of the disease are increasing,\" said Rabindra Nath Talukdar, a senior official of the Assam health department.\n\n\"Initially, it was only an upper Assam disease ... but now it has also been detected in lower Assam districts, and (now) cases have been reported from all the 27 districts in Assam,\" Talukdar said.\n\nHealth department officials said changes in agricultural patterns may be affecting the rise in encephalitis cases. Warmer conditions have allowed farmers to grow more crops of rice each year, which means rice paddies with standing water offer a breeding ground for mosquitoes for a larger part of each year. \"The _Culex_ mosquito breeds on water in the agricultural land, and now since there is water on the field for several more months than before, it gives more time and space for the mosquito to breed,\" Talukdar said.\n\nFaced with a surge in Japanese encephalitis cases, the Assam government has announced measures to tackle the problem, including more careful monitoring of cases. Assam Health Minister Nazrul Islam described the situation as \"a huge concern. I have asked the senior officials of the health department to monitor the situation carefully and to report to me on a regular basis,\" he said.\n\nFaced with a growing public outcry over the disease's rapid spread, Assam Chief Minister Tarun Gogoi has ordered officials of the Assam health department to develop a plan to control the disease.\n\nPlans should include \"setting up of an intensive care unit in each district hospital for treatment of emergency cases, along with laboratory testing units,\" Gogoi said. As well, \"I have already asked the health department to procure laboratory testing kits for quick diagnosis of the disease, adequate vaccines and medicines for the hospitals, and also to carry out intensive fogging in the affected areas,\" he said.\n\nCivil society groups and activists have, however, questioned why such steps were not taken earlier. \"The data from the state health department itself shows that the disease has taken a deadly turn over the years in the state. Unfortunately, the state machinery waited for the disease to go out of control, whereas it should have taken steps to control the disease much earlier,\" said Sankar Prasad Rai, of the All Assam Students Union (AASU).\n\nSeveral influential student groups of the state, including the All Assam Students Union and the Assam Jatiyatibadi Yuva Chatra Parishad (AJYCP), have staged protests over the government's failure to control the spread of Japanese encephalitis.\n\n[Byline: Amarjyoti Borah]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. The JE virus etiology of some encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests. However, many cases go undiagnosed or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, have been proposed.\n\nThe above report indicates that the cases referred to in Assam are JE. Increased surveillance, coupled with timely laboratory support, is very important for any control efforts to be successful. Although delivery of JE virus vaccine to hospitals is mentioned, it is curious that no mention is made of an Assam-wide vaccination campaign, nor is there mention of campaigns in previous years. Vaccination is more likely to be more effective for prevention of JE cases than vector control, particularly with the increase in the areas of paddy rice cultivation that provide _Culex_ vector mosquito breeding sites. The virus doubtless is endemic in northeastern India. Ardeid birds [heron family] are reservoir hosts.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/images2/india-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/323. - Mod.TY\n\nProMED 1st reported JE in Assam in 1998 and has carried reports annually since 2003. It would indeed be good to develop a plan to control the disease there. Vaccination works well in other parts of India. - Mod.,JW]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (MH) 20141121.2978346\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (BR) 20140930.2818512\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (UP) 20140924.2799733\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (UP) 20140910.2764597\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (ML) 20140830.2736957\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (WB) 20140815.2691972\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS, WB) Viet Nam 20140807.2669178\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): comment, Reye-like encephalopathy 20140804.2656983\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS,WB) 20140801.2652476\n.................................................sb/jw/ty/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "warmer", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3534646", "headline": "PRO/AH> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (AS) vaccine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3534646", "date": "2015-01-28 20:10:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (01): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/26/us-india-encephalitis-idUSKBN0KZ10L20150126\n\n\nCases of deadly mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis [JE] have risen nearly 5-fold in 5 years in India's northeast Assam state as a result of warming weather and changing rainfall, health experts say.\n\nBetween 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. The disease, which in 2009 was recorded in only half of the state's districts, now is seen in all of them.\n\nDoctors say climate change has played a major role in the spread of the disease, which once appeared largely from May to July but now is seen as late in the year as November, as mosquitoes survive longer in warmer conditions.\n\nJapanese encephalitis is characterized by inflammation of the brain and high fever.\n\n\"Now, the temperature ... which is ideal for breeding of the _Culex_ mosquito, is present almost until October or so, and as a result of this, the cases of the disease are increasing,\" said Rabindra Nath Talukdar, a senior official of the Assam health department.\n\n\"Initially, it was only an upper Assam disease ... but now it has also been detected in lower Assam districts, and (now) cases have been reported from all the 27 districts in Assam,\" Talukdar said.\n\nHealth department officials said changes in agricultural patterns may be affecting the rise in encephalitis cases. Warmer conditions have allowed farmers to grow more crops of rice each year, which means rice paddies with standing water offer a breeding ground for mosquitoes for a larger part of each year. \"The _Culex_ mosquito breeds on water in the agricultural land, and now since there is water on the field for several more months than before, it gives more time and space for the mosquito to breed,\" Talukdar said.\n\nFaced with a surge in Japanese encephalitis cases, the Assam government has announced measures to tackle the problem, including more careful monitoring of cases. Assam Health Minister Nazrul Islam described the situation as \"a huge concern. I have asked the senior officials of the health department to monitor the situation carefully and to report to me on a regular basis,\" he said.\n\nFaced with a growing public outcry over the disease's rapid spread, Assam Chief Minister Tarun Gogoi has ordered officials of the Assam health department to develop a plan to control the disease.\n\nPlans should include \"setting up of an intensive care unit in each district hospital for treatment of emergency cases, along with laboratory testing units,\" Gogoi said. As well, \"I have already asked the health department to procure laboratory testing kits for quick diagnosis of the disease, adequate vaccines and medicines for the hospitals, and also to carry out intensive fogging in the affected areas,\" he said.\n\nCivil society groups and activists have, however, questioned why such steps were not taken earlier. \"The data from the state health department itself shows that the disease has taken a deadly turn over the years in the state. Unfortunately, the state machinery waited for the disease to go out of control, whereas it should have taken steps to control the disease much earlier,\" said Sankar Prasad Rai, of the All Assam Students Union (AASU).\n\nSeveral influential student groups of the state, including the All Assam Students Union and the Assam Jatiyatibadi Yuva Chatra Parishad (AJYCP), have staged protests over the government's failure to control the spread of Japanese encephalitis.\n\n[Byline: Amarjyoti Borah]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. The JE virus etiology of some encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests. However, many cases go undiagnosed or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, have been proposed.\n\nThe above report indicates that the cases referred to in Assam are JE. Increased surveillance, coupled with timely laboratory support, is very important for any control efforts to be successful. Although delivery of JE virus vaccine to hospitals is mentioned, it is curious that no mention is made of an Assam-wide vaccination campaign, nor is there mention of campaigns in previous years. INDIA (01): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/26/us-india-encephalitis-idUSKBN0KZ10L20150126\n\n\nCases of deadly mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis [JE] have risen nearly 5-fold in 5 years in India's northeast Assam state as a result of warming weather and changing rainfall, health experts say.\n\nBetween 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. The disease, which in 2009 was recorded in only half of the state's districts, now is seen in all of them.\n\nDoctors say climate change has played a major role in the spread of the disease, which once appeared largely from May to July but now is seen as late in the year as November, as mosquitoes survive longer in warmer conditions.\n\nJapanese encephalitis is characterized by inflammation of the brain and high fever.\n\n\"Now, the temperature ... which is ideal for breeding of the _Culex_ mosquito, is present almost until October or so, and as a result of this, the cases of the disease are increasing,\" said Rabindra Nath Talukdar, a senior official of the Assam health department.\n\n\"Initially, it was only an upper Assam disease ... but now it has also been detected in lower Assam districts, and (now) cases have been reported from all the 27 districts in Assam,\" Talukdar said.\n\nHealth department officials said changes in agricultural patterns may be affecting the rise in encephalitis cases. Warmer conditions have allowed farmers to grow more crops of rice each year, which means rice paddies with standing water offer a breeding ground for mosquitoes for a larger part of each year. \"The _Culex_ mosquito breeds on water in the agricultural land, and now since there is water on the field for several more months than before, it gives more time and space for the mosquito to breed,\" Talukdar said.\n\nFaced with a surge in Japanese encephalitis cases, the Assam government has announced measures to tackle the problem, including more careful monitoring of cases. Assam Health Minister Nazrul Islam described the situation as \"a huge concern. I have asked the senior officials of the health department to monitor the situation carefully and to report to me on a regular basis,\" he said.\n\nFaced with a growing public outcry over the disease's rapid spread, Assam Chief Minister Tarun Gogoi has ordered officials of the Assam health department to develop a plan to control the disease.\n\nPlans should include \"setting up of an intensive care unit in each district hospital for treatment of emergency cases, along with laboratory testing units,\" Gogoi said. As well, \"I have already asked the health department to procure laboratory testing kits for quick diagnosis of the disease, adequate vaccines and medicines for the hospitals, and also to carry out intensive fogging in the affected areas,\" he said.\n\nCivil society groups and activists have, however, questioned why such steps were not taken earlier. \"The data from the state health department itself shows that the disease has taken a deadly turn over the years in the state. Unfortunately, the state machinery waited for the disease to go out of control, whereas it should have taken steps to control the disease much earlier,\" said Sankar Prasad Rai, of the All Assam Students Union (AASU).\n\nSeveral influential student groups of the state, including the All Assam Students Union and the Assam Jatiyatibadi Yuva Chatra Parishad (AJYCP), have staged protests over the government's failure to control the spread of Japanese encephalitis.\n\n[Byline: Amarjyoti Borah]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. However, many cases go undiagnosed or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, have been proposed.\n\nThe above report indicates that the cases referred to in Assam are JE. INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3513485", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (WB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3513485", "date": "2015-01-28 20:10:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (01): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/26/us-india-encephalitis-idUSKBN0KZ10L20150126\n\n\nCases of deadly mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis [JE] have risen nearly 5-fold in 5 years in India's northeast Assam state as a result of warming weather and changing rainfall, health experts say.\n\nBetween 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. The disease, which in 2009 was recorded in only half of the state's districts, now is seen in all of them.\n\nDoctors say climate change has played a major role in the spread of the disease, which once appeared largely from May to July but now is seen as late in the year as November, as mosquitoes survive longer in warmer conditions.\n\nJapanese encephalitis is characterized by inflammation of the brain and high fever.\n\n\"Now, the temperature ... which is ideal for breeding of the _Culex_ mosquito, is present almost until October or so, and as a result of this, the cases of the disease are increasing,\" said Rabindra Nath Talukdar, a senior official of the Assam health department.\n\n\"Initially, it was only an upper Assam disease ... but now it has also been detected in lower Assam districts, and (now) cases have been reported from all the 27 districts in Assam,\" Talukdar said.\n\nHealth department officials said changes in agricultural patterns may be affecting the rise in encephalitis cases. Warmer conditions have allowed farmers to grow more crops of rice each year, which means rice paddies with standing water offer a breeding ground for mosquitoes for a larger part of each year. \"The _Culex_ mosquito breeds on water in the agricultural land, and now since there is water on the field for several more months than before, it gives more time and space for the mosquito to breed,\" Talukdar said.\n\nFaced with a surge in Japanese encephalitis cases, the Assam government has announced measures to tackle the problem, including more careful monitoring of cases. Assam Health Minister Nazrul Islam described the situation as \"a huge concern. I have asked the senior officials of the health department to monitor the situation carefully and to report to me on a regular basis,\" he said.\n\nFaced with a growing public outcry over the disease's rapid spread, Assam Chief Minister Tarun Gogoi has ordered officials of the Assam health department to develop a plan to control the disease.\n\nPlans should include \"setting up of an intensive care unit in each district hospital for treatment of emergency cases, along with laboratory testing units,\" Gogoi said. As well, \"I have already asked the health department to procure laboratory testing kits for quick diagnosis of the disease, adequate vaccines and medicines for the hospitals, and also to carry out intensive fogging in the affected areas,\" he said.\n\nCivil society groups and activists have, however, questioned why such steps were not taken earlier. \"The data from the state health department itself shows that the disease has taken a deadly turn over the years in the state. Unfortunately, the state machinery waited for the disease to go out of control, whereas it should have taken steps to control the disease much earlier,\" said Sankar Prasad Rai, of the All Assam Students Union (AASU).\n\nSeveral influential student groups of the state, including the All Assam Students Union and the Assam Jatiyatibadi Yuva Chatra Parishad (AJYCP), have staged protests over the government's failure to control the spread of Japanese encephalitis.\n\n[Byline: Amarjyoti Borah]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. The JE virus etiology of some encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests. However, many cases go undiagnosed or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, have been proposed.\n\nThe above report indicates that the cases referred to in Assam are JE. Although delivery of JE virus vaccine to hospitals is mentioned, it is curious that no mention is made of an Assam-wide vaccination campaign, nor is there mention of campaigns in previous years. India (21): (UP) 20140924.2799733\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (UP) 20140910.2764597\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (ML) 20140830.2736957\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (WB) 20140815.2691972\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS, WB) Viet Nam 20140807.2669178\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): comment, Reye-like encephalopathy 20140804.2656983\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS,WB) 20140801.2652476\n.................................................sb/jw/ty/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "warmer", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3510678", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (AS) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3510678", "date": "2015-01-28 20:10:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (01): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/26/us-india-encephalitis-idUSKBN0KZ10L20150126\n\n\nCases of deadly mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis [JE] have risen nearly 5-fold in 5 years in India's northeast Assam state as a result of warming weather and changing rainfall, health experts say.\n\nBetween 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. The disease, which in 2009 was recorded in only half of the state's districts, now is seen in all of them.\n\nDoctors say climate change has played a major role in the spread of the disease, which once appeared largely from May to July but now is seen as late in the year as November, as mosquitoes survive longer in warmer conditions.\n\nJapanese encephalitis is characterized by inflammation of the brain and high fever.\n\n\"Now, the temperature ... which is ideal for breeding of the _Culex_ mosquito, is present almost until October or so, and as a result of this, the cases of the disease are increasing,\" said Rabindra Nath Talukdar, a senior official of the Assam health department.\n\n\"Initially, it was only an upper Assam disease ... but now it has also been detected in lower Assam districts, and (now) cases have been reported from all the 27 districts in Assam,\" Talukdar said.\n\nHealth department officials said changes in agricultural patterns may be affecting the rise in encephalitis cases. Warmer conditions have allowed farmers to grow more crops of rice each year, which means rice paddies with standing water offer a breeding ground for mosquitoes for a larger part of each year. \"The _Culex_ mosquito breeds on water in the agricultural land, and now since there is water on the field for several more months than before, it gives more time and space for the mosquito to breed,\" Talukdar said.\n\nFaced with a surge in Japanese encephalitis cases, the Assam government has announced measures to tackle the problem, including more careful monitoring of cases. Assam Health Minister Nazrul Islam described the situation as \"a huge concern. I have asked the senior officials of the health department to monitor the situation carefully and to report to me on a regular basis,\" he said.\n\nFaced with a growing public outcry over the disease's rapid spread, Assam Chief Minister Tarun Gogoi has ordered officials of the Assam health department to develop a plan to control the disease.\n\nPlans should include \"setting up of an intensive care unit in each district hospital for treatment of emergency cases, along with laboratory testing units,\" Gogoi said. As well, \"I have already asked the health department to procure laboratory testing kits for quick diagnosis of the disease, adequate vaccines and medicines for the hospitals, and also to carry out intensive fogging in the affected areas,\" he said.\n\nCivil society groups and activists have, however, questioned why such steps were not taken earlier. \"The data from the state health department itself shows that the disease has taken a deadly turn over the years in the state. Unfortunately, the state machinery waited for the disease to go out of control, whereas it should have taken steps to control the disease much earlier,\" said Sankar Prasad Rai, of the All Assam Students Union (AASU).\n\nSeveral influential student groups of the state, including the All Assam Students Union and the Assam Jatiyatibadi Yuva Chatra Parishad (AJYCP), have staged protests over the government's failure to control the spread of Japanese encephalitis.\n\n[Byline: Amarjyoti Borah]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. The JE virus etiology of some encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests. However, many cases go undiagnosed or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, have been proposed.\n\nThe above report indicates that the cases referred to in Assam are JE. Increased surveillance, coupled with timely laboratory support, is very important for any control efforts to be successful. Although delivery of JE virus vaccine to hospitals is mentioned, it is curious that no mention is made of an Assam-wide vaccination campaign, nor is there mention of campaigns in previous years. Vaccination is more likely to be more effective for prevention of JE cases than vector control, particularly with the increase in the areas of paddy rice cultivation that provide _Culex_ vector mosquito breeding sites. The virus doubtless is endemic in northeastern India. Ardeid birds [heron family] are reservoir hosts.\n\nMaps of India can be seen at http://www.mapsofindia.com/images2/india-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/323. - Mod.TY\n\nProMED 1st reported JE in Assam in 1998 and has carried reports annually since 2003. It would indeed be good to develop a plan to control the disease there. Vaccination works well in other parts of India. - Mod.,JW]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (MH) 20141121.2978346\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (BR) 20140930.2818512\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (21): (UP) 20140924.2799733\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (UP) 20140910.2764597\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (ML) 20140830.2736957\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (WB) 20140815.2691972\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS, WB) Viet Nam 20140807.2669178\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): comment, Reye-like encephalopathy 20140804.2656983\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (AS,WB) 20140801.2652476\n.................................................sb/jw/ty/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "warmer", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3499921", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (WB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3499921", "date": "2015-01-28 20:10:09", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (01): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/26/us-india-encephalitis-idUSKBN0KZ10L20150126\n\n\nCases of deadly mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis [JE] have risen nearly 5-fold in 5 years in India's northeast Assam state as a result of warming weather and changing rainfall, health experts say.\n\nBetween 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. The disease, which in 2009 was recorded in only half of the state's districts, now is seen in all of them.\n\nDoctors say climate change has played a major role in the spread of the disease, which once appeared largely from May to July but now is seen as late in the year as November, as mosquitoes survive longer in warmer conditions.\n\nJapanese encephalitis is characterized by inflammation of the brain and high fever.\n\n\"Now, the temperature ... which is ideal for breeding of the _Culex_ mosquito, is present almost until October or so, and as a result of this, the cases of the disease are increasing,\" said Rabindra Nath Talukdar, a senior official of the Assam health department.\n\n\"Initially, it was only an upper Assam disease ... but now it has also been detected in lower Assam districts, and (now) cases have been reported from all the 27 districts in Assam,\" Talukdar said.\n\nHealth department officials said changes in agricultural patterns may be affecting the rise in encephalitis cases. Warmer conditions have allowed farmers to grow more crops of rice each year, which means rice paddies with standing water offer a breeding ground for mosquitoes for a larger part of each year. \"The _Culex_ mosquito breeds on water in the agricultural land, and now since there is water on the field for several more months than before, it gives more time and space for the mosquito to breed,\" Talukdar said.\n\nFaced with a surge in Japanese encephalitis cases, the Assam government has announced measures to tackle the problem, including more careful monitoring of cases. Assam Health Minister Nazrul Islam described the situation as \"a huge concern. I have asked the senior officials of the health department to monitor the situation carefully and to report to me on a regular basis,\" he said.\n\nFaced with a growing public outcry over the disease's rapid spread, Assam Chief Minister Tarun Gogoi has ordered officials of the Assam health department to develop a plan to control the disease.\n\nPlans should include \"setting up of an intensive care unit in each district hospital for treatment of emergency cases, along with laboratory testing units,\" Gogoi said. As well, \"I have already asked the health department to procure laboratory testing kits for quick diagnosis of the disease, adequate vaccines and medicines for the hospitals, and also to carry out intensive fogging in the affected areas,\" he said.\n\nCivil society groups and activists have, however, questioned why such steps were not taken earlier. \"The data from the state health department itself shows that the disease has taken a deadly turn over the years in the state. Unfortunately, the state machinery waited for the disease to go out of control, whereas it should have taken steps to control the disease much earlier,\" said Sankar Prasad Rai, of the All Assam Students Union (AASU).\n\nSeveral influential student groups of the state, including the All Assam Students Union and the Assam Jatiyatibadi Yuva Chatra Parishad (AJYCP), have staged protests over the government's failure to control the spread of Japanese encephalitis.\n\n[Byline: Amarjyoti Borah]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. However, many cases go undiagnosed or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, have been proposed.\n\nThe above report indicates that the cases referred to in Assam are JE. Increased surveillance, coupled with timely laboratory support, is very important for any control efforts to be successful. Although delivery of JE virus vaccine to hospitals is mentioned, it is curious that no mention is made of an Assam-wide vaccination campaign, nor is there mention of campaigns in previous years. Vaccination is more likely to be more effective for prevention of JE cases than vector control, particularly with the increase in the areas of paddy rice cultivation that provide _Culex_ vector mosquito breeding sites. INDIA (01): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/26/us-india-encephalitis-idUSKBN0KZ10L20150126\n\n\nCases of deadly mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis [JE] have risen nearly 5-fold in 5 years in India's northeast Assam state as a result of warming weather and changing rainfall, health experts say.\n\nBetween 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. INDIA (01): (ASSAM)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 26 Jan 2015\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/26/us-india-encephalitis-idUSKBN0KZ10L20150126\n\n\nCases of deadly mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis [JE] have risen nearly 5-fold in 5 years in India's northeast Assam state as a result of warming weather and changing rainfall, health experts say.\n\nBetween 2010 and 2014, the number of annual cases rose from 154 to 744, with deaths rising from 41-160, according to data from the Assam health department. India (15): (AS,WB) 20140801.2652476\n.................................................sb/jw/ty/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2015-01-26 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-10-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Assam", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "warmer", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3032106", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (OR) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3032106", "date": "2014-08-15 15:50:42", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - CHINA (03): (HONG KONG)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2014\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/478538/local_confirmed_case_of_japanese_encephalitis_under_chp_investigation.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [6 Aug 2014] investigating a local confirmed case of Japanese encephalitis (JE) [virus infection], and hence urged the public to take precautions against mosquito-transmitted diseases.\n\nThe male patient, aged 36, with good past health, developed headache on 28 Jul [2014] and attended the Accident & Emergency Department (AED) of Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH) on 30 Jul [2014]. He was noted to have confused speech and seizures on 1 Aug [2014] and was taken to the AED of TMH again. He was admitted for further management on the same day. The patient is now afebrile in stable condition.\n\nHis cerebrospinal fluid and serum specimens tested positive for antibodies against JE [virus antigens] today [6 Aug 2014] upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch.\n\nInitial enquiries revealed that the patient lives in the quarters of Crossroads Foundation near Gold Coast, Tuen Mun, and had no recent travel history during the incubation period.\n\nHe could not recall any recent mosquito bites. His family contact has remained asymptomatic and will be put under medical surveillance. The CHP's investigations are ongoing.\n\nOfficers of the CHP will conduct home visits and surveys among neighbours of the patient's residence for active case finding and arranging of blood tests.\n\nThe CHP's hotline (2125 1122), set up for public enquiries since the 1st local confirmed JE case, will operate till 9 pm today and from 9 am to 6 pm from tomorrow (7 Aug 2014] onwards.\n\nA health talk will be held at Crossroads Foundation this evening to deliver health advice to the public. Residents of Tuen Mun District with JE symptoms are also advised to promptly seek medical attention.\n\nThe CHP will issue letters to doctors and hospitals to draw their attention to the case and enlist their support in early diagnosis, control and prevention of JE.\n\nThis is the 4th JE case (3 local, one imported) reported to the CHP this year. In 2013, 6 cases (2 local, 3 imported, one unclassified) were reported in 2013 while 3 (one local, 2 imported) were filed in 2012.\n\n\"JE is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes. _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ (culicine mosquito) is the principal vector of JE and is nocturnal. It mainly breeds in waterlogged fields, marshes, ditches, and small stagnant collections of water around cultivated fields. The mosquitoes become infected by feeding on pigs and wild birds infected with the JE virus, and then transmit the virus to humans and animals during the feeding process. JE is endemic on the Mainland and in Southeast Asia,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nMost JE virus infections are mild without apparent symptoms other than fever with headache. More severe infections are clinically characterised by the quick onset of headache, high fever, neck stiffness, impaired mental state, coma, tremors, occasional convulsions (especially in infants) and paralysis.\n\nTo avoid contracting JE, members of the public, particularly those living in rural areas, are reminded to take heed of the following preventive measures, especially after dark:\n- wear loose, light-coloured, long-sleeved clothes and trousers;\n- use effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothing when outdoors; and\n- use mosquito screens or nets in rooms which are not air-conditioned.\n\nTravellers to endemic areas of JE should take the following precautions:\n- avoid outdoor exposure to mosquito bites at dusk and dawn, especially in rural areas, when mosquitoes spreading this virus are most active;\n- apply effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothes; and\n- consider vaccination and arrange a travel health consultation with a doctor to determine the need for vaccination and vector preventive measures at least 6 weeks before departure to endemic areas in Asia or the Western Pacific for stays of over one month, particularly in high-risk rural areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As the report above indicates, there have been sporadic cases of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infection in Hong Kong (see ProMED-mail archives listed below). There have been 3 cases previously reported this year (2014) in Hong Kong. The virus is endemic in large areas of Asia, including Japan and China. Because Hong Kong is well within the geographic distribution of JEV, it would not be surprising to see additional cases occur occasionally. Individuals living in, or traveling to, JEV endemic areas are well advised to follow precautions to avoid mosquito bites. JEV vaccine is available in China, but there is no mention about the immunization status of the above 2014 cases, although there is a recommendation for people to be vaccinated if they are going to be in a high risk area for a month or more. The CHP has responded to this case with vigorous neighborhood action to detect and prevent additional cases.\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (AS, WB) Viet Nam 20140807.2669178\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): comment, Reye-like encephalopathy 20140804.2656983\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (WB) 20140722.2628448\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (WB) RFI 20140722.2628044\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (WB) RFI 20140717.2616015\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India 20140508.2459977\n.................................................sb/lm/ml/ty/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "1122-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-08-07 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2978346", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (MH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2978346", "date": "2014-08-15 15:50:42", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - CHINA (03): (HONG KONG)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2014\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/478538/local_confirmed_case_of_japanese_encephalitis_under_chp_investigation.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [6 Aug 2014] investigating a local confirmed case of Japanese encephalitis (JE) [virus infection], and hence urged the public to take precautions against mosquito-transmitted diseases.\n\nThe male patient, aged 36, with good past health, developed headache on 28 Jul [2014] and attended the Accident & Emergency Department (AED) of Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH) on 30 Jul [2014]. He was noted to have confused speech and seizures on 1 Aug [2014] and was taken to the AED of TMH again. He was admitted for further management on the same day. The patient is now afebrile in stable condition.\n\nHis cerebrospinal fluid and serum specimens tested positive for antibodies against JE [virus antigens] today [6 Aug 2014] upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch.\n\nInitial enquiries revealed that the patient lives in the quarters of Crossroads Foundation near Gold Coast, Tuen Mun, and had no recent travel history during the incubation period.\n\nHe could not recall any recent mosquito bites. His family contact has remained asymptomatic and will be put under medical surveillance. The CHP's investigations are ongoing.\n\nOfficers of the CHP will conduct home visits and surveys among neighbours of the patient's residence for active case finding and arranging of blood tests.\n\nThe CHP's hotline (2125 1122), set up for public enquiries since the 1st local confirmed JE case, will operate till 9 pm today and from 9 am to 6 pm from tomorrow (7 Aug 2014] onwards.\n\nA health talk will be held at Crossroads Foundation this evening to deliver health advice to the public. Residents of Tuen Mun District with JE symptoms are also advised to promptly seek medical attention.\n\nThe CHP will issue letters to doctors and hospitals to draw their attention to the case and enlist their support in early diagnosis, control and prevention of JE.\n\nThis is the 4th JE case (3 local, one imported) reported to the CHP this year. In 2013, 6 cases (2 local, 3 imported, one unclassified) were reported in 2013 while 3 (one local, 2 imported) were filed in 2012.\n\n\"JE is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes. _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ (culicine mosquito) is the principal vector of JE and is nocturnal. It mainly breeds in waterlogged fields, marshes, ditches, and small stagnant collections of water around cultivated fields. The mosquitoes become infected by feeding on pigs and wild birds infected with the JE virus, and then transmit the virus to humans and animals during the feeding process. JE is endemic on the Mainland and in Southeast Asia,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nMost JE virus infections are mild without apparent symptoms other than fever with headache. More severe infections are clinically characterised by the quick onset of headache, high fever, neck stiffness, impaired mental state, coma, tremors, occasional convulsions (especially in infants) and paralysis.\n\nTo avoid contracting JE, members of the public, particularly those living in rural areas, are reminded to take heed of the following preventive measures, especially after dark:\n- wear loose, light-coloured, long-sleeved clothes and trousers;\n- use effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothing when outdoors; and\n- use mosquito screens or nets in rooms which are not air-conditioned.\n\nTravellers to endemic areas of JE should take the following precautions:\n- avoid outdoor exposure to mosquito bites at dusk and dawn, especially in rural areas, when mosquitoes spreading this virus are most active;\n- apply effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothes; and\n- consider vaccination and arrange a travel health consultation with a doctor to determine the need for vaccination and vector preventive measures at least 6 weeks before departure to endemic areas in Asia or the Western Pacific for stays of over one month, particularly in high-risk rural areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As the report above indicates, there have been sporadic cases of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infection in Hong Kong (see ProMED-mail archives listed below). There have been 3 cases previously reported this year (2014) in Hong Kong. The virus is endemic in large areas of Asia, including Japan and China. Because Hong Kong is well within the geographic distribution of JEV, it would not be surprising to see additional cases occur occasionally. Individuals living in, or traveling to, JEV endemic areas are well advised to follow precautions to avoid mosquito bites. JEV vaccine is available in China, but there is no mention about the immunization status of the above 2014 cases, although there is a recommendation for people to be vaccinated if they are going to be in a high risk area for a month or more. The CHP has responded to this case with vigorous neighborhood action to detect and prevent additional cases.\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - India (22): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2818512", "date": "2014-08-15 15:50:42", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - CHINA (03): (HONG KONG)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2014\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/478538/local_confirmed_case_of_japanese_encephalitis_under_chp_investigation.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [6 Aug 2014] investigating a local confirmed case of Japanese encephalitis (JE) [virus infection], and hence urged the public to take precautions against mosquito-transmitted diseases.\n\nThe male patient, aged 36, with good past health, developed headache on 28 Jul [2014] and attended the Accident & Emergency Department (AED) of Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH) on 30 Jul [2014]. He was noted to have confused speech and seizures on 1 Aug [2014] and was taken to the AED of TMH again. He was admitted for further management on the same day. The patient is now afebrile in stable condition.\n\nHis cerebrospinal fluid and serum specimens tested positive for antibodies against JE [virus antigens] today [6 Aug 2014] upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch.\n\nInitial enquiries revealed that the patient lives in the quarters of Crossroads Foundation near Gold Coast, Tuen Mun, and had no recent travel history during the incubation period.\n\nHe could not recall any recent mosquito bites. His family contact has remained asymptomatic and will be put under medical surveillance. The CHP's investigations are ongoing.\n\nOfficers of the CHP will conduct home visits and surveys among neighbours of the patient's residence for active case finding and arranging of blood tests.\n\nThe CHP's hotline (2125 1122), set up for public enquiries since the 1st local confirmed JE case, will operate till 9 pm today and from 9 am to 6 pm from tomorrow (7 Aug 2014] onwards.\n\nA health talk will be held at Crossroads Foundation this evening to deliver health advice to the public. Residents of Tuen Mun District with JE symptoms are also advised to promptly seek medical attention.\n\nThe CHP will issue letters to doctors and hospitals to draw their attention to the case and enlist their support in early diagnosis, control and prevention of JE.\n\nThis is the 4th JE case (3 local, one imported) reported to the CHP this year. In 2013, 6 cases (2 local, 3 imported, one unclassified) were reported in 2013 while 3 (one local, 2 imported) were filed in 2012.\n\n\"JE is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes. _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ (culicine mosquito) is the principal vector of JE and is nocturnal. It mainly breeds in waterlogged fields, marshes, ditches, and small stagnant collections of water around cultivated fields. The mosquitoes become infected by feeding on pigs and wild birds infected with the JE virus, and then transmit the virus to humans and animals during the feeding process. JE is endemic on the Mainland and in Southeast Asia,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nMost JE virus infections are mild without apparent symptoms other than fever with headache. More severe infections are clinically characterised by the quick onset of headache, high fever, neck stiffness, impaired mental state, coma, tremors, occasional convulsions (especially in infants) and paralysis.\n\nTo avoid contracting JE, members of the public, particularly those living in rural areas, are reminded to take heed of the following preventive measures, especially after dark:\n- wear loose, light-coloured, long-sleeved clothes and trousers;\n- use effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothing when outdoors; and\n- use mosquito screens or nets in rooms which are not air-conditioned.\n\nTravellers to endemic areas of JE should take the following precautions:\n- avoid outdoor exposure to mosquito bites at dusk and dawn, especially in rural areas, when mosquitoes spreading this virus are most active;\n- apply effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothes; and\n- consider vaccination and arrange a travel health consultation with a doctor to determine the need for vaccination and vector preventive measures at least 6 weeks before departure to endemic areas in Asia or the Western Pacific for stays of over one month, particularly in high-risk rural areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As the report above indicates, there have been sporadic cases of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infection in Hong Kong (see ProMED-mail archives listed below). There have been 3 cases previously reported this year (2014) in Hong Kong. The virus is endemic in large areas of Asia, including Japan and China. Because Hong Kong is well within the geographic distribution of JEV, it would not be surprising to see additional cases occur occasionally. Individuals living in, or traveling to, JEV endemic areas are well advised to follow precautions to avoid mosquito bites. JEV vaccine is available in China, but there is no mention about the immunization status of the above 2014 cases, although there is a recommendation for people to be vaccinated if they are going to be in a high risk area for a month or more. The CHP has responded to this case with vigorous neighborhood action to detect and prevent additional cases.\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - India (21): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2799733", "date": "2014-08-15 15:50:42", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - CHINA (03): (HONG KONG)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2014\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/478538/local_confirmed_case_of_japanese_encephalitis_under_chp_investigation.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [6 Aug 2014] investigating a local confirmed case of Japanese encephalitis (JE) [virus infection], and hence urged the public to take precautions against mosquito-transmitted diseases.\n\nThe male patient, aged 36, with good past health, developed headache on 28 Jul [2014] and attended the Accident & Emergency Department (AED) of Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH) on 30 Jul [2014]. He was noted to have confused speech and seizures on 1 Aug [2014] and was taken to the AED of TMH again. He was admitted for further management on the same day. The patient is now afebrile in stable condition.\n\nHis cerebrospinal fluid and serum specimens tested positive for antibodies against JE [virus antigens] today [6 Aug 2014] upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch.\n\nInitial enquiries revealed that the patient lives in the quarters of Crossroads Foundation near Gold Coast, Tuen Mun, and had no recent travel history during the incubation period.\n\nHe could not recall any recent mosquito bites. His family contact has remained asymptomatic and will be put under medical surveillance. The CHP's investigations are ongoing.\n\nOfficers of the CHP will conduct home visits and surveys among neighbours of the patient's residence for active case finding and arranging of blood tests.\n\nThe CHP's hotline (2125 1122), set up for public enquiries since the 1st local confirmed JE case, will operate till 9 pm today and from 9 am to 6 pm from tomorrow (7 Aug 2014] onwards.\n\nA health talk will be held at Crossroads Foundation this evening to deliver health advice to the public. Residents of Tuen Mun District with JE symptoms are also advised to promptly seek medical attention.\n\nThe CHP will issue letters to doctors and hospitals to draw their attention to the case and enlist their support in early diagnosis, control and prevention of JE.\n\nThis is the 4th JE case (3 local, one imported) reported to the CHP this year. In 2013, 6 cases (2 local, 3 imported, one unclassified) were reported in 2013 while 3 (one local, 2 imported) were filed in 2012.\n\n\"JE is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes. _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ (culicine mosquito) is the principal vector of JE and is nocturnal. It mainly breeds in waterlogged fields, marshes, ditches, and small stagnant collections of water around cultivated fields. The mosquitoes become infected by feeding on pigs and wild birds infected with the JE virus, and then transmit the virus to humans and animals during the feeding process. JE is endemic on the Mainland and in Southeast Asia,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nMost JE virus infections are mild without apparent symptoms other than fever with headache. More severe infections are clinically characterised by the quick onset of headache, high fever, neck stiffness, impaired mental state, coma, tremors, occasional convulsions (especially in infants) and paralysis.\n\nTo avoid contracting JE, members of the public, particularly those living in rural areas, are reminded to take heed of the following preventive measures, especially after dark:\n- wear loose, light-coloured, long-sleeved clothes and trousers;\n- use effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothing when outdoors; and\n- use mosquito screens or nets in rooms which are not air-conditioned.\n\nTravellers to endemic areas of JE should take the following precautions:\n- avoid outdoor exposure to mosquito bites at dusk and dawn, especially in rural areas, when mosquitoes spreading this virus are most active;\n- apply effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothes; and\n- consider vaccination and arrange a travel health consultation with a doctor to determine the need for vaccination and vector preventive measures at least 6 weeks before departure to endemic areas in Asia or the Western Pacific for stays of over one month, particularly in high-risk rural areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As the report above indicates, there have been sporadic cases of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infection in Hong Kong (see ProMED-mail archives listed below). There have been 3 cases previously reported this year (2014) in Hong Kong. The virus is endemic in large areas of Asia, including Japan and China. Because Hong Kong is well within the geographic distribution of JEV, it would not be surprising to see additional cases occur occasionally. Individuals living in, or traveling to, JEV endemic areas are well advised to follow precautions to avoid mosquito bites. JEV vaccine is available in China, but there is no mention about the immunization status of the above 2014 cases, although there is a recommendation for people to be vaccinated if they are going to be in a high risk area for a month or more. The CHP has responded to this case with vigorous neighborhood action to detect and prevent additional cases.\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - India 20140508.2459977\n.................................................sb/lm/ml/ty/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "1122-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-08-07 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2764597", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2764597", "date": "2014-08-15 15:50:42", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - CHINA (03): (HONG KONG)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2014\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/478538/local_confirmed_case_of_japanese_encephalitis_under_chp_investigation.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [6 Aug 2014] investigating a local confirmed case of Japanese encephalitis (JE) [virus infection], and hence urged the public to take precautions against mosquito-transmitted diseases.\n\nThe male patient, aged 36, with good past health, developed headache on 28 Jul [2014] and attended the Accident & Emergency Department (AED) of Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH) on 30 Jul [2014]. He was noted to have confused speech and seizures on 1 Aug [2014] and was taken to the AED of TMH again. He was admitted for further management on the same day. The patient is now afebrile in stable condition.\n\nHis cerebrospinal fluid and serum specimens tested positive for antibodies against JE [virus antigens] today [6 Aug 2014] upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch.\n\nInitial enquiries revealed that the patient lives in the quarters of Crossroads Foundation near Gold Coast, Tuen Mun, and had no recent travel history during the incubation period.\n\nHe could not recall any recent mosquito bites. His family contact has remained asymptomatic and will be put under medical surveillance. The CHP's investigations are ongoing.\n\nOfficers of the CHP will conduct home visits and surveys among neighbours of the patient's residence for active case finding and arranging of blood tests.\n\nThe CHP's hotline (2125 1122), set up for public enquiries since the 1st local confirmed JE case, will operate till 9 pm today and from 9 am to 6 pm from tomorrow (7 Aug 2014] onwards.\n\nA health talk will be held at Crossroads Foundation this evening to deliver health advice to the public. Residents of Tuen Mun District with JE symptoms are also advised to promptly seek medical attention.\n\nThe CHP will issue letters to doctors and hospitals to draw their attention to the case and enlist their support in early diagnosis, control and prevention of JE.\n\nThis is the 4th JE case (3 local, one imported) reported to the CHP this year. In 2013, 6 cases (2 local, 3 imported, one unclassified) were reported in 2013 while 3 (one local, 2 imported) were filed in 2012.\n\n\"JE is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes. _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ (culicine mosquito) is the principal vector of JE and is nocturnal. It mainly breeds in waterlogged fields, marshes, ditches, and small stagnant collections of water around cultivated fields. The mosquitoes become infected by feeding on pigs and wild birds infected with the JE virus, and then transmit the virus to humans and animals during the feeding process. JE is endemic on the Mainland and in Southeast Asia,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nMost JE virus infections are mild without apparent symptoms other than fever with headache. More severe infections are clinically characterised by the quick onset of headache, high fever, neck stiffness, impaired mental state, coma, tremors, occasional convulsions (especially in infants) and paralysis.\n\nTo avoid contracting JE, members of the public, particularly those living in rural areas, are reminded to take heed of the following preventive measures, especially after dark:\n- wear loose, light-coloured, long-sleeved clothes and trousers;\n- use effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothing when outdoors; and\n- use mosquito screens or nets in rooms which are not air-conditioned.\n\nTravellers to endemic areas of JE should take the following precautions:\n- avoid outdoor exposure to mosquito bites at dusk and dawn, especially in rural areas, when mosquitoes spreading this virus are most active;\n- apply effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothes; and\n- consider vaccination and arrange a travel health consultation with a doctor to determine the need for vaccination and vector preventive measures at least 6 weeks before departure to endemic areas in Asia or the Western Pacific for stays of over one month, particularly in high-risk rural areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As the report above indicates, there have been sporadic cases of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infection in Hong Kong (see ProMED-mail archives listed below). There have been 3 cases previously reported this year (2014) in Hong Kong. The virus is endemic in large areas of Asia, including Japan and China. Because Hong Kong is well within the geographic distribution of JEV, it would not be surprising to see additional cases occur occasionally. Individuals living in, or traveling to, JEV endemic areas are well advised to follow precautions to avoid mosquito bites. JEV vaccine is available in China, but there is no mention about the immunization status of the above 2014 cases, although there is a recommendation for people to be vaccinated if they are going to be in a high risk area for a month or more. The CHP has responded to this case with vigorous neighborhood action to detect and prevent additional cases.\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - India (19): (ML)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2736957", "date": "2014-08-15 15:50:42", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - CHINA (03): (HONG KONG)\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 6 Aug 2014\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/478538/local_confirmed_case_of_japanese_encephalitis_under_chp_investigation.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today [6 Aug 2014] investigating a local confirmed case of Japanese encephalitis (JE) [virus infection], and hence urged the public to take precautions against mosquito-transmitted diseases.\n\nThe male patient, aged 36, with good past health, developed headache on 28 Jul [2014] and attended the Accident & Emergency Department (AED) of Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH) on 30 Jul [2014]. He was noted to have confused speech and seizures on 1 Aug [2014] and was taken to the AED of TMH again. He was admitted for further management on the same day. The patient is now afebrile in stable condition.\n\nHis cerebrospinal fluid and serum specimens tested positive for antibodies against JE [virus antigens] today [6 Aug 2014] upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch.\n\nInitial enquiries revealed that the patient lives in the quarters of Crossroads Foundation near Gold Coast, Tuen Mun, and had no recent travel history during the incubation period.\n\nHe could not recall any recent mosquito bites. His family contact has remained asymptomatic and will be put under medical surveillance. The CHP's investigations are ongoing.\n\nOfficers of the CHP will conduct home visits and surveys among neighbours of the patient's residence for active case finding and arranging of blood tests.\n\nThe CHP's hotline (2125 1122), set up for public enquiries since the 1st local confirmed JE case, will operate till 9 pm today and from 9 am to 6 pm from tomorrow (7 Aug 2014] onwards.\n\nA health talk will be held at Crossroads Foundation this evening to deliver health advice to the public. Residents of Tuen Mun District with JE symptoms are also advised to promptly seek medical attention.\n\nThe CHP will issue letters to doctors and hospitals to draw their attention to the case and enlist their support in early diagnosis, control and prevention of JE.\n\nThis is the 4th JE case (3 local, one imported) reported to the CHP this year. In 2013, 6 cases (2 local, 3 imported, one unclassified) were reported in 2013 while 3 (one local, 2 imported) were filed in 2012.\n\n\"JE is a viral disease transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes. _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ (culicine mosquito) is the principal vector of JE and is nocturnal. It mainly breeds in waterlogged fields, marshes, ditches, and small stagnant collections of water around cultivated fields. The mosquitoes become infected by feeding on pigs and wild birds infected with the JE virus, and then transmit the virus to humans and animals during the feeding process. JE is endemic on the Mainland and in Southeast Asia,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nMost JE virus infections are mild without apparent symptoms other than fever with headache. More severe infections are clinically characterised by the quick onset of headache, high fever, neck stiffness, impaired mental state, coma, tremors, occasional convulsions (especially in infants) and paralysis.\n\nTo avoid contracting JE, members of the public, particularly those living in rural areas, are reminded to take heed of the following preventive measures, especially after dark:\n- wear loose, light-coloured, long-sleeved clothes and trousers;\n- use effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothing when outdoors; and\n- use mosquito screens or nets in rooms which are not air-conditioned.\n\nTravellers to endemic areas of JE should take the following precautions:\n- avoid outdoor exposure to mosquito bites at dusk and dawn, especially in rural areas, when mosquitoes spreading this virus are most active;\n- apply effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothes; and\n- consider vaccination and arrange a travel health consultation with a doctor to determine the need for vaccination and vector preventive measures at least 6 weeks before departure to endemic areas in Asia or the Western Pacific for stays of over one month, particularly in high-risk rural areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As the report above indicates, there have been sporadic cases of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infection in Hong Kong (see ProMED-mail archives listed below). There have been 3 cases previously reported this year (2014) in Hong Kong. The virus is endemic in large areas of Asia, including Japan and China. Because Hong Kong is well within the geographic distribution of JEV, it would not be surprising to see additional cases occur occasionally. Individuals living in, or traveling to, JEV endemic areas are well advised to follow precautions to avoid mosquito bites. JEV vaccine is available in China, but there is no mention about the immunization status of the above 2014 cases, although there is a recommendation for people to be vaccinated if they are going to be in a high risk area for a month or more. The CHP has responded to this case with vigorous neighborhood action to detect and prevent additional cases.\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be seen at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - It mainly breeds in waterlogged fields, marshes, ditches, and small stagnant collections of water around cultivated fields. The mosquitoes become infected by feeding on pigs and wild birds infected with the JE virus, and then transmit the virus to humans and animals during the feeding process. JE is endemic on the Mainland and in Southeast Asia,\" a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nMost JE virus infections are mild without apparent symptoms other than fever with headache. More severe infections are clinically characterised by the quick onset of headache, high fever, neck stiffness, impaired mental state, coma, tremors, occasional convulsions (especially in infants) and paralysis.\n\nTo avoid contracting JE, members of the public, particularly those living in rural areas, are reminded to take heed of the following preventive measures, especially after dark:\n- wear loose, light-coloured, long-sleeved clothes and trousers;\n- use effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothing when outdoors; and\n- use mosquito screens or nets in rooms which are not air-conditioned.\n\nTravellers to endemic areas of JE should take the following precautions:\n- avoid outdoor exposure to mosquito bites at dusk and dawn, especially in rural areas, when mosquitoes spreading this virus are most active;\n- apply effective insect repellents containing DEET over exposed parts of the body and clothes; and\n- consider vaccination and arrange a travel health consultation with a doctor to determine the need for vaccination and vector preventive measures at least 6 weeks before departure to endemic areas in Asia or the Western Pacific for stays of over one month, particularly in high-risk rural areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As the report above indicates, there have been sporadic cases of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infection in Hong Kong (see ProMED-mail archives listed below).
