India (04): (BR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1706357", "date": "2013-04-11 15:53:54", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (02): (UTTAR PRADESH, BIHAR)\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 10 Apr 2013\nSource: The Times of India [TOI], Times News Network (TNN) [edited]\nhttp://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-10/lucknow/38433672_1_japanese-encephalitis-brd-medical-college-acute-encephalitis\n\n\nEncephalitis normally makes its presence felt during monsoons. However, this time, acute encephalitis has claimed 38 lives and affected 118 persons even before the onset of the disease season. This despite chief secretary Jawed Usmani issuing repeated directives to the state health department and officials posted in the districts to initiate preventive measures.\n\nEncephalitis is the inflammation of the brain caused by microbial agents such as bacteria and viruses. The cause of infection in [Indian] eastern districts of Uttar Pradesh [UP] and parts of Bihar, and Nepal is virus in 98 per cent of the patients. Encephalitis has killed children for [a] long [time], but the documentation work began in the mid 1970s. Earlier, the Arbo-B virus [flavivirus] was the cause of encephalitis and the disease was called Japanese encephalitis. After extensive vaccination campaigns, the incidence of Japanese encephalitis subsided. Still children continue to die. Researches have shown that the cause of encephalitis in about 45 per cent of the cases is not known.\n\nStatistics gathered from the health department show that of the total cases, 103 patients belonged to UP of whom 34 died. Bihar accounted for the remaining 14 cases and 4 deaths. A patient from Nepal is also undergoing treatment at the Baba Raghav Das Medical College of Gorakhpur [Uttar Pradesh]. Kushinagar turned out to be the worst affected district so far, but Gorakhpur has seen the maximum deaths.\n\nIn Kushinagar, as many as 30 cases and 10 deaths have been reported while in Gorakhpur, 12 of the 23 patients suffering with acute encephalitis have died. What has pressed the panic button for the health department officials is that the case fatality rate for the 1st quarter of 2013 is significantly higher than that in 2012. Case fatality rate refers to the number of patients who die against those admitted. In the 1st quarter of 2012, as many as 26.9 per cent of the children suffering from AES [acute encephalitis syndrome] died, a growth of 33 per cent in 2013. Doctors at the communicable diseases unit of state health directorate believe that by the end of the year, the case fatality rate will subside.\n\nThe only silver lining is that the number of cases of Japanese encephalitis [has declined]. Experts at the Gorakhpur unit of National Institute of Virology give credit to the special vaccination drive against JE [Japanese encephalitis] for the low number of cases. Still as these children struggle for life, staff employed in the hospital attended them calmly. \"The season is yet to begin. Come in August or September to know what the encephalitis epidemic looks like,\" a medical officer told TOI.\n\nSenior faculty members at the BRD Medical College stated that the cause of encephalitis in about 45 per cent is not known. But in an equal proportion of children, strains of enterovirus are causing disease.\n\nEnterovirus[es are in] a large family divided into 4, like: echo, coxsackie-B, polio, and human enterovirus (HEV). It [enteroviruses] is normally associated with polio [controlled in India. - Mod.TY], and is largely found in human excreta.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The appearance of encephalitis, often termed acute encephalitis syndrome in India, this early in the year is of concern. One hopes that this is not a harbinger of an unusually large outbreak to come when the monsoon season arrives. Interestingly, cases of encephalitis have occurred this year (2013) in several locations in eastern India. A 1 Apr 2013 ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20130402.1615081) stated, \"Encephalitis cases have already been reported from Andhra Pradesh, Assam, Uttar Pradesh, and West Bengal in India this year, totalling 228 cases and 49 fatalities up to 19 Mar 2013. Of those cases, 7, all from West Bengal, were classified as Japanese encephalitis [virus infections].\" There have also been cases in neighboring Bangladesh this year (2013).\n\nWithout knowing the specific etiology of these encephalitis cases, targeted control measures will not be possible. This despite chief secretary Jawed Usmani issuing repeated directives to the state health department and officials posted in the districts to initiate preventive measures.\n\nEncephalitis is the inflammation of the brain caused by microbial agents such as bacteria and viruses. The cause of infection in [Indian] eastern districts of Uttar Pradesh [UP] and parts of Bihar, and Nepal is virus in 98 per cent of the patients. But in an equal proportion of children, strains of enterovirus are causing disease.\n\nEnterovirus[es are in] a large family divided into 4, like: echo, coxsackie-B, polio, and human enterovirus (HEV). With another 354 people under treatment for encephalitis currently, that number can be expected to climb still further. As with many previous reports, the etiological agent responsible for these cases is not indicated.\n\nAn interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of India showing the location of Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh state, can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/3h8J. - With another 354 people under treatment for encephalitis currently, that number can be expected to climb still further. As with many previous reports, the etiological agent responsible for these cases is not indicated.\n\nAn interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of India showing the location of Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh state, can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/3h8J. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1291540", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1291540", "date": "2012-06-29 15:15:49", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (07): (BIHAR)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Jun 2012\nSource: Zee News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://zeenews.india.com/news/health/exclusive/bihar-aes-is-not-japanese-encephalitis_17654.html\n\n\nIt is official now, the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) that has killed 233 children in Bihar since May [2012] is not Japanese encephalitis, announced Thursday [28 Jun 2012] the Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV).\n\n\"In fact the disease remains a mysterious one,\" Additional Secretary (Health) RP Ojha said. \"NIV has told the Bihar government that no one had a positive strain [test?] for Japanese encephalitis,\" he said.\n\nAccording to him, the NIV collected cerebral spinal fluid and blood samples of 73 patients from Muzaffarpur district.\n\nEarlier this month [June 2012], Health Minister Ashwani Kumar Choubey announced that the mysterious disease was AES.\n\nOjha said of the 599 children with AES symptoms admitted to hospitals in Muzaffarpur, Patna, and Gaya, 233 have died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The encephalitis situation in Bihar and Uttar Pradesh states remains unclear. Although reports from this year (2012) and previous years implicates Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infections in at least some of the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases, the report above rules out JEV infections in the current Bihar cases. The question now is -- if not JEV infections, then what is the etiological agent involved? A recent publication attributed AES cases to heat stroke, rather than to an infectious disease (see ProMED-mail archive no 20120613.1166861). No mention is made of that possible etiology in the report above.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Bihar state can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1*O9. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (BI, UP) 20120616.1170331\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (BI) 20120613.1166861\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (BI), RFI 20120612.1165900\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1278429", "date": "2012-06-29 15:15:49", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (07): (BIHAR)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Jun 2012\nSource: Zee News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://zeenews.india.com/news/health/exclusive/bihar-aes-is-not-japanese-encephalitis_17654.html\n\n\nIt is official now, the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) that has killed 233 children in Bihar since May [2012] is not Japanese encephalitis, announced Thursday [28 Jun 2012] the Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV).\n\n\"In fact the disease remains a mysterious one,\" Additional Secretary (Health) RP Ojha said. \"NIV has told the Bihar government that no one had a positive strain [test?] for Japanese encephalitis,\" he said.\n\nAccording to him, the NIV collected cerebral spinal fluid and blood samples of 73 patients from Muzaffarpur district.\n\nEarlier this month [June 2012], Health Minister Ashwani Kumar Choubey announced that the mysterious disease was AES.\n\nOjha said of the 599 children with AES symptoms admitted to hospitals in Muzaffarpur, Patna, and Gaya, 233 have died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The encephalitis situation in Bihar and Uttar Pradesh states remains unclear. Although reports from this year (2012) and previous years implicates Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infections in at least some of the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases, the report above rules out JEV infections in the current Bihar cases. The question now is -- if not JEV infections, then what is the etiological agent involved? A recent publication attributed AES cases to heat stroke, rather than to an infectious disease (see ProMED-mail archive no 20120613.1166861). No mention is made of that possible etiology in the report above.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Bihar state can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1*O9. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (BI, UP) 20120616.1170331\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (BI) 20120613.1166861\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (BI), RFI 20120612.1165900\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (BI) RFI 20120607.1159903\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (UP) 20120606.1158514\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (BI) 20120604.1155306\n.................................................ml/ty/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2012-06-28 00:00:00", "2012-06-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UP", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "Muzaffarpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - India (12): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1221784", "date": "2012-06-29 15:15:49", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (07): (BIHAR)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Jun 2012\nSource: Zee News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://zeenews.india.com/news/health/exclusive/bihar-aes-is-not-japanese-encephalitis_17654.html\n\n\nIt is official now, the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) that has killed 233 children in Bihar since May [2012] is not Japanese encephalitis, announced Thursday [28 Jun 2012] the Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV).\n\n\"In fact the disease remains a mysterious one,\" Additional Secretary (Health) RP Ojha said. \"NIV has told the Bihar government that no one had a positive strain [test?] for Japanese encephalitis,\" he said.\n\nAccording to him, the NIV collected cerebral spinal fluid and blood samples of 73 patients from Muzaffarpur district.\n\nEarlier this month [June 2012], Health Minister Ashwani Kumar Choubey announced that the mysterious disease was AES.\n\nOjha said of the 599 children with AES symptoms admitted to hospitals in Muzaffarpur, Patna, and Gaya, 233 have died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The encephalitis situation in Bihar and Uttar Pradesh states remains unclear. Although reports from this year (2012) and previous years implicates Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infections in at least some of the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases, the report above rules out JEV infections in the current Bihar cases. The question now is -- if not JEV infections, then what is the etiological agent involved? A recent publication attributed AES cases to heat stroke, rather than to an infectious disease (see ProMED-mail archive no 20120613.1166861). No mention is made of that possible etiology in the report above.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Bihar state can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1*O9. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1201337", "date": "2012-06-29 15:15:49", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (07): (BIHAR)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Jun 2012\nSource: Zee News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://zeenews.india.com/news/health/exclusive/bihar-aes-is-not-japanese-encephalitis_17654.html\n\n\nIt is official now, the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) that has killed 233 children in Bihar since May [2012] is not Japanese encephalitis, announced Thursday [28 Jun 2012] the Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV).\n\n\"In fact the disease remains a mysterious one,\" Additional Secretary (Health) RP Ojha said. \"NIV has told the Bihar government that no one had a positive strain [test?] for Japanese encephalitis,\" he said.\n\nAccording to him, the NIV collected cerebral spinal fluid and blood samples of 73 patients from Muzaffarpur district.\n\nEarlier this month [June 2012], Health Minister Ashwani Kumar Choubey announced that the mysterious disease was AES.\n\nOjha said of the 599 children with AES symptoms admitted to hospitals in Muzaffarpur, Patna, and Gaya, 233 have died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The encephalitis situation in Bihar and Uttar Pradesh states remains unclear. Although reports from this year (2012) and previous years implicates Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infections in at least some of the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases, the report above rules out JEV infections in the current Bihar cases. The question now is -- if not JEV infections, then what is the etiological agent involved? A recent publication attributed AES cases to heat stroke, rather than to an infectious disease (see ProMED-mail archive no 20120613.1166861). No mention is made of that possible etiology in the report above.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Bihar state can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1*O9. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1199565", "date": "2012-06-29 15:15:49", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (07): (BIHAR)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Jun 2012\nSource: Zee News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://zeenews.india.com/news/health/exclusive/bihar-aes-is-not-japanese-encephalitis_17654.html\n\n\nIt is official now, the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) that has killed 233 children in Bihar since May [2012] is not Japanese encephalitis, announced Thursday [28 Jun 2012] the Pune-based National Institute of Virology (NIV).\n\n\"In fact the disease remains a mysterious one,\" Additional Secretary (Health) RP Ojha said. \"NIV has told the Bihar government that no one had a positive strain [test?] for Japanese encephalitis,\" he said.\n\nAccording to him, the NIV collected cerebral spinal fluid and blood samples of 73 patients from Muzaffarpur district.\n\nEarlier this month [June 2012], Health Minister Ashwani Kumar Choubey announced that the mysterious disease was AES.\n\nOjha said of the 599 children with AES symptoms admitted to hospitals in Muzaffarpur, Patna, and Gaya, 233 have died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The encephalitis situation in Bihar and Uttar Pradesh states remains unclear. Although reports from this year (2012) and previous years implicates Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) infections in at least some of the acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases, the report above rules out JEV infections in the current Bihar cases. The question now is -- if not JEV infections, then what is the etiological agent involved? A recent publication attributed AES cases to heat stroke, rather than to an infectious disease (see ProMED-mail archive no 20120613.1166861). The 2 children died in the last 2 days, Additional Director\n(health) Diwakar Prasad said today [30 Dec 2011].\n\nAs many as 82 people suffering from encephalitis are undergoing\ntreatment in various government hospitals in Basti and Gorakhpur, he\nsaid.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\npromed@promedmail.org\n\n[The numbers of encephalitis cases in children continue to climb in\nUttar Pradesh state. Mumbai, being a hub, has a high number of people from the\naffected states of UP and Bihar that work as temporary workers in the\ncity. The appearance of disease after Diwali [festival of lights], in\nthe last week of October, when a large number of these migrant workers\nvisit their homes in the north of the country, should point towards\nimported cases than actual transmission in the city. Also, it might\npoint towards the higher than estimated transmission of the yet\nundiagnosed etiological agent in the Northern states of the country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPrabhjot Singh\n<drprabhjot@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Prabhjot Sing for these interesting comments. It\nwould be of interest to know the recent travel histories of the\npatients involved to know, as Dr Singh suggests, if these are all\nimported cases or have been locally acquired. Ronan Kelly of\nFluTrackers suggested that Chandipura virus infection should be\nconsidered as a possible etiologic agent in some of these recent\n(2011) encephalitis cases in India (see ProMED-mail archive no.\n20100807.2690). Laboratory tests are needed to confirm or rule out\nthis possibility.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Mumbai\ncan be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1pr7. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (32): (MA) 20111106.3302\nWest Nile virus - Eurasia (13): India (KL) 20111105.3295\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (31): (UP) 20111103.3265\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (30): (Delhi) 20111102.3256\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA (29): (Delhi, UP) 20111027.3197\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (28): (BI,UP) 20111019.3122\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (27) 20111012.3054\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (26): (UP) 20111010.3035\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (25): (UP, BI) 20111006.3004\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (UP) 20111004.2989\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (BI) 20111002.2970\n2004\n----\nChandipura virus - India (Gujarat) (04) 20100807.2690\n.................................................lm/ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "west nile virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UP", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "Chandipura", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mumbai", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - India (39): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=985161", "date": "2011-11-07 09:09:10", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (33): MAHARASHTRA, COMMENT\n******************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Nov 2011\nFrom: Prabhjot Singh <drprabhjot@gmail.com>\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Japanese encephalitis & other - India (32): (MA)\n20111106.3302]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nIt's not strange to see these cases of encephalitis appearing in\nMumbai. Mumbai, being a hub, has a high number of people from the\naffected states of UP and Bihar that work as temporary workers in the\ncity. The appearance of disease after Diwali [festival of lights], in\nthe last week of October, when a large number of these migrant workers\nvisit their homes in the north of the country, should point towards\nimported cases than actual transmission in the city. Also, it might\npoint towards the higher than estimated transmission of the yet\nundiagnosed etiological agent in the Northern states of the country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPrabhjot Singh\n<drprabhjot@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Prabhjot Sing for these interesting comments. It\nwould be of interest to know the recent travel histories of the\npatients involved to know, as Dr Singh suggests, if these are all\nimported cases or have been locally acquired. Ronan Kelly of\nFluTrackers suggested that Chandipura virus infection should be\nconsidered as a possible etiologic agent in some of these recent\n(2011) encephalitis cases in India (see ProMED-mail archive no.\n20100807.2690). Laboratory tests are needed to confirm or rule out\nthis possibility.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Mumbai\ncan be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1pr7. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (32): (MA)\n20111106.3302]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nIt's not strange to see these cases of encephalitis appearing in\nMumbai. Mumbai, being a hub, has a high number of people from the\naffected states of UP and Bihar that work as temporary workers in the\ncity. The appearance of disease after Diwali [festival of lights], in\nthe last week of October, when a large number of these migrant workers\nvisit their homes in the north of the country, should point towards\nimported cases than actual transmission in the city. Also, it might\npoint towards the higher than estimated transmission of the yet\nundiagnosed etiological agent in the Northern states of the country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPrabhjot Singh\n<drprabhjot@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Prabhjot Sing for these interesting comments. It\nwould be of interest to know the recent travel histories of the\npatients involved to know, as Dr Singh suggests, if these are all\nimported cases or have been locally acquired. Ronan Kelly of\nFluTrackers suggested that Chandipura virus infection should be\nconsidered as a possible etiologic agent in some of these recent\n(2011) encephalitis cases in India (see ProMED-mail archive no.\n20100807.2690). Laboratory tests are needed to confirm or rule out\nthis possibility.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Mumbai\ncan be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1pr7. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (32): (MA)\n20111106.3302]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nIt's not strange to see these cases of encephalitis appearing in\nMumbai. Mumbai, being a hub, has a high number of people from the\naffected states of UP and Bihar that work as temporary workers in the\ncity. The appearance of disease after Diwali [festival of lights], in\nthe last week of October, when a large number of these migrant workers\nvisit their homes in the north of the country, should point towards\nimported cases than actual transmission in the city. Also, it might\npoint towards the higher than estimated transmission of the yet\nundiagnosed etiological agent in the Northern states of the country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPrabhjot Singh\n<drprabhjot@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Prabhjot Sing for these interesting comments. It\nwould be of interest to know the recent travel histories of the\npatients involved to know, as Dr Singh suggests, if these are all\nimported cases or have been locally acquired. Ronan Kelly of\nFluTrackers suggested that Chandipura virus infection should be\nconsidered as a possible etiologic agent in some of these recent\n(2011) encephalitis cases in India (see ProMED-mail archive no.\n20100807.2690). Laboratory tests are needed to confirm or rule out\nthis possibility.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Mumbai\ncan be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1pr7. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - INDIA (29): (Delhi, UP) 20111027.3197\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (28): (BI,UP) 20111019.3122\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (27) 20111012.3054\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (26): (UP) 20111010.3035\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (25): (UP, BI) 20111006.3004\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (UP) 20111004.2989\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (BI) 20111002.2970\n2004\n----\nChandipura virus - India (Gujarat) (04) 20100807.2690\n.................................................lm/ty/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "west nile virus", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UP", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "Chandipura", "country": "Pakistan"}, {"location": "INDIA", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Mumbai", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BI", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Gujarat", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "939059", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (32): (MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=939059", "date": "2011-10-06 13:40:07", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (25): (UTTAR PRADESH, BIHAR)\n********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Oct 2011\nSource: Thomson Reuters Foundation AlertNet [edited]\nhttp://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/encephalitis-kills-400-in-flood-hit-northern-india\n\n\nMore than 400 people in northern India have died in the past month\nfrom encephalitis, a rare condition that causes inflammation of the\nbrain, government officials said on Wednesday [5 Oct 2011].\nEncephalitis is most often caused by a viral infection from eating or\ndrinking contaminated food or water, from mosquito or other insect\nbites, or through breathing in respiratory droplets from an infected\nperson. Around 347 people have died in the Indian state of Uttar\nPradesh, while 54 children have died in the neighbouring state of\nBihar. Over 2000 cases have been reported in the last 3 months.\n\n\"Acute encephalitis syndrome has 2 types of infections -- Japanese\nencephalitis [virus], which occurs due to mosquitoes, and enteroviral\nencephalitis, which is caused due to unsafe drinking water,\" said\nDinesh Kumar Srivastava from the Community Medicine Department in\nUttar Pradesh's Gorakhpur district, where patients are receiving\ntreatment.\n\nOfficials said the main areas where the outbreak of the virus has been\nnoticed have been poor, flood-hit areas of the region, where this\nyear's [2011] monsoons have left pools of stagnant water that have\nallowed mosquitoes to breed and infect villagers. The floods have also\nled to the contamination of clean water sources such as wells, leaving\nmany people with no option but to use the same dirty water for both\ndrinking and sanitation. The infection spreads every year in\nimpoverished parts of Uttar Pradesh during the monsoon season,\nresulting in hundreds of deaths.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, viral encephalitis causes\nhigh fever, headache, stiff neck and back, vomiting, confusion and, in\nsevere cases, seizures, paralysis, and coma. Infants and elderly\npeople are particularly at risk of severe illness.\n\nOfficials say the government has earmarked 22 million rupees (USD 450\n000) to tackle problems like the unavailability of clean drinking\nwater, lack of sanitation, and water logging, to prevent the virus\nfrom spreading. But local aid workers say efforts need to be stepped\nup. \"The infection started in the early 1970s and since then it has\nbecome an annual feature. The government is adopting short term\nmeasures to deal with the infection instead of making any long term\nplan to get rid of the virus,\" said Sanjay Kumar Srivastava from\nAction for Peace, Prosperity and Liberty (APPL), a charity doing\nresearch on the disease. \"Besides, no preventive measures are taken to\nstop the outbreak,\" he added, suggesting that vaccinations be more\nreadily available to adults as well as to children.\n\n[Byline: Alka Pande, Nita Bhalla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of unspecified acute encephalitis syndrome\nimplicated contaminated water as a source of the infectious agent,\nsuggesting, without stating, that enteroviruses might be involved. The\nreport above states that enteroviruses are involved, but does not\nindicate which ones are responsible for the encephalitis cases that\nare occurring. At least, this points to the source of the problem and\nsuggests preventive measures that might be taken. There is no\nindication that a vaccination campaign for Japanese encephalitis is\nbeing planned.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Uttar\nPradesh and Bihar states can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1iZ5. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (UP) 20111004.2989\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (BI) 20111002.2970\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (UP, JH) 20110929.2942\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (BI) 20110923.2885\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (UP), RFI 20110920.2857\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (UP) 20110919.2850\n.................................................ty/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "BIHAR", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "other - INDIA (25): (UTTAR PRADESH, BIHAR)\n********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Oct 2011\nSource: Thomson Reuters Foundation AlertNet [edited]\nhttp://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/encephalitis-kills-400-in-flood-hit-northern-india\n\n\nMore than 400 people in northern India have died in the past month\nfrom encephalitis, a rare condition that causes inflammation of the\nbrain, government officials said on Wednesday [5 Oct 2011].\nEncephalitis is most often caused by a viral infection from eating or\ndrinking contaminated food or water, from mosquito or other insect\nbites, or through breathing in respiratory droplets from an infected\nperson. Around 347 people have died in the Indian state of Uttar\nPradesh, while 54 children have died in the neighbouring state of\nBihar. Over 2000 cases have been reported in the last 3 months.\n\n\"Acute encephalitis syndrome has 2 types of infections -- Japanese\nencephalitis [virus], which occurs due to mosquitoes, and enteroviral\nencephalitis, which is caused due to unsafe drinking water,\" said\nDinesh Kumar Srivastava from the Community Medicine Department in\nUttar Pradesh's Gorakhpur district, where patients are receiving\ntreatment.\n\nOfficials said the main areas where the outbreak of the virus has been\nnoticed have been poor, flood-hit areas of the region, where this\nyear's [2011] monsoons have left pools of stagnant water that have\nallowed mosquitoes to breed and infect villagers. The floods have also\nled to the contamination of clean water sources such as wells, leaving\nmany people with no option but to use the same dirty water for both\ndrinking and sanitation. The infection spreads every year in\nimpoverished parts of Uttar Pradesh during the monsoon season,\nresulting in hundreds of deaths.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, viral encephalitis causes\nhigh fever, headache, stiff neck and back, vomiting, confusion and, in\nsevere cases, seizures, paralysis, and coma. Infants and elderly\npeople are particularly at risk of severe illness.\n\nOfficials say the government has earmarked 22 million rupees (USD 450\n000) to tackle problems like the unavailability of clean drinking\nwater, lack of sanitation, and water logging, to prevent the virus\nfrom spreading. But local aid workers say efforts need to be stepped\nup. \"The infection started in the early 1970s and since then it has\nbecome an annual feature. The government is adopting short term\nmeasures to deal with the infection instead of making any long term\nplan to get rid of the virus,\" said Sanjay Kumar Srivastava from\nAction for Peace, Prosperity and Liberty (APPL), a charity doing\nresearch on the disease. \"Besides, no preventive measures are taken to\nstop the outbreak,\" he added, suggesting that vaccinations be more\nreadily available to adults as well as to children.\n\n[Byline: Alka Pande, Nita Bhalla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of unspecified acute encephalitis syndrome\nimplicated contaminated water as a source of the infectious agent,\nsuggesting, without stating, that enteroviruses might be involved. The\nreport above states that enteroviruses are involved, but does not\nindicate which ones are responsible for the encephalitis cases that\nare occurring. At least, this points to the source of the problem and\nsuggests preventive measures that might be taken. There is no\nindication that a vaccination campaign for Japanese encephalitis is\nbeing planned.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Uttar\nPradesh and Bihar states can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1iZ5. - INDIA (25): (UTTAR PRADESH, BIHAR)\n********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Oct 2011\nSource: Thomson Reuters Foundation AlertNet [edited]\nhttp://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/encephalitis-kills-400-in-flood-hit-northern-india\n\n\nMore than 400 people in northern India have died in the past month\nfrom encephalitis, a rare condition that causes inflammation of the\nbrain, government officials said on Wednesday [5 Oct 2011].\nEncephalitis is most often caused by a viral infection from eating or\ndrinking contaminated food or water, from mosquito or other insect\nbites, or through breathing in respiratory droplets from an infected\nperson. Around 347 people have died in the Indian state of Uttar\nPradesh, while 54 children have died in the neighbouring state of\nBihar. Over 2000 cases have been reported in the last 3 months.\n\n\"Acute encephalitis syndrome has 2 types of infections -- Japanese\nencephalitis [virus], which occurs due to mosquitoes, and enteroviral\nencephalitis, which is caused due to unsafe drinking water,\" said\nDinesh Kumar Srivastava from the Community Medicine Department in\nUttar Pradesh's Gorakhpur district, where patients are receiving\ntreatment.\n\nOfficials said the main areas where the outbreak of the virus has been\nnoticed have been poor, flood-hit areas of the region, where this\nyear's [2011] monsoons have left pools of stagnant water that have\nallowed mosquitoes to breed and infect villagers. The floods have also\nled to the contamination of clean water sources such as wells, leaving\nmany people with no option but to use the same dirty water for both\ndrinking and sanitation. The infection spreads every year in\nimpoverished parts of Uttar Pradesh during the monsoon season,\nresulting in hundreds of deaths.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, viral encephalitis causes\nhigh fever, headache, stiff neck and back, vomiting, confusion and, in\nsevere cases, seizures, paralysis, and coma. Infants and elderly\npeople are particularly at risk of severe illness.\n\nOfficials say the government has earmarked 22 million rupees (USD 450\n000) to tackle problems like the unavailability of clean drinking\nwater, lack of sanitation, and water logging, to prevent the virus\nfrom spreading. But local aid workers say efforts need to be stepped\nup. \"The infection started in the early 1970s and since then it has\nbecome an annual feature. The government is adopting short term\nmeasures to deal with the infection instead of making any long term\nplan to get rid of the virus,\" said Sanjay Kumar Srivastava from\nAction for Peace, Prosperity and Liberty (APPL), a charity doing\nresearch on the disease. \"Besides, no preventive measures are taken to\nstop the outbreak,\" he added, suggesting that vaccinations be more\nreadily available to adults as well as to children.\n\n[Byline: Alka Pande, Nita Bhalla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of unspecified acute encephalitis syndrome\nimplicated contaminated water as a source of the infectious agent,\nsuggesting, without stating, that enteroviruses might be involved. The\nreport above states that enteroviruses are involved, but does not\nindicate which ones are responsible for the encephalitis cases that\nare occurring. At least, this points to the source of the problem and\nsuggests preventive measures that might be taken. There is no\nindication that a vaccination campaign for Japanese encephalitis is\nbeing planned.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Uttar\nPradesh and Bihar states can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1iZ5. - The government is adopting short term\nmeasures to deal with the infection instead of making any long term\nplan to get rid of the virus,\" said Sanjay Kumar Srivastava from\nAction for Peace, Prosperity and Liberty (APPL), a charity doing\nresearch on the disease. \"Besides, no preventive measures are taken to\nstop the outbreak,\" he added, suggesting that vaccinations be more\nreadily available to adults as well as to children.\n\n[Byline: Alka Pande, Nita Bhalla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of unspecified acute encephalitis syndrome\nimplicated contaminated water as a source of the infectious agent,\nsuggesting, without stating, that enteroviruses might be involved. Infants and elderly\npeople are particularly at risk of severe illness.\n\nOfficials say the government has earmarked 22 million rupees (USD 450\n000) to tackle problems like the unavailability of clean drinking\nwater, lack of sanitation, and water logging, to prevent the virus\nfrom spreading. The government is adopting short term\nmeasures to deal with the infection instead of making any long term\nplan to get rid of the virus,\" said Sanjay Kumar Srivastava from\nAction for Peace, Prosperity and Liberty (APPL), a charity doing\nresearch on the disease. \"Besides, no preventive measures are taken to\nstop the outbreak,\" he added, suggesting that vaccinations be more\nreadily available to adults as well as to children.\n\n[Byline: Alka Pande, Nita Bhalla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of unspecified acute encephalitis syndrome\nimplicated contaminated water as a source of the infectious agent,\nsuggesting, without stating, that enteroviruses might be involved. There is no\nindication that a vaccination campaign for Japanese encephalitis is\nbeing planned.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Uttar\nPradesh and Bihar states can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1iZ5. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (UP) 20111004.2989\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (BI) 20111002.2970\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (UP, JH) 20110929.2942\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (20): (BI) 20110923.2885\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (UP), RFI 20110920.2857\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (UP) 20110919.2850\n.................................................ty/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "BIHAR", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "907140", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (27)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=907140", "date": "2011-10-06 13:40:07", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (25): (UTTAR PRADESH, BIHAR)\n********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Oct 2011\nSource: Thomson Reuters Foundation AlertNet [edited]\nhttp://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/encephalitis-kills-400-in-flood-hit-northern-india\n\n\nMore than 400 people in northern India have died in the past month\nfrom encephalitis, a rare condition that causes inflammation of the\nbrain, government officials said on Wednesday [5 Oct 2011].\nEncephalitis is most often caused by a viral infection from eating or\ndrinking contaminated food or water, from mosquito or other insect\nbites, or through breathing in respiratory droplets from an infected\nperson. Around 347 people have died in the Indian state of Uttar\nPradesh, while 54 children have died in the neighbouring state of\nBihar. Over 2000 cases have been reported in the last 3 months.\n\n\"Acute encephalitis syndrome has 2 types of infections -- Japanese\nencephalitis [virus], which occurs due to mosquitoes, and enteroviral\nencephalitis, which is caused due to unsafe drinking water,\" said\nDinesh Kumar Srivastava from the Community Medicine Department in\nUttar Pradesh's Gorakhpur district, where patients are receiving\ntreatment.\n\nOfficials said the main areas where the outbreak of the virus has been\nnoticed have been poor, flood-hit areas of the region, where this\nyear's [2011] monsoons have left pools of stagnant water that have\nallowed mosquitoes to breed and infect villagers. The floods have also\nled to the contamination of clean water sources such as wells, leaving\nmany people with no option but to use the same dirty water for both\ndrinking and sanitation. The infection spreads every year in\nimpoverished parts of Uttar Pradesh during the monsoon season,\nresulting in hundreds of deaths.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, viral encephalitis causes\nhigh fever, headache, stiff neck and back, vomiting, confusion and, in\nsevere cases, seizures, paralysis, and coma. Infants and elderly\npeople are particularly at risk of severe illness.\n\nOfficials say the government has earmarked 22 million rupees (USD 450\n000) to tackle problems like the unavailability of clean drinking\nwater, lack of sanitation, and water logging, to prevent the virus\nfrom spreading. But local aid workers say efforts need to be stepped\nup. \"The infection started in the early 1970s and since then it has\nbecome an annual feature. The government is adopting short term\nmeasures to deal with the infection instead of making any long term\nplan to get rid of the virus,\" said Sanjay Kumar Srivastava from\nAction for Peace, Prosperity and Liberty (APPL), a charity doing\nresearch on the disease. \"Besides, no preventive measures are taken to\nstop the outbreak,\" he added, suggesting that vaccinations be more\nreadily available to adults as well as to children.\n\n[Byline: Alka Pande, Nita Bhalla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of unspecified acute encephalitis syndrome\nimplicated contaminated water as a source of the infectious agent,\nsuggesting, without stating, that enteroviruses might be involved. The\nreport above states that enteroviruses are involved, but does not\nindicate which ones are responsible for the encephalitis cases that\nare occurring. At least, this points to the source of the problem and\nsuggests preventive measures that might be taken. There is no\nindication that a vaccination campaign for Japanese encephalitis is\nbeing planned.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Uttar\nPradesh and Bihar states can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1iZ5. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "903885", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (26): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=903885", "date": "2011-10-06 13:40:07", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (25): (UTTAR PRADESH, BIHAR)\n********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Oct 2011\nSource: Thomson Reuters Foundation AlertNet [edited]\nhttp://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/encephalitis-kills-400-in-flood-hit-northern-india\n\n\nMore than 400 people in northern India have died in the past month\nfrom encephalitis, a rare condition that causes inflammation of the\nbrain, government officials said on Wednesday [5 Oct 2011].\nEncephalitis is most often caused by a viral infection from eating or\ndrinking contaminated food or water, from mosquito or other insect\nbites, or through breathing in respiratory droplets from an infected\nperson. Around 347 people have died in the Indian state of Uttar\nPradesh, while 54 children have died in the neighbouring state of\nBihar. Over 2000 cases have been reported in the last 3 months.\n\n\"Acute encephalitis syndrome has 2 types of infections -- Japanese\nencephalitis [virus], which occurs due to mosquitoes, and enteroviral\nencephalitis, which is caused due to unsafe drinking water,\" said\nDinesh Kumar Srivastava from the Community Medicine Department in\nUttar Pradesh's Gorakhpur district, where patients are receiving\ntreatment.\n\nOfficials said the main areas where the outbreak of the virus has been\nnoticed have been poor, flood-hit areas of the region, where this\nyear's [2011] monsoons have left pools of stagnant water that have\nallowed mosquitoes to breed and infect villagers. The floods have also\nled to the contamination of clean water sources such as wells, leaving\nmany people with no option but to use the same dirty water for both\ndrinking and sanitation. The infection spreads every year in\nimpoverished parts of Uttar Pradesh during the monsoon season,\nresulting in hundreds of deaths.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, viral encephalitis causes\nhigh fever, headache, stiff neck and back, vomiting, confusion and, in\nsevere cases, seizures, paralysis, and coma. Infants and elderly\npeople are particularly at risk of severe illness.\n\nOfficials say the government has earmarked 22 million rupees (USD 450\n000) to tackle problems like the unavailability of clean drinking\nwater, lack of sanitation, and water logging, to prevent the virus\nfrom spreading. But local aid workers say efforts need to be stepped\nup. \"The infection started in the early 1970s and since then it has\nbecome an annual feature. The government is adopting short term\nmeasures to deal with the infection instead of making any long term\nplan to get rid of the virus,\" said Sanjay Kumar Srivastava from\nAction for Peace, Prosperity and Liberty (APPL), a charity doing\nresearch on the disease. \"Besides, no preventive measures are taken to\nstop the outbreak,\" he added, suggesting that vaccinations be more\nreadily available to adults as well as to children.\n\n[Byline: Alka Pande, Nita Bhalla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of unspecified acute encephalitis syndrome\nimplicated contaminated water as a source of the infectious agent,\nsuggesting, without stating, that enteroviruses might be involved. The\nreport above states that enteroviruses are involved, but does not\nindicate which ones are responsible for the encephalitis cases that\nare occurring. At least, this points to the source of the problem and\nsuggests preventive measures that might be taken. There is no\nindication that a vaccination campaign for Japanese encephalitis is\nbeing planned.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map showing the location of Uttar\nPradesh and Bihar states can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1iZ5. - INDIA (25): (UTTAR PRADESH, BIHAR)\n********************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Oct 2011\nSource: Thomson Reuters Foundation AlertNet [edited]\nhttp://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/encephalitis-kills-400-in-flood-hit-northern-india\n\n\nMore than 400 people in northern India have died in the past month\nfrom encephalitis, a rare condition that causes inflammation of the\nbrain, government officials said on Wednesday [5 Oct 2011].\nEncephalitis is most often caused by a viral infection from eating or\ndrinking contaminated food or water, from mosquito or other insect\nbites, or through breathing in respiratory droplets from an infected\nperson. Around 347 people have died in the Indian state of Uttar\nPradesh, while 54 children have died in the neighbouring state of\nBihar. Over 2000 cases have been reported in the last 3 months.\n\n\"Acute encephalitis syndrome has 2 types of infections -- Japanese\nencephalitis [virus], which occurs due to mosquitoes, and enteroviral\nencephalitis, which is caused due to unsafe drinking water,\" said\nDinesh Kumar Srivastava from the Community Medicine Department in\nUttar Pradesh's Gorakhpur district, where patients are receiving\ntreatment.\n\nOfficials said the main areas where the outbreak of the virus has been\nnoticed have been poor, flood-hit areas of the region, where this\nyear's [2011] monsoons have left pools of stagnant water that have\nallowed mosquitoes to breed and infect villagers. The floods have also\nled to the contamination of clean water sources such as wells, leaving\nmany people with no option but to use the same dirty water for both\ndrinking and sanitation. The infection spreads every year in\nimpoverished parts of Uttar Pradesh during the monsoon season,\nresulting in hundreds of deaths.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, viral encephalitis causes\nhigh fever, headache, stiff neck and back, vomiting, confusion and, in\nsevere cases, seizures, paralysis, and coma. Infants and elderly\npeople are particularly at risk of severe illness.\n\nOfficials say the government has earmarked 22 million rupees (USD 450\n000) to tackle problems like the unavailability of clean drinking\nwater, lack of sanitation, and water logging, to prevent the virus\nfrom spreading. But local aid workers say efforts need to be stepped\nup. \"The infection started in the early 1970s and since then it has\nbecome an annual feature. The government is adopting short term\nmeasures to deal with the infection instead of making any long term\nplan to get rid of the virus,\" said Sanjay Kumar Srivastava from\nAction for Peace, Prosperity and Liberty (APPL), a charity doing\nresearch on the disease. \"Besides, no preventive measures are taken to\nstop the outbreak,\" he added, suggesting that vaccinations be more\nreadily available to adults as well as to children.\n\n[Byline: Alka Pande, Nita Bhalla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of unspecified acute encephalitis syndrome\nimplicated contaminated water as a source of the infectious agent,\nsuggesting, without stating, that enteroviruses might be involved. The\nreport above states that enteroviruses are involved, but does not\nindicate which ones are responsible for the encephalitis cases that\nare occurring. At least, this points to the source of the problem and\nsuggests preventive measures that might be taken. INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "897072", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (24): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=897072", "date": "2011-09-14 16:44:04", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (17): (BIHAR)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Bihar\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\n\n******\n[1]Bihar\nDate: Wed 14 Sep 2011\nSource: Yahoo News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://in.news.yahoo.com/bihar-suspected-encephalitis-kills-six-more-080138810.html\n\n\nWith 6 more children dying, encephalitis is now suspected to have\nclaimed 25 young lives in Bihar, an official said Wednesday [14 Sep\n2011]. The 6 children died in the last 2 days at Anugrah Narain\nMedical College and Hospital (ANMCH) in Gaya, about 100 km [62 mi]\nfrom [Patna], said the district health official. 19 children had died\nearlier. The children reported high fever, followed by bouts of\nunconsciousness and convulsions.\n\nTo date, more than 75 children with suspected encephalitis admitted,\nto the hospital, said its superintendent, Sitaram Prasad. \"Most of the\nchildren were from rural areas of Gaya and neighbouring districts.\nMore than 2 dozen children are still battling for life,\" he said.\n\nMeasures were being taken to check the spread of the disease, said\nHealth Minister Ashwini Kumar Choubey.\n\nSuspected encephalitis hit Gaya in 2009, 2007, and 2005 and killed\ndozens of children, said a district administration official.\n\nFear of suspected encephalitis is haunting the Patna Medical College\nand Hospital (PMCH) with 45 samples of brain fever cases having tested\npositive in the last 1.5 months. 3 people reportedly died due to the\ndisease.\n\nThe state health department is running short of Japanese encephalitis\n[JE] kits to test [for] the infection. \"In view of seriousness of the\nissue, ANMCH and PMCH have sent an SOS to the National Institute of\nVirology, Pune, to send the kits soon,\" an official of the health\ndepartment told IANS.\n\n2 months ago, 51 children died in Muzaffarpur district but the state\ngovernment is yet to confirm these as encephalitis deaths. Last month\n[August 2011], union Health and Family Welfare Minister Ghulam Nabi\nAzad informed the Rajya Sabha [Council of States] that clinical and\nepidemiological data suggested that it was an outbreak of acute\nencephalitis syndrome, resulting in 150 cases and 55 deaths, mostly\namong children. In a written reply, the minister said these cases were\nreported from early June to mid-July [2011] from Muzaffarpur and its\nbordering areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\nDate: 14 Sep 2011\nSource: NVBDCP (National Vector Borne Disease Control Program) India\nhttp://nvbdcp.gov.in/je-cd.html\n\nThe following cumulative case numbers of AES/JE (to Sep 13) were\nreleased today by the NVBDCP;\n\n\nState: Cases / Fatalities\nAndhra Pradesh: 59 / 1\nAssam: 1308 / 246\nBihar: 288 / 54\nGoa: 53 / 0\nKarnataka: 94 / 0\nKerala: 79 / 3\nMaharashtra: 4 / 3\nManipur: 2 / 0\nNagaland: 44 / 6\nTamil Nadu: 404 / 13\nUttar Pradesh: 1782 / 248\nWest Bengal: 341 / 10\n\nTotal: 4458 / 584\n\n(The numbers for Bihar do not include a current outbreak in Gaya which\nhas caused an additional 25 fatalities.)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRonan Kelly for FluTrackers.com\n<ronankelly@comcast.net>\n\n[The one additional death cited in the report in [1] above has\noccurred in the past 24 hours (see ProMED-mail archive no\n20110913.2793). Presumably this case is also due to JE virus\ninfection, as yesterday's (13 Sep 2011) report indicated that the 24\ndeaths were due to infection by that virus.\n\nThere are no indications given about the measures to be taken to halt\nthe spread of the disease. Is a JE virus vaccination campaign planned?\nAgain, the etiology of the acute encephalitis syndrome cases in the\nMuzaffarpur district mentioned above is not specified.\n\nGaya is the 2nd largest city in Bihar state and the capital of the\ndistrict. A HealthMap Interactive map showing the location of Gaya can\nbe accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1emt.\n\nWith respect to the information in report [2] above, JE cases are\nwidely scattered across the Indian states. It would be of interest to\nknow if vaccination campaigns were carried out in the states most\naffected. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (BI) 20110913.2793\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (BI) 20110912.2774\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (BI) 20110910.2757\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20110824.2582\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (UP) 20110813.2456\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20110727.2263\nand older items in the archives\n.................................................ty/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2011-09-13 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-08-15 00:00:00", "2011-09-13 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-09-13 00:00:00", "1308-03-15 00:00:00", "1782-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-09-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bihar", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "Muzaffarpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Gaya", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "894304", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (23): (BI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=894304", "date": "2011-09-14 16:44:04", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (17): (BIHAR)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Bihar\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\n\n******\n[1]Bihar\nDate: Wed 14 Sep 2011\nSource: Yahoo News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://in.news.yahoo.com/bihar-suspected-encephalitis-kills-six-more-080138810.html\n\n\nWith 6 more children dying, encephalitis is now suspected to have\nclaimed 25 young lives in Bihar, an official said Wednesday [14 Sep\n2011]. The 6 children died in the last 2 days at Anugrah Narain\nMedical College and Hospital (ANMCH) in Gaya, about 100 km [62 mi]\nfrom [Patna], said the district health official. 19 children had died\nearlier. The children reported high fever, followed by bouts of\nunconsciousness and convulsions.\n\nTo date, more than 75 children with suspected encephalitis admitted,\nto the hospital, said its superintendent, Sitaram Prasad. \"Most of the\nchildren were from rural areas of Gaya and neighbouring districts.\nMore than 2 dozen children are still battling for life,\" he said.\n\nMeasures were being taken to check the spread of the disease, said\nHealth Minister Ashwini Kumar Choubey.\n\nSuspected encephalitis hit Gaya in 2009, 2007, and 2005 and killed\ndozens of children, said a district administration official.\n\nFear of suspected encephalitis is haunting the Patna Medical College\nand Hospital (PMCH) with 45 samples of brain fever cases having tested\npositive in the last 1.5 months. 3 people reportedly died due to the\ndisease.\n\nThe state health department is running short of Japanese encephalitis\n[JE] kits to test [for] the infection. \"In view of seriousness of the\nissue, ANMCH and PMCH have sent an SOS to the National Institute of\nVirology, Pune, to send the kits soon,\" an official of the health\ndepartment told IANS.\n\n2 months ago, 51 children died in Muzaffarpur district but the state\ngovernment is yet to confirm these as encephalitis deaths. Last month\n[August 2011], union Health and Family Welfare Minister Ghulam Nabi\nAzad informed the Rajya Sabha [Council of States] that clinical and\nepidemiological data suggested that it was an outbreak of acute\nencephalitis syndrome, resulting in 150 cases and 55 deaths, mostly\namong children. In a written reply, the minister said these cases were\nreported from early June to mid-July [2011] from Muzaffarpur and its\nbordering areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\nDate: 14 Sep 2011\nSource: NVBDCP (National Vector Borne Disease Control Program) India\nhttp://nvbdcp.gov.in/je-cd.html\n\nThe following cumulative case numbers of AES/JE (to Sep 13) were\nreleased today by the NVBDCP;\n\n\nState: Cases / Fatalities\nAndhra Pradesh: 59 / 1\nAssam: 1308 / 246\nBihar: 288 / 54\nGoa: 53 / 0\nKarnataka: 94 / 0\nKerala: 79 / 3\nMaharashtra: 4 / 3\nManipur: 2 / 0\nNagaland: 44 / 6\nTamil Nadu: 404 / 13\nUttar Pradesh: 1782 / 248\nWest Bengal: 341 / 10\n\nTotal: 4458 / 584\n\n(The numbers for Bihar do not include a current outbreak in Gaya which\nhas caused an additional 25 fatalities.)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRonan Kelly for FluTrackers.com\n<ronankelly@comcast.net>\n\n[The one additional death cited in the report in [1] above has\noccurred in the past 24 hours (see ProMED-mail archive no\n20110913.2793). It would be of interest to\nknow if vaccination campaigns were carried out in the states most\naffected. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (BI) 20110913.2793\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (AS) 20110727.2263\nand older items in the archives\n.................................................ty/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2011-09-13 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-08-15 00:00:00", "2011-09-13 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-09-13 00:00:00", "1308-03-15 00:00:00", "1782-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-09-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bihar", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "Muzaffarpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Gaya", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "891237", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (22): (UP, JH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=891237", "date": "2011-09-14 16:44:04", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (17): (BIHAR)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Bihar\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\n\n******\n[1]Bihar\nDate: Wed 14 Sep 2011\nSource: Yahoo News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://in.news.yahoo.com/bihar-suspected-encephalitis-kills-six-more-080138810.html\n\n\nWith 6 more children dying, encephalitis is now suspected to have\nclaimed 25 young lives in Bihar, an official said Wednesday [14 Sep\n2011]. The 6 children died in the last 2 days at Anugrah Narain\nMedical College and Hospital (ANMCH) in Gaya, about 100 km [62 mi]\nfrom [Patna], said the district health official. 19 children had died\nearlier. The children reported high fever, followed by bouts of\nunconsciousness and convulsions.\n\nTo date, more than 75 children with suspected encephalitis admitted,\nto the hospital, said its superintendent, Sitaram Prasad. \"Most of the\nchildren were from rural areas of Gaya and neighbouring districts.\nMore than 2 dozen children are still battling for life,\" he said.\n\nMeasures were being taken to check the spread of the disease, said\nHealth Minister Ashwini Kumar Choubey.\n\nSuspected encephalitis hit Gaya in 2009, 2007, and 2005 and killed\ndozens of children, said a district administration official.\n\nFear of suspected encephalitis is haunting the Patna Medical College\nand Hospital (PMCH) with 45 samples of brain fever cases having tested\npositive in the last 1.5 months. 3 people reportedly died due to the\ndisease.\n\nThe state health department is running short of Japanese encephalitis\n[JE] kits to test [for] the infection. \"In view of seriousness of the\nissue, ANMCH and PMCH have sent an SOS to the National Institute of\nVirology, Pune, to send the kits soon,\" an official of the health\ndepartment told IANS.\n\n2 months ago, 51 children died in Muzaffarpur district but the state\ngovernment is yet to confirm these as encephalitis deaths. Last month\n[August 2011], union Health and Family Welfare Minister Ghulam Nabi\nAzad informed the Rajya Sabha [Council of States] that clinical and\nepidemiological data suggested that it was an outbreak of acute\nencephalitis syndrome, resulting in 150 cases and 55 deaths, mostly\namong children. In a written reply, the minister said these cases were\nreported from early June to mid-July [2011] from Muzaffarpur and its\nbordering areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\nDate: 14 Sep 2011\nSource: NVBDCP (National Vector Borne Disease Control Program) India\nhttp://nvbdcp.gov.in/je-cd.html\n\nThe following cumulative case numbers of AES/JE (to Sep 13) were\nreleased today by the NVBDCP;\n\n\nState: Cases / Fatalities\nAndhra Pradesh: 59 / 1\nAssam: 1308 / 246\nBihar: 288 / 54\nGoa: 53 / 0\nKarnataka: 94 / 0\nKerala: 79 / 3\nMaharashtra: 4 / 3\nManipur: 2 / 0\nNagaland: 44 / 6\nTamil Nadu: 404 / 13\nUttar Pradesh: 1782 / 248\nWest Bengal: 341 / 10\n\nTotal: 4458 / 584\n\n(The numbers for Bihar do not include a current outbreak in Gaya which\nhas caused an additional 25 fatalities.)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRonan Kelly for FluTrackers.com\n<ronankelly@comcast.net>\n\n[The one additional death cited in the report in [1] above has\noccurred in the past 24 hours (see ProMED-mail archive no\n20110913.2793). Presumably this case is also due to JE virus\ninfection, as yesterday's (13 Sep 2011) report indicated that the 24\ndeaths were due to infection by that virus.\n\nThere are no indications given about the measures to be taken to halt\nthe spread of the disease. Is a JE virus vaccination campaign planned?\nAgain, the etiology of the acute encephalitis syndrome cases in the\nMuzaffarpur district mentioned above is not specified.\n\nGaya is the 2nd largest city in Bihar state and the capital of the\ndistrict. A HealthMap Interactive map showing the location of Gaya can\nbe accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1emt.\n\nWith respect to the information in report [2] above, JE cases are\nwidely scattered across the Indian states. It would be of interest to\nknow if vaccination campaigns were carried out in the states most\naffected. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (BI) 20110913.2793\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (BI) 20110912.2774\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (BI) 20110910.2757\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20110824.2582\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (UP) 20110813.2456\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=877029", "date": "2011-09-14 16:44:04", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (17): (BIHAR)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Bihar\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\n\n******\n[1]Bihar\nDate: Wed 14 Sep 2011\nSource: Yahoo News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://in.news.yahoo.com/bihar-suspected-encephalitis-kills-six-more-080138810.html\n\n\nWith 6 more children dying, encephalitis is now suspected to have\nclaimed 25 young lives in Bihar, an official said Wednesday [14 Sep\n2011]. The 6 children died in the last 2 days at Anugrah Narain\nMedical College and Hospital (ANMCH) in Gaya, about 100 km [62 mi]\nfrom [Patna], said the district health official. 19 children had died\nearlier. The children reported high fever, followed by bouts of\nunconsciousness and convulsions.\n\nTo date, more than 75 children with suspected encephalitis admitted,\nto the hospital, said its superintendent, Sitaram Prasad. \"Most of the\nchildren were from rural areas of Gaya and neighbouring districts.\nMore than 2 dozen children are still battling for life,\" he said.\n\nMeasures were being taken to check the spread of the disease, said\nHealth Minister Ashwini Kumar Choubey.\n\nSuspected encephalitis hit Gaya in 2009, 2007, and 2005 and killed\ndozens of children, said a district administration official.\n\nFear of suspected encephalitis is haunting the Patna Medical College\nand Hospital (PMCH) with 45 samples of brain fever cases having tested\npositive in the last 1.5 months. 3 people reportedly died due to the\ndisease.\n\nThe state health department is running short of Japanese encephalitis\n[JE] kits to test [for] the infection. \"In view of seriousness of the\nissue, ANMCH and PMCH have sent an SOS to the National Institute of\nVirology, Pune, to send the kits soon,\" an official of the health\ndepartment told IANS.\n\n2 months ago, 51 children died in Muzaffarpur district but the state\ngovernment is yet to confirm these as encephalitis deaths. Last month\n[August 2011], union Health and Family Welfare Minister Ghulam Nabi\nAzad informed the Rajya Sabha [Council of States] that clinical and\nepidemiological data suggested that it was an outbreak of acute\nencephalitis syndrome, resulting in 150 cases and 55 deaths, mostly\namong children. In a written reply, the minister said these cases were\nreported from early June to mid-July [2011] from Muzaffarpur and its\nbordering areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\nDate: 14 Sep 2011\nSource: NVBDCP (National Vector Borne Disease Control Program) India\nhttp://nvbdcp.gov.in/je-cd.html\n\nThe following cumulative case numbers of AES/JE (to Sep 13) were\nreleased today by the NVBDCP;\n\n\nState: Cases / Fatalities\nAndhra Pradesh: 59 / 1\nAssam: 1308 / 246\nBihar: 288 / 54\nGoa: 53 / 0\nKarnataka: 94 / 0\nKerala: 79 / 3\nMaharashtra: 4 / 3\nManipur: 2 / 0\nNagaland: 44 / 6\nTamil Nadu: 404 / 13\nUttar Pradesh: 1782 / 248\nWest Bengal: 341 / 10\n\nTotal: 4458 / 584\n\n(The numbers for Bihar do not include a current outbreak in Gaya which\nhas caused an additional 25 fatalities.)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRonan Kelly for FluTrackers.com\n<ronankelly@comcast.net>\n\n[The one additional death cited in the report in [1] above has\noccurred in the past 24 hours (see ProMED-mail archive no\n20110913.2793). Presumably this case is also due to JE virus\ninfection, as yesterday's (13 Sep 2011) report indicated that the 24\ndeaths were due to infection by that virus.\n\nThere are no indications given about the measures to be taken to halt\nthe spread of the disease. Is a JE virus vaccination campaign planned?\nAgain, the etiology of the acute encephalitis syndrome cases in the\nMuzaffarpur district mentioned above is not specified.\n\nGaya is the 2nd largest city in Bihar state and the capital of the\ndistrict. A HealthMap Interactive map showing the location of Gaya can\nbe accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1emt.\n\nWith respect to the information in report [2] above, JE cases are\nwidely scattered across the Indian states. It would be of interest to\nknow if vaccination campaigns were carried out in the states most\naffected. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (BI) 20110913.2793\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (BI) 20110912.2774\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (BI) 20110910.2757\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (AS) 20110824.2582\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (UP) 20110813.2456\nJapanese encephalitis & other -
