India (17): (BI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=871043", "date": "2011-09-14 16:44:04", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (17): (BIHAR)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Bihar\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\n\n******\n[1]Bihar\nDate: Wed 14 Sep 2011\nSource: Yahoo News, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]\nhttp://in.news.yahoo.com/bihar-suspected-encephalitis-kills-six-more-080138810.html\n\n\nWith 6 more children dying, encephalitis is now suspected to have\nclaimed 25 young lives in Bihar, an official said Wednesday [14 Sep\n2011]. The 6 children died in the last 2 days at Anugrah Narain\nMedical College and Hospital (ANMCH) in Gaya, about 100 km [62 mi]\nfrom [Patna], said the district health official. 19 children had died\nearlier. The children reported high fever, followed by bouts of\nunconsciousness and convulsions.\n\nTo date, more than 75 children with suspected encephalitis admitted,\nto the hospital, said its superintendent, Sitaram Prasad. \"Most of the\nchildren were from rural areas of Gaya and neighbouring districts.\nMore than 2 dozen children are still battling for life,\" he said.\n\nMeasures were being taken to check the spread of the disease, said\nHealth Minister Ashwini Kumar Choubey.\n\nSuspected encephalitis hit Gaya in 2009, 2007, and 2005 and killed\ndozens of children, said a district administration official.\n\nFear of suspected encephalitis is haunting the Patna Medical College\nand Hospital (PMCH) with 45 samples of brain fever cases having tested\npositive in the last 1.5 months. 3 people reportedly died due to the\ndisease.\n\nThe state health department is running short of Japanese encephalitis\n[JE] kits to test [for] the infection. \"In view of seriousness of the\nissue, ANMCH and PMCH have sent an SOS to the National Institute of\nVirology, Pune, to send the kits soon,\" an official of the health\ndepartment told IANS.\n\n2 months ago, 51 children died in Muzaffarpur district but the state\ngovernment is yet to confirm these as encephalitis deaths. Last month\n[August 2011], union Health and Family Welfare Minister Ghulam Nabi\nAzad informed the Rajya Sabha [Council of States] that clinical and\nepidemiological data suggested that it was an outbreak of acute\nencephalitis syndrome, resulting in 150 cases and 55 deaths, mostly\namong children. In a written reply, the minister said these cases were\nreported from early June to mid-July [2011] from Muzaffarpur and its\nbordering areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] NVBDC statistics as of 13 Sep 2011\nDate: 14 Sep 2011\nSource: NVBDCP (National Vector Borne Disease Control Program) India\nhttp://nvbdcp.gov.in/je-cd.html\n\nThe following cumulative case numbers of AES/JE (to Sep 13) were\nreleased today by the NVBDCP;\n\n\nState: Cases / Fatalities\nAndhra Pradesh: 59 / 1\nAssam: 1308 / 246\nBihar: 288 / 54\nGoa: 53 / 0\nKarnataka: 94 / 0\nKerala: 79 / 3\nMaharashtra: 4 / 3\nManipur: 2 / 0\nNagaland: 44 / 6\nTamil Nadu: 404 / 13\nUttar Pradesh: 1782 / 248\nWest Bengal: 341 / 10\n\nTotal: 4458 / 584\n\n(The numbers for Bihar do not include a current outbreak in Gaya which\nhas caused an additional 25 fatalities.)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nRonan Kelly for FluTrackers.com\n<ronankelly@comcast.net>\n\n[The one additional death cited in the report in [1] above has\noccurred in the past 24 hours (see ProMED-mail archive no\n20110913.2793). Presumably this case is also due to JE virus\ninfection, as yesterday's (13 Sep 2011) report indicated that the 24\ndeaths were due to infection by that virus.\n\nThere are no indications given about the measures to be taken to halt\nthe spread of the disease. Is a JE virus vaccination campaign planned?\nAgain, the etiology of the acute encephalitis syndrome cases in the\nMuzaffarpur district mentioned above is not specified.\n\nGaya is the 2nd largest city in Bihar state and the capital of the\ndistrict. India (16): (BI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=869687", "date": "2011-08-06 20:56:21", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (09): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 6 Aug 2011\nSource: News 24 [edited]\nhttp://www.news24online.com/ViewDetails.aspx?NewsID=31536\n\n\nOne more child succumbed to encephalitis at a hospital here, taking\nthe death toll due to the deadly disease in eastern UP to 128 this\nyear [2011]. 13 new cases have been reported to the state-run BRD\nMedical College Hospital since yesterday [5 Aug 2011], Senior\nPaediatrician K.P Kushwaha said. 124 patients suffering from the\ndisease are undergoing treatment in the hospital.\n\nAs many as 731 encephalitis cases were reported in hospitals in the\nregion this year [2011]. Gorakhpur and Kushinagar are the worst\naffected districts.\n\nThe fever is caused by a virus found in pigs and is transferred to\nhumans by mosquito bite.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 3 Aug 2011 ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20110804.2356) indicated\nthat there have been 107 deaths from Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections. The above report indicates that there are now 128 cases.\nAlthough the above report does not indicate the specific etiology of\nthe encephalitis cases, the mention that the virus is found in pigs\nand transmitted by mosquitoes is a clear implication that JE virus is\ninvolved. It would be of interest to know whether all of these cases\nwere laboratory confirmed as JE virus infections.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India showing the location\nof Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh state can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "867434", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (BI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=867434", "date": "2011-08-06 20:56:21", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (09): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 6 Aug 2011\nSource: News 24 [edited]\nhttp://www.news24online.com/ViewDetails.aspx?NewsID=31536\n\n\nOne more child succumbed to encephalitis at a hospital here, taking\nthe death toll due to the deadly disease in eastern UP to 128 this\nyear [2011]. 13 new cases have been reported to the state-run BRD\nMedical College Hospital since yesterday [5 Aug 2011], Senior\nPaediatrician K.P Kushwaha said. 124 patients suffering from the\ndisease are undergoing treatment in the hospital.\n\nAs many as 731 encephalitis cases were reported in hospitals in the\nregion this year [2011]. Gorakhpur and Kushinagar are the worst\naffected districts.\n\nThe fever is caused by a virus found in pigs and is transferred to\nhumans by mosquito bite.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 3 Aug 2011 ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20110804.2356) indicated\nthat there have been 107 deaths from Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections. The above report indicates that there are now 128 cases.\nAlthough the above report does not indicate the specific etiology of\nthe encephalitis cases, the mention that the virus is found in pigs\nand transmitted by mosquitoes is a clear implication that JE virus is\ninvolved. It would be of interest to know whether all of these cases\nwere laboratory confirmed as JE virus infections.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India showing the location\nof Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh state can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "865614", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (BI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=865614", "date": "2011-08-06 20:56:21", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (09): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 6 Aug 2011\nSource: News 24 [edited]\nhttp://www.news24online.com/ViewDetails.aspx?NewsID=31536\n\n\nOne more child succumbed to encephalitis at a hospital here, taking\nthe death toll due to the deadly disease in eastern UP to 128 this\nyear [2011]. 13 new cases have been reported to the state-run BRD\nMedical College Hospital since yesterday [5 Aug 2011], Senior\nPaediatrician K.P Kushwaha said. 124 patients suffering from the\ndisease are undergoing treatment in the hospital.\n\nAs many as 731 encephalitis cases were reported in hospitals in the\nregion this year [2011]. Gorakhpur and Kushinagar are the worst\naffected districts.\n\nThe fever is caused by a virus found in pigs and is transferred to\nhumans by mosquito bite.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 3 Aug 2011 ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20110804.2356) indicated\nthat there have been 107 deaths from Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections. The above report indicates that there are now 128 cases.\nAlthough the above report does not indicate the specific etiology of\nthe encephalitis cases, the mention that the virus is found in pigs\nand transmitted by mosquitoes is a clear implication that JE virus is\ninvolved. It would be of interest to know whether all of these cases\nwere laboratory confirmed as JE virus infections.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India showing the location\nof Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh state can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - Gorakhpur and Kushinagar are the worst\naffected districts.\n\nThe fever is caused by a virus found in pigs and is transferred to\nhumans by mosquito bite.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 3 Aug 2011 ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20110804.2356) indicated\nthat there have been 107 deaths from Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections. The above report indicates that there are now 128 cases.\nAlthough the above report does not indicate the specific etiology of\nthe encephalitis cases, the mention that the virus is found in pigs\nand transmitted by mosquitoes is a clear implication that JE virus is\ninvolved. It would be of interest to know whether all of these cases\nwere laboratory confirmed as JE virus infections.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India showing the location\nof Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh state can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "828478", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (UP, BI, NA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=828478", "date": "2011-08-06 20:56:21", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (09): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 6 Aug 2011\nSource: News 24 [edited]\nhttp://www.news24online.com/ViewDetails.aspx?NewsID=31536\n\n\nOne more child succumbed to encephalitis at a hospital here, taking\nthe death toll due to the deadly disease in eastern UP to 128 this\nyear [2011]. 13 new cases have been reported to the state-run BRD\nMedical College Hospital since yesterday [5 Aug 2011], Senior\nPaediatrician K.P Kushwaha said. 124 patients suffering from the\ndisease are undergoing treatment in the hospital.\n\nAs many as 731 encephalitis cases were reported in hospitals in the\nregion this year [2011]. Gorakhpur and Kushinagar are the worst\naffected districts.\n\nThe fever is caused by a virus found in pigs and is transferred to\nhumans by mosquito bite.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 3 Aug 2011 ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20110804.2356) indicated\nthat there have been 107 deaths from Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections. The above report indicates that there are now 128 cases.\nAlthough the above report does not indicate the specific etiology of\nthe encephalitis cases, the mention that the virus is found in pigs\nand transmitted by mosquitoes is a clear implication that JE virus is\ninvolved. It would be of interest to know whether all of these cases\nwere laboratory confirmed as JE virus infections.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India showing the location\nof Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh state can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - INDIA (09): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 6 Aug 2011\nSource: News 24 [edited]\nhttp://www.news24online.com/ViewDetails.aspx?NewsID=31536\n\n\nOne more child succumbed to encephalitis at a hospital here, taking\nthe death toll due to the deadly disease in eastern UP to 128 this\nyear [2011]. 13 new cases have been reported to the state-run BRD\nMedical College Hospital since yesterday [5 Aug 2011], Senior\nPaediatrician K.P Kushwaha said. 124 patients suffering from the\ndisease are undergoing treatment in the hospital.\n\nAs many as 731 encephalitis cases were reported in hospitals in the\nregion this year [2011]. Gorakhpur and Kushinagar are the worst\naffected districts.\n\nThe fever is caused by a virus found in pigs and is transferred to\nhumans by mosquito bite.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 3 Aug 2011 ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20110804.2356) indicated\nthat there have been 107 deaths from Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections. The above report indicates that there are now 128 cases.\nAlthough the above report does not indicate the specific etiology of\nthe encephalitis cases, the mention that the virus is found in pigs\nand transmitted by mosquitoes is a clear implication that JE virus is\ninvolved. INDIA (09): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 6 Aug 2011\nSource: News 24 [edited]\nhttp://www.news24online.com/ViewDetails.aspx?NewsID=31536\n\n\nOne more child succumbed to encephalitis at a hospital here, taking\nthe death toll due to the deadly disease in eastern UP to 128 this\nyear [2011]. 13 new cases have been reported to the state-run BRD\nMedical College Hospital since yesterday [5 Aug 2011], Senior\nPaediatrician K.P Kushwaha said. 124 patients suffering from the\ndisease are undergoing treatment in the hospital.\n\nAs many as 731 encephalitis cases were reported in hospitals in the\nregion this year [2011]. Gorakhpur and Kushinagar are the worst\naffected districts.\n\nThe fever is caused by a virus found in pigs and is transferred to\nhumans by mosquito bite.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 3 Aug 2011 ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20110804.2356) indicated\nthat there have been 107 deaths from Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections. The above report indicates that there are now 128 cases.\nAlthough the above report does not indicate the specific etiology of\nthe encephalitis cases, the mention that the virus is found in pigs\nand transmitted by mosquitoes is a clear implication that JE virus is\ninvolved. It would be of interest to know whether all of these cases\nwere laboratory confirmed as JE virus infections.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India showing the location\nof Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh state can be accessed at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "808728", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=808728", "date": "2011-07-07 15:23:39", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA: (UTTAR PRADESH)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nSource: Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.indianexpress.com/news/encephalitis-cases-up-with-onset-of-monsoon/813942/\n\n\nThe number of cases of Japanese encephalitis [JE] in the 7 high-risk\ndistricts of Uttar Pradesh has shot up with the arrival of the\nmonsoon, despite the extensive immunisation undertaken by the\ngovernment to control it. The state has already seen 79 more cases and\n10 more deaths due to encephalitis till 5 Jul [2011], as compared to\nlast year [2010].\n\nAccording to reports received by the Medical and Health Department,\nlast year [2010] the state recorded 371 cases and 67 deaths from acute\nencephalitis syndrome (AES), while this year [2011] the number of\ncases has already reached 450 and deaths 77. Similar is the case with\nJE. Until 5 Jul 2010, the state had seen merely 5 cases and one death\nfrom JE, but this time the number of JE cases is already 20, with 3\ndeaths.\n\nThe worst affected districts are Gorakhpur with 111 cases and 21\ndeaths of AES so far, closely followed by Deoria (109 cases and 15\ndeaths), and Kushinagar (103 cases and 22 deaths). JE cases have also\nbeen reported from these 3 districts along with Basti,\nSiddharthanagar, Sant Kabir Nagar, and Maharajganj.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a JE virus endemic area, and so with the onset of the annual\nmonsoon season, it is not surprising that cases of infection by this\nvirus are occurring. It would be of interest to know the vaccine\ncoverage of the large populations in these areas. Again, as in reports\nfrom previous years, there are reported this year (2011) cases of JE\nvirus infection, mixed with cases of \"acute encephalitis syndrome\"\n(AES) of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe 28 Jul 2010 edition of The Pioneer\n(http://www.dailypioneer.com/272045/Mystery-virus-besets-east-UP.html)\nquoted the director general (medical & health), Dr RR Bharti as\nsaying, \"When even the local unit of the National Institute of\nVirology (NIV) Pune, based in Gorakhpur, failed to arrive at any\nconclusion [about the etiology of non-JE virus AES cases], Bharti\nrequested the Union Health Ministry to intervene. A team of Union\nHealth Ministry officials and scientists from the Indian Council of\nMedical Research (ICMR) -- along with Bharti and Dr SP Ram -- visited\nGorakhpur on Saturday [24 Jul 2010]. However, they also failed to\ndiagnose the viral strain causing deaths of children in the region.\n\"At times, it shows symptoms of an enterovirus [meningitis?] but not\nuniformly, so we cannot arrive at any concrete conclusion,\" said\nBharti (see ProMED-mail archive no 20100728.2535).\n\nThere was no indication in any of the previous reports of AES cases\nthat samples were sent to any of the WHO world reference centers to\ndetermine the etiology involved in these AES cases. Without a\ndiagnosis, it will not be possible to develop a rational prevention\nstrategy.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\nhttp://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India is available at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - Mod.TY\n\nThe districts mentioned are in eastern Uttar Pradesh and can be seen\non the map at\nhttp://maps.newkerala.com/Uttar-Pradesh-Travel-Map.jpg. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2010\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (UP) 20100728.2535\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (ML) 20100723.2473\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN) conf. 20100716.2380\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (MN) conf. 20100713.2352\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (AP) 20100422.1309\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (UP) 20100416.1236\n.................................................sb/sh/ty/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Deoria", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Gorakhpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "799962", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis and other - India (07): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=799962", "date": "2011-07-07 15:23:39", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA: (UTTAR PRADESH)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nSource: Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.indianexpress.com/news/encephalitis-cases-up-with-onset-of-monsoon/813942/\n\n\nThe number of cases of Japanese encephalitis [JE] in the 7 high-risk\ndistricts of Uttar Pradesh has shot up with the arrival of the\nmonsoon, despite the extensive immunisation undertaken by the\ngovernment to control it. The state has already seen 79 more cases and\n10 more deaths due to encephalitis till 5 Jul [2011], as compared to\nlast year [2010].\n\nAccording to reports received by the Medical and Health Department,\nlast year [2010] the state recorded 371 cases and 67 deaths from acute\nencephalitis syndrome (AES), while this year [2011] the number of\ncases has already reached 450 and deaths 77. Similar is the case with\nJE. Until 5 Jul 2010, the state had seen merely 5 cases and one death\nfrom JE, but this time the number of JE cases is already 20, with 3\ndeaths.\n\nThe worst affected districts are Gorakhpur with 111 cases and 21\ndeaths of AES so far, closely followed by Deoria (109 cases and 15\ndeaths), and Kushinagar (103 cases and 22 deaths). JE cases have also\nbeen reported from these 3 districts along with Basti,\nSiddharthanagar, Sant Kabir Nagar, and Maharajganj.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a JE virus endemic area, and so with the onset of the annual\nmonsoon season, it is not surprising that cases of infection by this\nvirus are occurring. It would be of interest to know the vaccine\ncoverage of the large populations in these areas. Again, as in reports\nfrom previous years, there are reported this year (2011) cases of JE\nvirus infection, mixed with cases of \"acute encephalitis syndrome\"\n(AES) of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe 28 Jul 2010 edition of The Pioneer\n(http://www.dailypioneer.com/272045/Mystery-virus-besets-east-UP.html)\nquoted the director general (medical & health), Dr RR Bharti as\nsaying, \"When even the local unit of the National Institute of\nVirology (NIV) Pune, based in Gorakhpur, failed to arrive at any\nconclusion [about the etiology of non-JE virus AES cases], Bharti\nrequested the Union Health Ministry to intervene. A team of Union\nHealth Ministry officials and scientists from the Indian Council of\nMedical Research (ICMR) -- along with Bharti and Dr SP Ram -- visited\nGorakhpur on Saturday [24 Jul 2010]. However, they also failed to\ndiagnose the viral strain causing deaths of children in the region.\n\"At times, it shows symptoms of an enterovirus [meningitis?] but not\nuniformly, so we cannot arrive at any concrete conclusion,\" said\nBharti (see ProMED-mail archive no 20100728.2535).\n\nThere was no indication in any of the previous reports of AES cases\nthat samples were sent to any of the WHO world reference centers to\ndetermine the etiology involved in these AES cases. Without a\ndiagnosis, it will not be possible to develop a rational prevention\nstrategy.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\nhttp://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India is available at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - Mod.TY\n\nThe districts mentioned are in eastern Uttar Pradesh and can be seen\non the map at\nhttp://maps.newkerala.com/Uttar-Pradesh-Travel-Map.jpg. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2010\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=797218", "date": "2011-07-07 15:23:39", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA: (UTTAR PRADESH)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nSource: Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.indianexpress.com/news/encephalitis-cases-up-with-onset-of-monsoon/813942/\n\n\nThe number of cases of Japanese encephalitis [JE] in the 7 high-risk\ndistricts of Uttar Pradesh has shot up with the arrival of the\nmonsoon, despite the extensive immunisation undertaken by the\ngovernment to control it. The state has already seen 79 more cases and\n10 more deaths due to encephalitis till 5 Jul [2011], as compared to\nlast year [2010].\n\nAccording to reports received by the Medical and Health Department,\nlast year [2010] the state recorded 371 cases and 67 deaths from acute\nencephalitis syndrome (AES), while this year [2011] the number of\ncases has already reached 450 and deaths 77. Similar is the case with\nJE. Until 5 Jul 2010, the state had seen merely 5 cases and one death\nfrom JE, but this time the number of JE cases is already 20, with 3\ndeaths.\n\nThe worst affected districts are Gorakhpur with 111 cases and 21\ndeaths of AES so far, closely followed by Deoria (109 cases and 15\ndeaths), and Kushinagar (103 cases and 22 deaths). JE cases have also\nbeen reported from these 3 districts along with Basti,\nSiddharthanagar, Sant Kabir Nagar, and Maharajganj.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a JE virus endemic area, and so with the onset of the annual\nmonsoon season, it is not surprising that cases of infection by this\nvirus are occurring. It would be of interest to know the vaccine\ncoverage of the large populations in these areas. Again, as in reports\nfrom previous years, there are reported this year (2011) cases of JE\nvirus infection, mixed with cases of \"acute encephalitis syndrome\"\n(AES) of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe 28 Jul 2010 edition of The Pioneer\n(http://www.dailypioneer.com/272045/Mystery-virus-besets-east-UP.html)\nquoted the director general (medical & health), Dr RR Bharti as\nsaying, \"When even the local unit of the National Institute of\nVirology (NIV) Pune, based in Gorakhpur, failed to arrive at any\nconclusion [about the etiology of non-JE virus AES cases], Bharti\nrequested the Union Health Ministry to intervene. A team of Union\nHealth Ministry officials and scientists from the Indian Council of\nMedical Research (ICMR) -- along with Bharti and Dr SP Ram -- visited\nGorakhpur on Saturday [24 Jul 2010]. However, they also failed to\ndiagnose the viral strain causing deaths of children in the region.\n\"At times, it shows symptoms of an enterovirus [meningitis?] but not\nuniformly, so we cannot arrive at any concrete conclusion,\" said\nBharti (see ProMED-mail archive no 20100728.2535).\n\nThere was no indication in any of the previous reports of AES cases\nthat samples were sent to any of the WHO world reference centers to\ndetermine the etiology involved in these AES cases. Without a\ndiagnosis, it will not be possible to develop a rational prevention\nstrategy.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\nhttp://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India is available at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - Mod.TY\n\nThe districts mentioned are in eastern Uttar Pradesh and can be seen\non the map at\nhttp://maps.newkerala.com/Uttar-Pradesh-Travel-Map.jpg. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2010\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (AP) 20100422.1309\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (UP) 20100416.1236\n.................................................sb/sh/ty/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Deoria", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Gorakhpur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "796919", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=796919", "date": "2011-07-07 15:23:39", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA: (UTTAR PRADESH)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nSource: Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.indianexpress.com/news/encephalitis-cases-up-with-onset-of-monsoon/813942/\n\n\nThe number of cases of Japanese encephalitis [JE] in the 7 high-risk\ndistricts of Uttar Pradesh has shot up with the arrival of the\nmonsoon, despite the extensive immunisation undertaken by the\ngovernment to control it. The state has already seen 79 more cases and\n10 more deaths due to encephalitis till 5 Jul [2011], as compared to\nlast year [2010].\n\nAccording to reports received by the Medical and Health Department,\nlast year [2010] the state recorded 371 cases and 67 deaths from acute\nencephalitis syndrome (AES), while this year [2011] the number of\ncases has already reached 450 and deaths 77. Similar is the case with\nJE. Until 5 Jul 2010, the state had seen merely 5 cases and one death\nfrom JE, but this time the number of JE cases is already 20, with 3\ndeaths.\n\nThe worst affected districts are Gorakhpur with 111 cases and 21\ndeaths of AES so far, closely followed by Deoria (109 cases and 15\ndeaths), and Kushinagar (103 cases and 22 deaths). JE cases have also\nbeen reported from these 3 districts along with Basti,\nSiddharthanagar, Sant Kabir Nagar, and Maharajganj.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a JE virus endemic area, and so with the onset of the annual\nmonsoon season, it is not surprising that cases of infection by this\nvirus are occurring. It would be of interest to know the vaccine\ncoverage of the large populations in these areas. Again, as in reports\nfrom previous years, there are reported this year (2011) cases of JE\nvirus infection, mixed with cases of \"acute encephalitis syndrome\"\n(AES) of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe 28 Jul 2010 edition of The Pioneer\n(http://www.dailypioneer.com/272045/Mystery-virus-besets-east-UP.html)\nquoted the director general (medical & health), Dr RR Bharti as\nsaying, \"When even the local unit of the National Institute of\nVirology (NIV) Pune, based in Gorakhpur, failed to arrive at any\nconclusion [about the etiology of non-JE virus AES cases], Bharti\nrequested the Union Health Ministry to intervene. A team of Union\nHealth Ministry officials and scientists from the Indian Council of\nMedical Research (ICMR) -- along with Bharti and Dr SP Ram -- visited\nGorakhpur on Saturday [24 Jul 2010]. However, they also failed to\ndiagnose the viral strain causing deaths of children in the region.\n\"At times, it shows symptoms of an enterovirus [meningitis?] but not\nuniformly, so we cannot arrive at any concrete conclusion,\" said\nBharti (see ProMED-mail archive no 20100728.2535).\n\nThere was no indication in any of the previous reports of AES cases\nthat samples were sent to any of the WHO world reference centers to\ndetermine the etiology involved in these AES cases. Without a\ndiagnosis, it will not be possible to develop a rational prevention\nstrategy.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\nhttp://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India is available at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - Mod.TY\n\nThe districts mentioned are in eastern Uttar Pradesh and can be seen\non the map at\nhttp://maps.newkerala.com/Uttar-Pradesh-Travel-Map.jpg. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2010\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=794234", "date": "2011-07-07 15:23:39", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA: (UTTAR PRADESH)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nSource: Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.indianexpress.com/news/encephalitis-cases-up-with-onset-of-monsoon/813942/\n\n\nThe number of cases of Japanese encephalitis [JE] in the 7 high-risk\ndistricts of Uttar Pradesh has shot up with the arrival of the\nmonsoon, despite the extensive immunisation undertaken by the\ngovernment to control it. The state has already seen 79 more cases and\n10 more deaths due to encephalitis till 5 Jul [2011], as compared to\nlast year [2010].\n\nAccording to reports received by the Medical and Health Department,\nlast year [2010] the state recorded 371 cases and 67 deaths from acute\nencephalitis syndrome (AES), while this year [2011] the number of\ncases has already reached 450 and deaths 77. Similar is the case with\nJE. Until 5 Jul 2010, the state had seen merely 5 cases and one death\nfrom JE, but this time the number of JE cases is already 20, with 3\ndeaths.\n\nThe worst affected districts are Gorakhpur with 111 cases and 21\ndeaths of AES so far, closely followed by Deoria (109 cases and 15\ndeaths), and Kushinagar (103 cases and 22 deaths). JE cases have also\nbeen reported from these 3 districts along with Basti,\nSiddharthanagar, Sant Kabir Nagar, and Maharajganj.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a JE virus endemic area, and so with the onset of the annual\nmonsoon season, it is not surprising that cases of infection by this\nvirus are occurring. It would be of interest to know the vaccine\ncoverage of the large populations in these areas. Again, as in reports\nfrom previous years, there are reported this year (2011) cases of JE\nvirus infection, mixed with cases of \"acute encephalitis syndrome\"\n(AES) of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe 28 Jul 2010 edition of The Pioneer\n(http://www.dailypioneer.com/272045/Mystery-virus-besets-east-UP.html)\nquoted the director general (medical & health), Dr RR Bharti as\nsaying, \"When even the local unit of the National Institute of\nVirology (NIV) Pune, based in Gorakhpur, failed to arrive at any\nconclusion [about the etiology of non-JE virus AES cases], Bharti\nrequested the Union Health Ministry to intervene. A team of Union\nHealth Ministry officials and scientists from the Indian Council of\nMedical Research (ICMR) -- along with Bharti and Dr SP Ram -- visited\nGorakhpur on Saturday [24 Jul 2010]. However, they also failed to\ndiagnose the viral strain causing deaths of children in the region.\n\"At times, it shows symptoms of an enterovirus [meningitis?] but not\nuniformly, so we cannot arrive at any concrete conclusion,\" said\nBharti (see ProMED-mail archive no 20100728.2535).\n\nThere was no indication in any of the previous reports of AES cases\nthat samples were sent to any of the WHO world reference centers to\ndetermine the etiology involved in these AES cases. Without a\ndiagnosis, it will not be possible to develop a rational prevention\nstrategy.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\nhttp://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif. The state has already seen 79 more cases and\n10 more deaths due to encephalitis till 5 Jul [2011], as compared to\nlast year [2010].\n\nAccording to reports received by the Medical and Health Department,\nlast year [2010] the state recorded 371 cases and 67 deaths from acute\nencephalitis syndrome (AES), while this year [2011] the number of\ncases has already reached 450 and deaths 77. Similar is the case with\nJE. Until 5 Jul 2010, the state had seen merely 5 cases and one death\nfrom JE, but this time the number of JE cases is already 20, with 3\ndeaths.\n\nThe worst affected districts are Gorakhpur with 111 cases and 21\ndeaths of AES so far, closely followed by Deoria (109 cases and 15\ndeaths), and Kushinagar (103 cases and 22 deaths). JE cases have also\nbeen reported from these 3 districts along with Basti,\nSiddharthanagar, Sant Kabir Nagar, and Maharajganj.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a JE virus endemic area, and so with the onset of the annual\nmonsoon season, it is not surprising that cases of infection by this\nvirus are occurring. It would be of interest to know the vaccine\ncoverage of the large populations in these areas. Again, as in reports\nfrom previous years, there are reported this year (2011) cases of JE\nvirus infection, mixed with cases of \"acute encephalitis syndrome\"\n(AES) of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe 28 Jul 2010 edition of The Pioneer\n(http://www.dailypioneer.com/272045/Mystery-virus-besets-east-UP.html)\nquoted the director general (medical & health), Dr RR Bharti as\nsaying, \"When even the local unit of the National Institute of\nVirology (NIV) Pune, based in Gorakhpur, failed to arrive at any\nconclusion [about the etiology of non-JE virus AES cases], Bharti\nrequested the Union Health Ministry to intervene. A team of Union\nHealth Ministry officials and scientists from the Indian Council of\nMedical Research (ICMR) -- along with Bharti and Dr SP Ram -- visited\nGorakhpur on Saturday [24 Jul 2010]. However, they also failed to\ndiagnose the viral strain causing deaths of children in the region.\n\"At times, it shows symptoms of an enterovirus [meningitis?] but not\nuniformly, so we cannot arrive at any concrete conclusion,\" said\nBharti (see ProMED-mail archive no 20100728.2535).\n\nThere was no indication in any of the previous reports of AES cases\nthat samples were sent to any of the WHO world reference centers to\ndetermine the etiology involved in these AES cases. Without a\ndiagnosis, it will not be possible to develop a rational prevention\nstrategy.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\nhttp://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif. The state has already seen 79 more cases and\n10 more deaths due to encephalitis till 5 Jul [2011], as compared to\nlast year [2010].\n\nAccording to reports received by the Medical and Health Department,\nlast year [2010] the state recorded 371 cases and 67 deaths from acute\nencephalitis syndrome (AES), while this year [2011] the number of\ncases has already reached 450 and deaths 77. Similar is the case with\nJE. Until 5 Jul 2010, the state had seen merely 5 cases and one death\nfrom JE, but this time the number of JE cases is already 20, with 3\ndeaths.\n\nThe worst affected districts are Gorakhpur with 111 cases and 21\ndeaths of AES so far, closely followed by Deoria (109 cases and 15\ndeaths), and Kushinagar (103 cases and 22 deaths). JE cases have also\nbeen reported from these 3 districts along with Basti,\nSiddharthanagar, Sant Kabir Nagar, and Maharajganj.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a JE virus endemic area, and so with the onset of the annual\nmonsoon season, it is not surprising that cases of infection by this\nvirus are occurring. It would be of interest to know the vaccine\ncoverage of the large populations in these areas. Again, as in reports\nfrom previous years, there are reported this year (2011) cases of JE\nvirus infection, mixed with cases of \"acute encephalitis syndrome\"\n(AES) of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe 28 Jul 2010 edition of The Pioneer\n(http://www.dailypioneer.com/272045/Mystery-virus-besets-east-UP.html)\nquoted the director general (medical & health), Dr RR Bharti as\nsaying, \"When even the local unit of the National Institute of\nVirology (NIV) Pune, based in Gorakhpur, failed to arrive at any\nconclusion [about the etiology of non-JE virus AES cases], Bharti\nrequested the Union Health Ministry to intervene. A team of Union\nHealth Ministry officials and scientists from the Indian Council of\nMedical Research (ICMR) -- along with Bharti and Dr SP Ram -- visited\nGorakhpur on Saturday [24 Jul 2010]. However, they also failed to\ndiagnose the viral strain causing deaths of children in the region.\n\"At times, it shows symptoms of an enterovirus [meningitis?] but not\nuniformly, so we cannot arrive at any concrete conclusion,\" said\nBharti (see ProMED-mail archive no 20100728.2535).\n\nThere was no indication in any of the previous reports of AES cases\nthat samples were sent to any of the WHO world reference centers to\ndetermine the etiology involved in these AES cases. Without a\ndiagnosis, it will not be possible to develop a rational prevention\nstrategy.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\nhttp://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif. India (28): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=616562", "date": "2011-07-07 15:23:39", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA: (UTTAR PRADESH)\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jul 2011\nSource: Indian Express [edited]\nhttp://www.indianexpress.com/news/encephalitis-cases-up-with-onset-of-monsoon/813942/\n\n\nThe number of cases of Japanese encephalitis [JE] in the 7 high-risk\ndistricts of Uttar Pradesh has shot up with the arrival of the\nmonsoon, despite the extensive immunisation undertaken by the\ngovernment to control it. The state has already seen 79 more cases and\n10 more deaths due to encephalitis till 5 Jul [2011], as compared to\nlast year [2010].\n\nAccording to reports received by the Medical and Health Department,\nlast year [2010] the state recorded 371 cases and 67 deaths from acute\nencephalitis syndrome (AES), while this year [2011] the number of\ncases has already reached 450 and deaths 77. Similar is the case with\nJE. Until 5 Jul 2010, the state had seen merely 5 cases and one death\nfrom JE, but this time the number of JE cases is already 20, with 3\ndeaths.\n\nThe worst affected districts are Gorakhpur with 111 cases and 21\ndeaths of AES so far, closely followed by Deoria (109 cases and 15\ndeaths), and Kushinagar (103 cases and 22 deaths). JE cases have also\nbeen reported from these 3 districts along with Basti,\nSiddharthanagar, Sant Kabir Nagar, and Maharajganj.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a JE virus endemic area, and so with the onset of the annual\nmonsoon season, it is not surprising that cases of infection by this\nvirus are occurring. It would be of interest to know the vaccine\ncoverage of the large populations in these areas. Again, as in reports\nfrom previous years, there are reported this year (2011) cases of JE\nvirus infection, mixed with cases of \"acute encephalitis syndrome\"\n(AES) of undetermined etiology.\n\nThe 28 Jul 2010 edition of The Pioneer\n(http://www.dailypioneer.com/272045/Mystery-virus-besets-east-UP.html)\nquoted the director general (medical & health), Dr RR Bharti as\nsaying, \"When even the local unit of the National Institute of\nVirology (NIV) Pune, based in Gorakhpur, failed to arrive at any\nconclusion [about the etiology of non-JE virus AES cases], Bharti\nrequested the Union Health Ministry to intervene. A team of Union\nHealth Ministry officials and scientists from the Indian Council of\nMedical Research (ICMR) -- along with Bharti and Dr SP Ram -- visited\nGorakhpur on Saturday [24 Jul 2010]. However, they also failed to\ndiagnose the viral strain causing deaths of children in the region.\n\"At times, it shows symptoms of an enterovirus [meningitis?] but not\nuniformly, so we cannot arrive at any concrete conclusion,\" said\nBharti (see ProMED-mail archive no 20100728.2535).\n\nThere was no indication in any of the previous reports of AES cases\nthat samples were sent to any of the WHO world reference centers to\ndetermine the etiology involved in these AES cases. Without a\ndiagnosis, it will not be possible to develop a rational prevention\nstrategy.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\nhttp://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India is available at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/02lp. - Mod.TY\n\nThe districts mentioned are in eastern Uttar Pradesh and can be seen\non the map at\nhttp://maps.newkerala.com/Uttar-Pradesh-Travel-Map.jpg. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2010\n---\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (27): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=614156", "date": "2010-09-21 14:00:07", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (20): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 20 Sep 2010\nSource: The Times of India, Press Trust of India (PTI) report [edited]\n<http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/7-more-die-of-encephalitis-toll-319-in-eastern-UP/articleshow/6594532.cms>\n\n\nIn Gorakhpur district, 7 more persons died of encephalitis, taking\nthe toll in the deadly disease in eastern Uttar Pradesh to 319,\nhealth officials today said [20 Sep 2010]. All 7 patients died in\nBaba Raghav Das Medical College Hospital [BRDMCH], additional\ndirector (Health) UK Srivastava said, adding 39 new patients were\nadmitted in the hospital today [20 Sep 2010]. Srivastava said of the\ntotal 319 deaths so far, 299 took place in BRDMCH while the remaining\nwere reported from government hospitals in Gorakhpur, Siddharthnagar,\nKushinagar, Maharajganj, Basti, and Deoria districts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak continues to slowly march along in Uttar Pradesh. This\nreport does not indicate if the new cases are due to Japanese\nencephalitis virus (JEV) or something else. It is not clear if a\nvaccination campaign against JEV has been mounted in the affected\nareas. However, previous reports indicate that JEV infections account\nfor less than half of the cases, the etiology of the majority\nremaining undiagnosed. Without a reliable diagnosis, effective\npreventive measures cannot be implemented in the affected areas.\n\nA map showing the location of Uttar Pradesh state can be accessed at\n<http://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif>. All 7 patients died in\nBaba Raghav Das Medical College Hospital [BRDMCH], additional\ndirector (Health) UK Srivastava said, adding 39 new patients were\nadmitted in the hospital today [20 Sep 2010]. Srivastava said of the\ntotal 319 deaths so far, 299 took place in BRDMCH while the remaining\nwere reported from government hospitals in Gorakhpur, Siddharthnagar,\nKushinagar, Maharajganj, Basti, and Deoria districts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak continues to slowly march along in Uttar Pradesh. This\nreport does not indicate if the new cases are due to Japanese\nencephalitis virus (JEV) or something else. It is not clear if a\nvaccination campaign against JEV has been mounted in the affected\nareas. However, previous reports indicate that JEV infections account\nfor less than half of the cases, the etiology of the majority\nremaining undiagnosed. Without a reliable diagnosis, effective\npreventive measures cannot be implemented in the affected areas.\n\nA map showing the location of Uttar Pradesh state can be accessed at\n<http://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif>. A\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02lp>. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (19): (UP) 20100918.3379\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (UP, BH) Nepal 20100915.3340\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (17): (UP) 20100909.3247\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (16): (UP, BH) 20100904.3179\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (UP, BH) 20100831.3106\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (14): (UP) 20100829.3082\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (13): (UP) 20100828.3065\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (12): (UP) 20100825.3000\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (UP) 20100811.2755\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS) 20100805.2646\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (UP) 20100728.2535\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (ML) 20100723.2473\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN) conf. 20100716.2380\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (MN) conf. 20100713.2352\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (MN) susp. 20100711.2323\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (MN) susp 20100707.2261\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (MN) susp 20100630.2185\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (AP) 20100422.1309\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (UP) 20100416.1236\n...................................ty/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. All 7 patients died in\nBaba Raghav Das Medical College Hospital [BRDMCH], additional\ndirector (Health) UK Srivastava said, adding 39 new patients were\nadmitted in the hospital today [20 Sep 2010]. Srivastava said of the\ntotal 319 deaths so far, 299 took place in BRDMCH while the remaining\nwere reported from government hospitals in Gorakhpur, Siddharthnagar,\nKushinagar, Maharajganj, Basti, and Deoria districts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak continues to slowly march along in Uttar Pradesh. This\nreport does not indicate if the new cases are due to Japanese\nencephalitis virus (JEV) or something else. It is not clear if a\nvaccination campaign against JEV has been mounted in the affected\nareas. However, previous reports indicate that JEV infections account\nfor less than half of the cases, the etiology of the majority\nremaining undiagnosed. Out of the 32\nfresh cases of the deadly disease that were reported yesterday [23\nAug 2010], there have been 4 deaths. Children in particular have\nbecome targets of this deadly disease with 1179 cases reported alone\namong children this year [2010].\n\n29 districts of eastern UP, some parts of Bihar and neighbouring\nNepal have been hit hard by the virus. Deaths due to encephalitis\nhave been reported from Gorahkpur, Deoria, Mahrajganj, Kushinagar\ndistrict of Eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Nepal, Additional\nDirector Health, U K Srivastava said.\n\nAbout 170 patients are undergoing treatment in various hospitals\nacross the region, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this outbreak indicated that both Japanese\nencephalitis virus and other unnamed viruses (responsible for\nso-called acute encephalitis syndrome) were the etiological agents\nresponsible for the encephalitis cases. This report mentions neither,\nalthough it refers to \"the virus,\" implying that only one is\ninvolved. It would be of interest to know the results of laboratory\ntests to determine the identity of the viruses involved in these cases.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\n<http://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02lp>. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (UP) 20100811.2755\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS) 20100805.2646\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (UP) 20100728.2535\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (ML) 20100723.2473\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN) conf. 20100716.2380\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (MN) conf. 20100713.2352\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (MN) susp. 20100711.2323\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (MN) susp 20100707.2261\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (MN) susp 20100630.2185\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (AP) 20100422.1309\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (UP) 20100416.1236\n.....................................................sb/mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Bihar", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "528744", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (18): (UP, BH) Nepal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=528744", "date": "2010-08-25 18:00:04", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (12): (UTTAR PRADESH)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 24 Aug 2010\nSource: Chennaionline.com [edited]\n<http://news.chennaionline.com/national/Four-die-due-to-encephalitis--toll-reaches-189/8373c577-04c8-45d4-bcdc-b2f6eb76c265.col>\n\n\nWith 4 more encephalitis deaths in the region, the total number of\npeople killed by the disease in Uttar Pradesh's eastern region this\nyear [2010] has gone up to 189, health officials said. Out of the 32\nfresh cases of the deadly disease that were reported yesterday [23\nAug 2010], there have been 4 deaths. Children in particular have\nbecome targets of this deadly disease with 1179 cases reported alone\namong children this year [2010].\n\n29 districts of eastern UP, some parts of Bihar and neighbouring\nNepal have been hit hard by the virus. Deaths due to encephalitis\nhave been reported from Gorahkpur, Deoria, Mahrajganj, Kushinagar\ndistrict of Eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Nepal, Additional\nDirector Health, U K Srivastava said.\n\nAbout 170 patients are undergoing treatment in various hospitals\nacross the region, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this outbreak indicated that both Japanese\nencephalitis virus and other unnamed viruses (responsible for\nso-called acute encephalitis syndrome) were the etiological agents\nresponsible for the encephalitis cases. This report mentions neither,\nalthough it refers to \"the virus,\" implying that only one is\ninvolved. It would be of interest to know the results of laboratory\ntests to determine the identity of the viruses involved in these cases.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\n<http://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02lp>. - Mod.TY]\nSee Also\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (11): (UP) 20100811.2755\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (10): (AS) 20100805.2646\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (09): (UP) 20100728.2535\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (08): (ML) 20100723.2473\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (07): (MN) conf. 20100716.2380\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (MN) conf. 20100713.2352\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (05): (MN) susp. 20100711.2323\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (MN) susp 20100707.2261\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (MN) susp 20100630.2185\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (AP) 20100422.1309\nJapanese encephalitis & other - India: (UP) 20100416.1236\n.....................................................sb/mpp/ty/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Out of the 32\nfresh cases of the deadly disease that were reported yesterday [23\nAug 2010], there have been 4 deaths. Children in particular have\nbecome targets of this deadly disease with 1179 cases reported alone\namong children this year [2010].\n\n29 districts of eastern UP, some parts of Bihar and neighbouring\nNepal have been hit hard by the virus. Deaths due to encephalitis\nhave been reported from Gorahkpur, Deoria, Mahrajganj, Kushinagar\ndistrict of Eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Nepal, Additional\nDirector Health, U K Srivastava said.\n\nAbout 170 patients are undergoing treatment in various hospitals\nacross the region, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this outbreak indicated that both Japanese\nencephalitis virus and other unnamed viruses (responsible for\nso-called acute encephalitis syndrome) were the etiological agents\nresponsible for the encephalitis cases. This report mentions neither,\nalthough it refers to \"the virus,\" implying that only one is\ninvolved. It would be of interest to know the results of laboratory\ntests to determine the identity of the viruses involved in these cases.\n\nA map showing the locations of the Indian states can be accessed at\n<http://www.indianorphanages.net/images/india-political-map.gif>. Out of the 32\nfresh cases of the deadly disease that were reported yesterday [23\nAug 2010], there have been 4 deaths. Children in particular have\nbecome targets of this deadly disease with 1179 cases reported alone\namong children this year [2010].\n\n29 districts of eastern UP, some parts of Bihar and neighbouring\nNepal have been hit hard by the virus. Deaths due to encephalitis\nhave been reported from Gorahkpur, Deoria, Mahrajganj, Kushinagar\ndistrict of Eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Nepal, Additional\nDirector Health, U K Srivastava said.\n\nAbout 170 patients are undergoing treatment in various hospitals\nacross the region, they added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this outbreak indicated that both Japanese\nencephalitis virus and other unnamed viruses (responsible for\nso-called acute encephalitis syndrome) were the etiological agents\nresponsible for the encephalitis cases. As per official surveillance\nreports, more than 100 cases of suspected AES have been found mostly\nin the valley districts of the state.\n\nThe patients with such syndrome have been admitted to RIMS [Regional\nInstitute of Medical Sciences] and some other private hospitals. The\nofficial reports further revealed that 3 deaths were reported from\nBishnupur, Khelakhong, and Mantripukhri. All of the victims were\nchildren below the age of one year.\n\nBlood samples of some infected persons have already been sent to\nadvanced laboratory at Dibugarh (Assam) for the confirmation of\nJapanese encephalitis [JE] and more blood samples would also be sent\nto the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), New Delhi,\nstated the source.\n\nThe official source further maintained that equipments for the\ndiagnosis of Japanese encephalitis have already been installed at the\nJN Hospital, Porompat. However, at this crucial point of time the\nequipments are malfunctioning adding more hurdles to counter the\nsuspected cases of acute encephalitis syndrome.\n\nThe state health services and district vector borne diseases control\nsocieties have taken up necessary steps to counter the outbreak of\nsuspected AES in the state. Fogging of malathion chemical was widely\ndone in those areas where there are cases of such syndrome.\n\nImphal East district vector borne diseases control society has\nalready done fogging at Naorem Leikai, Uchekon Laikon, and\nMantripukhri areas. Both urban and rural areas of the state have been\nwidely fogged as a part of the emergency measures to counter outbreak\nof Japanese encephalitis which is carried by _Culex_ mosquitoes.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, the state vector borne diseases control\nsociety would take up mass vaccination programme for Japanese\nencephalitis for children between 0-14 years of age within few months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of what this report termed as acute encephalitis syndrome\n(AES) continue in the Manipur area. It will be of interest to see if\nthese and earlier cases are confirmed as Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections, or due to infection by some other virus(es). It is\nunfortunate that the equipment is not functioning for local\nlaboratory diagnosis of JE virus infections. ProMED-mail awaits the\nresults of the laboratory tests with interest. Effectively\ncontrolling the _Culex_ JE virus vector mosquitoes over large\ngeographic areas is difficult and expensive. Vaccination of the\npopulation at risk seems to be the better approach to reducing the\nnumber of encephalitis cases, should JE virus prove to be the\netiological agent involved.\n\nAn interactive map showing the region where these cases occurred in\nfar eastern India can be accessed at\n<http://www.maplandia.com/india/manipur/imphal/>.\nA map showing the location of states in India, including Manipur, can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Cs>. - India (10): (AS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=484744", "date": "2010-07-07 15:00:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (04): (MANIPUR) SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2010\nSource: Kangla Online, The Imphal Free Press report [edited]\n<http://www.kanglaonline.com/index.php?template=headline&newsid=53886&typeid=1>\n\n\nAn epidemic alert has been sounded in the state following reports of\n3 fatal cases so far from suspected acute encephalitis syndrome (AES)\nin several parts of the state [Manipur]. As per official surveillance\nreports, more than 100 cases of suspected AES have been found mostly\nin the valley districts of the state.\n\nThe patients with such syndrome have been admitted to RIMS [Regional\nInstitute of Medical Sciences] and some other private hospitals. The\nofficial reports further revealed that 3 deaths were reported from\nBishnupur, Khelakhong, and Mantripukhri. All of the victims were\nchildren below the age of one year.\n\nBlood samples of some infected persons have already been sent to\nadvanced laboratory at Dibugarh (Assam) for the confirmation of\nJapanese encephalitis [JE] and more blood samples would also be sent\nto the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), New Delhi,\nstated the source.\n\nThe official source further maintained that equipments for the\ndiagnosis of Japanese encephalitis have already been installed at the\nJN Hospital, Porompat. However, at this crucial point of time the\nequipments are malfunctioning adding more hurdles to counter the\nsuspected cases of acute encephalitis syndrome.\n\nThe state health services and district vector borne diseases control\nsocieties have taken up necessary steps to counter the outbreak of\nsuspected AES in the state. Fogging of malathion chemical was widely\ndone in those areas where there are cases of such syndrome.\n\nImphal East district vector borne diseases control society has\nalready done fogging at Naorem Leikai, Uchekon Laikon, and\nMantripukhri areas. Both urban and rural areas of the state have been\nwidely fogged as a part of the emergency measures to counter outbreak\nof Japanese encephalitis which is carried by _Culex_ mosquitoes.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, the state vector borne diseases control\nsociety would take up mass vaccination programme for Japanese\nencephalitis for children between 0-14 years of age within few months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of what this report termed as acute encephalitis syndrome\n(AES) continue in the Manipur area. It will be of interest to see if\nthese and earlier cases are confirmed as Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections, or due to infection by some other virus(es). It is\nunfortunate that the equipment is not functioning for local\nlaboratory diagnosis of JE virus infections. ProMED-mail awaits the\nresults of the laboratory tests with interest. Effectively\ncontrolling the _Culex_ JE virus vector mosquitoes over large\ngeographic areas is difficult and expensive. Vaccination of the\npopulation at risk seems to be the better approach to reducing the\nnumber of encephalitis cases, should JE virus prove to be the\netiological agent involved.\n\nAn interactive map showing the region where these cases occurred in\nfar eastern India can be accessed at\n<http://www.maplandia.com/india/manipur/imphal/>.\nA map showing the location of states in India, including Manipur, can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Cs>. - India (09): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=477979", "date": "2010-07-07 15:00:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (04): (MANIPUR) SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2010\nSource: Kangla Online, The Imphal Free Press report [edited]\n<http://www.kanglaonline.com/index.php?template=headline&newsid=53886&typeid=1>\n\n\nAn epidemic alert has been sounded in the state following reports of\n3 fatal cases so far from suspected acute encephalitis syndrome (AES)\nin several parts of the state [Manipur]. As per official surveillance\nreports, more than 100 cases of suspected AES have been found mostly\nin the valley districts of the state.\n\nThe patients with such syndrome have been admitted to RIMS [Regional\nInstitute of Medical Sciences] and some other private hospitals. The\nofficial reports further revealed that 3 deaths were reported from\nBishnupur, Khelakhong, and Mantripukhri. All of the victims were\nchildren below the age of one year.\n\nBlood samples of some infected persons have already been sent to\nadvanced laboratory at Dibugarh (Assam) for the confirmation of\nJapanese encephalitis [JE] and more blood samples would also be sent\nto the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), New Delhi,\nstated the source.\n\nThe official source further maintained that equipments for the\ndiagnosis of Japanese encephalitis have already been installed at the\nJN Hospital, Porompat. However, at this crucial point of time the\nequipments are malfunctioning adding more hurdles to counter the\nsuspected cases of acute encephalitis syndrome.\n\nThe state health services and district vector borne diseases control\nsocieties have taken up necessary steps to counter the outbreak of\nsuspected AES in the state. Fogging of malathion chemical was widely\ndone in those areas where there are cases of such syndrome.\n\nImphal East district vector borne diseases control society has\nalready done fogging at Naorem Leikai, Uchekon Laikon, and\nMantripukhri areas. Both urban and rural areas of the state have been\nwidely fogged as a part of the emergency measures to counter outbreak\nof Japanese encephalitis which is carried by _Culex_ mosquitoes.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, the state vector borne diseases control\nsociety would take up mass vaccination programme for Japanese\nencephalitis for children between 0-14 years of age within few months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of what this report termed as acute encephalitis syndrome\n(AES) continue in the Manipur area. It will be of interest to see if\nthese and earlier cases are confirmed as Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections, or due to infection by some other virus(es). It is\nunfortunate that the equipment is not functioning for local\nlaboratory diagnosis of JE virus infections. ProMED-mail awaits the\nresults of the laboratory tests with interest. Effectively\ncontrolling the _Culex_ JE virus vector mosquitoes over large\ngeographic areas is difficult and expensive. Vaccination of the\npopulation at risk seems to be the better approach to reducing the\nnumber of encephalitis cases, should JE virus prove to be the\netiological agent involved.\n\nAn interactive map showing the region where these cases occurred in\nfar eastern India can be accessed at\n<http://www.maplandia.com/india/manipur/imphal/>.\nA map showing the location of states in India, including Manipur, can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Cs>. - You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UP", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "New Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Khelakhong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bishnupur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Porompat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Encephalitis", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "474092", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (08):  (ML)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=474092", "date": "2010-07-07 15:00:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (04): (MANIPUR) SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2010\nSource: Kangla Online, The Imphal Free Press report [edited]\n<http://www.kanglaonline.com/index.php?template=headline&newsid=53886&typeid=1>\n\n\nAn epidemic alert has been sounded in the state following reports of\n3 fatal cases so far from suspected acute encephalitis syndrome (AES)\nin several parts of the state [Manipur]. As per official surveillance\nreports, more than 100 cases of suspected AES have been found mostly\nin the valley districts of the state.\n\nThe patients with such syndrome have been admitted to RIMS [Regional\nInstitute of Medical Sciences] and some other private hospitals. The\nofficial reports further revealed that 3 deaths were reported from\nBishnupur, Khelakhong, and Mantripukhri. All of the victims were\nchildren below the age of one year.\n\nBlood samples of some infected persons have already been sent to\nadvanced laboratory at Dibugarh (Assam) for the confirmation of\nJapanese encephalitis [JE] and more blood samples would also be sent\nto the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), New Delhi,\nstated the source.\n\nThe official source further maintained that equipments for the\ndiagnosis of Japanese encephalitis have already been installed at the\nJN Hospital, Porompat. However, at this crucial point of time the\nequipments are malfunctioning adding more hurdles to counter the\nsuspected cases of acute encephalitis syndrome.\n\nThe state health services and district vector borne diseases control\nsocieties have taken up necessary steps to counter the outbreak of\nsuspected AES in the state. Fogging of malathion chemical was widely\ndone in those areas where there are cases of such syndrome.\n\nImphal East district vector borne diseases control society has\nalready done fogging at Naorem Leikai, Uchekon Laikon, and\nMantripukhri areas. Both urban and rural areas of the state have been\nwidely fogged as a part of the emergency measures to counter outbreak\nof Japanese encephalitis which is carried by _Culex_ mosquitoes.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, the state vector borne diseases control\nsociety would take up mass vaccination programme for Japanese\nencephalitis for children between 0-14 years of age within few months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of what this report termed as acute encephalitis syndrome\n(AES) continue in the Manipur area. It will be of interest to see if\nthese and earlier cases are confirmed as Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections, or due to infection by some other virus(es). It is\nunfortunate that the equipment is not functioning for local\nlaboratory diagnosis of JE virus infections. ProMED-mail awaits the\nresults of the laboratory tests with interest. Effectively\ncontrolling the _Culex_ JE virus vector mosquitoes over large\ngeographic areas is difficult and expensive. Vaccination of the\npopulation at risk seems to be the better approach to reducing the\nnumber of encephalitis cases, should JE virus prove to be the\netiological agent involved.\n\nAn interactive map showing the region where these cases occurred in\nfar eastern India can be accessed at\n<http://www.maplandia.com/india/manipur/imphal/>.\nA map showing the location of states in India, including Manipur, can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Cs>. -
