India (07): (MN) conf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=468248", "date": "2010-07-07 15:00:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (04): (MANIPUR) SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2010\nSource: Kangla Online, The Imphal Free Press report [edited]\n<http://www.kanglaonline.com/index.php?template=headline&newsid=53886&typeid=1>\n\n\nAn epidemic alert has been sounded in the state following reports of\n3 fatal cases so far from suspected acute encephalitis syndrome (AES)\nin several parts of the state [Manipur]. As per official surveillance\nreports, more than 100 cases of suspected AES have been found mostly\nin the valley districts of the state.\n\nThe patients with such syndrome have been admitted to RIMS [Regional\nInstitute of Medical Sciences] and some other private hospitals. The\nofficial reports further revealed that 3 deaths were reported from\nBishnupur, Khelakhong, and Mantripukhri. All of the victims were\nchildren below the age of one year.\n\nBlood samples of some infected persons have already been sent to\nadvanced laboratory at Dibugarh (Assam) for the confirmation of\nJapanese encephalitis [JE] and more blood samples would also be sent\nto the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), New Delhi,\nstated the source.\n\nThe official source further maintained that equipments for the\ndiagnosis of Japanese encephalitis have already been installed at the\nJN Hospital, Porompat. However, at this crucial point of time the\nequipments are malfunctioning adding more hurdles to counter the\nsuspected cases of acute encephalitis syndrome.\n\nThe state health services and district vector borne diseases control\nsocieties have taken up necessary steps to counter the outbreak of\nsuspected AES in the state. Fogging of malathion chemical was widely\ndone in those areas where there are cases of such syndrome.\n\nImphal East district vector borne diseases control society has\nalready done fogging at Naorem Leikai, Uchekon Laikon, and\nMantripukhri areas. Both urban and rural areas of the state have been\nwidely fogged as a part of the emergency measures to counter outbreak\nof Japanese encephalitis which is carried by _Culex_ mosquitoes.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, the state vector borne diseases control\nsociety would take up mass vaccination programme for Japanese\nencephalitis for children between 0-14 years of age within few months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of what this report termed as acute encephalitis syndrome\n(AES) continue in the Manipur area. It will be of interest to see if\nthese and earlier cases are confirmed as Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections, or due to infection by some other virus(es). It is\nunfortunate that the equipment is not functioning for local\nlaboratory diagnosis of JE virus infections. ProMED-mail awaits the\nresults of the laboratory tests with interest. Effectively\ncontrolling the _Culex_ JE virus vector mosquitoes over large\ngeographic areas is difficult and expensive. Vaccination of the\npopulation at risk seems to be the better approach to reducing the\nnumber of encephalitis cases, should JE virus prove to be the\netiological agent involved.\n\nAn interactive map showing the region where these cases occurred in\nfar eastern India can be accessed at\n<http://www.maplandia.com/india/manipur/imphal/>.\nA map showing the location of states in India, including Manipur, can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Cs>. - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Porompat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Encephalitis", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "465534", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (06): (MN) conf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=465534", "date": "2010-07-07 15:00:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (04): (MANIPUR) SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2010\nSource: Kangla Online, The Imphal Free Press report [edited]\n<http://www.kanglaonline.com/index.php?template=headline&newsid=53886&typeid=1>\n\n\nAn epidemic alert has been sounded in the state following reports of\n3 fatal cases so far from suspected acute encephalitis syndrome (AES)\nin several parts of the state [Manipur]. As per official surveillance\nreports, more than 100 cases of suspected AES have been found mostly\nin the valley districts of the state.\n\nThe patients with such syndrome have been admitted to RIMS [Regional\nInstitute of Medical Sciences] and some other private hospitals. The\nofficial reports further revealed that 3 deaths were reported from\nBishnupur, Khelakhong, and Mantripukhri. All of the victims were\nchildren below the age of one year.\n\nBlood samples of some infected persons have already been sent to\nadvanced laboratory at Dibugarh (Assam) for the confirmation of\nJapanese encephalitis [JE] and more blood samples would also be sent\nto the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), New Delhi,\nstated the source.\n\nThe official source further maintained that equipments for the\ndiagnosis of Japanese encephalitis have already been installed at the\nJN Hospital, Porompat. However, at this crucial point of time the\nequipments are malfunctioning adding more hurdles to counter the\nsuspected cases of acute encephalitis syndrome.\n\nThe state health services and district vector borne diseases control\nsocieties have taken up necessary steps to counter the outbreak of\nsuspected AES in the state. Fogging of malathion chemical was widely\ndone in those areas where there are cases of such syndrome.\n\nImphal East district vector borne diseases control society has\nalready done fogging at Naorem Leikai, Uchekon Laikon, and\nMantripukhri areas. Both urban and rural areas of the state have been\nwidely fogged as a part of the emergency measures to counter outbreak\nof Japanese encephalitis which is carried by _Culex_ mosquitoes.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, the state vector borne diseases control\nsociety would take up mass vaccination programme for Japanese\nencephalitis for children between 0-14 years of age within few months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of what this report termed as acute encephalitis syndrome\n(AES) continue in the Manipur area. It will be of interest to see if\nthese and earlier cases are confirmed as Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections, or due to infection by some other virus(es). It is\nunfortunate that the equipment is not functioning for local\nlaboratory diagnosis of JE virus infections. ProMED-mail awaits the\nresults of the laboratory tests with interest. Effectively\ncontrolling the _Culex_ JE virus vector mosquitoes over large\ngeographic areas is difficult and expensive. Vaccination of the\npopulation at risk seems to be the better approach to reducing the\nnumber of encephalitis cases, should JE virus prove to be the\netiological agent involved.\n\nAn interactive map showing the region where these cases occurred in\nfar eastern India can be accessed at\n<http://www.maplandia.com/india/manipur/imphal/>.\nA map showing the location of states in India, including Manipur, can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Cs>. - India (05): (MN) susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=463961", "date": "2010-07-07 15:00:06", "main_text": "JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS AND OTHER - INDIA (04): (MANIPUR) SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2010\nSource: Kangla Online, The Imphal Free Press report [edited]\n<http://www.kanglaonline.com/index.php?template=headline&newsid=53886&typeid=1>\n\n\nAn epidemic alert has been sounded in the state following reports of\n3 fatal cases so far from suspected acute encephalitis syndrome (AES)\nin several parts of the state [Manipur]. As per official surveillance\nreports, more than 100 cases of suspected AES have been found mostly\nin the valley districts of the state.\n\nThe patients with such syndrome have been admitted to RIMS [Regional\nInstitute of Medical Sciences] and some other private hospitals. The\nofficial reports further revealed that 3 deaths were reported from\nBishnupur, Khelakhong, and Mantripukhri. All of the victims were\nchildren below the age of one year.\n\nBlood samples of some infected persons have already been sent to\nadvanced laboratory at Dibugarh (Assam) for the confirmation of\nJapanese encephalitis [JE] and more blood samples would also be sent\nto the National Institute of Communicable Diseases (NICD), New Delhi,\nstated the source.\n\nThe official source further maintained that equipments for the\ndiagnosis of Japanese encephalitis have already been installed at the\nJN Hospital, Porompat. However, at this crucial point of time the\nequipments are malfunctioning adding more hurdles to counter the\nsuspected cases of acute encephalitis syndrome.\n\nThe state health services and district vector borne diseases control\nsocieties have taken up necessary steps to counter the outbreak of\nsuspected AES in the state. Fogging of malathion chemical was widely\ndone in those areas where there are cases of such syndrome.\n\nImphal East district vector borne diseases control society has\nalready done fogging at Naorem Leikai, Uchekon Laikon, and\nMantripukhri areas. Both urban and rural areas of the state have been\nwidely fogged as a part of the emergency measures to counter outbreak\nof Japanese encephalitis which is carried by _Culex_ mosquitoes.\n\nAs a precautionary measure, the state vector borne diseases control\nsociety would take up mass vaccination programme for Japanese\nencephalitis for children between 0-14 years of age within few months.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of what this report termed as acute encephalitis syndrome\n(AES) continue in the Manipur area. It will be of interest to see if\nthese and earlier cases are confirmed as Japanese encephalitis virus\ninfections, or due to infection by some other virus(es). It is\nunfortunate that the equipment is not functioning for local\nlaboratory diagnosis of JE virus infections. ProMED-mail awaits the\nresults of the laboratory tests with interest. Effectively\ncontrolling the _Culex_ JE virus vector mosquitoes over large\ngeographic areas is difficult and expensive. Vaccination of the\npopulation at risk seems to be the better approach to reducing the\nnumber of encephalitis cases, should JE virus prove to be the\netiological agent involved.\n\nAn interactive map showing the region where these cases occurred in\nfar eastern India can be accessed at\n<http://www.maplandia.com/india/manipur/imphal/>.\nA map showing the location of states in India, including Manipur, can\nbe accessed at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/middle_east_and_asia/india_pol01.jpg>.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of India can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01Cs>. - Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UP", "country": "South Korea"}, {"location": "New Delhi", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Khelakhong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bishnupur", "country": "India"}, {"location": "other - INDIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Porompat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Encephalitis", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "456384", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (03): (MN) susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=456384", "date": "2009-06-18 22:00:05", "main_text": "INFLUENZA A (H1N1) - WORLDWIDE (69): OTHER VIRAL INFECTIONS\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Jun 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 14, Issue 24, 18 Jun 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19242>\n\n\nA variety of respiratory viruses found in\nsymptomatic travellers returning from countries\nwith ongoing spread of the new influenza A(H1N1)v\nvirus strain\n\nBy: P Follin1, A Lindqvist1, K Nystrom1, M Lindh2\n\nAt: 1. Department of Communicable Disease\nPrevention and Control, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, 2. Department of Virology, Sahlgrenska\nUniversity Hospital, Gothenburg, Sweden\n\nClinical specimens from 79 symptomatic\nindividuals with a recent history of travel to\ncountries with verified transmission of influenza\nA(H1N1) virus (North America) were tested with a\nmultiple real-time PCR targeting a broad range of\nagents that may cause acute respiratory\ninfection. This analysis revealed that besides 4\ncases of influenza A(H1N1) virus, other\nrespiratory viruses were diagnosed in almost 60\npercent of the samples. These observations are a\nreminder that many different viral transmissions\noccur simultaneously in countries with ongoing\nspread of influenza A(H1N1) virus. The findings\ndemonstrate that the definition of suspected\ncases by clinical and epidemiological criteria\nhas only a poor capacity for discriminating\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v from other viral infections.\n\nBackground\n\nA new influenza A(H1N1) virus variant has spread\nglobally since its 1st appearance in April 2009\n[1,2] and as of 17 Jun 2009, there were 39 620\ncases reported by the World Health Organization\n(WHO) [3]. On 30 Apr 2009, the European\nCommission suggested a case definition [4], which\nhas been adopted and modified by most authorities\nin the European Union Member States. In agreement\nwith this recommendation, testing for influenza A\nwas recommended in Sweden for cases with a\nclinical presentation including respiratory\nsymptoms and fever above 38 C and epidemiological\ncircumstances such as recent travel (within 7\ndays) to areas where the new influenza has been\nobserved [5] or close contact with confirmed\ncases.\n\nThe regular sentinel surveillance for seasonal\ninfluenza has been extended and now focuses on\nidentification of imported cases with influenza\nA(H1N1) virus, and on preventing secondary\ntransmission by contact tracing and antiviral\nmedication in an attempt to delay sustained\ncommunity transmission. In order to provide a\nbetter basis for the decision whether or not to\ninitiate preventive measures, expanded testing,\ntargeting a broad range of respiratory agents has\nbeen applied to specimens from all suspected\ncases in the region Vastra Gotaland (1.5 million\ninhabitants). We report here the results of this\nexpanded testing.\n\nMaterial and methods\n\nThis report includes samples of patients who,\nduring the period from 24 Apr to 10 Jun 2009\npresented with influenza-like symptoms and a\nhistory of recent travel to the United States or\nMexico, and therefore were recommended for\nexamination and sampling. This clinical\nexamination was performed by infectious disease\nclinicians on call at Sahlgrenska University\nHostpital/\u00d6stra in Gothenburg, and our report is\nbased on their evaluation and laboratory results.\nIn summary, of all 79 patients included with a\ntravel history, 90 percent presented with\nrespiratory symptoms, 5 percent without\nrespiratory symptoms, and for the remaining 5\npercent this information is not documented. 66\npercent had fever above 38 C, 29 percent had no\nfever; information on fever was missing for 5\npercent. Nasopharyngeal swabs were sent to the\nmolecular diagnostic unit at the virological\nlaboratory at Sahlgrenska University Hospital for\ntesting by a multiple real-time PCR targeting 13\nviruses and 2 bacteria, !\nrun in 6 parallel multiplex PCRs on an ABI 7500\ninstrument [6]. Samples that were reactive for\nthe influenza A component (matrix protein target,\n[7]) of this PCR were subtyped by an additional\nreal-time PCR targeting the haemagglutinin gene,\nrun in 3 parallel reactions specific for the H3N2\nand H1N1 subtypes that have been circulating for\na long time, as well as for the new H1N1v strain.\n[Readers requiring information on the primers and\nprobes used in the real-time PCR are referred to\na Table in the original text].\n\nResults and discussion\n\nIn total, samples from 79 patients were tested\n(42 males, 37 females; median age 30 years, range\n1-75 years), with between 10 and 16 samples on\naverage each week and most of them taken from\npatients with respiratory symptoms and a history\nof recent travel to North America. Four cases\nwith the new influenza A (H1N1)v variant were\ndiagnosed. Interestingly, in 56 percent of the\ncases, other aetiologies were identified (Table).\n\nTable. Viral aetiologies for the patients\nfulfilling definition of suspected cases of\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, Apr-Jun 2009 (n=79)\n\nViral aetiology / Number / Percentage\n\nRhinovirus / 28 / 34\nCoronavirus / 8 / 10\nInfluenza B virus / 3 / 4\nHuman parainfluenza virus types 1-3 / 3 / 3 / 4\nAdenovirus / 2 / 2\nInfluenza A (H1N1) virus / 4 / 5\nMetapneumovirus / 1 / 1\nEnterovirus / 1 / 1\nRespiratory syncytial virus / 0 / 0\nMycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae / 0 / 0\nNegative / 32 / 39\nTotal number / 82 / 100\n\n(Note: 3 patients had double infections with\nrhinovirus, together with enterovirus,\nmetapneumovirus or adenovirus.)\n\nThe most common finding was rhinovirus, observed\nin 28 of 82 cases (34 percent), and 3 of these\npatients also had a 2nd viral infection\n(enterovirus, metapneumovirus and adenovirus).\nThe frequent identification of rhinovirus and\nother viruses demonstrates that the criteria for\nsuspected cases of influenza A(H1N1)v are\nrelevant as indicators of a viral infection, but\nnot specific for influenza A. On the other hand,\napplying more restrictive criteria would probably\nhave excluded most infections with the new\nA(H1N1) virus strain, considering that their\nclinical presentation has been reported to be\nrelatively mild. This illustrates a dilemma with\nsurveillance actions aiming at revealing the\nspread of new respiratory infections. If the\napplied criteria are too strict (for example\nfever above 39 C, cough and muscle pain), the\nepidemic is likely to be underestimated, because\nonly the severe cases are identified. If on the\nother hand the criteria are liberal, as\nillustrated by the cur!\nrent epidemic, most of the cases will probably\nhave other aetiologies. The positive predictive\nvalue of clinical criteria for identification of\ninfluenza A is particularly low in the early\nphase of an epidemic, when the incidence of\ninfluenza A is low, but will become relatively\nhigh during the peak when a large proportion of\nrespiratory infections will be due to influenza A\nvirus. The value of broad virology testing\ndecreases in the course of an influenza epidemic,\nwhen the detection rate of other aetiologies may\ndecrease from above 50 percent as observed in\nthis report to below 10 percent during the\ninfluenza peak (unpublished observations from our\nlaboratory).\n\nThe cases with influenza A were analysed further\nby a typing PCR that within 4-5 hours could\nidentify whether the strain was a traditional\nH1N1 or H3N2 virus, or the new H1N1 variant. This\ntyping system targets specific regions of the\nhaemagglutinin gene and has been developed in our\nlaboratory (unpublished). It has proved to have a\ngood sensitivity, as illustrated by cycle\nthreshold (Ct) values that are typically lower\nthan those obtained in the general PCR for\ninfluenza A, which targets a conserved region of\nthe matrix protein gene.\n\nThe results of the multiple PCR used in our\nsetting were available within 24 hours after\nsampling and served at the same time as\nconfirmation for the result of the 1st, general\ninfluenza A PCR. In cases that presented with\ntypical influenza-like symptoms but were negative\nfor influenza A in the 1st PCR, the finding of an\nalternative aetiology was helpful for the\ndecision to refrain from preventive measures.\nSuch measures include oseltamivir treatment of\npatients and influenza testing and prophylactic\ntreatment of their close contacts. The clinical\npractice was not always different, but in some\ncases, the identification of an alternative\naetiology such as rhinovirus was helpful for the\ndecision not to treat the patient of contacts,\neven when the patient had symptoms clearly\nindicative of possible influenza. From this\nexperience, we therefore conclude that a broad\ndiagnostic test is a valuable tool in the early\ninvestigation of a new emerging respiratory virus\nlike the new influ!\nenza A(H1N1)v.\n\n[Note added in proof: On 17 Jun 2009, Sweden\nchanged to a stricter case definition for\nsuspected cases. It now requires more than 2\nsymptoms besides epidemiology and fever.]\n\nReferences\n\n1. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC). Swine influenza A (H1N1) infection in 2\nchildren--Southern California, Mar-Apr 2009. MMWR\nMorb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2009;58(15):400-2.\n2. Novel Swine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus\nInvestigation Team. Emergence of a Novel\nSwine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus in Humans.\nN Engl J Med. 2009 Jun 3. [Epub ahead of print].\n3. World Health Organization (WHO). Influenza\nA(H1N1) - update 50. Jun 17, 2009. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_06_17/en/index.html>.\n4. Commission Decision of 30 Apr 2009 amending\nDecision 2002/253/ EC laying down case\ndefinitions for reporting communicable diseases\nto the Community network under Decision n\n21/19/98/EC. 2009/363/EC. Official Journal L\n110/58. 01.05.2009. Available from:\n<http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:110:0058:0059:EN:PDF>.\n5. World Health Organization (WHO). owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-06-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-04-15 00:00:00", "2009-06-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-06-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2068-03-15 00:00:00", "1918-03-15 00:00:00", "2066-03-15 00:00:00", "2065-03-15 00:00:00", "2064-03-15 00:00:00", "2063-03-15 00:00:00", "2062-03-15 00:00:00", "2059-03-15 00:00:00", "2057-03-15 00:00:00", "2056-03-15 00:00:00", "2054-03-15 00:00:00", "2053-03-15 00:00:00", "2052-03-15 00:00:00", "2051-03-15 00:00:00", "2050-03-15 00:00:00", "2049-03-15 00:00:00", "2048-03-15 00:00:00", "2047-03-15 00:00:00", "2046-03-15 00:00:00", "2044-03-15 00:00:00", "2043-03-15 00:00:00", "2040-03-15 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-11-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Lindqvist1", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "Lebanon"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Gothenburg", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Sahlgrenska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "414001", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (02): (AP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=414001", "date": "2009-06-18 22:00:05", "main_text": "INFLUENZA A (H1N1) - WORLDWIDE (69): OTHER VIRAL INFECTIONS\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Jun 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 14, Issue 24, 18 Jun 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19242>\n\n\nA variety of respiratory viruses found in\nsymptomatic travellers returning from countries\nwith ongoing spread of the new influenza A(H1N1)v\nvirus strain\n\nBy: P Follin1, A Lindqvist1, K Nystrom1, M Lindh2\n\nAt: 1. Department of Communicable Disease\nPrevention and Control, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, 2. Department of Virology, Sahlgrenska\nUniversity Hospital, Gothenburg, Sweden\n\nClinical specimens from 79 symptomatic\nindividuals with a recent history of travel to\ncountries with verified transmission of influenza\nA(H1N1) virus (North America) were tested with a\nmultiple real-time PCR targeting a broad range of\nagents that may cause acute respiratory\ninfection. This analysis revealed that besides 4\ncases of influenza A(H1N1) virus, other\nrespiratory viruses were diagnosed in almost 60\npercent of the samples. These observations are a\nreminder that many different viral transmissions\noccur simultaneously in countries with ongoing\nspread of influenza A(H1N1) virus. The findings\ndemonstrate that the definition of suspected\ncases by clinical and epidemiological criteria\nhas only a poor capacity for discriminating\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v from other viral infections.\n\nBackground\n\nA new influenza A(H1N1) virus variant has spread\nglobally since its 1st appearance in April 2009\n[1,2] and as of 17 Jun 2009, there were 39 620\ncases reported by the World Health Organization\n(WHO) [3]. On 30 Apr 2009, the European\nCommission suggested a case definition [4], which\nhas been adopted and modified by most authorities\nin the European Union Member States. In agreement\nwith this recommendation, testing for influenza A\nwas recommended in Sweden for cases with a\nclinical presentation including respiratory\nsymptoms and fever above 38 C and epidemiological\ncircumstances such as recent travel (within 7\ndays) to areas where the new influenza has been\nobserved [5] or close contact with confirmed\ncases.\n\nThe regular sentinel surveillance for seasonal\ninfluenza has been extended and now focuses on\nidentification of imported cases with influenza\nA(H1N1) virus, and on preventing secondary\ntransmission by contact tracing and antiviral\nmedication in an attempt to delay sustained\ncommunity transmission. In order to provide a\nbetter basis for the decision whether or not to\ninitiate preventive measures, expanded testing,\ntargeting a broad range of respiratory agents has\nbeen applied to specimens from all suspected\ncases in the region Vastra Gotaland (1.5 million\ninhabitants). We report here the results of this\nexpanded testing.\n\nMaterial and methods\n\nThis report includes samples of patients who,\nduring the period from 24 Apr to 10 Jun 2009\npresented with influenza-like symptoms and a\nhistory of recent travel to the United States or\nMexico, and therefore were recommended for\nexamination and sampling. This clinical\nexamination was performed by infectious disease\nclinicians on call at Sahlgrenska University\nHostpital/\u00d6stra in Gothenburg, and our report is\nbased on their evaluation and laboratory results.\nIn summary, of all 79 patients included with a\ntravel history, 90 percent presented with\nrespiratory symptoms, 5 percent without\nrespiratory symptoms, and for the remaining 5\npercent this information is not documented. 66\npercent had fever above 38 C, 29 percent had no\nfever; information on fever was missing for 5\npercent. Nasopharyngeal swabs were sent to the\nmolecular diagnostic unit at the virological\nlaboratory at Sahlgrenska University Hospital for\ntesting by a multiple real-time PCR targeting 13\nviruses and 2 bacteria, !\nrun in 6 parallel multiplex PCRs on an ABI 7500\ninstrument [6]. Samples that were reactive for\nthe influenza A component (matrix protein target,\n[7]) of this PCR were subtyped by an additional\nreal-time PCR targeting the haemagglutinin gene,\nrun in 3 parallel reactions specific for the H3N2\nand H1N1 subtypes that have been circulating for\na long time, as well as for the new H1N1v strain.\n[Readers requiring information on the primers and\nprobes used in the real-time PCR are referred to\na Table in the original text].\n\nResults and discussion\n\nIn total, samples from 79 patients were tested\n(42 males, 37 females; median age 30 years, range\n1-75 years), with between 10 and 16 samples on\naverage each week and most of them taken from\npatients with respiratory symptoms and a history\nof recent travel to North America. Four cases\nwith the new influenza A (H1N1)v variant were\ndiagnosed. Interestingly, in 56 percent of the\ncases, other aetiologies were identified (Table).\n\nTable. Viral aetiologies for the patients\nfulfilling definition of suspected cases of\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, Apr-Jun 2009 (n=79)\n\nViral aetiology / Number / Percentage\n\nRhinovirus / 28 / 34\nCoronavirus / 8 / 10\nInfluenza B virus / 3 / 4\nHuman parainfluenza virus types 1-3 / 3 / 3 / 4\nAdenovirus / 2 / 2\nInfluenza A (H1N1) virus / 4 / 5\nMetapneumovirus / 1 / 1\nEnterovirus / 1 / 1\nRespiratory syncytial virus / 0 / 0\nMycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae / 0 / 0\nNegative / 32 / 39\nTotal number / 82 / 100\n\n(Note: 3 patients had double infections with\nrhinovirus, together with enterovirus,\nmetapneumovirus or adenovirus.)\n\nThe most common finding was rhinovirus, observed\nin 28 of 82 cases (34 percent), and 3 of these\npatients also had a 2nd viral infection\n(enterovirus, metapneumovirus and adenovirus).\nThe frequent identification of rhinovirus and\nother viruses demonstrates that the criteria for\nsuspected cases of influenza A(H1N1)v are\nrelevant as indicators of a viral infection, but\nnot specific for influenza A. On the other hand,\napplying more restrictive criteria would probably\nhave excluded most infections with the new\nA(H1N1) virus strain, considering that their\nclinical presentation has been reported to be\nrelatively mild. This illustrates a dilemma with\nsurveillance actions aiming at revealing the\nspread of new respiratory infections. If the\napplied criteria are too strict (for example\nfever above 39 C, cough and muscle pain), the\nepidemic is likely to be underestimated, because\nonly the severe cases are identified. If on the\nother hand the criteria are liberal, as\nillustrated by the cur!\nrent epidemic, most of the cases will probably\nhave other aetiologies. The positive predictive\nvalue of clinical criteria for identification of\ninfluenza A is particularly low in the early\nphase of an epidemic, when the incidence of\ninfluenza A is low, but will become relatively\nhigh during the peak when a large proportion of\nrespiratory infections will be due to influenza A\nvirus. The value of broad virology testing\ndecreases in the course of an influenza epidemic,\nwhen the detection rate of other aetiologies may\ndecrease from above 50 percent as observed in\nthis report to below 10 percent during the\ninfluenza peak (unpublished observations from our\nlaboratory).\n\nThe cases with influenza A were analysed further\nby a typing PCR that within 4-5 hours could\nidentify whether the strain was a traditional\nH1N1 or H3N2 virus, or the new H1N1 variant. This\ntyping system targets specific regions of the\nhaemagglutinin gene and has been developed in our\nlaboratory (unpublished). It has proved to have a\ngood sensitivity, as illustrated by cycle\nthreshold (Ct) values that are typically lower\nthan those obtained in the general PCR for\ninfluenza A, which targets a conserved region of\nthe matrix protein gene.\n\nThe results of the multiple PCR used in our\nsetting were available within 24 hours after\nsampling and served at the same time as\nconfirmation for the result of the 1st, general\ninfluenza A PCR. In cases that presented with\ntypical influenza-like symptoms but were negative\nfor influenza A in the 1st PCR, the finding of an\nalternative aetiology was helpful for the\ndecision to refrain from preventive measures.\nSuch measures include oseltamivir treatment of\npatients and influenza testing and prophylactic\ntreatment of their close contacts. The clinical\npractice was not always different, but in some\ncases, the identification of an alternative\naetiology such as rhinovirus was helpful for the\ndecision not to treat the patient of contacts,\neven when the patient had symptoms clearly\nindicative of possible influenza. From this\nexperience, we therefore conclude that a broad\ndiagnostic test is a valuable tool in the early\ninvestigation of a new emerging respiratory virus\nlike the new influ!\nenza A(H1N1)v.\n\n[Note added in proof: On 17 Jun 2009, Sweden\nchanged to a stricter case definition for\nsuspected cases. It now requires more than 2\nsymptoms besides epidemiology and fever.]\n\nReferences\n\n1. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC). Swine influenza A (H1N1) infection in 2\nchildren--Southern California, Mar-Apr 2009. MMWR\nMorb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2009;58(15):400-2.\n2. Novel Swine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus\nInvestigation Team. Emergence of a Novel\nSwine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus in Humans.\nN Engl J Med. 2009 Jun 3. [Epub ahead of print].\n3. World Health Organization (WHO). Influenza\nA(H1N1) - update 50. Jun 17, 2009. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_06_17/en/index.html>.\n4. Commission Decision of 30 Apr 2009 amending\nDecision 2002/253/ EC laying down case\ndefinitions for reporting communicable diseases\nto the Community network under Decision n\n21/19/98/EC. 2009/363/EC. Official Journal L\n110/58. 01.05.2009. Available from:\n<http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:110:0058:0059:EN:PDF>.\n5. World Health Organization (WHO). Influenza\nA(H1N1) - update 2. Apr 26, 2009. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_06_17/en/index.html>\n6. Brittain-Long R, Nord S, Olofsson S, Westin\nJ, Anderson LM, Lindh M. Multiplex real-time PCR\nfor detection of respiratory tract infections. J\nClin Virol. 2008;41(1):53-.\n7. Ward CL, Dempsey MH, Ring CJ, Kempson RE,\nZhang L, Gor D, et al. Design and performance\ntesting of quantitative real time PCR assays for\ninfluenza A and B viral load measurement. J Clin\nVirol. 2004;29(3): 179-88.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These data among other things reveal that the\npositive predictive value of clinical criteria\nfor identification of influenza A is low in the\nearly phase of an epidemic, when the incidence of\ninfluenza A is low, but will become relatively\nhigher during the peak, when a large proportion\nof respiratory infections will be due to\ninfluenza A virus. Among the viruses detected,\nrhinoviruses and coronaviruses predominated in\nthis survey. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nInfluenza A (H1N1) - worldwide (68): southern hemisphere (to be archived)\nInfluenza A (H1N1) - owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-06-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-04-15 00:00:00", "2009-06-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-06-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2068-03-15 00:00:00", "1918-03-15 00:00:00", "2066-03-15 00:00:00", "2065-03-15 00:00:00", "2064-03-15 00:00:00", "2063-03-15 00:00:00", "2062-03-15 00:00:00", "2059-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "411109", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India: (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=411109", "date": "2009-06-18 22:00:05", "main_text": "INFLUENZA A (H1N1) - WORLDWIDE (69): OTHER VIRAL INFECTIONS\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Jun 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 14, Issue 24, 18 Jun 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19242>\n\n\nA variety of respiratory viruses found in\nsymptomatic travellers returning from countries\nwith ongoing spread of the new influenza A(H1N1)v\nvirus strain\n\nBy: P Follin1, A Lindqvist1, K Nystrom1, M Lindh2\n\nAt: 1. Department of Communicable Disease\nPrevention and Control, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, 2. Department of Virology, Sahlgrenska\nUniversity Hospital, Gothenburg, Sweden\n\nClinical specimens from 79 symptomatic\nindividuals with a recent history of travel to\ncountries with verified transmission of influenza\nA(H1N1) virus (North America) were tested with a\nmultiple real-time PCR targeting a broad range of\nagents that may cause acute respiratory\ninfection. This analysis revealed that besides 4\ncases of influenza A(H1N1) virus, other\nrespiratory viruses were diagnosed in almost 60\npercent of the samples. These observations are a\nreminder that many different viral transmissions\noccur simultaneously in countries with ongoing\nspread of influenza A(H1N1) virus. The findings\ndemonstrate that the definition of suspected\ncases by clinical and epidemiological criteria\nhas only a poor capacity for discriminating\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v from other viral infections.\n\nBackground\n\nA new influenza A(H1N1) virus variant has spread\nglobally since its 1st appearance in April 2009\n[1,2] and as of 17 Jun 2009, there were 39 620\ncases reported by the World Health Organization\n(WHO) [3]. On 30 Apr 2009, the European\nCommission suggested a case definition [4], which\nhas been adopted and modified by most authorities\nin the European Union Member States. In agreement\nwith this recommendation, testing for influenza A\nwas recommended in Sweden for cases with a\nclinical presentation including respiratory\nsymptoms and fever above 38 C and epidemiological\ncircumstances such as recent travel (within 7\ndays) to areas where the new influenza has been\nobserved [5] or close contact with confirmed\ncases.\n\nThe regular sentinel surveillance for seasonal\ninfluenza has been extended and now focuses on\nidentification of imported cases with influenza\nA(H1N1) virus, and on preventing secondary\ntransmission by contact tracing and antiviral\nmedication in an attempt to delay sustained\ncommunity transmission. In order to provide a\nbetter basis for the decision whether or not to\ninitiate preventive measures, expanded testing,\ntargeting a broad range of respiratory agents has\nbeen applied to specimens from all suspected\ncases in the region Vastra Gotaland (1.5 million\ninhabitants). We report here the results of this\nexpanded testing.\n\nMaterial and methods\n\nThis report includes samples of patients who,\nduring the period from 24 Apr to 10 Jun 2009\npresented with influenza-like symptoms and a\nhistory of recent travel to the United States or\nMexico, and therefore were recommended for\nexamination and sampling. This clinical\nexamination was performed by infectious disease\nclinicians on call at Sahlgrenska University\nHostpital/\u00d6stra in Gothenburg, and our report is\nbased on their evaluation and laboratory results.\nIn summary, of all 79 patients included with a\ntravel history, 90 percent presented with\nrespiratory symptoms, 5 percent without\nrespiratory symptoms, and for the remaining 5\npercent this information is not documented. 66\npercent had fever above 38 C, 29 percent had no\nfever; information on fever was missing for 5\npercent. Nasopharyngeal swabs were sent to the\nmolecular diagnostic unit at the virological\nlaboratory at Sahlgrenska University Hospital for\ntesting by a multiple real-time PCR targeting 13\nviruses and 2 bacteria, !\nrun in 6 parallel multiplex PCRs on an ABI 7500\ninstrument [6]. Samples that were reactive for\nthe influenza A component (matrix protein target,\n[7]) of this PCR were subtyped by an additional\nreal-time PCR targeting the haemagglutinin gene,\nrun in 3 parallel reactions specific for the H3N2\nand H1N1 subtypes that have been circulating for\na long time, as well as for the new H1N1v strain.\n[Readers requiring information on the primers and\nprobes used in the real-time PCR are referred to\na Table in the original text].\n\nResults and discussion\n\nIn total, samples from 79 patients were tested\n(42 males, 37 females; median age 30 years, range\n1-75 years), with between 10 and 16 samples on\naverage each week and most of them taken from\npatients with respiratory symptoms and a history\nof recent travel to North America. Four cases\nwith the new influenza A (H1N1)v variant were\ndiagnosed. Interestingly, in 56 percent of the\ncases, other aetiologies were identified (Table).\n\nTable. Viral aetiologies for the patients\nfulfilling definition of suspected cases of\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, Apr-Jun 2009 (n=79)\n\nViral aetiology / Number / Percentage\n\nRhinovirus / 28 / 34\nCoronavirus / 8 / 10\nInfluenza B virus / 3 / 4\nHuman parainfluenza virus types 1-3 / 3 / 3 / 4\nAdenovirus / 2 / 2\nInfluenza A (H1N1) virus / 4 / 5\nMetapneumovirus / 1 / 1\nEnterovirus / 1 / 1\nRespiratory syncytial virus / 0 / 0\nMycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae / 0 / 0\nNegative / 32 / 39\nTotal number / 82 / 100\n\n(Note: 3 patients had double infections with\nrhinovirus, together with enterovirus,\nmetapneumovirus or adenovirus.)\n\nThe most common finding was rhinovirus, observed\nin 28 of 82 cases (34 percent), and 3 of these\npatients also had a 2nd viral infection\n(enterovirus, metapneumovirus and adenovirus).\nThe frequent identification of rhinovirus and\nother viruses demonstrates that the criteria for\nsuspected cases of influenza A(H1N1)v are\nrelevant as indicators of a viral infection, but\nnot specific for influenza A. On the other hand,\napplying more restrictive criteria would probably\nhave excluded most infections with the new\nA(H1N1) virus strain, considering that their\nclinical presentation has been reported to be\nrelatively mild. This illustrates a dilemma with\nsurveillance actions aiming at revealing the\nspread of new respiratory infections. If the\napplied criteria are too strict (for example\nfever above 39 C, cough and muscle pain), the\nepidemic is likely to be underestimated, because\nonly the severe cases are identified. If on the\nother hand the criteria are liberal, as\nillustrated by the cur!\nrent epidemic, most of the cases will probably\nhave other aetiologies. The positive predictive\nvalue of clinical criteria for identification of\ninfluenza A is particularly low in the early\nphase of an epidemic, when the incidence of\ninfluenza A is low, but will become relatively\nhigh during the peak when a large proportion of\nrespiratory infections will be due to influenza A\nvirus. The value of broad virology testing\ndecreases in the course of an influenza epidemic,\nwhen the detection rate of other aetiologies may\ndecrease from above 50 percent as observed in\nthis report to below 10 percent during the\ninfluenza peak (unpublished observations from our\nlaboratory).\n\nThe cases with influenza A were analysed further\nby a typing PCR that within 4-5 hours could\nidentify whether the strain was a traditional\nH1N1 or H3N2 virus, or the new H1N1 variant. This\ntyping system targets specific regions of the\nhaemagglutinin gene and has been developed in our\nlaboratory (unpublished). It has proved to have a\ngood sensitivity, as illustrated by cycle\nthreshold (Ct) values that are typically lower\nthan those obtained in the general PCR for\ninfluenza A, which targets a conserved region of\nthe matrix protein gene.\n\nThe results of the multiple PCR used in our\nsetting were available within 24 hours after\nsampling and served at the same time as\nconfirmation for the result of the 1st, general\ninfluenza A PCR. In cases that presented with\ntypical influenza-like symptoms but were negative\nfor influenza A in the 1st PCR, the finding of an\nalternative aetiology was helpful for the\ndecision to refrain from preventive measures.\nSuch measures include oseltamivir treatment of\npatients and influenza testing and prophylactic\ntreatment of their close contacts. The clinical\npractice was not always different, but in some\ncases, the identification of an alternative\naetiology such as rhinovirus was helpful for the\ndecision not to treat the patient of contacts,\neven when the patient had symptoms clearly\nindicative of possible influenza. From this\nexperience, we therefore conclude that a broad\ndiagnostic test is a valuable tool in the early\ninvestigation of a new emerging respiratory virus\nlike the new influ!\nenza A(H1N1)v.\n\n[Note added in proof: On 17 Jun 2009, Sweden\nchanged to a stricter case definition for\nsuspected cases. It now requires more than 2\nsymptoms besides epidemiology and fever.]\n\nReferences\n\n1. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC). Swine influenza A (H1N1) infection in 2\nchildren--Southern California, Mar-Apr 2009. MMWR\nMorb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2009;58(15):400-2.\n2. Novel Swine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus\nInvestigation Team. Emergence of a Novel\nSwine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus in Humans.\nN Engl J Med. 2009 Jun 3. [Epub ahead of print].\n3. World Health Organization (WHO). Influenza\nA(H1N1) - update 50. Jun 17, 2009. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_06_17/en/index.html>.\n4. Commission Decision of 30 Apr 2009 amending\nDecision 2002/253/ EC laying down case\ndefinitions for reporting communicable diseases\nto the Community network under Decision n\n21/19/98/EC. 2009/363/EC. Official Journal L\n110/58. 01.05.2009. Available from:\n<http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:110:0058:0059:EN:PDF>.\n5. World Health Organization (WHO). Influenza\nA(H1N1) - update 2. Apr 26, 2009. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_06_17/en/index.html>\n6. Brittain-Long R, Nord S, Olofsson S, Westin\nJ, Anderson LM, Lindh M. Multiplex real-time PCR\nfor detection of respiratory tract infections. J\nClin Virol. 2008;41(1):53-.\n7. Ward CL, Dempsey MH, Ring CJ, Kempson RE,\nZhang L, Gor D, et al. Design and performance\ntesting of quantitative real time PCR assays for\ninfluenza A and B viral load measurement. J Clin\nVirol. 2004;29(3): 179-88.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These data among other things reveal that the\npositive predictive value of clinical criteria\nfor identification of influenza A is low in the\nearly phase of an epidemic, when the incidence of\ninfluenza A is low, but will become relatively\nhigher during the peak, when a large proportion\nof respiratory infections will be due to\ninfluenza A virus. Among the viruses detected,\nrhinoviruses and coronaviruses predominated in\nthis survey. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nInfluenza A (H1N1) - worldwide (68): southern hemisphere (to be archived)\nInfluenza A (H1N1) - owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-06-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-04-15 00:00:00", "2009-06-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-06-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2068-03-15 00:00:00", "1918-03-15 00:00:00", "2066-03-15 00:00:00", "2065-03-15 00:00:00", "2064-03-15 00:00:00", "2063-03-15 00:00:00", "2062-03-15 00:00:00", "2059-03-15 "2048-03-15 00:00:00", "2047-03-15 00:00:00", "2046-03-15 00:00:00", "2044-03-15 00:00:00", "2043-03-15 00:00:00", "2040-03-15 00:00:00", "2038-03-15 00:00:00", "2036-03-15 00:00:00", "2035-03-15 00:00:00", "2033-03-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", {"location": "Cairo", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Lindqvist1", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "Lebanon"}, {"location": "IA", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Gothenburg", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Sahlgrenska", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Mycoplasma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Olofsson S", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "355402", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (04): (UP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=355402", "date": "2009-06-18 22:00:05", "main_text": "INFLUENZA A (H1N1) - WORLDWIDE (69): OTHER VIRAL INFECTIONS\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Jun 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 14, Issue 24, 18 Jun 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19242>\n\n\nA variety of respiratory viruses found in\nsymptomatic travellers returning from countries\nwith ongoing spread of the new influenza A(H1N1)v\nvirus strain\n\nBy: P Follin1, A Lindqvist1, K Nystrom1, M Lindh2\n\nAt: 1. Department of Communicable Disease\nPrevention and Control, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, 2. Department of Virology, Sahlgrenska\nUniversity Hospital, Gothenburg, Sweden\n\nClinical specimens from 79 symptomatic\nindividuals with a recent history of travel to\ncountries with verified transmission of influenza\nA(H1N1) virus (North America) were tested with a\nmultiple real-time PCR targeting a broad range of\nagents that may cause acute respiratory\ninfection. This analysis revealed that besides 4\ncases of influenza A(H1N1) virus, other\nrespiratory viruses were diagnosed in almost 60\npercent of the samples. These observations are a\nreminder that many different viral transmissions\noccur simultaneously in countries with ongoing\nspread of influenza A(H1N1) virus. The findings\ndemonstrate that the definition of suspected\ncases by clinical and epidemiological criteria\nhas only a poor capacity for discriminating\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v from other viral infections.\n\nBackground\n\nA new influenza A(H1N1) virus variant has spread\nglobally since its 1st appearance in April 2009\n[1,2] and as of 17 Jun 2009, there were 39 620\ncases reported by the World Health Organization\n(WHO) [3]. On 30 Apr 2009, the European\nCommission suggested a case definition [4], which\nhas been adopted and modified by most authorities\nin the European Union Member States. In agreement\nwith this recommendation, testing for influenza A\nwas recommended in Sweden for cases with a\nclinical presentation including respiratory\nsymptoms and fever above 38 C and epidemiological\ncircumstances such as recent travel (within 7\ndays) to areas where the new influenza has been\nobserved [5] or close contact with confirmed\ncases.\n\nThe regular sentinel surveillance for seasonal\ninfluenza has been extended and now focuses on\nidentification of imported cases with influenza\nA(H1N1) virus, and on preventing secondary\ntransmission by contact tracing and antiviral\nmedication in an attempt to delay sustained\ncommunity transmission. In order to provide a\nbetter basis for the decision whether or not to\ninitiate preventive measures, expanded testing,\ntargeting a broad range of respiratory agents has\nbeen applied to specimens from all suspected\ncases in the region Vastra Gotaland (1.5 million\ninhabitants). We report here the results of this\nexpanded testing.\n\nMaterial and methods\n\nThis report includes samples of patients who,\nduring the period from 24 Apr to 10 Jun 2009\npresented with influenza-like symptoms and a\nhistory of recent travel to the United States or\nMexico, and therefore were recommended for\nexamination and sampling. This clinical\nexamination was performed by infectious disease\nclinicians on call at Sahlgrenska University\nHostpital/\u00d6stra in Gothenburg, and our report is\nbased on their evaluation and laboratory results.\nIn summary, of all 79 patients included with a\ntravel history, 90 percent presented with\nrespiratory symptoms, 5 percent without\nrespiratory symptoms, and for the remaining 5\npercent this information is not documented. 66\npercent had fever above 38 C, 29 percent had no\nfever; information on fever was missing for 5\npercent. Nasopharyngeal swabs were sent to the\nmolecular diagnostic unit at the virological\nlaboratory at Sahlgrenska University Hospital for\ntesting by a multiple real-time PCR targeting 13\nviruses and 2 bacteria, !\nrun in 6 parallel multiplex PCRs on an ABI 7500\ninstrument [6]. Samples that were reactive for\nthe influenza A component (matrix protein target,\n[7]) of this PCR were subtyped by an additional\nreal-time PCR targeting the haemagglutinin gene,\nrun in 3 parallel reactions specific for the H3N2\nand H1N1 subtypes that have been circulating for\na long time, as well as for the new H1N1v strain.\n[Readers requiring information on the primers and\nprobes used in the real-time PCR are referred to\na Table in the original text].\n\nResults and discussion\n\nIn total, samples from 79 patients were tested\n(42 males, 37 females; median age 30 years, range\n1-75 years), with between 10 and 16 samples on\naverage each week and most of them taken from\npatients with respiratory symptoms and a history\nof recent travel to North America. Four cases\nwith the new influenza A (H1N1)v variant were\ndiagnosed. Interestingly, in 56 percent of the\ncases, other aetiologies were identified (Table).\n\nTable. Viral aetiologies for the patients\nfulfilling definition of suspected cases of\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, Apr-Jun 2009 (n=79)\n\nViral aetiology / Number / Percentage\n\nRhinovirus / 28 / 34\nCoronavirus / 8 / 10\nInfluenza B virus / 3 / 4\nHuman parainfluenza virus types 1-3 / 3 / 3 / 4\nAdenovirus / 2 / 2\nInfluenza A (H1N1) virus / 4 / 5\nMetapneumovirus / 1 / 1\nEnterovirus / 1 / 1\nRespiratory syncytial virus / 0 / 0\nMycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae / 0 / 0\nNegative / 32 / 39\nTotal number / 82 / 100\n\n(Note: 3 patients had double infections with\nrhinovirus, together with enterovirus,\nmetapneumovirus or adenovirus.)\n\nThe most common finding was rhinovirus, observed\nin 28 of 82 cases (34 percent), and 3 of these\npatients also had a 2nd viral infection\n(enterovirus, metapneumovirus and adenovirus).\nThe frequent identification of rhinovirus and\nother viruses demonstrates that the criteria for\nsuspected cases of influenza A(H1N1)v are\nrelevant as indicators of a viral infection, but\nnot specific for influenza A. On the other hand,\napplying more restrictive criteria would probably\nhave excluded most infections with the new\nA(H1N1) virus strain, considering that their\nclinical presentation has been reported to be\nrelatively mild. This illustrates a dilemma with\nsurveillance actions aiming at revealing the\nspread of new respiratory infections. If the\napplied criteria are too strict (for example\nfever above 39 C, cough and muscle pain), the\nepidemic is likely to be underestimated, because\nonly the severe cases are identified. If on the\nother hand the criteria are liberal, as\nillustrated by the cur!\nrent epidemic, most of the cases will probably\nhave other aetiologies. The positive predictive\nvalue of clinical criteria for identification of\ninfluenza A is particularly low in the early\nphase of an epidemic, when the incidence of\ninfluenza A is low, but will become relatively\nhigh during the peak when a large proportion of\nrespiratory infections will be due to influenza A\nvirus. The value of broad virology testing\ndecreases in the course of an influenza epidemic,\nwhen the detection rate of other aetiologies may\ndecrease from above 50 percent as observed in\nthis report to below 10 percent during the\ninfluenza peak (unpublished observations from our\nlaboratory).\n\nThe cases with influenza A were analysed further\nby a typing PCR that within 4-5 hours could\nidentify whether the strain was a traditional\nH1N1 or H3N2 virus, or the new H1N1 variant. This\ntyping system targets specific regions of the\nhaemagglutinin gene and has been developed in our\nlaboratory (unpublished). It has proved to have a\ngood sensitivity, as illustrated by cycle\nthreshold (Ct) values that are typically lower\nthan those obtained in the general PCR for\ninfluenza A, which targets a conserved region of\nthe matrix protein gene.\n\nThe results of the multiple PCR used in our\nsetting were available within 24 hours after\nsampling and served at the same time as\nconfirmation for the result of the 1st, general\ninfluenza A PCR. In cases that presented with\ntypical influenza-like symptoms but were negative\nfor influenza A in the 1st PCR, the finding of an\nalternative aetiology was helpful for the\ndecision to refrain from preventive measures.\nSuch measures include oseltamivir treatment of\npatients and influenza testing and prophylactic\ntreatment of their close contacts. The clinical\npractice was not always different, but in some\ncases, the identification of an alternative\naetiology such as rhinovirus was helpful for the\ndecision not to treat the patient of contacts,\neven when the patient had symptoms clearly\nindicative of possible influenza. From this\nexperience, we therefore conclude that a broad\ndiagnostic test is a valuable tool in the early\ninvestigation of a new emerging respiratory virus\nlike the new influ!\nenza A(H1N1)v.\n\n[Note added in proof: On 17 Jun 2009, Sweden\nchanged to a stricter case definition for\nsuspected cases. It now requires more than 2\nsymptoms besides epidemiology and fever.]\n\nReferences\n\n1. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC). Swine influenza A (H1N1) infection in 2\nchildren--Southern California, Mar-Apr 2009. MMWR\nMorb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2009;58(15):400-2.\n2. Novel Swine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus\nInvestigation Team. Emergence of a Novel\nSwine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus in Humans.\nN Engl J Med. 2009 Jun 3. [Epub ahead of print].\n3. World Health Organization (WHO). Influenza\nA(H1N1) - update 50. Jun 17, 2009. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_06_17/en/index.html>.\n4. Commission Decision of 30 Apr 2009 amending\nDecision 2002/253/ EC laying down case\ndefinitions for reporting communicable diseases\nto the Community network under Decision n\n21/19/98/EC. 2009/363/EC. Official Journal L\n110/58. 01.05.2009. Available from:\n<http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:110:0058:0059:EN:PDF>.\n5. World Health Organization (WHO). Influenza\nA(H1N1) - update 2. Apr 26, 2009. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_06_17/en/index.html>\n6. Brittain-Long R, Nord S, Olofsson S, Westin\nJ, Anderson LM, Lindh M. Multiplex real-time PCR\nfor detection of respiratory tract infections. J\nClin Virol. 2008;41(1):53-.\n7. Ward CL, Dempsey MH, Ring CJ, Kempson RE,\nZhang L, Gor D, et al. Design and performance\ntesting of quantitative real time PCR assays for\ninfluenza A and B viral load measurement. J Clin\nVirol. 2004;29(3): 179-88.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These data among other things reveal that the\npositive predictive value of clinical criteria\nfor identification of influenza A is low in the\nearly phase of an epidemic, when the incidence of\ninfluenza A is low, but will become relatively\nhigher during the peak, when a large proportion\nof respiratory infections will be due to\ninfluenza A virus. Among the viruses detected,\nrhinoviruses and coronaviruses predominated in\nthis survey. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nInfluenza A (H1N1) - worldwide (68): southern hemisphere (to be archived)\nInfluenza A (H1N1) - INFECTIONS\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 18 Jun 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 14, Issue 24, 18 Jun 2009 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19242>\n\n\nA variety of respiratory viruses found in\nsymptomatic travellers returning from countries\nwith ongoing spread of the new influenza A(H1N1)v\nvirus strain\n\nBy: P Follin1, A Lindqvist1, K Nystrom1, M Lindh2\n\nAt: 1. Department of Communicable Disease\nPrevention and Control, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, 2. Department of Virology, Sahlgrenska\nUniversity Hospital, Gothenburg, Sweden\n\nClinical specimens from 79 symptomatic\nindividuals with a recent history of travel to\ncountries with verified transmission of influenza\nA(H1N1) virus (North America) were tested with a\nmultiple real-time PCR targeting a broad range of\nagents that may cause acute respiratory\ninfection. This analysis revealed that besides 4\ncases of influenza A(H1N1) virus, other\nrespiratory viruses were diagnosed in almost 60\npercent of the samples. These observations are a\nreminder that many different viral transmissions\noccur simultaneously in countries with ongoing\nspread of influenza A(H1N1) virus. The findings\ndemonstrate that the definition of suspected\ncases by clinical and epidemiological criteria\nhas only a poor capacity for discriminating\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v from other viral infections.\n\nBackground\n\nA new influenza A(H1N1) virus variant has spread\nglobally since its 1st appearance in April 2009\n[1,2] and as of 17 Jun 2009, there were 39 620\ncases reported by the World Health Organization\n(WHO) [3]. On 30 Apr 2009, the European\nCommission suggested a case definition [4], which\nhas been adopted and modified by most authorities\nin the European Union Member States. In agreement\nwith this recommendation, testing for influenza A\nwas recommended in Sweden for cases with a\nclinical presentation including respiratory\nsymptoms and fever above 38 C and epidemiological\ncircumstances such as recent travel (within 7\ndays) to areas where the new influenza has been\nobserved [5] or close contact with confirmed\ncases.\n\nThe regular sentinel surveillance for seasonal\ninfluenza has been extended and now focuses on\nidentification of imported cases with influenza\nA(H1N1) virus, and on preventing secondary\ntransmission by contact tracing and antiviral\nmedication in an attempt to delay sustained\ncommunity transmission. In order to provide a\nbetter basis for the decision whether or not to\ninitiate preventive measures, expanded testing,\ntargeting a broad range of respiratory agents has\nbeen applied to specimens from all suspected\ncases in the region Vastra Gotaland (1.5 million\ninhabitants). We report here the results of this\nexpanded testing.\n\nMaterial and methods\n\nThis report includes samples of patients who,\nduring the period from 24 Apr to 10 Jun 2009\npresented with influenza-like symptoms and a\nhistory of recent travel to the United States or\nMexico, and therefore were recommended for\nexamination and sampling. This clinical\nexamination was performed by infectious disease\nclinicians on call at Sahlgrenska University\nHostpital/\u00d6stra in Gothenburg, and our report is\nbased on their evaluation and laboratory results.\nIn summary, of all 79 patients included with a\ntravel history, 90 percent presented with\nrespiratory symptoms, 5 percent without\nrespiratory symptoms, and for the remaining 5\npercent this information is not documented. 66\npercent had fever above 38 C, 29 percent had no\nfever; information on fever was missing for 5\npercent. Nasopharyngeal swabs were sent to the\nmolecular diagnostic unit at the virological\nlaboratory at Sahlgrenska University Hospital for\ntesting by a multiple real-time PCR targeting 13\nviruses and 2 bacteria, !\nrun in 6 parallel multiplex PCRs on an ABI 7500\ninstrument [6]. Samples that were reactive for\nthe influenza A component (matrix protein target,\n[7]) of this PCR were subtyped by an additional\nreal-time PCR targeting the haemagglutinin gene,\nrun in 3 parallel reactions specific for the H3N2\nand H1N1 subtypes that have been circulating for\na long time, as well as for the new H1N1v strain.\n[Readers requiring information on the primers and\nprobes used in the real-time PCR are referred to\na Table in the original text].\n\nResults and discussion\n\nIn total, samples from 79 patients were tested\n(42 males, 37 females; median age 30 years, range\n1-75 years), with between 10 and 16 samples on\naverage each week and most of them taken from\npatients with respiratory symptoms and a history\nof recent travel to North America. Four cases\nwith the new influenza A (H1N1)v variant were\ndiagnosed. Interestingly, in 56 percent of the\ncases, other aetiologies were identified (Table).\n\nTable. Viral aetiologies for the patients\nfulfilling definition of suspected cases of\ninfluenza A(H1N1)v, Region Vastra Gotaland,\nSweden, Apr-Jun 2009 (n=79)\n\nViral aetiology / Number / Percentage\n\nRhinovirus / 28 / 34\nCoronavirus / 8 / 10\nInfluenza B virus / 3 / 4\nHuman parainfluenza virus types 1-3 / 3 / 3 / 4\nAdenovirus / 2 / 2\nInfluenza A (H1N1) virus / 4 / 5\nMetapneumovirus / 1 / 1\nEnterovirus / 1 / 1\nRespiratory syncytial virus / 0 / 0\nMycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae / 0 / 0\nNegative / 32 / 39\nTotal number / 82 / 100\n\n(Note: 3 patients had double infections with\nrhinovirus, together with enterovirus,\nmetapneumovirus or adenovirus.)\n\nThe most common finding was rhinovirus, observed\nin 28 of 82 cases (34 percent), and 3 of these\npatients also had a 2nd viral infection\n(enterovirus, metapneumovirus and adenovirus).\nThe frequent identification of rhinovirus and\nother viruses demonstrates that the criteria for\nsuspected cases of influenza A(H1N1)v are\nrelevant as indicators of a viral infection, but\nnot specific for influenza A. On the other hand,\napplying more restrictive criteria would probably\nhave excluded most infections with the new\nA(H1N1) virus strain, considering that their\nclinical presentation has been reported to be\nrelatively mild. This illustrates a dilemma with\nsurveillance actions aiming at revealing the\nspread of new respiratory infections. If the\napplied criteria are too strict (for example\nfever above 39 C, cough and muscle pain), the\nepidemic is likely to be underestimated, because\nonly the severe cases are identified. If on the\nother hand the criteria are liberal, as\nillustrated by the cur!\nrent epidemic, most of the cases will probably\nhave other aetiologies. The positive predictive\nvalue of clinical criteria for identification of\ninfluenza A is particularly low in the early\nphase of an epidemic, when the incidence of\ninfluenza A is low, but will become relatively\nhigh during the peak when a large proportion of\nrespiratory infections will be due to influenza A\nvirus. The value of broad virology testing\ndecreases in the course of an influenza epidemic,\nwhen the detection rate of other aetiologies may\ndecrease from above 50 percent as observed in\nthis report to below 10 percent during the\ninfluenza peak (unpublished observations from our\nlaboratory).\n\nThe cases with influenza A were analysed further\nby a typing PCR that within 4-5 hours could\nidentify whether the strain was a traditional\nH1N1 or H3N2 virus, or the new H1N1 variant. This\ntyping system targets specific regions of the\nhaemagglutinin gene and has been developed in our\nlaboratory (unpublished). It has proved to have a\ngood sensitivity, as illustrated by cycle\nthreshold (Ct) values that are typically lower\nthan those obtained in the general PCR for\ninfluenza A, which targets a conserved region of\nthe matrix protein gene.\n\nThe results of the multiple PCR used in our\nsetting were available within 24 hours after\nsampling and served at the same time as\nconfirmation for the result of the 1st, general\ninfluenza A PCR. In cases that presented with\ntypical influenza-like symptoms but were negative\nfor influenza A in the 1st PCR, the finding of an\nalternative aetiology was helpful for the\ndecision to refrain from preventive measures.\nSuch measures include oseltamivir treatment of\npatients and influenza testing and prophylactic\ntreatment of their close contacts. The clinical\npractice was not always different, but in some\ncases, the identification of an alternative\naetiology such as rhinovirus was helpful for the\ndecision not to treat the patient of contacts,\neven when the patient had symptoms clearly\nindicative of possible influenza. From this\nexperience, we therefore conclude that a broad\ndiagnostic test is a valuable tool in the early\ninvestigation of a new emerging respiratory virus\nlike the new influ!\nenza A(H1N1)v.\n\n[Note added in proof: On 17 Jun 2009, Sweden\nchanged to a stricter case definition for\nsuspected cases. It now requires more than 2\nsymptoms besides epidemiology and fever.]\n\nReferences\n\n1. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC). Swine influenza A (H1N1) infection in 2\nchildren--Southern California, Mar-Apr 2009. MMWR\nMorb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2009;58(15):400-2.\n2. Novel Swine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus\nInvestigation Team. Emergence of a Novel\nSwine-Origin Influenza A (H1N1) Virus in Humans.\nN Engl J Med. 2009 Jun 3. [Epub ahead of print].\n3. World Health Organization (WHO). Influenza\nA(H1N1) - update 50. Jun 17, 2009. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_06_17/en/index.html>.\n4. Commission Decision of 30 Apr 2009 amending\nDecision 2002/253/ EC laying down case\ndefinitions for reporting communicable diseases\nto the Community network under Decision n\n21/19/98/EC. 2009/363/EC. Official Journal L\n110/58. 01.05.2009. Available from:\n<http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:110:0058:0059:EN:PDF>.\n5. World Health Organization (WHO). Influenza\nA(H1N1) - update 2. Apr 26, 2009. Available from:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_06_17/en/index.html>\n6. Brittain-Long R, Nord S, Olofsson S, Westin\nJ, Anderson LM, Lindh M. Multiplex real-time PCR\nfor detection of respiratory tract infections. J\nClin Virol. 2008;41(1):53-.\n7. Ward CL, Dempsey MH, Ring CJ, Kempson RE,\nZhang L, Gor D, et al. Design and performance\ntesting of quantitative real time PCR assays for\ninfluenza A and B viral load measurement. J Clin\nVirol. 2004;29(3): 179-88.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These data among other things reveal that the\npositive predictive value of clinical criteria\nfor identification of influenza A is low in the\nearly phase of an epidemic, when the incidence of\ninfluenza A is low, but will become relatively\nhigher during the peak, when a large proportion\nof respiratory infections will be due to\ninfluenza A virus. Among the viruses detected,\nrhinoviruses and coronaviruses predominated in\nthis survey. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nInfluenza A (H1N1) - worldwide (68): southern hemisphere (to be archived)\nInfluenza A (H1N1) -
